title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but existing VR interfaces often exclude people with disabilities. This paper presents a novel, inclusive VR interface design framework that incorporates accessibility features for users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a user study with 30 participants with diverse abilities and identified key challenges and opportunities in VR interaction. Our proposed framework, 'AccessibleVR', includes a set of design guidelines, a software development kit, and a virtual assistant to facilitate accessible VR experiences. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AccessibleVR through a case study on a VR-based education application.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems (DDS) continue to scale, query performance optimization becomes increasingly challenging. This paper presents an adaptive indexing approach, 'AIQ', that dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distributions. AIQ utilizes a reinforcement learning framework to optimize index selection, leveraging graph-based representations of query plans and data statistics. Experimental results on a real-world DDS benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in query latency and throughput, outperforming state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 30%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often rely on simplistic user-item interaction data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that incorporates both user and item embeddings, as well as their interactions, to provide personalized and interpretable recommendations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on three benchmark datasets, showing significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: As multi-agent systems become increasingly prevalent, the need for transparent decision-making processes grows. This paper introduces HAN-MAD, a hierarchical attention network architecture that enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent environments. HAN-MAD leverages attention mechanisms to identify relevant agent interactions and contextual information, generating interpretable explanations for joint decisions. We evaluate HAN-MAD on a range of multi-agent tasks, demonstrating improved decision-making performance and enhanced explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interfaces
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on the impact of gestural interfaces on user experience and performance. We designed a VR system that incorporates hand-tracking and full-body motion capture, allowing participants to engage with virtual objects in a more immersive and intuitive manner. Our user study reveals that embodied cognition principles can significantly enhance user engagement, spatial awareness, and cognitive load reduction in VR applications. We also identify key design implications for VR systems that leverage gestural interfaces to support more natural and effective human-computer interaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a challenging task due to the inherent heterogeneity of data sources. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that integrates graph-based representation learning with attention mechanisms to effectively capture complex relationships between modalities. We demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods on two benchmark datasets, achieving improvements of up to 12.5% in overall emotion recognition accuracy. Our ablation studies highlight the importance of hierarchical attention in modeling intra- and inter-modal interactions.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but the lack of haptic feedback can lead to a sense of disconnection and reduced user experience. This study investigates the effects of haptic feedback on user engagement, immersion, and task performance in VR environments. We designed a novel haptic feedback system that utilizes electroactive polymers to provide tactile feedback to users. Our user study with 30 participants shows that the inclusion of haptic feedback significantly improves user experience, reduces motion sickness, and enhances task completion rates. The results have implications for the design of VR systems and highlight the importance of haptic feedback in creating an immersive and interactive experience.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Neural Entity Disambiguation for Improving Search Engine Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in search engine retrieval, as it enables the system to capture the user's intent more accurately. However, existing approaches often struggle with entity disambiguation, leading to suboptimal expansion results. This paper proposes a novel neural entity disambiguation framework, 'NeuroDis', which leverages contextualized embeddings and graph-based attention to resolve entity ambiguities. We integrate NeuroDis with a state-of-the-art query expansion model, demonstrating significant improvements in retrieval performance on a benchmark dataset. Our approach outperforms traditional entity disambiguation methods, especially in cases where entity mentions are ambiguous or have limited context.

title: Query-Adaptive Re-Ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Modern search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from massive indexes. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive re-ranking approach, 'QAR', that leverages neural query embeddings and document representations to re-rank the initial retrieval results. QAR learns to adapt to the query context and importance of different ranking features, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency. We conduct extensive experiments on the TREC Web Track dataset, demonstrating that QAR outperforms state-of-the-art re-ranking methods while reducing computational overhead.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', which learns to optimize resource allocation in real-time. CloudOpt leverages a hybrid approach combining a deep Q-network (DQN) with a graph neural network (GNN) to model complex dependencies between resources and workloads. We evaluate CloudOpt on a large-scale cloud computing dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to state-of-the-art allocation policies.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex interactions between agents. While deep learning models can learn effective policies, they typically lack transparency and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent environments. By incorporating attention mechanisms at both the agent and system levels, HANs can identify influential agents and highlight key interactions that drive decision-making. Experimental results on a simulated traffic control scenario demonstrate improved policy performance and enhanced interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Zero-Shot Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) enables models to recognize unseen classes, but existing approaches often suffer from high computational overhead and poor performance. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for efficient ZSL in computer vision. Our HAN model leverages a dual-attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant semantic attributes and visual features, allowing for efficient knowledge transfer from seen to unseen classes. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational cost by up to 3x compared to existing ZSL methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition systems often rely on a single modality, such as facial expressions or speech patterns. However, humans use multiple cues to infer emotional states. This paper introduces a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates acoustic, visual, and linguistic features to recognize emotions in a multi-modal setting. Our HAN model employs attention mechanisms at both the feature and modality levels to adaptively weight the importance of each modality and feature type. Experimental results on the EMOTIC dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from facial expressions, speech, and text.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Real-World Robotics
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable successes in various robotics tasks, but its lack of transparency and interpretability hinders its deployment in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel explainability framework, 'RL-Explain', which leverages attention mechanisms and model-based reinforcement learning to provide insights into DRL decision-making processes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Explain in a robotic grasping task, showing that it not only improves model interpretability but also enhances overall performance by identifying and correcting suboptimal policies.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for various applications, including monitoring critical infrastructure and detecting financial fraud. However, most existing methods lack interpretability, making it challenging to identify the root causes of anomalies. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) for explainable time-series anomaly detection. Our HAN model consists of two levels of attention mechanisms: a local attention module that captures short-term patterns and a global attention module that incorporates long-term dependencies. We evaluate our approach on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting anomalies while providing insightful explanations.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Data Warehouses using Column Stores
paper_abstract: As data warehousing continues to grow in scale and complexity, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper explores the application of column-store indexing to multi-dimensional data warehouses, demonstrating improved query performance and reduced storage overhead. We propose a novel cost-based optimization framework, 'ColOpt', that leverages statistical summaries and machine learning models to predict query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that ColOpt outperforms traditional row-store indexing by up to 3x on complex queries, while reducing storage requirements by 40%.

title: Exploring Embodiment in Virtual Reality for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current systems often lack a sense of embodiment, leading to user discomfort and disorientation. This paper presents an investigation into the role of embodiment in VR, exploring the impact of proprioceptive feedback, body awareness, and self-representation on user experience. We develop and evaluate a novel VR system that incorporates real-time tracking of the user's body, providing a more immersive and engaging experience. Our findings suggest that embodiment significantly enhances user satisfaction, reduces cybersickness, and improves task performance in VR environments.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to enhance the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but current VR interfaces often pose significant accessibility barriers. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'CogniVR', a novel VR interface tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We employed a user-centered design approach, incorporating insights from gerontology and cognitive psychology to develop interface elements that accommodate cognitive decline. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to standard VR interfaces. Our findings have implications for the development of inclusive VR systems that promote digital accessibility and social inclusion for older adults.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in node classification tasks. However, existing methods often struggle with multi-label classification, where nodes can belong to multiple classes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages label correlations to improve multi-label node classification. HGAT consists of multiple attention layers that aggregate features from neighboring nodes and labels, enabling the model to capture complex label relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art GNNs in terms of macro-F1 score and label ranking metrics.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities face significant challenges when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gesture-based interfaces that can accommodate varying levels of motor ability. We propose a machine learning-based framework that uses real-time gesture recognition and adaptation to provide personalized interaction modalities. Our user study with 20 participants with motor disabilities demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces. Our findings have implications for the design of inclusive and accessible HCI systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Chatbots: A Study on Conversational Accessibility for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but their accessibility for visually impaired users remains a significant concern. This study investigates the design of inclusive chatbots that cater to the needs of visually impaired individuals. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving user interviews, surveys, and usability testing to identify key accessibility barriers and design requirements. Our findings inform the development of a novel chatbot framework, 'AccessibleConverse', which integrates assistive technologies such as screen readers, Braille displays, and voice commands. We demonstrate the efficacy of AccessibleConverse in improving conversational experience and user satisfaction for visually impaired users.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve cooperative goals. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose an algorithm, 'MARL-TA', that enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing task requirements. MARL-TA employs a decentralized, asynchronous framework, allowing agents to communicate and negotiate task assignments in real-time. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it directly affects the quality of search results. Traditional query expansion methods rely on term co-occurrence or statistical models, which may not capture the complex relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding approach, 'GraphExpan', which represents query terms as nodes in a graph and leverages their semantic relationships to identify relevant expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing the computational cost of query expansion.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interfaces for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to enhance user experience. We designed a gesture-based interface that leverages the cognitive benefits of bodily engagement, allowing users to manipulate virtual objects with natural gestures. A user study (N=30) compared our embodied interface with a traditional controller-based interface, revealing significant improvements in spatial awareness, object manipulation accuracy, and overall user satisfaction. Our findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and immersive VR interactions, particularly in domains such as education, training, and entertainment.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on Temporal Graphs
paper_abstract: Temporal graphs are increasingly used to model dynamic relationships in various domains, such as social networks, traffic patterns, and financial transactions. Real-time analytics on these graphs requires efficient indexing mechanisms to support fast query processing. This paper presents 'TG-Index', a novel indexing framework that leverages graph summarization and tiered indexing to enable scalable and efficient query processing on large temporal graphs. Our experimental evaluation on real-world datasets demonstrates that TG-Index outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 5x in terms of query response time and 3x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve complex tasks requires effective communication and cooperation. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention framework, HierGAT, which enables explainable multi-agent cooperation. HierGAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions, allowing for more informed decision-making. We evaluate HierGAT on a real-world traffic management scenario, demonstrating improved cooperation efficiency and interpretability compared to existing graph neural network-based methods.

title: Emotion-aware Adaptive Interfaces for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with disabilities. However, existing VR interfaces often neglect the emotional and cognitive states of users, leading to frustration and disengagement. This paper presents an emotion-aware adaptive interface framework, 'EmpaVR', which leverages real-time affective computing and user modeling to dynamically adjust VR experiences. EmpaVR incorporates machine learning-driven emotional state recognition, personalized feedback mechanisms, and adaptivity algorithms to optimize user engagement and task performance. Our user study with 30 participants showed significant improvements in emotional satisfaction, task completion rates, and self-reported accessibility.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and constraints need to collaborate to achieve complex goals. We propose a distributed task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. Our approach, called HRL-TA, uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn task allocation policies that balance individual agent preferences with system-wide efficiency. Experiments on a real-world disaster response scenario demonstrate that HRL-TA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing. However, optimizing queries in such systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our method, called QOPT-RL, leverages a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan policy. We evaluate QOPT-RL on several benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques. Our experiments also show that QOPT-RL adapts well to changing database workloads and scales to large distributed systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has become increasingly popular in deep learning, but interpreting the relationships between tasks remains challenging. We propose Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel MTL framework that learns to selectively share knowledge across tasks while providing interpretable attention weights. HANs consist of a hierarchical encoder and a task-specific attention mechanism, enabling the model to capture complex task relationships. We evaluate HANs on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate improved performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art MTL methods. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as healthcare and finance, where model interpretability is crucial.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval using Graph-Based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval, where the brevity of queries hinders the effectiveness of traditional retrieval models. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding approach for query expansion, which leverages the semantic relationships between words in the query and the document collection. Our method, GraphEx, represents queries and documents as dense vectors in a joint graph-structured space, enabling the capture of nuanced contextual dependencies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Context-Aware Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems often neglect the semantic relationships between documents and their contextual information. This paper proposes a novel context-aware document retrieval framework, 'HierDoc', which leverages hierarchical graph convolutional networks (HGCNs) to model document structures and capture contextual dependencies. Our approach incorporates node-wise attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant contextual features, enabling more accurate retrieval results. Experimental evaluations on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HierDoc in improving retrieval performance, especially for complex queries and long documents.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex network data. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph structures and the need to minimize communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph summarization and cost-based optimization to reduce query latency. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 3x, while maintaining high accuracy and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to predict sentiment from heterogeneous data sources, including text, images, and audio. Existing approaches often suffer from inadequate modeling of complex relationships between modalities. We propose a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that effectively captures both intra- and inter-modality interactions. HGAT employs a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights modality-specific features and iteratively refines sentiment representations at multiple scales. Experiments on benchmark MSA datasets demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art methods, highlighting the effectiveness of HGAT in modeling multimodal sentiment.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation with Attention-based Semantic Encoding for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: In information retrieval, document representation is a critical component that affects the performance of search engines. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation framework that leverages attention-based semantic encoding to capture complex contextual relationships between words and documents. Our approach, dubbed HiDRE, learns to represent documents as a weighted combination of semantic concepts, which enables more accurate query-document matching. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiDRE outperforms state-of-the-art document representation methods, including BERT-based models, in terms of retrieval accuracy and robustness to noise.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is crucial for real-world applications. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at both the agent and group levels to provide interpretable policies. We demonstrate that HANs outperform state-of-the-art MARL methods in a variety of cooperative and competitive scenarios, while also providing visual explanations of agent decision-making processes. Our results have implications for the development of transparent and trustworthy AI systems in domains such as autonomous driving and robotics.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning-based Index Selection
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics workloads. However, query performance in DDS is often bottlenecked by inefficient index selection. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning (ML) to optimize index selection for DDS. We develop a decision-tree-based model that takes into account various query and dataset characteristics to predict the most effective index configuration. Experimental results on a real-world DDS benchmark demonstrate that our ML-based approach achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional static indexing methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face the challenge of optimizing query execution plans to minimize latency and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed database systems. Our method, 'RL-QOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan based on the database schema, query workload, and system resources. We evaluate RL-QOpt on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Distributed Belief Revision for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, agents often hold incomplete or uncertain information about their environment. This paper presents a novel distributed belief revision framework that enables agents to update their beliefs in response to new information, while respecting the constraints imposed by incomplete knowledge. Our approach leverages a probabilistic ontology to represent agent beliefs and a distributed consensus protocol to ensure consistency across the system. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through simulations on a smart traffic management scenario, where agents must adapt to changing traffic patterns and uncertain sensor readings.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting models have achieved impressive performance with deep learning techniques, but often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for time series forecasting, which incorporates both local and global attention mechanisms to capture complex temporal dependencies. Our approach learns to focus on relevant input features and time steps, providing explainable predictions. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the accuracy and interpretability of our HAN model, outperforming state-of-the-art models in both tasks.

title: Neural Re-ranking with Document Expansion for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval has become a crucial component in many natural language processing applications. However, the ranking of passages often relies on simple lexical matching methods, which can lead to suboptimal results. In this paper, we propose a neural re-ranking approach that incorporates document expansion to capture contextual information. Our model, ExpandoRank, utilizes a hierarchical encoder to represent passages and their surrounding documents, and then applies a neural ranking function to re-score the passages. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ExpandoRank achieves significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval models.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts system performance and scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using machine learning techniques. We develop a query plan prediction model that leverages historical query execution data to forecast optimal execution plans for new queries. Our approach incorporates advanced feature engineering techniques, including query graph embedding and workload characterization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our approach reduces query execution time by up to 30% compared to traditional query optimization methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Cognitive Load on User Experience in Voice-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including smart homes, virtual assistants, and in-vehicle systems. However, the cognitive load imposed by these interfaces on users remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of cognitive load on user experience, focusing on speech recognition accuracy, response time, and subjective workload. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, who interacted with a voice-based interface while performing cognitive tasks of varying difficulty. Our results show that high cognitive load significantly impairs speech recognition accuracy and increases response time, leading to decreased user satisfaction. We propose design guidelines for mitigating cognitive load in voice-based interfaces, emphasizing the importance of considering users' cognitive capacity in HCI design.

title: Optimizing Query Processing on Distributed Graph Databases using Hierarchical Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have emerged as a scalable solution for managing large-scale graph-structured data. However, query processing on these systems remains a significant challenge, particularly in the presence of skewed data distributions and varying query workloads. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical replication strategy, 'HierRepl', which dynamically adapts to query patterns and data hotspots. We demonstrate that HierRepl achieves significant improvements in query response times and system throughput compared to traditional replication schemes, while maintaining data consistency and minimizing replication overhead. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset validate the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity and variability of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features for improved emotion recognition. Our approach employs a multi-level attention mechanism, combining modality-aware and feature-aware attention to capture both inter-modal and intra-modal relationships. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our HAN model, achieving state-of-the-art performance and outperforming existing methods by up to 10% in terms of accuracy and F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of database systems, but it becomes increasingly complex in distributed settings. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and design an RL agent that learns to select efficient query plans based on runtime statistics and feedback. Our experiments on a distributed database system show that the RL-based optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Query Optimization for Scalable Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between data entities. However, optimizing queries for graph databases remains a challenging problem due to the exponential growth of possible query plans. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, where the query optimizer learns to select the most efficient query plan based on rewards generated from execution time and memory usage. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, called 'GraphQLearn', on a range of graph datasets and show significant improvements in query performance compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed human-computer interaction, but the role of embodied cognition in VR remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of gesture-based interaction on cognitive load and task performance in VR. We designed an experiment involving 30 participants, who performed a series of spatial reasoning tasks using either gesture-based or controller-based interfaces. Results show that gesture-based interaction reduces cognitive load and improves task performance, suggesting that embodied cognition plays a significant role in VR. We discuss implications for the design of intuitive and efficient VR interfaces, highlighting the potential for gesture-based interaction to enhance user experience.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but efficient query processing remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'DRIAD', that accelerates multi-dimensional range queries in distributed databases. DRIAD leverages a hierarchical indexing structure that adapts to the data distribution and query patterns, reducing the number of nodes involved in query processing. We evaluate DRIAD on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing indexing techniques, achieving an average query response time reduction of 35%.

title: Exploiting Indexing Techniques for Efficient Graph Pattern Matching in Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Graph pattern matching has emerged as a crucial query processing technique in various applications, including social network analysis and biological data mining. However, its integration with relational databases remains inefficient due to the absence of native graph support. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'Graphix', which leverages relational database indexing techniques to accelerate graph pattern matching. We develop a graph-to-relational schema mapping algorithm and design a hybrid index that combines the benefits of B+-tree and graph indexing. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that Graphix outperforms existing graph pattern matching algorithms by up to 3x, while maintaining compatibility with existing relational databases.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on distributed graph databases poses significant query optimization challenges. Existing approaches either sacrifice query performance or incur high overheads for maintaining graph consistency. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphPulse', which leverages graph summarization and adaptive sampling to reduce query latency by up to 75%. GraphPulse utilizes a probabilistic graph model to estimate query results and dynamically adjusts sampling rates based on query complexity and graph topology. Experimental evaluations on large-scale graph datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphPulse in supporting real-time analytics workloads.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Attention Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval (IR) rely on simplistic term-frequency representations, neglecting the rich semantic structures present in documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant document segments and terms. Our approach incorporates a document-aware attention mechanism that captures long-range dependencies and contextual relationships between tokens. Experimental results on the TREC-8 benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision (MAP) and normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG) over state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to allocate tasks to heterogeneous agents. Our method, 'DAGAT', learns to represent agents and tasks as nodes in a graph and employs a self-attention mechanism to capture complex dependencies between them. We show that DAGAT outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of solution quality and scalability, and demonstrate its effectiveness in a simulation study of a disaster response scenario.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation in Edge Computing
paper_abstract: Edge computing has enabled low-latency processing of massive amounts of data, but efficient resource allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARA', which enables autonomous decision-making among edge nodes. We design a novel action space that incorporates both resource allocation and task scheduling, and develop a decentralized Q-learning algorithm that adapts to dynamic edge computing environments. Experiments on a realistic edge computing simulator demonstrate that MARA achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and overall system throughput compared to traditional centralized resource allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments and resource utilization. We introduce a hierarchical architecture comprising a high-level task allocator and low-level agent controllers, which learn to coordinate through a decentralized, model-free reinforcement learning approach. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework in improving task completion rates and reducing agent collisions, outperforming traditional auction-based methods in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Explainable Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained increasing attention in recent years, but existing approaches often neglect the complex relationships between different modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Explainable Attention Network (HEAT) that integrates multimodal features through a hierarchical attention mechanism. Our approach learns to selectively focus on relevant regions of input data, providing interpretable results. We evaluate HEAT on two benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in sentiment analysis accuracy and explainability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Edge Computing
paper_abstract: Edge computing has emerged as a promising paradigm for reducing latency and improving real-time processing capabilities. However, efficient resource allocation remains a significant challenge in edge computing environments. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'EdgeOpt', which learns to allocate resources optimally in edge computing systems. EdgeOpt leverages a hierarchical architecture to represent the complex relationships between edge devices, applications, and resources, and employs a reinforcement learning agent to make adaptive allocation decisions. Experimental results on a real-world edge computing testbed demonstrate that EdgeOpt achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Meta-Learning for Adaptive Explainability in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Despite their success, deep neural networks often lack transparency, hindering trust in AI-driven decision-making. This paper contributes to the growing field of explainable AI by proposing a meta-learning framework for adaptive explainability. Our approach, 'MetaXAI', leverages model-agnostic meta-learning to generate interpretable explanations for novel, unseen inputs. By adapting to the underlying data distribution, MetaXAI outperforms existing explainability methods in terms of fidelity, relevance, and computational efficiency. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaXAI on a range of image classification benchmarks, showcasing its potential for promoting trustworthy AI systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is crucial for developing empathetic human-robot interaction systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in real-time. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and temporal segments, improving recognition accuracy and robustness. Experimental results on a large-scale emotion dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our HAN model, achieving a 12.5% improvement over state-of-the-art multi-modal fusion methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Coordination using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel decentralized multi-agent coordination framework that leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to enable efficient and scalable decision-making in complex systems. We propose a graph-based representation of the agent interaction space, which allows agents to learn and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our framework is evaluated on a series of benchmarks, demonstrating improved coordination efficiency and robustness compared to traditional centralized and decentralized approaches. We envision applications in autonomous systems, smart cities, and swarm robotics.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and resources need to collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. We leverage graph neural networks (GNNs) to model the agent interactions and develop a distributed optimization algorithm that allocates tasks to agents based on their capabilities and the task requirements. Our approach is evaluated on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized task allocation methods.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interface Design
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but designing effective interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in VR, focusing on gesture-based interfaces. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, examining how bodily gestures influence cognitive processes and task performance in a virtual environment. Our results show that embodied interfaces can improve spatial awareness, working memory, and overall user experience. We provide design recommendations for incorporating embodied cognition principles into VR interfaces, highlighting the importance of gesture-based interaction in future HCI systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: As data continues to grow in scale and complexity, distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular. However, optimizing queries in DDS remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization technique, 'HierOpt', which leverages hierarchical clustering to group correlated data fragments and reduce query latency. Our approach exploits the inherent structure of the data to identify optimal join orders and minimize inter-node communication. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HierOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 35% in terms of query response time.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Effective Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the limited query context. This paper presents a neural query expansion approach, NQE, which leverages transformer-based language models to generate context-aware query expansions. NQE incorporates a novel attention mechanism that selectively weights query terms based on their semantic importance and contextual relevance. Our experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark show that NQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their scalability and fault-tolerance. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and develop a deep Q-network-based algorithm to learn the optimal query plan. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on complex decision-making algorithms to navigate real-world scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-AV', which integrates high-level goal-directed planning with low-level motion control. Our approach leverages a novel hierarchical abstraction of the environment, allowing the agent to focus on relevant features and ignore distractions. We demonstrate improved decision-making performance in simulated urban driving scenarios, achieving a 25% reduction in accidents and a 15% increase in route efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval tasks often involve complex queries that require effective query expansion to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural query expansion approach, 'HNQE', which leverages a combination of semantic and syntactic features to generate a hierarchical representation of the query. Our experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that HNQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision. Furthermore, we show that HNQE can be efficiently integrated with existing retrieval models, enabling fast document filtering and retrieval.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained popularity in recent years due to the need for transparency in AI-driven decision-making. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for ERS, which leverages both item-level and user-level attention mechanisms to generate personalized explanations for recommended items. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art ERS models on three benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in explanation quality and user satisfaction. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned attention patterns, offering insights into the decision-making process of the model.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its performance heavily relies on the careful tuning of hyperparameters. This process is typically time-consuming and computationally expensive, especially when dealing with large-scale problems. We propose a novel approach, 'HyperBO', which leverages Bayesian optimization to efficiently search for optimal hyperparameters in DRL. By adopting a surrogate-based model and an acquisition function tailored to DRL's unique characteristics, HyperBO significantly reduces the number of evaluations required to achieve state-of-the-art performance. Experimental results on various Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Graph Neural Networks via Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based applications. However, their performance is highly dependent on the choice of hyperparameters, which is often a time-consuming and labor-intensive process. This paper proposes a Bayesian optimization framework, 'GNN-BO', for efficient hyperparameter tuning of GNNs. We leverage a probabilistic surrogate model to search for the optimal hyperparameters, and demonstrate its effectiveness on several graph-based benchmarks. Experimental results show that GNN-BO outperforms grid search and random search in terms of both optimization speed and model performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) is a crucial task for developing empathetic interfaces. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages multi-modal data from facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions. Our HAN model learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the EmoReact dataset. We also conduct an extensive ablation study to demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in handling noisy or missing data. The proposed framework has promising applications in affective computing, virtual assistants, and mental health monitoring.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans in distributed database systems is a complex problem due to the exponential growth of possible plans. Traditional approaches rely on rule-based systems or static cost models, which may not adapt well to changing workloads. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning to query optimization, where the database system learns to select optimal plans based on feedback from past executions. We propose a novel framework, 'RL-Optimizer', which integrates a deep Q-network with a distributed database system. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that RL-Optimizer outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers in reducing query latency and improving system throughput.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Cultural and Linguistic Adaptation
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their effectiveness is often limited by cultural and linguistic biases. This study investigates the impact of cultural and linguistic adaptation on the usability and acceptability of voice assistants among diverse user groups. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants from five linguistic and cultural backgrounds, examining their interactions with a custom-built voice assistant adapted to their respective cultures and languages. Our results show significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion rates, and perceived trust when the voice assistant is adapted to the user's cultural and linguistic context. We propose a framework for culturally and linguistically adaptive voice assistants and discuss implications for inclusive design in HCI.

title: Query Optimization for Massive RDF Graphs using Parallel Hash-Based Join Algorithms
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF data has led to a surge in massive graph datasets, posing significant challenges for query optimization. This paper presents a novel parallel hash-based join algorithm, 'RDFJoin', designed to efficiently process complex queries on massive RDF graphs. RDFJoin leverages a distributed indexing strategy and a lock-free hash table to minimize synchronization overhead and optimize join operations. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that RDFJoin outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. While deep learning models have shown promising results, their lack of interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that not only detects anomalies but also provides explanations for its predictions. Our approach leverages a hierarchical self-attention mechanism to identify relevant features and time steps contributing to the anomaly score. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies while offering meaningful insights into the decision-making process.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Swarm Intelligence
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, inspired by swarm intelligence principles. We develop a distributed algorithm that utilizes stigmergy-based communication and adaptive pheromone trails to optimize task assignments. Our approach considers agent capabilities, task requirements, and system-wide constraints, enabling efficient and flexible task allocation in dynamic environments. Simulation results demonstrate improved system performance, scalability, and robustness compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for efficient robot navigation in dynamic environments. The proposed approach combines a high-level task planner with a low-level motion controller, leveraging the strengths of both to adapt to changing environmental conditions. We introduce a novel curriculum learning strategy that gradually increases the complexity of the environment, allowing the agent to learn more efficiently. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate significant improvements in navigation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional flat reinforcement learning methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Augmented Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for intuitive and accurate gesture recognition systems. This paper presents an adaptive gesture recognition framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to recognize and adapt to user gestures in real-time. Our approach incorporates a novel gesture representation model that combines skeletal data with surface electromyography (sEMG) signals, enabling more accurate and personalized recognition. We evaluate our system through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Graph-Based Entity Disambiguation for Efficient Query Optimization in Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in query optimization to resolve ambiguity in entity references. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach, 'GEDB', that leverages the structural properties of relational databases to disambiguate entities. GEDB constructs a graph representation of the database schema and query, and then applies a community detection algorithm to identify densely connected subgraphs that correspond to distinct entities. Our experiments on two real-world databases demonstrate that GEDB outperforms state-of-the-art disambiguation techniques by up to 30% in query optimization efficiency while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition tasks often rely on fusion techniques that combine features from different modalities, such as audio, video, and text. However, these approaches can be limited by the quality of the features and the complexity of the fusion process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features at multiple levels of abstraction. Our experiments on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5% across six emotions.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems pose significant query optimization challenges due to varying workload patterns and resource constraints. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query execution plans in such systems. We propose a novel RL framework, 'QTune', which learns to adapt to changing workloads and resource availability through trial and error. QTune utilizes a combination of exploration-exploitation strategies and a custom-designed reward function to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world multi-tenant database benchmark demonstrate that QTune outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 35% in terms of query latency reduction.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for information retrieval often suffer from high computational costs and laborious training procedures. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking framework, 'HierRank', which leverages document embeddings and attention mechanisms to efficiently filter and rank documents. By hierarchically aggregating relevance signals from multiple granularities, HierRank achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness while reducing computational overhead. Experiments on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, outperforming existing neural ranking models in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the task allocation problem in decentralized multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and resources need to collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) framework that enables agents to locally negotiate and allocate tasks while respecting global constraints. Our approach utilizes a decentralized graph-based representation of the task allocation problem, which allows agents to efficiently exchange information and converge to a near-optimal solution. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task allocation efficiency and robustness compared to centralized methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to support older adults' independence, but existing designs often neglect their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a participatory study with 20 older adults, exploring their experiences and preferences with voice assistants. We identify key challenges, such as difficulties with voice recognition, language complexity, and discoverability of features. Based on our findings, we propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, including personalized voice profiles, simplified language, and multimodal feedback. Our study contributes to the development of more accessible and usable voice assistants for older adults.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Skew-Aware Histograms in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems often struggle with query performance due to data skew, leading to inefficient resource utilization and slow response times. This paper proposes a novel skew-aware histogram (SAH) approach to optimize query performance in distributed databases. SAH leverages statistical analysis and machine learning techniques to identify data hotspots and adapt histogram construction accordingly. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that SAH reduces query latency by up to 35% and improves resource utilization by 20% compared to traditional histogram methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and suffer from limited scalability. This paper presents a neural query expansion approach, dubbed 'NeuQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate semantic embeddings for queries and documents. NeuQE adaptively selects relevant expansion terms by optimizing a novel scoring function that balances relevance and diversity. Experiments on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on simplistic term frequency-based approaches. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding-based query expansion framework, 'CAQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and their contexts. We demonstrate that CAQE significantly improves retrieval performance on standard benchmarks, particularly for ambiguous and multi-faceted queries. Furthermore, we show that CAQE can be efficiently integrated with existing retrieval architectures, making it a practical solution for real-world search engines.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural document embeddings to better model semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'NeuQE', uses a dense passage retrieval model to generate contextualized embeddings for query terms and relevant documents. These embeddings are then used to expand the original query with semantically similar terms, resulting in improved retrieval performance. Experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate the efficacy of NeuQE, achieving a 12% increase in mean average precision over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults: An Exploratory Study on Cognitive Load Reduction
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible and user-friendly interfaces that cater to older adults. Voice-based interfaces have shown promise in reducing cognitive load, but their design must be tailored to accommodate age-related cognitive declines. This study conducted a series of user experiments to investigate the effects of voice-based interface design on cognitive load reduction in older adults. Our results indicate that incorporating age-specific design features, such as simplified language and feedback mechanisms, can significantly reduce cognitive load and improve user experience. We provide guidelines for designers to create more inclusive and accessible voice-based interfaces for older adults.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Task Networks for Smart Grid Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents in smart grid management using hierarchical task networks (HTNs). Our approach, called Agent-HTN, enables agents to reason about high-level goals and decompose them into smaller, actionable tasks that can be executed in a distributed manner. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Agent-HTN in a simulated smart grid environment, where it achieves improved efficiency and resilience compared to traditional centralized control methods. Additionally, we provide a formal analysis of the system's scalability and fault tolerance.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Learning Models using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their hyperparameter tuning remains a labor-intensive and computationally expensive task. This paper presents a novel Bayesian optimization framework, 'BOHB', that efficiently explores the hyperparameter space to find optimal configurations. BOHB leverages a probabilistic surrogate model to guide the search and incorporates a dynamic resource allocation strategy to adapt to changing computing resources. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that BOHB outperforms existing tuning methods, reducing the tuning time by up to 75% while maintaining comparable model performance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the varying importance of different modalities. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) to jointly model intra- and inter-modality relationships. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to adaptively weigh the importance of different modalities and their interactions, leading to improved emotion recognition performance. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in recognizing emotions from multimodal data, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Robust Deep Learning based Anomaly Detection for Time-Series Data using Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a robust deep learning framework, 'TransAD', that leverages transfer learning to improve anomaly detection performance. We demonstrate that pre-trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) on image datasets can be effectively fine-tuned on time-series data, achieving state-of-the-art results on benchmark datasets. Our approach is robust to varying anomaly types and densities, outperforming traditional statistical methods and shallow machine learning models. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets validate the efficacy of TransAD in detecting anomalies in time-series data.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Tracking for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of inclusive designs. This paper presents EmoTract, a novel affective state tracking system that enables VR systems to recognize and respond to users' emotional states in real-time. EmoTract combines computer vision, machine learning, and cognitive modeling to detect emotional cues from facial expressions, body language, and physiological signals. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that EmoTract-enhanced VR experiences lead to increased user engagement, comfort, and emotional satisfaction, particularly for users with disabilities.

title: Efficient Indexing for Neural Retrieval Models in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in ad-hoc search tasks, but their computational cost and memory requirements hinder their adoption in large-scale search engines. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, 'NeuralIndex', which leverages the underlying neural network's architecture to reduce the dimensionality of the search space. We introduce a hierarchical clustering algorithm that groups semantically similar documents, enabling fast filtering and scoring of candidates. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that NeuralIndex achieves a 3x speedup over existing approaches while maintaining comparable retrieval performance.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel deep neural network-based approach to query expansion, which leverages the strengths of both word embeddings and semantic matching models. Our proposed method, 'NeuroQE', learns to generate context-aware expanded queries that better capture the underlying semantics of the original query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents Using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages auction-based mechanisms to allocate tasks to autonomous agents. We propose a novel auction protocol that incorporates agents' private valuations and task dependencies, ensuring efficient and fair task allocation. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utility. We also provide a formal analysis of the protocol's convergence and stability properties.

title: Enhancing Query Reformulation using Deep Semantic Role Labeling for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems often struggle with complex, nuanced queries that require deeper semantic understanding. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep semantic role labeling (SRL) to enhance query reformulation in ODQA. Our method, SRL-QR, uses a BERT-based SRL model to identify and disambiguate predicate-argument structures in queries, which are then used to generate more effective reformulations. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that SRL-QR significantly improves answer retrieval accuracy and outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graph Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF graph databases in large-scale data integration and knowledge graph applications has led to a growing need for efficient query optimization techniques. This paper presents a novel, scalable query optimization framework for distributed RDF graph databases. Our approach leverages a combination of graph partitioning, query rewriting, and parallel execution to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. We evaluate our framework on a cluster of 16 machines using the LUBM benchmark and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Existing multimodal sentiment analysis approaches rely on complex fusion techniques, making it challenging to interpret the decision-making process. This paper introduces a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages visual, acoustic, and textual features to predict sentiment scores. Our HAN model employs a novel attention mechanism that learns to weight modality-specific features based on their relevance to the sentiment prediction task. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and F1-score, while providing transparent and interpretable results.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of expression across different modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in HCI. Our HAN model uses multi-modal fusion and hierarchical attention to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in emotion recognition accuracy and robustness. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale multimodal emotion recognition dataset, demonstrating its effectiveness in real-world HCI applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. Our method, called GraphAgent, represents the agent interaction graph as a dynamic graph signal processing framework, allowing agents to learn from local observations and communicate with their neighbors to allocate tasks efficiently. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphAgent in achieving high task allocation efficiency and robustness to agent failures.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
