paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDBS) with heterogeneous storage (e.g., HDD, SSD, and flash) have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data workloads efficiently. However, query optimization in such systems is a complex task due to the varying storage access patterns and speeds. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'HeteroOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and adaptive plan optimization to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Our experimental results on a real-world DDBS setup show that HeteroOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 35% in terms of query response time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a challenging task, especially when requiring explainability. We propose a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages both intra-modal and inter-modal relationships to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN architecture consists of modality-specific attention modules and a fusion layer that adaptively weights the modalities. We evaluate our approach on the CMU-MOSEI dataset and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods. Notably, our model provides interpretable attention weights, enabling explanation of the decision-making process.

title: Reinforced Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Heterogeneous Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in modern search engines, as it bridges the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. However, existing methods often struggle with heterogeneous document collections, where different genres or formats exhibit distinct linguistic patterns. We propose a novel reinforced query expansion framework, 'RQE-Het', which leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select expansion terms based on the document collection's characteristics. Our approach incorporates a heterogeneous document model, which captures diverse language styles and semantic relationships. Experimental results on a large-scale, heterogeneous dataset demonstrate that RQE-Het outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing the computational overhead.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinated exploration in multi-agent systems, where agents need to balance individual exploration with collective goal-oriented behavior. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MA-CERL', which combines centralized critics with decentralized actor networks. Our approach enables agents to learn coordinated exploration strategies that adapt to changing environmental conditions and improve overall system performance. Experimental results in a simulated robotics domain demonstrate the effectiveness of MA-CERL in achieving faster convergence and higher rewards compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Neural Search Engines
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with query formulation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using pseudo-relevance feedback, which leverages the neural model's own uncertainty to identify relevant terms. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroQE', adaptively selects expansion terms based on the model's confidence scores and relevance estimates. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, improving both precision and recall by up to 15%.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Massive-Scale Graph Databases using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: The proliferation of graph-structured data has led to a surge in query optimization research. This paper introduces 'GLIndex', a novel learned index framework specifically designed for massive-scale graph databases. By integrating deep learning-based index structures with traditional query optimization techniques, GLIndex achieves significant improvements in query performance and scalability. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GLIndex on several real-world graph datasets, showcasing up to 5x speedup over state-of-the-art query optimization methods.

title: Query-Aware Document Expansion for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively rank documents for complex queries. We propose a novel document expansion approach that incorporates query-aware context to improve retrieval performance. Our method, 'QEAX', generates a query-specific document representation by combining the original document content with relevant passages from a knowledge graph. We evaluate QEAX on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain compared to state-of-the-art retrieval models.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have different capabilities and tasks have varying requirements. We propose a decentralized deep reinforcement learning framework, 'AgentAllocator', which enables agents to learn effective task allocation policies through self-play. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and attention mechanisms to focus on relevant task features. Experimental results on a simulated robotics domain demonstrate that AgentAllocator outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion efficiency and agent utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attentional Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media has severe consequences for individuals and society. Existing detection methods often rely on hand-crafted features or complex neural networks, lacking transparency and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attentional Graph Convolutional Network (HAGCN) for explainable fake news detection. HAGCN captures the complex relationships between news articles, user interactions, and source credibility by learning hierarchical attention weights on graph-structured data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGCN on a large-scale fake news dataset, achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing visual explanations for its predictions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational agents is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction. Existing approaches typically rely on a single modality, such as speech or text, and struggle to generalize across diverse contexts. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal features from speech, text, and visual cues. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical structure to capture both local and global dependencies across modalities, enabling more accurate emotion recognition. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12.5% improvement in F1-score.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant challenges in optimizing query execution plans, leading to suboptimal performance and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed settings. Our method, 'RL-Optimizer', learns to adapt to changing workload patterns and database dynamics, outperforming traditional cost-based optimization techniques. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Databases using Machine Learning-based Index Selection
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to select the most effective index for a given query. Our method, called 'IndexOpt', uses a combination of query features and database characteristics to train a neural network that predicts the optimal index. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that IndexOpt outperforms traditional indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'Dec-TARL', enables agents to learn efficient task allocation strategies in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce a novel graph-based representation of agent-task relationships and a decentralized Q-learning algorithm that leverages local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate that Dec-TARL outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utility.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Adaptive Task Allocation and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems to achieve complex tasks is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper presents a novel framework that integrates adaptive task allocation with reinforcement learning to optimize agent coordination. Our approach, called 'ATA-RL', uses a decentralized task allocation algorithm to assign tasks to agents based on their capabilities and availability. The agents then learn to adjust their actions using reinforcement learning, taking into account the tasks assigned to them and the actions of other agents. We evaluate ATA-RL in a simulated search and rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the independence and quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, current systems often fail to account for the unique needs and challenges of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive voice assistants, incorporating insights from a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers. We identify key barriers to adoption, including difficulties with speech recognition, conversation flow, and error recovery, and propose design recommendations to address these issues. Our evaluation with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing scale and complexity of distributed relational databases necessitate efficient query optimization techniques to minimize response times and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to predict optimal query plans. We develop a graph neural network (GNN) that learns to represent query plans as graphs and predicts the most efficient plan based on historical query execution data. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time, while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans is crucial for efficient performance in distributed database systems. Current approaches rely on hand-crafted heuristics, which often fall short in complex scenarios. This paper presents 'DeepQOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to adaptively generate optimal execution plans. By modeling query optimization as a Markov decision process, our approach learns to navigate the vast space of possible plans and identifies superior solutions. Experimental results on a commercial database system demonstrate that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3.2x, while reducing optimization time by 45%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding has emerged as a crucial task in various applications, including question answering and recommender systems. However, existing methods struggle to effectively model complex relationships between entities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework, which leverages multi-relational knowledge graphs to learn rich entity representations. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant relational patterns, enabling more accurate and interpretable embeddings. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with motor impairments. However, existing systems often struggle to accurately recognize gestures performed by individuals with disabilities. This paper presents an adaptive gesture recognition framework that incorporates machine learning and computer vision techniques to accommodate varying levels of motor impairment. Our approach uses a hybrid model combining convolutional neural networks and hidden Markov models to recognize gestures, and adapts to individual users through an online learning mechanism. We evaluate our system with a user study involving 20 older adults with motor impairments, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning for Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models have achieved impressive performance, but their decision-making processes remain opaque. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based approach, 'HARE', which integrates explainable reasoning into VQA models. HARE uses a graph-based attention mechanism to highlight relevant regions in the image and identify the most informative question tokens. Our experiments on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that HARE not only improves answer accuracy but also provides interpretable visual and linguistic explanations for its predictions.

title: Coordinated Exploration for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating exploration in multi-agent systems is crucial for efficient decision-making and information gathering. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphAttentionExplore', which leverages graph attention networks to model inter-agent dependencies and coordinate exploration strategies. By incorporating attention mechanisms, our method adaptively focuses on the most informative agents and tasks, achieving improved exploration efficiency and reduced communication overhead. Experimental results on a range of cooperative exploration tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphAttentionExplore in enhancing overall system performance.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of virtual reality (VR) technology has sparked interest in enhancing user engagement and experience. This study explores the role of personalized avatars in VR environments, examining their impact on user motivation, self-expression, and overall satisfaction. We designed and implemented a VR system that generates customized avatars based on users' personality traits and preferences. Our user study involving 120 participants reveals that personalized avatars lead to higher levels of engagement, enjoyment, and social presence in VR, particularly among individuals with low self-esteem. The findings have implications for the design of inclusive and engaging VR experiences.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing VR interfaces often neglect the needs of users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel, inclusive VR interface framework that leverages audio and haptic cues to facilitate navigation and interaction for visually impaired users. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, comparing our framework to a conventional visual-based interface. Results show significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction. We discuss implications for designers and developers seeking to create more accessible VR experiences.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to achieve a common goal. This paper proposes a novel decentralized coalition formation algorithm, 'CoForm', which enables agents to dynamically form coalitions and allocate tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We model the task allocation problem as a hedonic game and design a distributed protocol that converges to a stable coalition structure. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that CoForm outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion rate and coalition stability.

title: Investigating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly prevalent, but its adoption is hindered by user discomfort and fatigue. This paper explores the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience in VR. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, using a custom-built VR system with integrated haptic feedback. Our results show a significant reduction in user discomfort and improved spatial awareness when haptic feedback is present. We also identify key design factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including vibration frequency and amplitude. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems and applications, particularly in fields like education, healthcare, and entertainment.

title: Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion for E-commerce Product Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce product search often relies on keyword-based queries, which can be imprecise and lead to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion (HNQE) model that leverages both semantic and syntactic features to generate more informative and context-aware queries. HNQE consists of a hierarchical encoder that captures long-range dependencies in product titles and descriptions, and a neural expansion module that adaptively generates new query terms based on the input query and product context. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HNQE significantly improves search relevance and retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a decentralized approach using reinforcement learning, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on local observations and communication with neighbors. Our method, called 'DRL-TA', uses a novel combination of deep Q-networks and graph neural networks to learn task allocation policies. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms traditional decentralized approaches, achieving higher task completion rates and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems have become ubiquitous in modern online services, but their black-box nature raises concerns about transparency and accountability. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates explainability mechanisms to provide insights into recommendation decisions. Our approach leverages user and item embeddings to learn attention weights that reflect the relative importance of different features. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art recommendation models while providing interpretable explanations for its predictions.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalization on User Engagement in Voice-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in various applications, including virtual assistants and smart home devices. While personalization is often touted as a key factor in enhancing user experience, its impact on user engagement in voice-based interfaces remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study that explores the effects of personalization on user engagement in voice-based interfaces. Our results show that personalized voice responses can significantly increase user engagement, but only when the personalization is perceived as relevant and accurate. We also identify several design implications for creating more engaging voice-based interfaces, including the importance of transparent personalization mechanisms and user control over personalized features.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a decentralized auction-based mechanism for task allocation, where agents bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We propose a novel auction protocol, 'Distributed Vickrey Auction', which ensures truthfulness and individual rationality. Our approach is scalable, flexible, and resilient to agent failures. Experimental results on a realistic scenario demonstrate that our method outperforms existing centralized and decentralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases face the challenge of optimizing query performance while handling large volumes of data. This paper introduces AIDA, an adaptive indexing framework that dynamically adjusts indexing strategies based on query patterns and data distributions. AIDA leverages machine learning models to predict query frequencies and optimize index creation, resulting in significant improvements in query response times. We evaluate AIDA on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate an average query performance improvement of 30% compared to traditional indexing approaches.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Query Expansion and Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval that aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, HQE-NR, which leverages a neural ranking model to select the most informative expansion terms. Our approach combines the strengths of both lexical and semantic expansion methods, reducing the dimensionality of the expanded query space while preserving the relevance of top-ranked documents. Experimental results on the TREC AP dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Scalable Graph Query Optimization using Subgraph Isomorphism
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become ubiquitous in modern data management, but querying large graphs remains a significant performance bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach to optimize graph queries by leveraging subgraph isomorphism. We propose a hierarchical indexing scheme that efficiently identifies candidate subgraphs, reducing the search space for isomorphism checks. Experimental evaluation on real-world graph datasets demonstrates that our approach achieves up to 5x speedup compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques, while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages graph-structured user-item interactions to generate personalized recommendations with transparent explanations. Our model integrates node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to identify influential users and items, and learns to explain recommendations by highlighting relevant interaction patterns. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in improving recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems via Adaptive Data Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDBS) are crucial for modern applications, but query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an adaptive data replication strategy, 'ADRe', which dynamically adjusts replication factors based on query patterns and data access frequencies. ADRe leverages machine learning techniques to predict query hotspots and optimize data placement across nodes, reducing latency and improving overall system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world DDBS deployment demonstrate significant performance gains, with average query response times reduced by up to 35% compared to traditional static replication schemes.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed databases using Graph-based Indexing
paper_abstract: As data scales, distributed databases face significant performance bottlenecks in query optimization. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GraphOpt', which leverages the inherent structure of query graphs to prune unnecessary joins and optimize query plans. We introduce a novel cost model that integrates both data fragmentation and network latency, enabling more accurate estimation of query execution times. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that GraphOpt reduces query response times by up to 3x compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Adaptive Trust and Reputation Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust and reputation play crucial roles in facilitating cooperation and mitigating malicious behavior. This paper presents a novel framework, 'AdapTrust', which integrates adaptive trust and reputation mechanisms to enhance the coordination of autonomous agents. AdapTrust leverages machine learning techniques to learn trust models from agent interactions and adapt to changing environmental conditions. We evaluate AdapTrust in a simulated smart grid scenario, demonstrating improved cooperation and reduced susceptibilities to manipulation attacks compared to existing trust-based approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Accurate and interpretable time-series forecasting is crucial in various applications, including finance and healthcare. This paper introduces 'HATSF', a novel hierarchical attention network that learns to selectively focus on relevant segments of multivariate time-series data. Our approach leverages a stacked self-attention mechanism to capture complex temporal dependencies and identify influential variables. We evaluate HATSF on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating improved forecasting performance and enhanced explainability compared to state-of-the-art methods. Visualizations of attention weights provide actionable insights into the forecasting process, enabling users to identify key drivers of predicted outcomes.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in many real-world applications, but existing models often lack interpretability. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates feature attention and temporal attention to generate explainable forecasts. Our approach captures complex interactions between variables and time steps, while providing insights into the contribution of each feature to the forecasting process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in terms of forecasting accuracy and explainability, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scoped Belief Revision for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, agents often possess incomplete information about their environment and other agents' beliefs. This paper introduces a novel scoped belief revision framework that enables agents to revise their beliefs in response to new information while respecting the boundaries of their knowledge. Our approach leverages a probabilistic ontology to model incomplete information and incorporates a negotiation mechanism to resolve conflicts between agents' beliefs. We evaluate our framework in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving coordination and decision-making among agents with incomplete information.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Video Summarization
paper_abstract: Automatic video summarization has garnered significant attention in recent years, but most existing methods lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for explainable video summarization. Our HAN architecture consists of two stages: a frame-level attention module that identifies relevant regions, and a shot-level attention module that selects informative shots. We introduce a novel attention regularization term that encourages the model to focus on diverse aspects of the video, thereby improving summary diversity and coherence. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in generating concise, informative summaries while providing insights into the summarization process.

title: Human-Centric Adaptive Notification Systems for Enhanced User Engagement
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel human-centric approach to adaptive notification systems, which leverages user behavior, context, and preferences to optimize notification timing and content. Our system, 'NotiFit', incorporates machine learning-based user modeling and real-time sensor data to personalize notifications, reducing distractions and improving user engagement. A 6-week user study with 100 participants demonstrates that NotiFit increases notification response rates by 35% and reduces perceived annoyance by 27% compared to traditional notification systems. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more human-centered and effective notification systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive conversational interfaces for this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults with cognitive impairments and their caregivers, identifying key design principles and heuristics. We developed a prototype conversational system, 'CareChat', which incorporates these principles, including simplified language, visual cues, and error tolerance. Our usability study shows that CareChat significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Task Planning
paper_abstract: Task planning for robots in complex environments requires efficient decision-making and adaptability. This paper introduces HRL-TPE, a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that integrates task planning and execution. We propose a novel hierarchical policy representation, which decomposes tasks into sub-tasks and learns to select the most promising ones based on the current state. Our approach leverages a graph-based representation of the task space and incorporates domain knowledge to prune the search space. Experimental results on a robotic arm platform demonstrate that HRL-TPE outperforms flat reinforcement learning methods in terms of task completion time and success rate.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning has seen significant progress in recent years, but scalability remains a major challenge. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables efficient learning in large-scale multi-agent environments. By selectively focusing on relevant agents and their interactions, HAN reduces the complexity of the learning problem and achieves state-of-the-art performance in several benchmark domains. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in scenarios with varying degrees of agent heterogeneity and dynamic behavior.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Keyword Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with the vocabulary mismatch problem, where query terms fail to match relevant document content. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'GraKE', which leverages graph-based keyword embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method represents queries and documents as graph structures, allowing for the propagation of semantic information between nodes. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that GraKE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision. Our approach is particularly effective for short queries and documents with limited context.

title: Ensuring Data Consistency in Real-Time Distributed Database Systems Using Multi-Version Concurrency Control
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems become increasingly prevalent, ensuring data consistency in real-time applications has become a pressing concern. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) approach that leverages timestamp-based ordering and conflict resolution mechanisms to guarantee consistency across distributed nodes. Our approach, called RT-MVCC, is designed to minimize latency and improve throughput in real-time systems. Experimental results on a simulated real-time database workload demonstrate that RT-MVCC outperforms existing MVCC schemes in terms of both consistency and performance.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on complex control systems to navigate diverse scenarios safely and efficiently. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework that decomposes the control task into a set of hierarchical sub-tasks, each addressing a specific aspect of vehicle control. Our approach leverages a multi-level abstraction of the environment, allowing the agent to focus on high-level decision-making while delegating low-level control to specialized sub-policies. Experimental results on a simulated urban driving environment demonstrate significant improvements in fuel efficiency, safety, and adaptability to changing traffic conditions compared to state-of-the-art model-based control methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Reinforcement Learning for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in e-commerce search to improve retrieval accuracy. Existing methods rely on manual feature engineering or simple heuristics, which may not generalize well across diverse product domains. We propose a novel reinforcement learning framework, 'QLX', which learns to adaptively expand queries based on user behavior and feedback. QLX uses a deep Q-network to select the most relevant expansion terms, and incorporates a reward function that balances precision and recall. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that QLX outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12.5% increase in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Clustering for Explainable Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for various applications, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, called 'HierAno', which detects anomalies while providing insights into their underlying causes. HierAno leverages a multi-resolution representation of time-series data, enabling the identification of anomalies at multiple scales. We introduce a novel metric, 'Explainability Score', to quantify the interpretability of detected anomalies. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HierAno outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both detection accuracy and explainability.

title: Efficient Indexing of Time-Series Data in Main-Memory Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential growth in time-series data, posing significant challenges for database systems. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'TS-Index', designed specifically for main-memory column-store databases. TS-Index leverages a combination of bit-packing, delta-encoding, and sampling to reduce storage overhead and improve query performance. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that TS-Index outperforms existing indexing methods, achieving up to 3x faster query execution and 2x better storage efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to select the most efficient query plans based on the underlying system dynamics and workload characteristics. Experimental results on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate that our approach achieves significant improvements in query response time and throughput compared to traditional rule-based optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for High-Dimensional Time Series Data
paper_abstract: High-dimensional time series data is ubiquitous in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. Anomaly detection in such data is crucial but challenging due to the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'Hierarchical Temporal Autoencoder' (HTAE), which leverages the strengths of both autoencoders and hierarchical clustering. HTAE learns a compact representation of the data by hierarchically grouping similar time series and identifying anomalies at multiple scales. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HTAE in detecting anomalies with high accuracy and efficiency, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the challenge of task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents possess different capabilities and resources. We propose a decentralized reinforcement learning approach, 'HRL-TA', which enables agents to learn and adapt to their environment and allocate tasks efficiently. Our approach utilizes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that integrates multiple agents' observations and actions to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HRL-TA outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized task allocation methods, achieving higher task completion rates and reduced communication overhead.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Evolutionary Game Theory
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that affects overall system performance. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework based on evolutionary game theory, which enables agents to adapt to changing environments and optimize their task assignments. Our approach, called 'Evo Alloc', uses a genetic algorithm to evolve agent strategies that balance individual utility with global system efficiency. We evaluate Evo Alloc on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate its ability to outperform traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of response time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database-as-a-service (DBaaS) platforms have gained popularity in recent years, but optimizing query performance across multiple tenants remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'OptiTen', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning-based workload characterization and adaptive resource allocation. OptiTen uses a combination of clustering and regression techniques to identify workload patterns and predict resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform show that OptiTen achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture query intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel query expansion approach, HDE-QE, which leverages hierarchical document embeddings to represent complex document relationships. Our method generates a hierarchical graph of document embeddings, enabling the identification of latent topics and semantic associations. This allows for more accurate and diverse query expansion, improving retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and recall over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interfaces for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on the role of gestural interfaces in enhancing user experience. We designed a VR system that incorporates hand-tracking technology and machine learning-based gesture recognition, enabling users to interact with virtual objects in a more natural and intuitive way. Our user study reveals that the embodied cognition approach improves user engagement, reduces cognitive load, and increases overall satisfaction. We also discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems and their potential applications in fields such as education, training, and therapy.

title: Enhanced Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires effective passage retrieval to identify relevant text snippets for answer extraction. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention (HGA) framework to enhance passage retrieval for ODQA. HGA exploits the graph structure of documents to model relationships between passages, entities, and keywords. We introduce a multi-level attention mechanism that adaptively weights passage representation, entity mentions, and keyword occurrences. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that our approach improves passage retrieval accuracy by 12.5% and overall ODQA performance by 7.2% compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Rewriting
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to query optimization using graph-based rewriting. Our method, called GraphOpt, represents the query as a graph and applies a set of rewriting rules to reduce the number of joins and subqueries. We demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques in terms of query execution time and scalability. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that GraphOpt achieves an average speedup of 3.2x compared to traditional query optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for various applications, including fault detection, predictive maintenance, and healthcare monitoring. While deep learning models have shown promising results, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying causes of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HATN) that addresses this limitation. HATN incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant segments of the time series, enabling explainable anomaly detection. Our experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATN outperforms state-of-the-art methods while providing insightful visualizations of the anomaly detection process.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the inherent complexity of coordinating agents with limited communication and partial observability. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'DTRL', that enables agents to learn decentralized task allocation policies in a self-organizing manner. We introduce a hierarchical graph neural network architecture that incorporates local observations, communication graphs, and task dependencies to generate effective task assignments. Experimental results on a range of benchmark problems demonstrate that DTRL outperforms existing decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate, communication overhead, and adaptability to dynamic task arrivals.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Query Representation for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for document retrieval often rely on computationally expensive query-document interaction mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query representation framework, 'HiQR', which leverages the semantic structure of queries to reduce the search space and accelerate retrieval. We introduce a query decomposition strategy that identifies key concepts and their relationships, enabling the construction of a hierarchical query graph. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that HiQR achieves significant speedups over existing methods while maintaining comparable retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have revolutionized information retrieval by leveraging deep learning models to capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, they often struggle with query ambiguity and scarcity, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'SemExpan', which utilizes semantic embeddings to generate high-quality expansion terms. SemExpan combines a neural query encoder with a graph-based expansion mechanism, allowing it to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and their contextualized meanings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SemExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Enhancing Relevance Feedback with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Relevance feedback is a crucial component of interactive information retrieval systems, as it enables users to refine their queries based on the retrieved documents. However, traditional relevance feedback methods rely heavily on heuristics and often fail to capture complex user behaviors. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepRF', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize relevance feedback. We model the user's feedback as a Markov decision process and train a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy for selecting the most informative documents. Experimental results on the TREC datasets demonstrate that DeepRF significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based semantic embeddings to better capture query intent. Our method, dubbed 'EmbedExpan', uses a convolutional neural network to encode query terms and their context into a dense vector space. We then utilize a clustering-based approach to identify semantically similar terms and expand the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbedExpan significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving an average improvement of 15% in retrieval accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis has become a crucial task in natural language processing, but most existing approaches focus on single-modal inputs (e.g., text or images). This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that fuses multi-modal inputs (text, images, and videos) to analyze sentiment in a more comprehensive manner. Our HAN model employs attention mechanisms at both the feature and modality levels to selectively weigh the importance of different input modalities and features. Experimental results on a large-scale, multi-modal sentiment analysis dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance with significant improvements over single-modal and existing multi-modal baselines.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems often relies on centralized decision-making, which can be vulnerable to single-point failures and limited scalability. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'CoopAllocator', which enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task allocation in a distributed manner. We introduce a novel communication protocol that facilitates exchange of partial observations and intentions among agents, improving overall system efficiency and adaptability. Experimental results on a simulated package delivery domain demonstrate the effectiveness of CoopAllocator in achieving high task completion rates and robustness to agent failures.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using reinforcement learning. We model the task allocation problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) and propose a reinforcement learning algorithm that enables agents to learn effective allocation policies. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to encode agent-agent and agent-task relationships, facilitating scalable and flexible task allocation. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms traditional heuristic-based approaches in various task allocation scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Systems
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational systems has become increasingly important for human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages multi-modal input from speech, text, and facial expressions. Our HAN model consists of two attention layers: a lower-level attention that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and an upper-level attention that integrates the outputs from each modality. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from conversations, achieving an F1-score of 0.83.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex systems, coordinating multiple agents to achieve efficient resource allocation is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to train a decentralized controller for multi-agent systems. Our method, called 'MARL-RA', enables agents to learn optimal resource allocation strategies through interactions with the environment and other agents. Experimental results demonstrate that MARL-RA outperforms traditional methods in terms of resource utilization and system efficiency, while also adapting to dynamic changes in the environment.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in various domains, such as robotics, traffic management, and smart grids. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning with graph attention to learn effective coordination strategies. Our method, called Graph Attention Multi-Agent Q-Network (GAMAQN), utilizes a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a deep Q-network to learn optimal actions. Experimental results on a traffic signal control problem demonstrate that GAMAQN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of coordination efficiency and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Explainable Graph Neural Networks for Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media platforms has severe consequences for individuals and society. This paper presents a novel explainable graph neural network (GNN) framework, 'FakeGNN', for detecting fake news articles. FakeGNN incorporates node-level attention mechanisms to identify crucial entities and relationships in the news article graph, and a graph-based explanation module to provide interpretable insights into the detection process. Experimental results on a large-scale fake news dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of FakeGNN in detecting fake news articles with high accuracy and providing transparent explanations.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents with Emotional Intelligence for Healthcare
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for designing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) with emotional intelligence in healthcare settings. We propose a multimodal affect recognition system that integrates facial expression analysis, speech recognition, and physiological signal processing to enable ECAs to recognize and respond to users' emotions. Our user study shows that the ECA's empathetic responses significantly reduce users' stress levels and improve their overall experience in a simulated healthcare scenario. We discuss the implications of our findings for the development of emotionally intelligent ECAs in healthcare and highlight future research directions.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Recognition for Adaptive Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but their effectiveness relies on accurately recognizing user intentions. This paper introduces 'GazeIntend', a novel HCI framework that leverages gaze tracking to infer user goals in virtual environments. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks with probabilistic graphical models to recognize gaze patterns and contextualize them within a task-based ontology. We evaluate GazeIntend on a dataset of 30 participants interacting with a virtual smart home interface, demonstrating a 25% reduction in misrecognized intentions compared to state-of-the-art speech-based approaches.

title: Deceptive Behavior Detection in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) are increasingly used in various applications, including autonomous vehicles, smart grids, and e-commerce platforms. However, the presence of deceptive agents can lead to catastrophic consequences. This paper proposes a novel approach for detecting deceptive behavior in MAS using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). We design a GCN-based model that learns to identify patterns of deception in agent interactions, leveraging both structural and behavioral features of the agent graph. Experimental results on a synthetic MAS dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting deceptive agents, outperforming traditional machine learning methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). Our approach represents the agent-task graph as a dynamic network, where agents and tasks are nodes, and edges denote potential assignments. We design a GCN-based model that learns to predict task assignment probabilities, taking into account agent capabilities, task requirements, and network constraints. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) requires models to perform complex reasoning over multiple sentences. While existing approaches achieve high accuracy, they often struggle to provide interpretable explanations for their predictions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates both word-level and sentence-level attention mechanisms to generate explainable MHQA models. We demonstrate that our HAN-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art models on several MHQA benchmarks while providing transparent and coherent explanations for its answers.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Human-Computer Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) within Virtual Reality (VR) environments. We conducted a user study to investigate how bodily sensations and motor experiences influence user behavior and performance in VR. Our results show that incorporating embodied cognition principles in VR interface design can significantly enhance user engagement, spatial awareness, and task completion times. We propose a novel framework for designing embodied VR interfaces and discuss the implications for future HCI research in VR.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have become increasingly popular, offering scalable and on-demand database resources to multiple tenants. However, query optimization in multi-tenant environments is a challenging problem due to resource contention and varying workload characteristics. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MTQO', which leverages machine learning-based workload classification and predictive modeling to optimize query execution plans. We evaluate MTQO on a real-world DBaaS platform and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and resource utilization compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Task Learning in Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has become increasingly popular in natural language processing (NLP) due to its ability to leverage shared knowledge across related tasks. However, existing MTL approaches often suffer from task interference and lack of interpretability. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that addresses these limitations. Our HAN model uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant tasks and taskspecific features, improving overall performance and providing insights into task relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark NLP datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art MTL methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but designing effective user interfaces remains a challenge. This paper explores the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, using a mixed-methods approach to investigate the impact of customized avatars on user engagement, presence, and overall satisfaction. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly improve user experience, particularly for users with high self-identification with their avatar. We discuss the implications of our findings for VR interface design and provide recommendations for future research.

title: Gaze-Based IntentionRecognition in Virtual Reality using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but accurate intention recognition remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'GazeIntention', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to recognize user intentions from gaze patterns in VR environments. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that considers both short-term and long-term gaze behaviors to infer user intentions. Our experiments on a large-scale VR dataset demonstrate that GazeIntention outperforms state-of-the-art intention recognition methods by 15% in terms of accuracy and 20% in terms of latency.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on manual rules or shallow linguistic features, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE', which leverages deep contextualized embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our experiments on the TREC-8 Ad-Hoc dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and recall over state-of-the-art baselines. Furthermore, we show that NQE is robust to query drift and outperforms traditional methods in cold-start scenarios.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases face significant challenges in optimizing complex queries. Traditional optimization methods rely on hand-tuned heuristics or exhaustive search, leading to suboptimal performance and high latency. This paper presents a novel approach, 'RL-Opt', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for distributed databases. We design a Markov decision process to model the query optimization problem and train an agent using deep Q-learning to select efficient query plans. Experimental results on a realistic workload demonstrate that RL-Opt outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Adaptive Agent Communication Strategies for Efficient Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, the complexity of agent communication strategies can significantly impact system performance. This paper proposes an adaptive communication framework that dynamically adjusts the level of information exchange between agents based on task requirements and environmental uncertainty. We develop a novel probabilistic model to quantify the value of information exchange and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing communication overhead while maintaining task allocation efficiency. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms existing strategies in various scenarios, including resource-constrained and dynamic environments.

title: Multimodal Fusion for Enhanced Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition is a crucial aspect of immersive virtual reality (VR) experiences. However, existing recognition systems often rely on a single modality, such as computer vision or inertial measurement units (IMUs), which can be prone to errors. This paper proposes a novel multimodal fusion framework that combines vision, IMU, and electromyography (EMG) data to recognize gestures in VR. Our approach leverages a deep neural network to fuse the modalities, achieving improved recognition accuracy and robustness to noise and variability. We evaluate our framework on a large-scale dataset of VR gestures, demonstrating significant performance gains over uni-modal approaches.

title: Robustifying Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. In this paper, we propose a novel defense mechanism that leverages contrastive learning to robustify neural networks against such attacks. Our approach, called CoRe, learns a robust representation by contrasting clean and perturbed samples in the latent space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CoRe on various benchmark datasets, showing improved robustness against state-of-the-art attacks. Moreover, we analyze the theoretical implications of our approach and provide insights into the underlying mechanisms.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR)-based learning environments. We designed an VR-based educational platform that incorporates gestures and body movements to enhance learning outcomes. Our user study with 120 participants shows that embodied cognition significantly improves knowledge retention and recall in STEM education compared to traditional desktop-based learning. We also analyzed the impact of individual differences in spatial cognition and motor skills on the effectiveness of embodied cognition in VR-based learning.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to improve the robustness of GNNs by incorporating hierarchical attention mechanisms. Our method, 'HierAttn', adaptively focuses on relevant subgraphs and node features to mitigate the effects of adversarial perturbations. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierAttn significantly enhances the robustness of GNNs against targeted attacks while maintaining their performance on clean data.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Adaptive Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings (KGEs) are crucial for various AI applications, but their performance often hinges on the quality of relation representations. This paper proposes 'ARA-KGE', a novel KGE method that incorporates adaptive relation attention to selectively emphasize relevant relations during training. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to learn attention weights that adapt to the entity-relation graph structure and task requirements. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that ARA-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods in link prediction and question answering tasks, while reducing training time by up to 30%

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a critical component of modern business intelligence, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColumnStar', which leverages column-store indexing to accelerate query processing. By adaptively selecting the most effective indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distributions, ColumnStar reduces query latency by up to 75% compared to traditional row-store indexing. We evaluate ColumnStar on a real-world dataset of 100 million records and demonstrate its efficacy in supporting real-time analytics workloads.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification in graphs is a challenging task, especially when dealing with limited labeled data. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages both node and graph-level attention mechanisms to adapt to new classes. HGAT employs a hierarchical clustering strategy to group similar nodes, enabling effective knowledge transfer from base to novel classes. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification, particularly when faced with scarce labeled data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of graph data and the distributed nature of the databases. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We formulate the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and train an agent to learn the optimal query plan for a given query. Our experimental results on a real-world graph dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various industries, but its adoption is hindered by user experience (UX) issues. This paper investigates the effects of personalization on UX in VR. We designed and implemented a VR system that adapts to users' preferences, abilities, and cognitive styles. A user study with 30 participants revealed significant improvements in user satisfaction, engagement, and task performance when personalized elements were introduced. Our results suggest that personalization can mitigate cybersickness, increase user confidence, and enhance overall UX in VR environments.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Neural Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for open-domain question answering. However, the computational complexity of neural retrieval hinders its scalability to large datasets. We propose a novel indexing scheme, 'NeurIX', which leverages the properties of dense embeddings to efficiently prune the search space. By combining a hierarchical navigable small world graph with a compact binary representation of passages, NeurIX achieves a 5x speedup in retrieval time while maintaining the same retrieval quality as exhaustive search. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of NeurIX in large-scale DPR systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval tasks often suffer from vocabulary mismatch between the query and relevant documents. This paper introduces a novel query expansion approach, Graph Semantic Expansion (GSE), which leverages graph-based semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. GSE represents the query and document terms as nodes in a graph, and computes semantic similarities using a variant of Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs). Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GSE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall. We further analyze the impact of graph structures and node features on the effectiveness of GSE.

title: Hybrid Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and facial expressions, is a challenging task due to the heterogeneity and complexity of modalities. This paper proposes a novel hybrid attentional graph neural network (HAGNN) that integrates graph attention and multi-head self-attention mechanisms to effectively capture inter-modal relationships and intra-modal patterns. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, achieving an average F1-score of 0.83 across six emotions.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Session-based Query Auto-Completion
paper_abstract: Query auto-completion (QAC) is a crucial component of modern search engines, aiming to predict the user's intended query based on the partial input. This paper introduces a novel neural ranking model, 'SessionRank', which exploits the session context to improve QAC performance. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture the semantic relationships between the query prefix, session history, and candidate completions. Experimental results on the AOL query log dataset demonstrate that SessionRank outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean reciprocal rank and coverage rate, with significant improvements in computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Neural Document Ranking with Query-Aware Attention for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model for ad-hoc retrieval, called HierAttRank. Our approach leverages a hierarchical document representation, combining local and global contextualized embeddings. A key innovation is the incorporation of query-aware attention, which selectively focuses on relevant document segments based on the query's semantic content. Experimental results on several benchmark collections demonstrate that HierAttRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, particularly in scenarios with long documents and complex queries. We also provide empirical insights into the benefits of hierarchical representations and query-aware attention for ad-hoc retrieval tasks.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their ability to provide transparency into the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that leverages item relationships and user preferences to generate personalized recommendations. Our model incorporates a attention-based graph neural network to learn item embeddings, which are then fed into a hierarchical graph attention mechanism to capture complex user-item interactions. Experimental results on four benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks via Bayesian Neural Architecture Search
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which pose significant security risks in various applications. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural architecture search (BNAS) framework to improve the adversarial robustness of DNNs. Our approach involves searching for robust architectures using a probabilistic formulation of the adversarial attack problem. We demonstrate that the resulting architectures exhibit improved robustness against state-of-the-art attacks while maintaining competitive performance on clean data. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that our method outperforms existing adversarial training methods in terms of both robustness and accuracy.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, understanding the role of embodiment in human-robot collaboration is crucial. This paper presents a virtual reality (VR) study exploring the effects of robotic embodiment on human trust, communication, and task performance in a collaborative assembly task.
