Results show that participants who interacted with an embodied robot (i.e., a robot with a physical presence in VR) exhibited higher levels of trust and communicated more effectively compared to those interacting with a non-embodied robot. Furthermore, embodied robots improved task performance by facilitating more efficient coordination and reducing errors. Our findings have implications for the design of future human-robot collaborative systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, aiming to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. Existing methods rely on heuristics or manual feature engineering, often resulting in suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'DeepQE', which learns to optimize query expansion policies through trial and error. We design a reward function that balances retrieval accuracy and efficiency, and incorporate a hierarchical attention mechanism to adaptively select relevant expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and retrieval time.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph-based Neural Networks for Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Time series data is increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can have devastating consequences in applications such as finance and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural network (GNN) architecture, 'TS-Guard', for detecting adversarial attacks in time series data. TS-Guard leverages the graph structure of time series data to identify anomalous patterns and uses a combination of spatial and temporal attention mechanisms to improve detection accuracy. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TS-Guard outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detecting both targeted and untargeted attacks.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for older adults with cognitive impairments remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an accessible conversational interface tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of interviews and usability studies to identify key design requirements, including simplified language, visual cues, and error tolerance. Our proposed interface, 'CARE', incorporates these features and was evaluated in a pilot study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rate and user satisfaction.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Multi-Armed Bandit Algorithms
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used to manage large-scale data-intensive applications. However, optimizing query performance in these systems is a challenging task due to the complexity of the underlying infrastructure and the variability of the workload. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages multi-armed bandit algorithms to adaptively select the optimal query plan based on the runtime performance of the system. Our approach uses online learning to balance exploration and exploitation, and we demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing query latency and improving system throughput using a real-world dataset.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of task-oriented dialogue systems. However, existing DST models often struggle to handle complex, multi-turn dialogues and lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages both word-level and turn-level attention to capture contextual dependencies in dialogue. We also introduce an explainability module that generates visualizations of attention weights, enabling users to understand the model's decision-making process. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art DST models while providing insightful explanations.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents that contain the answer. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Dense Retrieval (HDR) approach, which leverages a two-stage retrieval process to prune the search space and reduce computational costs. Our method exploits the hierarchical structure of documents and represents passages as dense vectors, enabling fast similarity search and accurate retrieval. Experimental results on several ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that HDR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods, achieving a 25% increase in recall while reducing computational costs by 40%.

title: Evaluating Embodiment and Agency in Virtual Reality Avatars for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) avatars have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but their design and implementation can significantly impact user experience. This paper presents an empirical study investigating the effects of embodiment and agency on user engagement and presence in VR environments. We develop a novel framework for evaluating avatar design, incorporating metrics for anthropomorphism, autonomy, and feedback. Our results show that avatars with higher embodiment and agency lead to increased user satisfaction and immersion, while also influencing user behavior and decision-making. The findings have implications for the design of VR systems in various domains, including gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for People with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces are increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of people with dyslexia. This paper presents a human-centered approach to creating accessible conversational interfaces for individuals with dyslexia. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving user interviews, cognitive walkthroughs, and usability testing to identify key design challenges and opportunities. Our findings inform the development of a set of design guidelines and a proof-of-concept interface that incorporates dyslexia-friendly features, such as text-to-speech, font customization, and error forgiveness. Our evaluation demonstrates significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for participants with dyslexia.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a challenging problem due to the exponential growth in action spaces and the need for effective communication among agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) to tackle these challenges. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn cooperative relationships between agents and hierarchical representations to reduce the action space complexity. We evaluate HGAT on several MARL benchmarks, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and sample efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Drone Navigation in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous drones operating in uncertain environments require efficient and adaptive navigation strategies. We propose a novel reinforcement learning framework that leverages a hierarchical policy architecture to balance exploration and exploitation. Our approach, 'Uncertainty-Aware Drone Navigation' (UADN), incorporates a probabilistic uncertainty model to estimate the confidence of sensor readings, enabling the drone to adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that UADN outperforms existing methods in terms of navigation efficiency and reliability in simulations and real-world experiments.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data in Main-Memory Column-Stores
paper_abstract: Main-memory column-stores have become increasingly popular for analytical workloads due to their performance benefits. However, indexing high-dimensional data in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'HDIX', which leverages a combination of bit-vector compression and clustering-based indexing to efficiently store and query high-dimensional data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HDIX through an extensive evaluation on real-world benchmarks, showing significant improvements in query performance and storage efficiency compared to existing indexing techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the impact of speech recognition accuracy and cognitive load on the user experience of older adults interacting with voice assistants. Our user study with 30 participants aged 65-85 reveals that older adults face significant difficulties with current voice assistants, attributed to speech recognition errors and high cognitive load. We propose a novel design framework, 'EASE', which incorporates age-related considerations, such as slower speech rates and augmented feedback. Our results show that EASE significantly improves user satisfaction, task completion rates, and reduces cognitive load for older adults.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-based Indexing for Large-Scale Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches struggle with scalability as datasets grow in size. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing technique, 'GraphED', which leverages the structural properties of knowledge graphs to efficiently disambiguate entities. By constructing a hierarchical graph index, GraphED reduces the search space for candidate entities, resulting in significant speedups and improved accuracy. Experimental results on large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average precision of 95.2% while reducing query times by up to 75%.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to retrieve relevant answers from a large corpus of documents in response to user queries. This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, 'ConvRank', which leverages pre-trained language models to capture the nuances of conversational queries. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant passages in the document, and a contrastive training objective that encourages the model to differentiate between relevant and irrelevant documents. Experimental results on a popular conversational search benchmark demonstrate that ConvRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems are crucial in modern e-commerce, but scaling them to massive user-item graphs remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively aggregate node features across multiple graph scales. HGAT is designed to capture complex item relationships, model user preferences, and adapt to dynamic graph structures. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art graph-based recommenders in terms of precision, recall, and computational efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance through Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems continue to grow in scale and complexity, query performance becomes a critical bottleneck. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing technique, 'AIx', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distributions. AIx leverages machine learning-based prediction models to forecast query workloads and optimize index creation, resulting in significant improvements to query response times. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system demonstrates that AIx outperforms traditional static indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significance in recent years, but existing methods often struggle with the complexity of integrating multimodal features. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that effectively captures both intra-modal and inter-modal relationships. Our HAN model employs a multimodal fusion module that adaptively weighs the importance of different modalities, followed by a sentiment analysis module that leverages hierarchical attention to focus on sentiment-bearing regions. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced Learning Outcomes
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition theory in virtual reality (VR) to enhance learning outcomes in educational settings. We designed a gesture-based interaction system that leverages the cognitive benefits of bodily engagement to improve knowledge retention and recall. Our user study with 120 participants revealed significant improvements in learning outcomes for users who employed gestures to manipulate virtual objects, compared to those using traditional keyboard-and-mouse interfaces. We also found that embodied interaction increased user engagement and motivation, leading to a more immersive and effective learning experience.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing VR interfaces can be inaccessible and overwhelming. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating accessible VR interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of usability studies and expert evaluations to identify key design principles, including simplified navigation, high-contrast visuals, and audio cues. We then developed and evaluated a prototype VR system incorporating these principles, demonstrating improved user performance and satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: Explainability is a pressing concern in multi-agent systems, where the complexity of interactions between agents hinders the understanding of decision-making processes. We propose a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that learns to represent agent interactions as a hierarchical graph, capturing both local and global relationships. Our approach enables the identification of influential agents and the visualization of decision-making pathways. Experimental results on a real-world traffic management scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAN in improving explainability and decision quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Pruning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly compromise their performance. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural pruning approach, 'BayesPrune', to robustify deep neural networks against such attacks. BayesPrune iteratively prunes the network based on Bayesian uncertainty estimates, removing redundant or vulnerable neurons. We demonstrate that BayesPrune achieves state-of-the-art robustness against various attack types, including PGD and CW attacks, while maintaining accuracy on clean data. Our approach can be integrated with existing defense mechanisms, providing a scalable solution for real-world applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but optimizing query execution remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and use a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for query execution. Our approach is able to adapt to changing workload and system conditions, and experimental results show significant improvements in query response time and system throughput compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Autonomous Agents with Uncertain Preferences
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of decentralized coalition formation among autonomous agents with uncertain preferences. We propose a novel framework that integrates Bayesian learning and distributed constraint optimization to enable agents to form coalitions in a decentralized and adaptive manner. Our approach allows agents to update their beliefs about others' preferences and adjust their coalition formation strategies accordingly. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of coalition stability and efficiency, and is scalable to large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Assistants: An Empirical Study on Multimodal Interaction for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have become ubiquitous, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the design of inclusive multimodal interfaces for VAs, focusing on voice, gesture, and text inputs. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, exploring their preferences, challenges, and behaviors when interacting with VAs. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptive feedback, personalized assistance, and multimodal redundancy to facilitate accessibility and trust. We propose a set of design guidelines for VA developers to create more inclusive and supportive interfaces for older adults.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with digital information, but current VR systems often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that are accessible to users with visual impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key challenges and opportunities for accessibility in VR, and developed a set of design guidelines and tools to support the creation of inclusive VR applications. Our evaluation results show that our approach can significantly improve the usability and enjoyment of VR experiences for users with visual impairments.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, distributed database systems face significant scalability challenges. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GraDix', which leverages the structural properties of data graphs to optimize query performance. By representing data relationships as a graph, GraDix enables efficient query routing, reduces data redundancy, and improves data locality. Experiments on a large-scale social network dataset demonstrate that GraDix outperforms traditional indexing methods by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In heterogeneous multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper proposes a decentralized auction-based mechanism, 'HetAuction', which allocates tasks to agents based on their capabilities, availability, and preferences. HetAuction uses a novel combination of combinatorial auctions and Vickrey-Clarke-Groves mechanisms to ensure truthful bidding and optimal task allocation. Experimental results on a realistic disaster response scenario demonstrate that HetAuction outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time, agent utility, and system scalability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval in Social Media
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval in social media poses unique challenges due to the brevity and noisiness of user-generated content. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'SocialTE', which leverages both local and global context to enrich the query representation. Our approach incorporates a graph-based method to model entity relationships and a neural ranking model to re-weight query terms. Experimental results on a large-scale Twitter dataset demonstrate that SocialTE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts system performance and scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, dubbed 'AdaptQL'. We model query optimization as a Markov decision process and train a deep Q-network to adaptively select the optimal query plan based on runtime statistics and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that AdaptQL outperforms traditional query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization, while also exhibiting improved robustness to workload fluctuations.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective objectives. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate task allocation among agents. Our method, called MARL-TA, uses a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn policies for each agent that maximize system-level rewards. We introduce a new attention-based mechanism that enables agents to selectively communicate and adapt to changing task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'MADRA', which leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. MADRA uses a decentralized, asynchronous learning approach, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on partial observations of the environment. Our experiments demonstrate that MADRA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency, even in dynamic and uncertain environments.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification in large-scale graphs is a fundamental problem in many domains. While Graph Attention Networks (GATs) have shown promising results, they suffer from scalability issues due to the quadratic complexity of attention mechanisms. This paper proposes Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGATs), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical graph representations to reduce the attention complexity. We develop a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group nodes into clusters, and apply GATs within each cluster. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGATs achieve state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 70%

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in autonomous vehicles to ensure safety and trustworthiness. This paper introduces HAREL, a hierarchical attention-based framework that integrates reinforcement learning with model-based explainability. HAREL incorporates a novel attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant sensory inputs, enabling the agent to learn interpretable policies. We evaluate HAREL on a realistic autonomous driving simulation and demonstrate improved explainability, safety, and performance compared to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Hearing Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their utility is limited for older adults with hearing impairments. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'ClearVoice', a novel voice assistant system tailored to the needs of this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants to understand their challenges and preferences. ClearVoice incorporates acoustic models trained on hearing-impaired speech, visual feedback mechanisms, and personalized audio enhancement. Our results show that ClearVoice significantly improves speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants, demonstrating the potential for inclusive design to bridge the accessibility gap.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous navigation in dynamic environments remains a challenging problem in AI research. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-NAV', which learns to navigate complex scenarios by decomposing the task into hierarchical sub-goals. We introduce a new curiosity-driven exploration strategy that adaptively adjusts the exploration-exploitation trade-off based on the environment's dynamics. Our experiments demonstrate that HRL-NAV outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various scenarios, including pedestrian-rich urban environments and warehouses with moving obstacles.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems, particularly in Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks like sentiment analysis. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates explainable AI techniques to identify influential words and phrases in sentiment-bearing texts. Our approach leverages a multi-level attention mechanism to capture both local and global contextual information, enabling the model to provide transparent and interpretable sentiment predictions. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using auction-based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, which leverages auction-based mechanisms to efficiently assign tasks to agents. We introduce a novel auction protocol, called 'ATAM', that takes into account agent capabilities, task requirements, and communication constraints. ATAM is shown to outperform traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of completion time and resource utilization. We evaluate our approach through extensive simulations on a variety of scenarios, demonstrating its scalability and adaptability in dynamic environments.

title: EyeGazePing: A Novel Gaze-Based Ping System for Improving Online Meeting Engagement
paper_abstract: Online meetings have become an essential part of remote work, but they often suffer from low engagement and participation. This paper presents EyeGazePing, a novel system that utilizes eye gaze tracking to detect and respond to users' attention and interest in real-time. Our system uses a machine learning model to analyze participants' eye movements and generate personalized 'pings' to encourage more active participation. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and found that EyeGazePing increased meeting engagement by 35% and reduced distractions by 27%. Our results demonstrate the potential of gaze-based interfaces to enhance online meeting experiences.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent cooperative reinforcement learning has garnered significant attention in recent years, particularly in applications such as autonomous vehicles and swarm robotics. However, existing methods often struggle to scale to large numbers of agents and complex environment dynamics. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture, which models agent interactions at multiple scales and incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on critical relationships. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in various cooperative tasks, including predator-prey pursuit and resource allocation, and show improved performance and sample efficiency compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promise in information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with vocabulary mismatch between the query and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion strategy that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to improve the retrieval performance of neural models. We introduce a neural pseudo-relevance feedback generator that predicts relevant terms based on the query and top-retrieved documents, and demonstrate its effectiveness in expanding the query representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that our approach significantly outperforms existing query expansion methods, achieving state-of-the-art retrieval performance on several tasks.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults Using Machine Learning-based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing accessible gestural interfaces for older adults using machine learning-based gesture recognition. We propose a framework that employs a combination of computer vision and machine learning techniques to recognize and classify gestures performed by older adults. Our approach incorporates a user-centered design methodology, involving co-design sessions with older adults to identify and prioritize gestural interactions that are intuitive and easy to perform. We evaluate our approach using a prototype system and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving the accessibility and usability of gestural interfaces for older adults.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in modern data management. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query optimization, which models the distributed database system as a graph and leverages graph algorithms to identify optimal query plans. Our experimental results show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time and reduces communication overhead by up to 25%. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the optimality of our approach.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have gained popularity for their scalability and convenience. However, optimizing query performance in multi-tenant environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'QTune', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and query rewriting techniques to minimize response times and resource utilization. We propose a multi-objective optimization approach that balances query performance, fairness, and resource allocation across tenants. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that QTune outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query latency and 2.2x in terms of resource efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Phrase-based Indexing
paper_abstract: Traditional keyword-based indexing methods for document retrieval often fail to capture the semantic relationships between phrases, leading to suboptimal query performance. We propose a novel hierarchical phrase-based indexing approach, dubbed 'PhraseTree', which leverages phrase embeddings to construct a tree-like index structure. PhraseTree enables efficient retrieval of documents by exploiting phrase co-occurrence patterns and reducing the dimensionality of the query space. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that PhraseTree outperforms state-of-the-art keyword-based indexing methods in terms of both query latency and retrieval accuracy.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Neural Ranking Models for Effective Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it helps to bridge the lexical gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion, leveraging deep neural ranking models to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'NeuralExp', integrates a pre-trained language model with a ranking-based neural network to generate context-aware expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuralExp outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, yielding significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and robustness.

title: Delta-Based Incremental View Maintenance for Distributed Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Distributed data warehouses (DDWs) have become essential for big data analytics. However, incremental view maintenance (IVM) in DDWs remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel delta-based IVM approach, DeltaIVM, which leverages the concept of deltas to efficiently maintain materialized views in a distributed setting. DeltaIVM utilizes a hierarchical architecture to process deltas in parallel, reducing the communication overhead and improving the maintenance performance. We conduct extensive experiments on a real-world dataset, demonstrating that DeltaIVM outperforms existing IVM approaches in terms of maintenance time and data freshness.

title: Efficient Multi-Objective Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time control decisions that balance competing objectives, such as safety, efficiency, and passenger comfort. This paper presents a novel multi-objective reinforcement learning framework, 'MORL-AV', which leverages a deep Q-network to learn a Pareto-optimal policy for autonomous vehicle control. MORL-AV incorporates a customized reward function that aggregating multiple objectives and utilizes a hierarchical exploration strategy to efficiently search the action space. Experimental results demonstrate that MORL-AV outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various simulated driving scenarios, achieving improved overall performance and reduced computational overhead.

title: Personalized Document Ranking using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval models often rely on simplistic term-frequency representations, neglecting the rich semantic relationships between documents. This paper presents a novel approach to personalized document ranking using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT). HGAT leverages document graphs to model complex relationships between entities, and incorporates user preferences through attention-based neural networks. Our experiments on a large-scale web search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art models, particularly for long-tail queries. We also show that HGAT can effectively generalize to new users and documents, making it a promising solution for large-scale IR systems.

title: Efficient Indexing of RDF Graphs for Scalable Query Processing
paper_abstract: The growing popularity of RDF data has led to an increasing need for efficient query processing mechanisms. This paper addresses the problem of indexing large RDF graphs to support scalable query execution. We propose a novel indexing approach, 'RDF-Index', which leverages a combination of graph partitioning and compression techniques to reduce storage overhead. Our experiments on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that RDF-Index outperforms existing indexing methods in terms of query response time and memory usage, making it a viable solution for large-scale RDF data processing.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various applications, but most existing methods lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAT) that detects anomalies while providing explainable insights into the decision-making process. HAT leverages a hierarchical structure to model complex temporal dependencies and attention mechanisms to identify relevant features. We evaluate HAT on three benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superior detection performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach to coordinated exploration in multi-agent systems, leveraging deep graph reinforcement learning. We propose a Graph Attention Network (GAT) based architecture that learns to represent agents' observations and actions as nodes in a graph, enabling the agents to share knowledge and coordinate their exploration strategies. Our approach is evaluated in a suite of multi-agent environments, demonstrating improved exploration efficiency and task performance compared to traditional single-agent exploration methods. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of our algorithm to an optimal joint policy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has seen significant progress in recent years, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in real-world applications. This paper introduces HAN-MARL, a novel hierarchical attention network that learns to explain the decision-making process of each agent in a multi-agent system. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to identify relevant features and agents, and generates natural language explanations for the learned policies. Experimental results on a series of benchmarks demonstrate that HAN-MARL outperforms state-of-the-art MARL algorithms in terms of both performance and explainability.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Age-Related Differences in Voice Command Interpretation
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their effectiveness can be limited by age-related differences in voice command interpretation. This study investigates how older adults (65+ years) interact with voice assistants compared to younger adults (18-30 years). We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 100 participants, analyzing voice command data and conducting semi-structured interviews. Our results show that older adults experience higher error rates and frustration due to differences in linguistic patterns, cognitive abilities, and technology familiarity. We propose a set of design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants, including adaptive language models, multimodal feedback, and personalized training protocols.

title: Real-time Human Emotion Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Speech and Facial Features
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to real-time human emotion recognition using multimodal fusion of speech and facial features. We propose a deep neural network architecture that integrates acoustic features extracted from speech signals with facial action units detected from video frames. Our model leverages attention mechanisms to selectively weigh the importance of each modality based on the emotional intensity of the input. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal emotion dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal methods, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% in recognizing six basic emotions.

title: EyeGazeTracker: A Machine Learning Approach for Real-time Eye Tracking in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Accurate eye tracking is crucial for various applications in virtual reality (VR), including foveated rendering, gaze-based interaction, and user experience analysis. This paper presents EyeGazeTracker, a machine learning-based approach for real-time eye tracking in VR. Our system utilizes a deep neural network to predict gaze directions from eye images captured using a VR headset-mounted camera. We propose a novel data augmentation technique to increase the diversity of the training dataset, achieving a significant improvement in gaze estimation accuracy. Evaluations on a public VR eye tracking dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of EyeGazeTracker in terms of accuracy, latency, and robustness to varying lighting conditions.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Reinforcement Learning using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various applications, but hyperparameter tuning remains a major bottleneck. This paper presents a novel Bayesian optimization framework, 'DRLOPT', which leverages probabilistic modeling to efficiently search the vast hyperparameter space of DRL algorithms. By incorporating prior knowledge from domain experts and exploiting the structure of DRL problems, DRLOPT significantly reduces the number of required evaluations and improves the quality of the obtained hyperparameters. Experimental results on several Atari games demonstrate the effectiveness of DRLOPT in finding better hyperparameters than traditional methods, leading to improved policy performance and faster convergence.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) over knowledge graphs (KGs) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing KG embedding methods suffer from scalability issues and neglect the hierarchical structure of KGs. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based KG embedding model, HAKE, which captures entity relationships at multiple levels of abstraction. HAKE outperforms state-of-the-art models on several benchmark QA datasets, achieving a 12.5% relative improvement in accuracy. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of HAKE in modeling complex KG structures and its potential applications in QA, recommendation systems, and natural language processing.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, but traditional methods often rely on handcrafted rules and fail to capture complex semantic relationships. This paper explores the application of deep neural networks to query expansion, proposing a novel architecture that jointly learns to identify relevant expansion terms and predict their weights. Our approach, dubbed 'DeepQE', leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent layers to model the context-aware representation of queries and documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that DeepQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12% increase in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) as it enables understanding of complex decision-making processes. This paper presents Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical reinforcement learning. HGAT learns to represent agents' interactions as hierarchical graphs, allowing it to focus on relevant agents and their relationships. We demonstrate HGAT's ability to provide interpretable explanations for MARL policies in complex scenarios, while achieving superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results on the SMAC benchmark show that HGAT improves the transparency and accountability of MARL systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroXPand', which leverages neural semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and documents. By integrating a pre-trained language model with a graph-based ranking algorithm, NeuroXPand generates more informative and diverse expansion terms, leading to significant improvements in ad-hoc retrieval performance. Experiments on several TREC benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of NeuroXPand, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve a common goal is a fundamental problem in artificial intelligence. While recent advances in deep reinforcement learning have shown promise, these methods often lack interpretability and transparency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that facilitates explainable multi-agent cooperation. By incorporating attention mechanisms at both the local and global levels, HAN enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information and communicate effectively with each other. We evaluate HAN on a range of cooperative tasks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Deep Variational Graph Autoencoders for Anomaly Detection in Attributed Networks
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in attributed networks is a crucial task with applications in cybersecurity, finance, and social media analysis. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework, 'VG-AE', which leverages the power of graph autoencoders and variational inference to identify anomalies in attributed networks. VG-AE models the underlying graph structure and attribute distributions jointly, enabling it to capture complex patterns and relationships between nodes. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of VG-AE in detecting anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin.

title: Efficient Document Representation for Scalable Query Expansion in Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of modern search engines, as it enhances the relevance of search results. However, the high dimensionality of document representations hinders the scalability of query expansion techniques. This paper proposes a novel document representation framework, 'DRIFT', which combines word embeddings with a novel dimensionality reduction technique. DRIFT enables efficient query expansion while preserving the semantic meaning of documents. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate that DRIFT outperforms existing methods in terms of both precision and query processing time.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents when the query lacks context or contains ambiguous terms. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach that leverages both local and global context to improve retrieval effectiveness. Our method, 'QDE', first identifies the most informative terms in the query and then expands the document representation by incorporating related concepts from a knowledge graph. We evaluate QDE on several standard ad-hoc search datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Detection using Deep Learning for Human-Robot Collaboration
paper_abstract: In human-robot collaboration, accurately detecting user intentions is crucial for efficient and safe task execution. We propose a novel gaze-based intention detection framework that leverages deep learning techniques to analyze user gaze patterns. Our approach uses a multimodal fusion of gaze, head pose, and scene context to infer user intentions. We evaluate our method on a dataset of human-robot collaborative tasks and demonstrate significant improvements in intention detection accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our framework has potential applications in various domains, including manufacturing, healthcare, and assistive robotics.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: We present a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, which leverages distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to efficiently assign tasks to agents in a multi-agent system. Our approach, dubbed 'AgentDCOP', enables agents to negotiate and coordinate with each other to find a globally optimal task allocation, while respecting individual agent capabilities and constraints. Experimental results on a simulated urban search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that AgentDCOP outperforms existing centralized and decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization. The proposed framework is scalable, flexible, and suitable for real-world applications involving autonomous agents.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often struggle with heterogeneous information networks (HINs). This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'NQE-HIN', which leverages graph neural networks to capture complex relationships between entities in HINs. Our approach generates expanded queries by predicting relevance scores for candidate terms, conditioned on the input query and document context. Experiments on a large-scale HIN dataset demonstrate that NQE-HIN outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision and a 25% reduction in query latency.

title: EmoTract: A Multimodal Affective State Tracking System for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Affective state tracking is crucial in human-computer interaction (HCI) to create empathetic and personalized systems. This paper presents EmoTract, a multimodal system that combines computer vision, speech processing, and machine learning to track users' emotional states in real-time. EmoTract utilizes a novel fusion approach that incorporates facial expression, speech tone, and linguistic features to recognize emotions. We evaluate EmoTract on a large dataset of human-computer interactions, demonstrating a significant improvement in affective state recognition accuracy compared to existing systems. The implications of EmoTract are far-reaching, enabling the development of more empathetic and responsive HCI systems.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Neural Retrieval in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in ad-hoc search tasks, but their computational cost and memory requirements remain significant barriers to deployment. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages the strengths of both neural and traditional retrieval models. Our method first uses a neural reranker to identify relevant top-ranked documents, and then applies a hierarchical clustering algorithm to expand the query using context-aware phrase extraction. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art neural models while reducing computational cost by up to 75%.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed database systems, indexing mechanisms play a crucial role in optimizing query performance. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'DxTree', designed to efficiently handle multi-dimensional range queries in distributed environments. DxTree leverages a hierarchical, distributed indexing structure that adaptively partitions the data space based on query patterns and data distribution. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DxTree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of query latency and throughput, while minimizing communication overhead and ensuring data consistency.

title: Reasoning-based Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a fundamental problem that involves grouping agents to achieve common goals. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often have incomplete information about each other's capabilities, preferences, or intentions. This paper proposes a novel approach to coalition formation that leverages reasoning techniques to address the issue of incomplete information. Our method, called RCF, uses a combination of logic-based reasoning and probabilistic inference to identify potential coalition partners and negotiate their participation. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that RCF outperforms existing methods in terms of coalition stability and task completion rate.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved significant success in various applications, but it remains vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel graph-based anomaly detection approach, 'GADRL', to identify adversarial attacks in DRL agents. GADRL constructs a graph representation of the agent's state-action trajectories and leverages graph neural networks to detect anomalies. We evaluate GADRL on several DRL benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting various types of adversarial attacks, including poisoning and evasion attacks. Our approach outperforms existing detection methods and provides a promising direction for securing DRL systems.

title: EyeTracking-based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Gamified Learning Systems
paper_abstract: Gamified learning systems have shown promise in enhancing user engagement and learning outcomes. However, a key challenge lies in adapting the game difficulty to individual learners' skills and preferences. This paper presents 'EyeLearn', a novel approach that leverages eye-tracking data to infer learners' cognitive states and adjust game difficulty in real-time. Our approach utilizes machine learning models to analyze eye movement patterns and correlate them with learner performance. We evaluate EyeLearn in a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in learning outcomes and user satisfaction compared to traditional difficulty adjustment methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Hop Reasoning
paper_abstract: Multi-hop reasoning is a crucial capability for question answering and knowledge graph completion tasks. However, existing models often rely on opaque neural networks, making it challenging to understand their decision-making process. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that integrates graph attention and hierarchical reasoning to facilitate explainable multi-hop reasoning. HGAT learns to iteratively refine its attention weights, enabling the model to focus on relevant nodes and edges while ignoring irrelevant information. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing interpretable explanations for its predictions.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Individuals with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of individuals with dyslexia. This paper presents a human-centered approach to designing accessible conversational agents that cater to users with dyslexia. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the development of 'DyslexiaChat', a novel conversational agent that incorporates multimodal input, speech-to-text functionality, and personalized learning pathways. A pilot evaluation with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to existing conversational agents.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning with Graph-Based Relational Embeddings
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) enables models to recognize unseen classes without training data. However, existing ZSL methods often rely on hand-crafted attributes or class embeddings, which can be limited and inflexible. This paper proposes a novel graph-based relational embedding (GURE) framework, which learns to encode semantic relationships between classes and attributes in a graph structure. By leveraging graph convolutional networks and a novel relational attention mechanism, GURE achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple ZSL benchmarks, outperforming existing methods by up to 12% in terms of harmonic mean. Furthermore, our approach is more interpretable and adaptable to new classes and attributes.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: The proliferation of big data has led to a surge in distributed database systems, which pose significant challenges for query optimization. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using graph-based methods. We model the database schema as a graph and leverage graph neural networks to learn a robust representation of query patterns. Our proposed algorithm, 'GraphOpt', uses this representation to efficiently prune the search space of possible query plans, reducing optimization time by up to 50%. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphOpt in improving query performance and scalability.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Machine Learning Approach to Predictive Eye Movement
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) head-mounted displays often rely on manual controllers for interaction, which can be cumbersome and detract from immersion. This paper presents a machine learning-based approach to predictive eye movement, enabling gaze-based interaction in VR. We propose a novel deep learning model that integrates eye tracking data with scene semantics to predict user intent. Our approach achieves a significant reduction in interaction latency and improves overall user experience. We evaluate our method using a custom-built VR platform and demonstrate its applicability to various interactive tasks, including object selection and manipulation.

title: Towards Efficient Coalition Formation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coalition formation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to form teams to accomplish complex tasks. However, finding an optimal coalition structure is computationally expensive and often intractable. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn coalition formation policies. Our method, called CoForm, represents the agent interactions as a graph and uses GNNs to learn a latent representation of the coalition structure. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CoForm in various benchmark domains, showing significant improvements in computational efficiency and solution quality compared to traditional methods.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (IR) systems face scalability challenges due to the exponential growth of data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HierIndex', to optimize query processing in distributed IR systems. HierIndex leverages a multi-layered indexing structure to prune irrelevant documents at early stages, reducing the number of nodes involved in query processing. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierIndex through extensive experiments on a large-scale web crawl dataset, achieving up to 40% reduction in query latency and 25% improvement in resource utilization compared to existing indexing techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to adapt to dynamic environments and make decisions without a central controller. This paper proposes a novel approach using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We introduce a hierarchical GNN architecture that captures agent-agent and agent-task relationships, enabling agents to make informed decisions about task assignment. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized algorithms.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a question. Recent advances in graph-based neural networks have shown promising results in ODQA, but are computationally expensive. This paper proposes a hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) that learns to represent passages as graphs and performs efficient retrieval using a pruning mechanism. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art results on the Natural Questions dataset while reducing inference time by 30%. We also provide an analysis of the learned graph structures, which reveals insights into the reasoning process of ODQA models.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Recognition for Assisted Living Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Assisted living technologies have transformed the way we support individuals with disabilities. However, existing systems often rely on explicit user input, which can be cognitively demanding. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based intention recognition system, 'GazeIntend', that leverages deep learning to infer user goals from eye movement patterns. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for feature extraction with recurrent neural networks (RNNs) for intention modeling. We evaluate GazeIntend on a dataset of 20 participants with mixed abilities, achieving an average accuracy of 87.4% in recognizing user intentions. The results demonstrate the potential of gaze-based interfaces for enhancing autonomy and independence in assisted living environments.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience in VR. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR environment using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results show that users with personalized avatars exhibited increased engagement, measured by time spent in the VR environment and self-reported feedback. We also found that personalized avatars led to higher levels of presence and immersion. The implications of this research have significant potential for enhancing user experience in VR-based applications.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Skewed Data Distributions
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for business intelligence and decision-making. However, traditional indexing techniques are often ineffective when dealing with skewed data distributions, leading to poor query performance. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, 'SkewIndex', which adapts to the underlying data distribution and dynamically reorganizes the index structure to minimize query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that SkewIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time while maintaining a comparable storage overhead.

title: Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in document retrieval systems, but it can be computationally expensive and may not generalize well to unseen queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural query expansion approach, 'HNQE', which leverages a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant terms from the document collection. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, while also providing interpretable query representations.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data Storage in Cloud-Based Database Systems
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data is becoming increasingly prevalent in various domains, posing significant challenges to efficient data storage and querying in cloud-based database systems. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'HDI-Tree', which leverages the inherent sparsity of high-dimensional data to reduce storage overhead and improve query performance. Our approach exploits the correlation between attributes to compress index structures and facilitates fast similarity searches using a hierarchical clustering-based approach. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HDI-Tree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of storage efficiency, query throughput, and scalability.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has shown promise in enhancing learning experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR learning environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR educational module using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results show that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, measured through time spent in the environment, interaction frequency, and self-reported enjoyment. We also identify key factors influencing this effect, including avatar similarity and customization options. The findings have implications for the design of VR learning experiences, highlighting the importance of personalized avatars in fostering user engagement.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it helps to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural ranking models to select the most informative expansion terms. We introduce a neural reranking framework that combines lexical, semantic, and contextual features to estimate the relevance of candidate expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the retrieval effectiveness of state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly in cases where the original query is short or ambiguous.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to document ranking for information retrieval using hierarchical neural networks. Our model, HierRank, leverages the strengths of both neural ranking models and traditional retrieval methods. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that combines semantic and syntactic features from multiple levels of document representation, allowing for more accurate and efficient ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models and traditional retrieval methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and computational efficiency.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it can significantly impact the retrieval performance. Traditional query expansion methods rely on hand-crafted features and statistical techniques, which may not capture the nuanced semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'SEMEX', which leverages semantic embeddings to learn dense representations of query terms and documents. Our method integrates a neural query expansion module with a ranking model, allowing for end-to-end training and optimization. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SEMEX outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Diverse Documents using Hierarchical Clustering and Deep Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Information retrieval systems often struggle to return diverse and relevant documents in response to complex queries. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical clustering and deep semantic embeddings to improve the diversity and relevance of retrieved documents. Our method, called HierDiv, first uses a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group similar documents based on their semantic embeddings. Then, it selects a diverse set of documents from each cluster using a maximum marginal relevance criterion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that HierDiv significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of novelty, diversity, and relevance metrics.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Attention-based Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in information retrieval, where the goal is to identify the correct entity referred to by a mention in unstructured text. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings and attention-based neural networks to disambiguate entities. We introduce a graph attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant entities and their relationships in the knowledge graph, improving disambiguation accuracy. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular in modern data management systems. However, their performance is heavily dependent on efficient query optimization. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database and observing the execution times. Our experimental results on a real-world benchmark dataset show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques, achieving up to 3x speedup in execution time. We also provide a detailed analysis of the learned query optimization strategies and their applicability to various database workloads.

title: Cooperative Task Planning for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperative task planning is a challenging problem due to the complexity of interactions between agents. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn cooperative policies. We introduce a decentralized framework, 'CoopPlan', which combines decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (Dec-POMDPs) with deep Q-networks. CoopPlan allows agents to learn to coordinate their actions and achieve common goals in complex, dynamic environments. Experimental results on a set of benchmark scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of CoopPlan in achieving higher task success rates and improved agent coordination compared to traditional planning methods.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time IoT Data Streams using In-Memory Column Stores
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has generated massive amounts of real-time data, posing significant challenges for efficient query processing. This paper presents 'RTIMS', a novel in-memory column store designed specifically for IoT data streams. By leveraging column-wise storage, RTIMS achieves improved query performance and reduced memory footprint. We propose a cost-based query optimization framework that adaptively adjusts query plans based on real-time data arrival rates and query patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that RTIMS outperforms traditional row-store-based approaches by up to 3x in terms of query response time and system throughput.

title: Robustifying Deep Reinforcement Learning with Adversarial Experience Replay
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. This paper proposes a novel approach, AdvExp, which integrates adversarial experience replay into DRL to improve its robustness. We generate adversarial experiences through a minimax game between the agent and an attacker, and then replay them alongside the original experiences to augment the agent's training. Our experiments on Atari games and robotic manipulation tasks demonstrate that AdvExp significantly enhances the agent's robustness to various types of attacks, including white-box, black-box, and zero-shot attacks.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on manual rules or statistical methods, limiting their effectiveness in modern search engines. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE', which leverages deep learning to learn contextualized query representations. NQE incorporates a novel attention mechanism that captures complex relationships between query terms and documents, enabling more accurate and efficient document retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC dataset demonstrate that NQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and query latency.

title: Efficient Dense Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies heavily on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant contexts for answer extraction. This paper presents a novel dense passage retrieval (DPR) approach, 'DPR-Fast', which leverages a dual-encoder architecture and a hierarchical clustering-based indexing scheme to reduce the computational cost of DPR while maintaining its retrieval effectiveness. We demonstrate the superiority of DPR-Fast over existing DPR methods on several ODQA benchmarks, achieving significant speedups and comparable or better retrieval performance.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by limitations in speech recognition, cognitive load, and accessibility. This study explores the design of inclusive voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a multimodal interaction study, involving 30 participants aged 65+, to investigate the effects of visual and tactile cues on interaction accuracy and user experience. Our results show that the proposed design reduces errors by 32% and improves user satisfaction by 25%. We discuss the implications of our findings for the development of accessible voice assistants and provide design recommendations for future systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Few-Shot Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction (FSRE) aims to identify relationships between entities in a given text, using limited supervision. We propose a novel hierarchical attention graph convolutional network (HAGCN) that leverages both entity-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to improve FSRE performance. Our approach utilizes a hierarchical graph structure to model complex relationships between entities and incorporates a meta-learning framework to adapt to new relations with few examples. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGCN in achieving state-of-the-art performance for FSRE tasks.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Query Expansion and Passage Retrieval
