paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, 'NQEPR', which integrates query expansion and passage retrieval to improve document ranking for information retrieval tasks. Our approach leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn query representations and expand them using relevant terms from the document collection. The expanded queries are then used to retrieve and rank passages, enabling more accurate relevance assessment. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset show that NQEPR outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving a 12% increase in NDCG@10.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Individuals with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder resulting from neurological conditions, often face difficulties interacting with voice assistants. This paper presents an inclusive design approach to develop voice assistants that cater to users with dysarthria. We conducted participatory design workshops with individuals with dysarthria, caregivers, and speech therapists to identify accessibility barriers and co-design solutions. Our proposed system incorporates acoustic models adapted to dysarthric speech patterns, error correction mechanisms, and personalized feedback strategies. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework, called 'AuctionMA', which leverages auction-based mechanisms to allocate tasks to agents with varying capabilities and preferences. AuctionMA incorporates a hierarchical clustering approach to group similar tasks and agents, reducing communication overhead and improving allocation efficiency. We evaluate AuctionMA through extensive simulations, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and agent satisfaction compared to existing decentralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search queries often suffer from vocabulary mismatch, leading to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select expansion terms. Our method, 'RL-QE', uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy for adding or removing terms based on their expected impact on retrieval quality. Experimental results on the TREC dataset show that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and NDCG@10.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking for Expert Search
paper_abstract: Expert search systems are critical in various domains, including academia and industry, where retrieving documents authored by specific experts is essential. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HierRank, which leverages the hierarchical structure of expert profiles to improve document retrieval efficiency. Our approach combines a neural document encoder with a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture the relationships between experts, documents, and topics. Experimental results on a large-scale expert search dataset demonstrate that HierRank outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranking for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a critical component of open-domain question answering systems. While neural re-ranking models have improved retrieval accuracy, they can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural re-ranking models to generate effective query expansions. Our method, dubbed 'NeuQE', uses a learned re-ranker to identify the most relevant passages for expansion, and then incorporates these expansions into a sparse retrieval model. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that NeuQE improves retrieval accuracy by 3.5% compared to state-of-the-art sparse retrieval models, while reducing computational overhead by 40%.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the complexity of agent interactions and the need for adaptability in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to allocate tasks in a distributed manner. We design a decentralized Q-network that enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task allocation while considering resource constraints and agent capabilities. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Transfer Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to predict sentiment from heterogeneous data sources, such as text, images, and audio. However, existing approaches often rely on modality-specific models, limiting their generalizability. This paper proposes a hierarchical transfer learning framework, 'HTL-MSA', which leverages pre-trained language and vision models to learn shared representations across modalities. We introduce a novel attention-based fusion mechanism that adaptively weights modality-specific features, enabling effective sentiment prediction in MSA tasks. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HTL-MSA over state-of-the-art methods, with significant improvements in sentiment accuracy and robustness.

title: Designing Accessible Smart Home Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As smart home technology becomes increasingly prevalent, it is essential to ensure that these systems are accessible to older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an accessible smart home interface tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to inform the design of our interface, which incorporates cognitive support features such as simplified language, visual cues, and error prevention mechanisms. Our user study results show that our interface significantly improves task completion rates and reduces user frustration compared to existing smart home interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search has emerged as a promising approach for information retrieval, but its effectiveness relies heavily on the quality of query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'RL-QE', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize the selection of expansion terms. We formulate the expansion process as a Markov decision process and train an RL agent to select terms that maximize the expected retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced Learning
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to improve learning outcomes. We design and evaluate a gesture-based interaction system that leverages users' bodily movements to enhance their understanding of complex concepts. Our study involves 30 participants who learn about spatial reasoning and geometry in a VR environment. Results show that the gesture-based interaction group outperforms the control group in terms of knowledge retention and transfer, highlighting the potential of embodied cognition in VR-based education. We discuss the implications of our findings for the development of more effective and engaging learning experiences.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Disabilities: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a participatory study involving 20 participants with visual, hearing, motor, or cognitive disabilities. We co-designed and evaluated a novel voice assistant prototype that incorporates accessible features such as customizable speech output, tactile feedback, and gesture-based input. Our findings highlight the importance of inclusive design principles and suggest that participatory methods can lead to more usable and empowering voice assistants for users with disabilities.

title: Autonomous Agent Cooperation in Dynamic Task Allocation using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to dynamic task allocation in multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. We introduce a decentralized framework, 'CoopRL', where autonomous agents learn to cooperate and allocate tasks in real-time based on their individual capabilities and environmental changes. Our approach uses a combination of Q-learning and graph-based coalition formation to optimize task allocation and reduce communication overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that CoopRL outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and system adaptability.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing systems often lack accessibility features tailored to their needs. This paper presents 'EasyVoice', a novel voice assistant framework that incorporates cognitive support mechanisms, such as semantic chunking, error correction, and personalized feedback. We conducted a usability study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments and found that EasyVoice significantly improved their ability to complete tasks and reported higher user satisfaction compared to a commercial voice assistant. Our findings highlight the importance of inclusive design in HCI and provide insights for future development of accessible voice assistants.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) are increasingly being deployed in various scenarios, including search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and urban transportation. Effective task allocation is critical to optimizing the performance of AV teams. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'CoopAV', which enables cooperative task allocation among AVs. CoopAV leverages a decentralized policy gradient method to learn communication protocols and task assignments that maximize the team's cumulative reward. Experimental results on a simulated AV fleet demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems with Heterogeneous Workloads
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems (MTDBS) have become increasingly popular in cloud computing environments, where multiple tenants share the same database instance. However, optimizing query performance for heterogeneous workloads remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MT-Opt', which leverages machine learning-based workload classification and dynamic re-optimization. MT-Opt adaptively adjusts query plans based on real-time workload characteristics, reducing average query latency by up to 35% and improving overall system throughput by 25%. Experimental evaluation on a real-world MTDBS setup demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification with Limited Labels
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but it often suffers from limited labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global graph structures to improve node classification performance. HGAT uses a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively focus on informative neighbors and capture long-range dependencies. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods, especially in the low-label regime. We also provide theoretical insights into the effectiveness of HGAT in capturing hierarchical graph structures.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-modal dialogue systems have gained popularity in recent years, but they often rely on shallow, symbolic representations of knowledge. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding framework, 'KG-MMDE', which jointly learns vector representations of entities, relationships, and modalities. We leverage a graph attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant knowledge graph triples into the embedding space, allowing for more informed and context-aware dialogue responses. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dialogue dataset demonstrate significant improvements in response accuracy and fluency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex, black-box models that lack transparency and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable decision-making in cooperative and competitive multi-agent scenarios. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents, features, and interactions, providing insight into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a variety of multi-agent environments demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in improving decision accuracy and transparency, while reducing the need for explicit communication between agents.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Modeling using Electroencephalography and Computer Vision for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Understanding human emotions is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents EmoTract, a multimodal approach that combines electroencephalography (EEG) and computer vision (CV) to model affective states in real-time. We propose a novel fusion framework that leverages the strengths of both modalities to recognize emotional states, achieving a 15% improvement in accuracy compared to uni-modal approaches. EmoTract is evaluated on a dataset of 50 participants, demonstrating its potential for enhancing user experience in various HCI applications, such as affective gaming and virtual reality.

title: Gaze-Based Input for Virtual Reality Interfaces using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces rely on manual input devices, which can be cumbersome and limit the immersive experience. This paper presents a novel gaze-based input method using deep learning-based eye tracking. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect gaze patterns and a recurrent neural network (RNN) to predict user intent. We evaluate our method on a VR gaming platform and show that it achieves high accuracy and low latency, enabling seamless interaction with virtual objects. Our approach has significant implications for enhancing the usability and accessibility of VR systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models in Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in ad-hoc information retrieval, but their performance can be limited by the quality of the initial query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroExp', which leverages the semantic relationships learned by a neural network to generate high-quality expansion terms. We demonstrate that NeuroExp outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as RM3 and Relevance Models, in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that NeuroExp can improve the performance of neural retrieval models by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Multimodal Sensor Data using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in multimodal sensor data, making it challenging to detect anomalies in real-time. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates convolutional and recurrent neural networks to model complex patterns in sensor data. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights features across different modalities and time scales, enabling the detection of subtle anomalies. Experimental results on a large-scale industrial dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting anomalies with high accuracy and low latency, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Enhanced User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but designing effective conversational agents for VR remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes an embodied conversational agent (ECA) framework that leverages nonverbal cues, emotional intelligence, and personalized feedback to enhance user engagement in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating that our ECA approach outperforms traditional chatbots in terms of user satisfaction, emotional arousal, and cognitive load. Our findings have implications for the design of future VR-based systems, including virtual assistants, educational platforms, and social interfaces.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their usability and accessibility for older adults remain a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an accessible voice assistant tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving interviews, surveys, and usability testing to identify the key challenges and preferences of older adults when interacting with voice assistants. Our design incorporates a simplified dialogue flow, enhanced error handling, and personalized feedback mechanisms. A pilot study with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing commercial voice assistants.

title: Designing Adaptive Menus for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive menus for elderly users with cognitive impairments. Our system, called 'EasyMenu', uses machine learning algorithms to adapt menu layouts and item arrangements based on user behavior, cognitive abilities, and task complexity. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and found that EasyMenu reduced menu navigation time by 35% and error rates by 50% compared to traditional menu designs. Our results demonstrate the potential of adaptive menus to improve the accessibility and usability of digital interfaces for elderly users with cognitive impairments.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model complex agent interactions. Our approach, called 'Distributed Task Allocator with GCNs' (DTA-GCN), uses GCNs to learn a representation of the agent communication graph and then allocates tasks based on the learned representation. We evaluate DTA-GCN on a variety of benchmark problems and demonstrate its effectiveness in achieving near-optimal task allocations compared to state-of-the-art centralized methods.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and financial applications has led to an explosion in time-series data, necessitating efficient indexing techniques for real-time querying. This paper presents 'TS-Index', a novel indexing framework designed for main-memory database systems. TS-Index leverages a combination of hierarchical clustering and approximate query processing to achieve sub-millisecond query response times while maintaining low memory overhead. Our experiments on a 10TB synthetic dataset demonstrate that TS-Index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x in terms of query performance, making it an attractive solution for real-time analytics workloads.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but the design of intuitive interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles to gesture-based interaction in VR. We propose a novel framework that leverages machine learning to recognize and interpret user gestures, thereby enhancing the sense of immersion and presence in VR environments. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in user experience and task performance when compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. The results have important implications for the design of next-generation VR systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems are increasingly popular in cloud-based services, but optimizing query performance in such environments remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We design a DRL agent that learns to select optimal query plans based on a reward function that considers both performance and fairness metrics. Our experimental results on a real-world benchmark demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization, while ensuring fairness across tenants.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Cues on User Trust in Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) are increasingly integrated into daily life, yet users' trust in these systems remains a significant concern. This study investigates the effect of anthropomorphic cues, such as facial expressions and body language, on user trust in VAs. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 120 participants, using a custom-built VA platform with varying levels of anthropomorphism. Results show that subtle anthropomorphic cues can significantly enhance user trust and perceived reliability, particularly among users with lower technology proficiency. However, overt anthropomorphism can lead to decreased trust due to perceived artificiality. Implications for VA design and future research directions are discussed.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires agents to coordinate and make decisions with incomplete information. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation algorithm that leverages graph neural networks to learn communication protocols and allocate tasks efficiently. Our approach is robust to incomplete information and adapts to changing agent capabilities and task requirements. We evaluate our algorithm on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized methods.

title: Designing Voice-Assisted Conversational Systems for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This research focuses on designing voice-assisted conversational systems that cater to elderly users with cognitive impairments. We conducted a user study to identify the key challenges and requirements for such systems. Our findings indicate that users with cognitive impairments face difficulties with complex voice commands, memory recall, and understanding system responses. We propose a novel design framework, 'EASE', which incorporates simplicity, consistency, and feedback mechanisms to facilitate user understanding and interaction. A prototype system was developed and evaluated, showing significant improvements in user engagement, task completion rates, and overall satisfaction.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using deep reinforcement learning. We introduce a novel agent architecture that combines a graph neural network with a deep Q-network, enabling agents to learn cooperative policies and allocate tasks in a distributed manner. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain show that our approach outperforms traditional centralized methods and achieves near-optimal performance in dynamic environments with varying task demands and agent availability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Contextual Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval effectiveness. Traditional query expansion methods are limited by their inability to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. We propose a novel approach, 'DeepCE', which leverages deep learning-based contextual embeddings to model query context. DeepCE learns to encode query terms and their dependencies using a graph-based neural network, enabling more effective query expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepCE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving improvements of up to 15% in mean average precision.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for autonomous traffic signal control. We model traffic signals as agents that learn to cooperate and adapt to dynamic traffic conditions to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. Our method, called MARL-TSC, extends the traditional Q-learning algorithm to incorporate graph neural networks for modeling complex traffic networks. Experimental results on a real-world traffic dataset demonstrate that MARL-TSC outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing average travel times by up to 23% and decreasing congestion by 17%

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) enables fast analytics on rapidly changing data, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents AQOR, an adaptive query optimizer that leverages machine learning to predict query performance and select optimal execution plans. AQOR incorporates a novel query embedding technique that captures semantic and syntactic features of queries, allowing it to generalize well to unseen queries. Experimental results on a real-world RTDW system show that AQOR reduces average query latency by 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimizers, while adapting to changing workload and data distributions.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility features for users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel VR interface design framework that incorporates audio and tactile cues to enable visually impaired users to navigate and interact with virtual environments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and evaluated the effectiveness of our approach in terms of task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction. The results show that our framework significantly improves the VR experience for users with visual impairments, paving the way for more inclusive VR applications.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Time-Series Databases
paper_abstract: Time-series databases have become crucial for various applications, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, efficient query processing remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach that combines the benefits of tree-based and hash-based indexing techniques. Our approach, called 'TS-Hybrid', leverages the strengths of each indexing method to optimize query performance for different types of time-series queries. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that TS-Hybrid outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3.5x for range queries and 2.2x for aggregation queries.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQR', for query reformulation. We leverage a transformer-based architecture to model the semantic relationships between query terms and generate a set of reformed queries that better align with the user's information need. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that DeepQR significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Event Extraction
paper_abstract: Event extraction from multi-modal data (e.g., images, text, and videos) is a crucial task in various applications, including surveillance, healthcare, and social media analysis. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages the complementary information from different modalities to improve event extraction performance. Our HGAN model consists of two stages: intra-modal attention and inter-modal attention. The intra-modal attention module learns to focus on relevant regions within each modality, while the inter-modal attention module integrates the features from different modalities to capture cross-modal correlations. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in extracting complex events from multi-modal data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for large-scale data analytics. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages a combination of statistical analysis and machine learning techniques to improve query execution efficiency. We introduce a column-oriented cost model that accurately estimates query execution times and proposes a set of optimization techniques to reduce data transfer and processing costs. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep learning-based sentiment analysis models have achieved state-of-the-art performance on various modalities, including text, images, and videos. However, their lack of transparency and interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal inputs and provides explainable sentiment predictions. Our HAN framework consists of modality-specific attention modules and a fusion layer that adaptively weights the importance of each modality. We evaluate our approach on a benchmark dataset and demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to existing multi-modal sentiment analysis models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but existing methods struggle to capture temporal dependencies in dynamic networks. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) that leverages both spatial and temporal attention mechanisms to model node relationships. HiGAT utilizes a hierarchical architecture to aggregate features across multiple scales, enabling the capture of complex patterns in dynamic networks. Our experiments on several benchmarks demonstrate that HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in node classification accuracy and robustness.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis for E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines often struggle to accurately capture user intent due to the complexity of natural language queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages aspect-based sentiment analysis to identify relevant product features and sentiment polarities. Our approach integrates a deep learning-based sentiment analyzer with a probabilistic query expansion framework, resulting in improved retrieval accuracy and diversity. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant gains in precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it aims to capture the underlying intent of the user's query. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and shallow models, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'NeuroQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of queries and documents. We utilize a multi-task learning objective that jointly optimizes query expansion and relevance ranking, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of NeuroQE in capturing nuanced query semantics and outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Task-Oriented Autonomous Agents
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized approach to coalition formation for task-oriented autonomous agents. We propose a multi-agent framework, 'TaskForge', that enables agents to self-organize into coalitions to accomplish complex tasks in dynamic environments. TaskForge integrates a distributed constraint optimization algorithm with a probabilistic task allocation mechanism, ensuring efficient and adaptive coalition formation. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of TaskForge in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead compared to centralized coalition formation methods.

title: Hybrid Attention Mechanisms for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a crucial task in human-computer interaction. However, existing approaches often rely on complex models that struggle to scale with large datasets. This paper proposes a novel hybrid attention mechanism that combines self-attention and graph-based attention to effectively capture intra-modal and inter-modal relationships. Our approach, dubbed 'HybridEmo', achieves state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark datasets while reducing computational requirements by up to 30%. We also provide an ablation study to demonstrate the effectiveness of each attention component.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to enhance the retrieval effectiveness by adding relevant terms to the original query. However, existing QE methods often rely on heuristics or manual tuning, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'QE-DRL', which formulates QE as a sequential decision-making problem. By interacting with the retrieval environment, QE-DRL learns to select optimal expansion terms that maximize the expected retrieval reward. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QE-DRL outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a widely used technique to improve retrieval performance, but existing methods often rely on simplistic term weighting schemes and ignore the semantic relationships between query terms. In this paper, we propose a neural query expansion model, 'NQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn the semantic representation of query terms and their relationships. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness while reducing computational overhead.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gamification Techniques in Enhancing User Engagement with Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have become ubiquitous, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the impact of gamification techniques on user engagement with VAs. We designed and developed a VA prototype that incorporates various gamification elements, such as points, badges, and leaderboards. A user study with 100 participants revealed that gamified VAs led to increased user interaction, improved task completion rates, and enhanced overall user experience. Our results provide insights into the effective design of gamified VAs and highlight the potential for gamification to improve human-computer interaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) systems must process and integrate features from various sources, such as speech, vision, and text. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and regions within each modality to improve MER performance. Our HAN model comprises two stages: an intra-modality attention module that captures local patterns within each modality, and an inter-modality attention module that adaptively weights the modalities to form a unified representation. Experiments on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art MER systems in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Temporal Graph Databases using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale network data with temporal dependencies. However, existing indexing techniques suffer from high memory overhead and slow query performance. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, Hierarchical Bloom Filter Index (HBFI), which leverages the hierarchical structure of Bloom filters to efficiently index temporal graphs. HBFI reduces memory usage by up to 70% and improves query performance by up to 5x compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques. We evaluate HBFI on real-world datasets and demonstrate its applicability to various temporal graph queries.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper introduces a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'QERL', which learns to expand queries by optimizing the expected retrieval performance. Our method leverages a hierarchical neural network to represent queries and documents, and a reinforcement learning framework to select the most informative expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QERL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving substantial improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial task that enables agents to achieve common goals. Existing approaches rely on centralized controllers or assume complete knowledge of the environment. This paper proposes a decentralized framework for coalition formation using graph neural networks (GNNs). We introduce a novel GNN architecture that learns to represent agent relationships and preferences, allowing agents to form coalitions in a distributed manner. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of coalition stability and task completion rate.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. One of the key challenges in ad-hoc retrieval is the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query terms do not appear in the relevant documents. Query expansion is a popular technique to address this issue. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion approach using deep neural networks. Our approach leverages the semantic relationships between words and phrases to generate effective expansion terms. We evaluate our approach on several standard datasets and show significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Wizard-of-Oz Study
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces are increasingly being used in various domains, but their accessibility and usability for older adults remain a concern. This paper presents a Wizard-of-Oz study that explores the design of inclusive conversational interfaces for older adults. We developed a conversational system that uses natural language processing and machine learning to understand and respond to user input. Our study involved 20 older adults who interacted with the system, and our results show that older adults prefer a more structured conversation flow and explicit cues for input. We also found that the use of multimodal feedback, such as voice and visual cues, improves the overall user experience. Our findings have implications for the design of conversational interfaces that are accessible and usable by older adults.

title: Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Older adults with cognitive impairments often face difficulties interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for voice-based interfaces tailored to this population. We conducted a series of workshops and usability studies to identify design principles that facilitate intuitive interaction, reduce cognitive load, and promote error recovery. Our findings inform the development of a novel voice-based interface, 'EasyTalk', which incorporates features such as simplified language processing, personalized feedback, and adaptive error correction. A pilot study with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Graph Attention Networks for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering over knowledge graphs has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing methods often struggle to capture complex relationships between entities and attributes. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) based approach, called KGQA-GAT, for efficient knowledge graph embedding. Our model leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant entities and attributes when answering questions. We evaluate KGQA-GAT on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Heterogeneous information networks (HINs) contain diverse node types and relations, posing significant challenges for node classification tasks. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages both local and global structural patterns in HINs. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant node neighborhoods and learns node representations by aggregating features from multiple relational contexts. Experimental results on several real-world HIN datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification tasks, especially when dealing with scarce labeled data.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Expansion for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval has become a crucial component in many information retrieval systems. However, existing methods often rely on computationally expensive dense retrieval models or require large amounts of annotated data. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document expansion approach, 'QADE', that leverages sparse representations and document-centric indexing to efficiently retrieve relevant passages. Our method adaptively selects and expands relevant documents based on the query context, reducing the search space and improving retrieval efficiency. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods while requiring significantly fewer computational resources.

title: Enriching Query Representation with Entity Disambiguation for Enhanced Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query representation is a crucial component of information retrieval (IR) systems, as it directly affects the retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to enrich query representation by incorporating entity disambiguation. We leverage knowledge graphs to identify entities mentioned in the query and disambiguate them using a graph-based algorithm. The enriched query representation is then used to re-rank the retrieved documents, resulting in improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art IR models, particularly for queries with ambiguous entities.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interaction and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: This paper explores the relationship between embodied cognition and gestural interaction in virtual reality (VR) environments. We conducted a user study to investigate how different gestural interfaces affect cognitive load and task performance in a virtual puzzle-solving task. Our results show that participants who used gestures that mimicked real-world actions (e.g., grasping and manipulating objects) demonstrated lower cognitive load and improved task performance compared to those using abstract gestures. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of intuitive and effective VR interfaces, highlighting the importance of embodied cognition in shaping user experience.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperation is crucial for achieving common goals. However, current methods often rely on complex black-box models, hindering interpretability. This paper presents HAN-MAC, a novel hierarchical attention network that facilitates explainable cooperation among agents. By incorporating attention mechanisms at both the intra-agent and inter-agent levels, HAN-MAC selectively focuses on relevant information and relationships, enabling more effective and interpretable decision-making. We evaluate HAN-MAC on a series of cooperative navigation tasks, demonstrating improved performance and transparency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis from multimodal data, such as text, images, and videos, is a challenging task due to the complexity of capturing cross-modal interactions. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages self-attention mechanisms to model intra-modal and inter-modal relationships. Our approach first learns modality-specific representations using separate attention modules, and then combines them using a hierarchical fusion strategy. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal sentiment analysis methods, achieving an average improvement of 4.2% in terms of F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their scalability and fault-tolerance. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GIDX', which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query plans. GIDX uses a combination of graph decomposition and join ordering to reduce the search space of possible query plans, resulting in significant improvements in query execution time. We evaluate GIDX on a real-world dataset and demonstrate an average speedup of 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We present a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to optimize task assignment and execution. Our approach, called 'AgentTA', utilizes a hierarchical graph neural network to model agent interactions and task dependencies. We demonstrate that AgentTA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to dynamic environments. Experimental results on a simulated drone swarm scenario show that AgentTA achieves a 25% reduction in task completion time compared to state-of-the-art decentralized allocation algorithms.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in decentralized settings where agents have limited communication and computation resources. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn efficient task allocation strategies. Our method, called GNN-TA, represents the agent-task graph as a learnable neural network, enabling agents to learn task allocation policies through self-organized communication and negotiation. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation benchmarks demonstrate that GNN-TA outperforms traditional decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: As the world transitions to renewable energy sources, smart grids require efficient resource allocation to ensure reliable power supply. This paper introduces 'Agent Harmony', a novel multi-agent system that enables real-time coordination of autonomous agents for resource allocation in smart grids. Our approach leverages a decentralized, hybrid architecture that combines model-free reinforcement learning with constraint-based reasoning to optimize power distribution. Experimental results on a simulated grid demonstrate that Agent Harmony outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of response time, power loss reduction, and adaptability to dynamic demand patterns.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Learned Index Structures for Modern Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of modern database systems, as it directly impacts query performance and overall system efficiency. This paper explores the application of learned index structures to accelerate query optimization. We propose a novel approach, 'Liqo', which integrates machine learning models into the query optimization process to predict optimal query plans. Liqo leverages a combination of feature extraction, model selection, and online learning to adapt to changing workloads and data distributions. Experimental results on a comprehensive benchmark suite demonstrate that Liqo achieves significant speedups over traditional query optimization techniques, while maintaining robustness and accuracy.

title: Enhancing Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) is a crucial task in natural language processing, which involves identifying sentiment polarities towards specific aspects or features in user reviews. Existing ABSA models often neglect the hierarchical structure of aspects and their relationships, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that captures aspect dependencies and sentiment propagation. Our HAN model consists of a sentiment-aware aspect encoder and a hierarchical attention mechanism, which learns to focus on relevant aspects and contextualize sentiment expressions. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of aspect-level sentiment accuracy and overall F1-score.

title: Optimizing Query Response Time in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Caching
paper_abstract: With the increasing scale of modern databases, query response time has become a critical performance bottleneck. This paper presents a novel adaptive caching framework, 'CacheFlex', designed to optimize query response time in distributed database systems. CacheFlex leverages machine learning-based predictive modeling to dynamically adjust cache sizes and content, taking into account workload patterns, data access frequencies, and system resource availability. Our experimental evaluation using the TPC-C benchmark demonstrates that CacheFlex achieves up to 35% reduction in average query response time compared to state-of-the-art caching strategies, while maintaining a low cache miss rate.

title: Gaze-Based Gesture Recognition for Enhanced Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel gaze-based gesture recognition approach that enables users to interact with VR environments using only their eye movements. Our method leverages a convolutional neural network (CNN) to classify gaze patterns into distinct gestures, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% on a dataset of 20 users. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a VR-based game, where users with motor impairments can play using only their gaze. Our results show that gaze-based gesture recognition can significantly enhance the accessibility of VR systems.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it significantly impacts the performance of complex queries. Traditional optimization techniques rely on hand-crafted heuristics or rule-based systems, which may not adapt well to diverse workload characteristics. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQOpt', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed settings. By modeling the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process, we train a neural network to learn optimal query plans that minimize execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Conversational Strategies for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often overlooks the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered study on conversational strategies for inclusive voice assistants. We conducted in-depth interviews and usability testing with 25 older adults to identify pain points and design opportunities. Our findings highlight the importance of explicit feedback, incremental learning, and empathetic responses. We propose a set of design guidelines and demonstrate their effectiveness through a prototype voice assistant, 'ElderGuide', which improved task completion rates by 35% and user satisfaction by 40% compared to a baseline system.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in virtual reality (VR)-based learning environments. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a VR learning platform using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results show that users who interacted with personalized avatars demonstrated higher levels of engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to those using generic avatars. We also found that users' self-reported sense of presence and embodiment in the virtual environment were strong predictors of engagement. The findings have implications for the design of VR-based learning systems and suggest that personalized avatars can be a key factor in enhancing user experience and learning outcomes.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Zero-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and computational efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that addresses these limitations by selectively focusing on relevant semantic features and relationships. Our approach leverages a graph-based attention mechanism to model complex interactions between seen and unseen classes, enabling efficient ZSL with minimal additional training data. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HAN over state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents via Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: We present a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to efficiently allocate tasks in a dynamic, real-time environment. Our approach, called 'AgentDCOP', models the task allocation problem as a DCOP, enabling agents to communicate and coordinate with each other to find a globally optimal solution. We propose a novel distributed algorithm that utilizes a combination of message-passing and local search to solve the DCOP, ensuring scalability and robustness in the face of agent failures or dynamic task changes. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentDCOP in achieving high-quality task allocations while adapting to changing environmental conditions.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Virtual Reality Environments Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems are increasingly being used in various domains, but their security remains a significant concern. This paper presents a novel gaze-based authentication system for VR environments using deep learning techniques. Our approach leverages the unique characteristics of VR head-mounted displays to capture users' gaze patterns and uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to learn discriminative features. Experimental results on a dataset of 100 users show that our system achieves a high accuracy of 97.5% and outperforms existing authentication methods. We also demonstrate the feasibility of our approach in a real-world VR application, providing a promising solution for securing VR systems.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Mechanisms for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and fair negotiation mechanisms. This paper proposes a decentralized framework for task allocation, where agents negotiate through bilateral agreements to maximize their individual utilities. We introduce a novel protocol, 'ANT', which incorporates a combination of auction-based and voting-based mechanisms to achieve Pareto optimality. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that ANT outperforms existing centralized and decentralized methods in terms of allocation efficiency and agent satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Cloud Databases
paper_abstract: As cloud-based database services continue to proliferate, optimizing query performance for multi-tenant environments has become a pressing concern. This paper presents 'MTQO', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and graph-based modeling to minimize contention and improve resource utilization. Our approach involves offline profiling of tenant workloads to construct a knowledge graph, which is then used to predict and mitigate resource bottlenecks at runtime. Experimental results on a real-world cloud database demonstrate significant reductions in query latency and improved overall system throughput.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but their effectiveness is heavily reliant on the quality of the query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion technique that leverages contrastive learning to generate semantically coherent and diverse expansion terms. Our approach, dubbed 'ConEx', marginalized the impact of irrelevant terms by learning a query-agnostic discriminator that separates relevant from non-relevant terms. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that ConEx consistently outperforms existing query expansion methods, leading to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial for trustworthy decision-making in autonomous vehicles. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based reinforcement learning (HARL) framework that learns to generate interpretable explanations for its actions. HARL combines a hierarchical attention mechanism with a reinforcement learning policy to identify relevant features and states that influence the decision-making process. We evaluate HARL on a realistic autonomous driving simulator and demonstrate improved explainability and performance compared to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Voice-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: This study examines the effects of personalization on user engagement in voice-based interfaces. We designed an experiment where participants interacted with a voice assistant that adapted to their preferences, goals, and behavioral patterns. Our results show that personalized voice interactions lead to increased user satisfaction, reduced frustration, and improved task completion rates. We also identify the key factors influencing user engagement, including contextual relevance, tone, and language style. The findings have implications for the design of future voice-based systems that aim to enhance user experience.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Flow Optimization
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for autonomous traffic flow optimization using deep reinforcement learning. Our framework, called MATRL, leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn cooperative policies for a fleet of autonomous vehicles. MATRL utilizes a graph-based representation of the traffic network to enable efficient communication and coordination among agents. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that MATRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reducing congestion and increasing traffic flow, while ensuring safety and feasibility constraints. Our approach has the potential to significantly improve the efficiency and safety of autonomous transportation systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis in social media is a challenging task due to the multimodal nature of online content. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates visual and textual features to analyze sentiment in social media posts. Our approach employs a stacked attention mechanism to model complex interactions between modalities, enabling the network to selectively focus on relevant regions of the input data. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in sentiment classification, particularly in cases where textual and visual cues are conflicting.

title: Scalable Graph Pattern Matching using GPU-Accelerated Indexing
paper_abstract: Graph pattern matching is a fundamental operation in graph databases, but its computational complexity hinders its adoption in large-scale applications. This paper proposes a novel GPU-accelerated indexing approach for efficient graph pattern matching. Our method, called GPU-GPM, leverages the massively parallel architecture of modern GPUs to accelerate the pattern matching process. We also introduce a novel indexing scheme that reduces the memory footprint of the graph index, allowing for scalable pattern matching on large graphs. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GPU-GPM outperforms state-of-the-art CPU-based approaches by up to 10x in terms of query response time.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Query Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on simplistic term weighting and suffer from limited context awareness. This paper proposes a neural query graph embedding (NQGE) approach that jointly models query terms, their relationships, and the document collection. Our NQGE model learns to encode queries as dense vectors, which are then used to expand the original query. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for challenging topics with limited relevant documents.

title: Emotional Avatar-based Feedback in Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the role of emotional avatars in enhancing user engagement and feedback in multimodal human-computer interaction. We propose an emotional avatar-based feedback system, 'EmoAvatar', which incorporates facial expression recognition, sentiment analysis, and speech synthesis to provide users with personalized, empathetic responses. Our user study results show that EmoAvatar significantly improves user satisfaction and perceived system understanding compared to traditional text-based feedback. Furthermore, we demonstrate the applicability of EmoAvatar in various HCI domains, including virtual assistants, e-learning, and affective computing.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a crucial task that enables agents to achieve common goals. However, existing approaches often rely on centralized algorithms, which can be vulnerable to single-point failures and lack scalability. This paper proposes a decentralized coalition formation framework that leverages distributed constraint optimization techniques. Our approach allows agents to negotiate and form coalitions in a distributed manner, while ensuring Pareto optimality and fairness. Experimental results on a simulation platform demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing decentralized methods in terms of coalition stability and agent utility.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a challenging task due to the inherent complexity and variability of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and features to improve emotion recognition accuracy and explainability. Our HAN model consists of three levels of attention: modality-level, feature-level, and instance-level, allowing it to adaptively weigh the importance of different modalities and features for each instance. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of emotion recognition accuracy and provides meaningful explanations for its predictions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Embeddings for Sparse Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is an essential technique to improve the retrieval effectiveness of information retrieval systems. However, traditional methods often struggle with sparse document collections. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our approach, 'EmbedExpan', learns to represent queries and documents as dense vectors and expands the query using a graph-based algorithm that incorporates both semantic and co-occurrence information. Experimental results on several sparse benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and NDCG.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models often struggle to effectively integrate information from different modalities, such as images and text. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that addresses this challenge. Our approach iteratively refines attention weights across modalities, allowing the model to selectively focus on relevant regions and tokens. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational overhead. Furthermore, we provide a comprehensive analysis of attention patterns, offering insights into the decision-making process of VQA models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs have become a crucial component in various AI applications, but their complex structures and multiple relationships pose significant challenges for effective representation learning. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that captures multi-relational knowledge graph embeddings. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations, and a graph convolutional layer to capture local and global structural information. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in knowledge graph completion, entity classification, and question answering tasks.

title: Hierarchical Task Decomposition for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, task complexity often hinders the learning process. We propose a novel hierarchical task decomposition framework, 'HTD-MA', which leverages a divide-and-conquer approach to simplify complex tasks. HTD-MA recursively decomposes tasks into sub-tasks, and each agent learns to solve these sub-tasks using a deep reinforcement learning policy. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HTD-MA in a variety of multi-agent scenarios, including robotic soccer and autonomous driving. Experimental results show that HTD-MA outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and learning efficiency.

title: Evaluating the Efficacy of Gamification in Enhancing User Engagement with Intelligent Assistive Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent assistive systems have the potential to revolutionize the lives of individuals with disabilities. However, user engagement and adoption rates remain a significant concern. This paper explores the role of gamification in enhancing user experience and motivation with intelligent assistive systems. We designed and implemented a gamified interface for a speech-to-text system and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Results show that gamification significantly improved user engagement, with participants exhibiting increased usage and self-reported satisfaction. We also identified key design factors that influence the efficacy of gamification in this context.

title: Disentangling Explainable AI: A Causal Graph Approach for Model Interpretability
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has become a crucial aspect of trustworthy AI systems. However, existing methods often rely on simplistic feature attribution or saliency maps, which can be misleading or incomplete. This paper introduces a novel causal graph-based approach, 'CausalXAI', which disentangles the complex relationships between input features and model predictions. By leveraging causal inference and graph theory, CausalXAI provides a more comprehensive and nuanced understanding of model behavior. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CausalXAI on several benchmark datasets, showcasing its ability to identify causal relationships and uncover hidden biases in AI models.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships between data entities. However, query optimization for distributed graph databases remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for distributed graph databases. We propose a Deep Q-Network (DQN) based framework that learns to predict the optimal query plan based on the graph structure, query patterns, and system workload. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Adaptive Gradient Sparsification for Efficient Deep Learning on Resource-Constrained Devices
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks often require significant computational resources, limiting their deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper presents an adaptive gradient sparsification technique, 'AdaSparse', which dynamically adjusts the sparsity of gradients during backpropagation to reduce computation and memory requirements. Our approach leverages a novel, differentiable sparsity metric that adaptively prunes gradients based on their importance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaSparse achieves comparable model accuracy to dense gradient updates while reducing compute time by up to 45% on mobile devices.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in scenarios where agents have diverse capabilities and tasks require varying levels of resources. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) model that learns to allocate tasks to agents by modeling their interactions and resource constraints. Our approach integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical clustering to capture complex dependencies between agents and tasks. Experimental results on a series of benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art task allocation algorithms, achieving significant improvements in task completion rates and resource utilization.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the daunting task of allocating resources efficiently to meet dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'CloudRL', which learns to optimize resource allocation in a hierarchical manner. CloudRL comprises a high-level planner that allocates resources to virtual machines and a low-level scheduler that allocates resources within each virtual machine. We employ a hierarchical actor-critic architecture with a novel attention mechanism to improve the learning efficiency and adapt to changing workload patterns. Our experiments on a real-world cloud computing dataset demonstrate that CloudRL outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of resource utilization and workload satisfaction.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly when agents have different capabilities and tasks have diverse requirements.
