This paper presents a novel approach, 'Deep Allocation', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate heterogeneous agents. We propose a graph neural network-based architecture that learns to represent task-agent affinity and allocates tasks efficiently. Experimental results on a realistic simulated environment demonstrate that Deep Allocation outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods, reducing task completion time by up to 30% and improving overall system utilization.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of human life, but personalized experiences are crucial to ensure user engagement and satisfaction. This study examines the effects of personalization on user experience in VR environments, focusing on factors such as user modeling, adaptive feedback, and content recommendation. Our user study involving 100 participants reveals that personalized VR experiences lead to increased user satisfaction, reduced cognitive load, and improved task performance. We also identify key challenges and limitations in achieving effective personalization in VR and propose future research directions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Efficient Document Retrieval in Large-Scale Collections
paper_abstract: With the rapid growth of digital libraries, efficient document retrieval has become a pressing concern. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for retrieving relevant documents in large-scale collections. Our HAN model leverages a two-level attention mechanism to capture both local and global contextual information in documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods, particularly in terms of precision and recall at top-k ranks. We also show that our model is computationally efficient and scalable to very large document collections.

title: Reinforced Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with complex queries. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'QRG-Rank', which leverages reinforced learning to optimize document ranking. We introduce neural query graphs to capture semantic relationships between query entities and documents, and employ a policy gradient method to learn the optimal ranking policy. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that QRG-Rank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to dynamic workloads. This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'AdaptAlloc', which learns to adapt resource allocation policies based on real-time workload patterns and system performance metrics. We develop a novel state-action representation that captures the complex relationships between workload characteristics, resource utilization, and system performance. Experimental results on a large-scale cloud simulation platform show that AdaptAlloc outperforms traditional rule-based and model-driven approaches in terms of resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency.

title: Reinforced Query Expansion for Dense Passage Retrieval in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a popular approach for ad-hoc search, but its effectiveness is heavily reliant on the quality of the input query. This paper proposes a reinforced query expansion (RQE) framework that iteratively refines the query representation by incorporatinLearning from user interactions. Our RQE model employs a deep reinforcement learning agent that learns to select the most informative expansion terms based on the retrieval results and user feedback. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art DPR methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Accelerating Graph Pattern Matching via Index-Based Pruning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Graph pattern matching is a fundamental operation in numerous data analytics and machine learning applications. However, its computational complexity hinders its adoption in large-scale distributed database systems. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, called GraphPulse, which accelerates graph pattern matching by pruning unnecessary subgraph exploration. We design a hierarchical index structure that captures structural and attribute-based properties of graph data, allowing for efficient filtering and verification of candidate matches. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphPulse achieves up to 5x speedup over state-of-the-art algorithms while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Adaptive Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coalition formation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to form groups to achieve common goals. Existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering or exhaustive search, which can be computationally expensive and suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel approach, Adaptive Coalition Formation with Graph Attention Networks (ACF-GAT), which leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn effective coalition structures from agent features and interactions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of ACF-GAT in various simulated environments, including disaster response and resource allocation scenarios, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of coalition quality and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a common problem in various applications, but it often suffers from label imbalance and high dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that efficiently tackles these challenges. Our HAN model consists of two attention mechanisms: a label-aware attention module that selectively focuses on relevant labels, and a feature-aware attention module that adaptively weights input features. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Column-store databases have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to efficiently store and query large amounts of data. However, supporting multi-dimensional range queries remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, called 'RangeCube', which leverages a combination of space-filling curves and hierarchical clustering to efficiently prune the search space. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that RangeCube outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query performance and 2x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is key to solving complex problems in domains like robotics and smart cities. However, as the number of agents increases, the size of the joint action space grows exponentially, leading to scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention framework, 'HierGAT', which leverages the inherent graph structure of agent interactions to reduce the dimensionality of the action space. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierGAT in several MARL benchmarks, achieving significant improvements in scalability and solution quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Neural Ranking Models in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but their computational cost hinders their deployment in real-world search engines. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'NeuroOpt', which leverages the structural properties of neural networks to reduce the number of model evaluations required during query processing. Our approach involves query rewriting, early termination, and parallelization techniques that can be seamlessly integrated into existing search engine architectures. Experimental results on the MS MARCO dataset demonstrate that NeuroOpt reduces query latency by up to 75% while maintaining retrieval effectiveness.

title: Query-Adaptive Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Modern information retrieval systems rely on neural ranking models to accurately rank documents for user queries. However, these models can be computationally expensive and may not generalize well to unseen queries. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive neural ranking model, 'QNRM', which leverages query semantics to dynamically adjust the ranking model's weights. We demonstrate that QNRM achieves significant improvements in ranking accuracy and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models, particularly for tail queries. Experiments on the TREC Web Track dataset show that QNRM reduces the average ranking time by 30% while maintaining a 10% increase in NDCG@10.

title: Deep Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning-based approach to query expansion, dubbed 'RL-QE'. RL-QE models the query expansion process as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select relevant terms to add to the original query. Our experiments on several TREC datasets demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has created a pressing need for efficient coordination mechanisms to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-Coord', to coordinate AVs in dynamic traffic scenarios. We model the problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process and employ a graph neural network-based architecture to learn coordination strategies. Our experiments demonstrate that MARL-Coord outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods in reducing congestion and travel times, while improving safety and stability.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Large-Scale Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it helps to mitigate the vocabulary mismatch problem. However, existing QE methods often incur high computational costs, making them impractical for large-scale document collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical QE approach that leverages a tiered indexing structure to efficiently prune irrelevant terms. Our method, termed 'HiQE', incorporates a probabilistic relevance model and a greedy term selection strategy to identify the most informative expansion terms. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HiQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art QE methods.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using Graph-based Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper introduces a novel graph-based contrastive learning framework, 'GraphCon', which leverages the structural properties of time series data to identify anomalies. By constructing a graph from time series segments and applying contrastive learning, GraphCon learns to distinguish between normal and anomalous patterns. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphCon outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Deep Ranking Models for Query-Document Interaction in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in Information Retrieval (IR) rely on hand-crafted features and shallow models, which struggle to capture complex query-document interactions. This paper presents a novel deep ranking framework, 'DeepInteract', which leverages transformer-based architectures to model query-document interactions. We propose a multi-task learning approach that jointly optimizes ranking, relevance, and semantic matching objectives. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepInteract outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness to query variations.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Voice Assistants using Participatory Design
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational interfaces often pose accessibility barriers for users with disabilities. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create more inclusive voice assistants. We collaborated with 20 participants with disabilities to co-design and evaluate a novel conversational interface that incorporates multimodal feedback, adaptive speech recognition, and personalized dialogue management. Our results show significant improvements in user experience, task completion rates, and perceived accessibility compared to commercial voice assistants. We contribute a set of design guidelines and a toolkit for developers to create more accessible conversational interfaces.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed traffic control. Our approach, called 'MARL-Traffic', enables a network of autonomous agents to learn cooperative policies for optimizing traffic flow in real-time. We leverage deep Q-networks with a decentralized actor-critic architecture, allowing agents to adapt to changing traffic patterns and communicate with neighboring agents to minimize congestion. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that MARL-Traffic outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing travel times by up to 30% and increasing network throughput by 25%

title: Gaze-Based Multimodal Interaction for Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on cumbersome controllers or limited gesture recognition, hindering immersive experiences. We present 'GazeVR', a novel multimodal interaction framework that leverages gaze tracking, voice commands, and hand gestures to enable more natural and expressive interactions in VR. Our approach utilizes a probabilistic fusion model to integrate input from various modalities, allowing for robust and flexible interaction. A user study demonstrates that GazeVR significantly improves task completion times and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control under Uncertain Weather Conditions
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) require robust control policies to navigate complex scenarios, including uncertain weather conditions. This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'Weather Aware Control' (WAC), which learns to adapt to varying weather conditions (rain, snow, fog) using a novel weather-aware reward function. WAC leverages a combination of sensor modalities (camera, lidar, radar) and weather forecasts to learn a robust policy. Experimental results demonstrate that WAC outperforms traditional model-based control methods in simulated and real-world scenarios, ensuring safe and efficient navigation under adverse weather conditions.

title: EyeGazePath: A Machine Learning Approach to Predicting User Intent from Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: Eye movement patterns can serve as a valuable indicator of user intent in human-computer interaction. This paper presents EyeGazePath, a machine learning framework that leverages deep learning techniques to predict user intent from eye gaze data. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to model the spatial and temporal aspects of eye movement patterns. We evaluate EyeGazePath on a large-scale eye tracking dataset and demonstrate its ability to accurately predict user intent in various scenarios, including web browsing and interactive gaming.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Ad-Hoc Retrieval in Narrow Domains
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval in narrow domains poses unique challenges due to the limited scope and specificity of the queries. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages external knowledge graphs and domain-specific ontologies to disambiguate query terms and inject relevant concepts. Our approach incorporates a novel graph-based ranking model that captures the semantic relationships between query terms, expansion terms, and document content. Experimental results on three narrow-domain collections show that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving up to 25% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Neural Topic Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel neural topic modeling approach, dubbed 'NeuQE', which leverages deep learning to learn semantic relationships between query terms and expand the query space. We incorporate a probabilistic topic model to capture latent topic structures in the document collection and generate expanded queries that better match user intent. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that NeuQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of MAP and NDCG@20.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel decentralized approach using partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) to model and coordinate agent behavior. We develop a scalable, distributed algorithm that enables agents to share and integrate local observations, reducing the dimensionality of the joint state space. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate improved coordination and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized POMDP approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploratory Study on Speech Patterns of Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their accessibility for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the speech patterns of older adults interacting with voice assistants, focusing on factors such as cognitive load, speech rate, and linguistic complexity. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, using a specially designed voice assistant prototype. Our results show that older adults exhibit distinct speech patterns, including slower speech rates and more frequent pauses, which can lead to errors in voice assistant interactions. We propose a set of design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants, including adaptive speech recognition and personalized feedback mechanisms.

title: Relevance-Based Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Hierarchical Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique for enhancing the retrieval performance of search engines, particularly in hierarchical document collections. However, existing methods often incur significant computational overhead and may not effectively capture the nuances of user queries. This paper proposes a relevance-based query expansion approach, dubbed 'HierExpan', which leverages hierarchical relationships to identify the most informative expansion terms. Our approach is grounded in a probabilistic framework that models the relevance of expansion terms to the original query, allowing for efficient pruning of irrelevant terms. Experimental results on a large-scale hierarchical dataset demonstrate that HierExpan outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness.

title: Emotional State Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Eye-Tracking and EEG Signals
paper_abstract: Accurate emotional state recognition is crucial for human-computer interaction (HCI) applications. This paper presents a novel multimodal approach that combines eye-tracking and electroencephalography (EEG) signals to recognize emotional states. Our proposed framework, 'EmoFusion', employs a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract features from eye-tracking data and a recurrent neural network (RNN) to analyze EEG signals. The fusion of these modalities using a Bayesian approach improves recognition accuracy compared to unimodal approaches. Experimental results on a dataset of 50 participants demonstrate that EmoFusion achieves an average accuracy of 87.2% in recognizing four emotional states: happiness, sadness, anger, and fear.

title: Reinforced Query Expansion for Effective Retrieval in Sparse Document Collections
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of information retrieval systems, particularly in sparse document collections where relevant terms may be missing. This paper proposes a novel reinforced query expansion approach, 'RQE-RL', which leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select expansion terms based on their potential impact on retrieval performance. We define a reward function that balances precision and recall, and demonstrate the effectiveness of RQE-RL in improving retrieval accuracy on several benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that RQE-RL outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, especially in cases where the initial query is ill-defined or incomplete.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Agents using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative agents in multi-agent systems often struggle with task allocation due to incomplete information and conflicting goals. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to enable cooperative agents to adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach, called 'CATARINA', utilizes a hierarchical graph neural network to learn a task allocation policy that balances individual agent rewards with global system efficiency. Experimental results on a simulated urban search and rescue scenario demonstrate that CATARINA outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion rate and agent satisfaction.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture recognition systems that adapt to the cognitive and motor abilities of older adults with cognitive impairments. We propose a machine learning-based framework that integrates insights from cognitive psychology and HCI principles to provide personalized gesture recognition models. Our approach leverages a multi-modal sensor setup and a participatory design methodology to co-design the system with older adults. The results of our user study demonstrate improved gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Deep Neural Ranking Models in Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Deep neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with limited query context. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuralQE', that leverages the semantic representation capabilities of pre-trained language models. NeuralQE adaptively generates context-aware query expansions by bridging the gap between the original query and relevant documents in the collection. Our experiments on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for queries with limited context, and outperform existing query expansion methods.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination in Smart Cities
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for coordinating autonomous vehicles in smart cities. Our approach, 'MARL-City', leverages graph neural networks to model the complex interactions between vehicles and the urban environment. We propose a decentralized, hierarchical policy that enables vehicles to adapt to changing traffic conditions and optimize their routes in real-time. Experimental results using a realistic simulator demonstrate that MARL-City outperforms traditional traffic management methods in reducing congestion and improving travel times.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems pose significant challenges in query optimization due to the complexity of data distribution and network latency. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). Our method, 'DQO-RLL', learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database environment and receiving rewards based on query execution time. We evaluate DQO-RLL on a real-world distributed database benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing VR systems often fail to account for their unique needs. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR experiences for this population. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults and caregivers to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our findings inform the development of a novel VR system that incorporates cognitive support tools, simple navigation, and personalized feedback. A pilot study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in user engagement and cognitive performance compared to traditional VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI is crucial for building trust in human-AI interactions. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for multi-modal dialogue systems that generates interpretable explanations for its responses. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to identify salient input features and dialogue history, and incorporates a hierarchical fusion layer to combine modalities. We evaluate our model on a benchmark dataset and demonstrate improved explanation quality and dialogue coherence compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach has implications for developing more transparent and user-friendly conversational AI systems.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Virtual Reality Games
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) games often struggle to provide an optimal difficulty level for players, leading to frustration or boredom. This paper presents 'GazeDAA', a novel approach that leverages eye-tracking data to adapt game difficulty in real-time. By analyzing the player's gaze patterns, our system infers their attention and expertise, adjusting the game's challenge level accordingly. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating that GazeDAA improves player engagement, reduces frustration, and enhances overall gaming experience.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has achieved success in various AI applications, but existing methods often neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in many graphs. This paper proposes a novel KGE framework, 'HiGATE', which leverages hierarchical graph attention to capture complex relationships between entities. By recursively applying attention mechanisms at different graph scales, HiGATE learns more informative and robust embeddings. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiGATE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE models in link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Elderly Users
paper_abstract: This study investigates the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) to reduce cognitive load for elderly users interacting with complex interfaces. We designed an ECA-based system that provides personalized assistance and feedback to users navigating a healthcare portal. Our user study with 30 elderly participants shows that the ECA condition resulted in significantly lower cognitive load, improved task completion rates, and higher user satisfaction compared to a text-based interface. We also analyzed the impact of ECA embodiment, voice, and gestures on user experience and found that a combination of these factors contributes to the observed benefits.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Voice Assistants
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their personalized responses often raise concerns about user experience and autonomy. This study explores the effects of personalization on user satisfaction, trust, and decision-making in voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, who interacted with either a personalized or non-personalized voice assistant. Our results show that personalization can lead to increased satisfaction and trust, but also decreases users' perceived control and autonomy. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of voice assistants and propose a framework for balancing personalization with user agency.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but its brittleness to adversarial attacks hinders its deployment in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'AdvRL', which leverages a zero-sum game formulation to learn robust policies. We introduce a dual-optimizer approach that jointly updates the policy and adversary networks, promoting exploration-exploitation trade-offs. Empirical evaluation on popular DRL benchmarks demonstrates that AdvRL significantly enhances the robustness of DRL agents against both white-box and black-box attacks, while maintaining competitive performance.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to analyze the robustness of deep neural networks against adversarial attacks using Bayesian uncertainty estimation. Our method, called 'BayesRobust', leverages Bayesian neural networks to model the uncertainty of the network's predictions and detect potential adversarial examples. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BayesRobust on several benchmark datasets, including ImageNet and CIFAR-10, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art robustness analysis methods. Our results have important implications for the development of robust and trustworthy AI systems.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Commonsense Reasoning
paper_abstract: Commonsense reasoning is a crucial aspect of human-level Artificial Intelligence (AI). Recent advances in knowledge graph embedding have shown promise in this direction. However, existing methods suffer from limited contextual understanding and lack of hierarchical structure. We propose 'HierAtt', a novel knowledge graph embedding framework that incorporates hierarchical attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between entities and their contexts. Our experiments on the ConceptNet dataset demonstrate significant improvements in link prediction and question answering tasks, outperforming state-of-the-art models by up to 12%.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to perform cooperative tasks in dynamic environments is a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach, called Cooperative Task Allocation (CTA), which enables agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and allocate tasks efficiently. CTA uses a decentralized, graph-based representation to model agent interactions and incorporates a reward function that balances individual and collective performance. Experimental results in a simulated robotic search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that CTA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and agent coordination.

title: Heterogeneous Ensemble Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often rely on a single modality or fail to capture complex relationships between modalities. This paper proposes a novel heterogeneous ensemble learning framework, 'ModaFuse', which integrates multiple modalities (text, image, and audio) using a stacked generalization approach. We introduce a modality-aware attention mechanism that adaptively weights the contributions of each modality based on the input data. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that ModaFuse achieves state-of-the-art performance in multimodal sentiment analysis tasks, outperforming single-modality and homogeneous ensemble methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Modern Database Management Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of modern database management systems, as it directly impacts the performance and scalability of data-intensive applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize queries based on a reward function that balances execution time, resource utilization, and query complexity. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world database workload shows that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Efficient Document Re-ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to effectively re-rank documents based on user queries. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph (NQG) approach that models complex query-document relationships. Our NQG framework represents queries as graphs, which are then used to compute semantic similarities with document graphs. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant query-document interactions, enabling more accurate re-ranking. Experimental results on the TREC dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain compared to state-of-the-art re-ranking methods.

title: Efficient Online Learning of Context-Dependent Embeddings for Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Context-dependent word embeddings have revolutionized natural language processing (NLP) tasks. However, most existing approaches require expensive offline computations, making them prohibitive for real-time applications. This paper presents an online learning framework, 'ConTEX', that efficiently updates context-dependent embeddings as new data arrives. ConTEX leverages a novel, streaming-friendly algorithm for incremental singular value decomposition and a hierarchical caching mechanism to minimize computational overhead. Our experiments on several benchmark NLP datasets demonstrate that ConTEX achieves competitive performance to state-of-the-art offline methods while significantly reducing computational costs and memory usage.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HierMA', which enables agents to learn both individual and coordinated behaviors. HierMA uses a hierarchical structure to decompose the global reward function into local rewards, allowing agents to focus on their individual objectives while still contributing to the global goal. We evaluate HierMA in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating improved coordination and task completion rates compared to existing decentralized reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Gesture-Based Interface for People with Motor Impairments Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface designed to assist people with motor impairments. Our approach leverages deep learning techniques to recognize and classify hand gestures from computer vision data. We propose a two-stage framework that first detects hand regions using a YOLO-based detector and then employs a convolutional neural network (CNN) to classify gestures. The proposed system is evaluated on a dataset of 100 participants with varying levels of motor impairment, achieving an average accuracy of 92.5%. The results demonstrate the potential of our approach to enable individuals with motor impairments to interact more effectively with digital systems.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Graph-based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GraphIx', which leverages the structural properties of data graphs to accelerate query execution. GraphIx integrates a hierarchical indexing scheme with a cost-based query optimizer to minimize query latency. Experimental evaluation on a real-world social network dataset demonstrates that GraphIx outperforms traditional indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query response time.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face challenges interacting with digital systems. We present an adaptive gesture recognition system that leverages machine learning and computer vision to accommodate diverse motor abilities. Our approach combines a wearable sensor with a deep neural network to recognize gestures, and incorporates a novel transfer learning mechanism to adapt to individual users' motor patterns. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed constraint optimization (DCO) framework for heterogeneous agents, where each agent has unique capabilities and constraints. Our approach, called Het-DCO, leverages asynchronous communication and iterative constraint propagation to ensure task allocation feasibility and optimality. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that Het-DCO outperforms centralized and decentralized baseline methods in terms of task completion time and success rate.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for adaptive traffic signal control. We model the traffic network as a decentralized Markov decision process, where each agent represents a traffic signal controller. The agents learn to coordinate their actions to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates real-time traffic data and road network topology. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional approaches in reducing congestion and improving traffic flow.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention for Node Classification in Attributed Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in attributed networks is a fundamental task in many applications, including social network analysis and recommender systems. However, existing methods often fail to effectively capture the complex relationships between node attributes and structural properties. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention (HGA) framework, which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant attributes and neighbors at multiple scales. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGA on several benchmark datasets, showing significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of classification accuracy and robustness to noisy attributes.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems aim to retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus to answer user queries. However, existing dense passage retrieval (DPR) methods suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation (HDR) approach that leverages both local and global contextualized embeddings to efficiently encode documents. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDR achieves comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art DPR models while reducing computational overhead by 30% and memory usage by 50%

title: Towards Efficient Contrastive Self-Supervised Learning for Visual Representation
paper_abstract: Contrastive self-supervised learning has shown remarkable success in learning visual representations. However, existing methods rely on computationally expensive contrastive loss functions and require large batches. This paper presents 'EffiCLR', a novel approach that leverages a momentum-based caching mechanism to reduce the computational overhead of contrastive learning. We also propose a hierarchical clustering-based strategy to construct more informative positive and negative pairs. Extensive experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that EffiCLR achieves competitive performance to state-of-the-art methods while reducing computational costs by up to 30%.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often rely on shallow models that fail to capture complex relationships between users and items. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding framework, 'ExplainKG', which integrates entity disentanglement and attention-based graph convolutional networks to learn interpretable representations of user-item interactions. We demonstrate the efficacy of ExplainKG on several benchmark datasets, showcasing improved recommendation accuracy and enhanced model interpretability through visualized explanations.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing input methods often hinder user experience. This paper explores gaze-based interaction as a promising alternative. We designed and evaluated a gaze-driven interface for AR applications, leveraging machine learning-based gaze estimation and precision timing. Our user study reveals significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods. Furthermore, we identify key factors influencing user performance and provide design recommendations for gaze-based AR interfaces.

title: Context-Aware Neural Ranking Model for Diverse Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Conventional information retrieval systems often prioritize relevance over diversity, leading to redundant and uninformative search results. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'CADR', which incorporates contextualized document embeddings and a diversity-promoting regularization term. Our approach leverages a transformer-based architecture to capture complex semantic relationships between documents and queries, while encouraging the retrieval of diverse and complementary results. Experimental evaluations on popular benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of CADR in improving retrieval diversity and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, requiring models to adapt to new classes with limited labeled data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning approach, 'HiCon', which leverages both inter-class and intra-class relationships to learn richer, more generalizable representations. Our method combines a hierarchical clustering module with a contrastive loss function, enabling the model to capture subtle patterns in the data. Experimental results on popular few-shot image classification benchmarks demonstrate that HiCon outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving higher accuracy with fewer labeled examples.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous negotiation in multi-agent systems, leveraging deep reinforcement learning to optimize negotiation strategies. We propose a hierarchical framework, AgentNegotiator, which integrates a deep Q-network with a set of domain-specific heuristics to adapt to diverse negotiation scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentNegotiator outperforms state-of-the-art negotiation strategies in terms of Pareto optimality, fairness, and robustness, while reducing the computational overhead. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as e-commerce, supply chain management, and conflict resolution.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (H-GAT) that learns to distribute tasks among agents based on their capabilities, spatial relationships, and task dependencies. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex agent interactions and a hierarchical architecture to capture both local and global dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that H-GAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition is a challenging task that involves fusing features from multiple sources such as speech, text, and vision. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention framework that selectively focuses on relevant features across modalities and time-steps, providing insights into the decision-making process. Our approach leverages a novel multimodal fusion strategy and a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global contextual information. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our model achieves significant improvements in emotion recognition accuracy while providing visual explanations for its predictions.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This study explores the role of embodiment in virtual reality (VR) experiences, examining how users' sense of agency and presence is influenced by avatar design and interaction modalities. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment with 40 participants, manipulating avatar realism and tracking systems. Our results show that users' embodiment perception is significantly enhanced by realistic avatars and full-body tracking, leading to increased feelings of presence and enjoyment. However, we also found that users' sense of agency is more strongly tied to controller-based interactions. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems and applications, highlighting the importance of embodiment in creating immersive and engaging experiences.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks for Autonomous Urban Planning
paper_abstract: Autonomous urban planning involves coordinating multiple agents to achieve complex tasks, such as traffic management and waste collection. This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent coordination using hierarchical task networks (HTNs). Our framework, called 'UrbanPlan', represents tasks as HTNs and leverages planning-based reasoning to generate coordinated plans for agents. We evaluate UrbanPlan in a simulated urban environment and demonstrate its ability to adapt to changing circumstances, such as traffic congestion or unexpected events. Results show that UrbanPlan outperforms traditional planning-based approaches in terms of plan quality and execution time.

title: Scalable Online Learning with Deep Kernel Approximations
paper_abstract: Online learning in non-stationary environments is a challenging task, particularly when dealing with large-scale datasets. This paper introduces a novel online learning algorithm, 'DeepKOA', that leverages deep kernel approximations to efficiently learn from streaming data. By combining a hierarchical kernel representation with a budgeted online learning framework, DeepKOA achieves state-of-the-art performance on various benchmark datasets while reducing computational complexity. We provide theoretical guarantees for DeepKOA's convergence and demonstrate its effectiveness in real-world applications, such as online recommendation systems and sentiment analysis.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems involving multiple agents require complex reasoning and context-aware decision-making. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for explainable multi-agent dialogue systems. Our HAN model captures both local and global dependencies across agents' utterances, allowing for more accurate and interpretable dialogue responses. We introduce a novel attention mechanism, 'AgentAware', which selectively focuses on relevant agents' inputs and provides explicit explanation of the response generation process. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in dialogue coherence and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex systems, autonomous agents often compete for shared resources, leading to inefficiencies and conflicts. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating agent behavior using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We propose a hierarchical framework, 'Agent Harmony', which integrates DRL with graph-based modeling to optimize resource allocation. Our experiments demonstrate that Agent Harmony outperforms traditional rule-based approaches in simulated environments, achieving up to 30% improvement in system-wide efficiency. We also discuss the applicability of our framework to real-world domains, such as smart grids and traffic management.

title: Scalable Incremental View Maintenance for Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Materialized views are essential for efficient query processing in data warehouses, but their maintenance can be costly, especially in the presence of frequent data updates. This paper presents a novel incremental view maintenance technique, 'IVM+', that leverages a combination of data sampling, delta-based processing, and parallelization to achieve scalability and efficiency. We evaluate IVM+ on a real-world data warehouse and demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing approaches, with an average speedup of 3.5x for incremental view maintenance.

title: Scalable Gaussian Process Regression for High-Dimensional Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Gaussian process regression (GPR) is a powerful tool for time series forecasting, but its cubic computational complexity limits its applicability to high-dimensional datasets. This paper presents 'HiTS', a scalable GPR framework that leverages a novel sparse covariance matrix approximation and a parallelized inference algorithm. We demonstrate HiTS's efficacy on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance and orders-of-magnitude speedup over existing GPR methods. Our approach enables accurate and efficient forecasting of high-dimensional time series data, with applications in areas such as finance, climate modeling, and healthcare.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-time Analytics in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and real-time analytics has led to an explosion in data volume and velocity, necessitating efficient query optimization techniques for NoSQL databases. This paper presents AQO, a novel adaptive query optimization framework for column-oriented NoSQL databases. AQO leverages machine learning-based workload forecasting and cost-based optimization to dynamically adjust query plans in response to changing workload patterns. Our experiments on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that AQO achieves up to 3x improvement in query performance and 2x reduction in latency compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph-Based Embeddings for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems often struggle with vocabulary mismatch between user queries and relevant documents. We propose a novel query expansion approach, 'MedGE', which leverages hierarchical graph-based embeddings to capture semantic relationships between medical concepts. Our method represents queries and documents as dense vectors in a shared semantic space, enabling more accurate matching and expansion. Experimental results on the TREC Medical Retrieval dataset show that MedGE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation with Incentive Mechanisms for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and fair distribution of tasks among agents. This paper proposes a novel cooperative task allocation framework that incorporates incentive mechanisms to motivate agents to participate and contribute to the system. We design a Vickrey-Clarke-Groves (VCG) based mechanism that ensures truthfulness and allocates tasks to agents based on their capabilities and preferences. Our approach is evaluated through simulations, demonstrating improved system efficiency and fairness compared to existing methods. The proposed framework has applications in various domains, including robotics, smart grids, and supply chain management.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a crucial AI capability. However, existing approaches often lack transparency and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable multimodal emotion recognition. HAN uses a modular design to learn hierarchical representations of emotions, allowing for the identification of salient features and modalities contributing to the recognition process. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate improved recognition accuracy and robustness, as well as meaningful attention patterns that provide insights into the emotional cues.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Existing neural ranking models for document retrieval often require substantial computational resources, limiting their applicability in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking framework, 'HiRank', which leverages a two-stage ranking architecture to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. The first stage employs a lightweight neural network to filter out irrelevant documents, while the second stage utilizes a more computationally expensive neural model to refine the ranking. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HiRank achieves comparable ranking performance to state-of-the-art models while reducing computational costs by up to 60%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various applications, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms with hierarchical representations to provide explainable DRL. We demonstrate that HAN improves the interpretability of DRL policies by highlighting critical state features and abstract representations that influence decision-making. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic control tasks show that HAN achieves competitive performance while providing actionable insights into the decision-making process.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Distributed Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Real-time resource allocation is a critical problem in many applications, including smart grids, traffic management, and cloud computing. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems using distributed reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, called 'DRIMA', leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture to enable agents to learn cooperative policies for resource allocation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DRIMA in a realistic simulation environment, showing significant improvements in response time, resource utilization, and overall system efficiency compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation approach that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn the complex interactions between agents and tasks. Our method, called Hierarchical Task Allocator (HTA), represents the agent-task graph as a hierarchical structure and uses GCNs to learn task embeddings that capture the dependencies between tasks. Experimental results on a simulated robot swarm scenario show that HTA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and communication overhead.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Elders: A Study on Voice-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the design of conversational interfaces for older adults, focusing on voice-based interaction. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, examining their experiences with existing voice assistants and identifying key usability challenges. Based on our findings, we propose a set of design guidelines for accessible conversational interfaces, including simplification of voice commands, explicit feedback mechanisms, and personalized error handling. Our study contributes to the development of more inclusive and supportive voice-based interfaces for older adults.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Sentence Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it directly affects the quality of retrieved documents. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion by leveraging neural embeddings to model sentence semantics. Our proposed method, 'NeuQE', uses a transformer-based architecture to learn contextualized embeddings of query terms and expands the query with semantically similar terms. Experimental results on the TREC datasets demonstrate that NeuQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, particularly in scenarios with limited query context, and improves the overall retrieval performance by 12% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Intent on Document Retrieval Performance in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The role of query intent in information retrieval systems has garnered significant attention in recent years. This study investigates the effects of query intent on document retrieval performance in modern search engines. We propose a novel intent-aware retrieval framework, which incorporates a deep learning-based intent detection module to classify queries into informational, navigational, or transactional categories. Experimental results on a large-scale query log dataset demonstrate that our approach yields significant improvements in precision, recall, and user satisfaction compared to traditional retrieval methods that ignore query intent.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Query Expansion in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but it can be computationally expensive and may not always improve retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion based on hierarchical document representation. We propose a multi-level document embedding model that captures both local and global semantic relationships between terms and documents. Our experiments on several standard IR datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Scalable and Secure Data Replication for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, distributed database systems face significant challenges in maintaining data consistency and ensuring high availability. This paper proposes a novel data replication scheme, 'RepliGuard', which leverages a combination of erasure coding and homomorphic encryption to achieve scalability and security. RepliGuard enables efficient data replication across geographically dispersed nodes while providing robust protection against data breaches and unauthorized access. Our experimental evaluation on a Apache Cassandra cluster demonstrates that RepliGuard outperforms existing replication schemes in terms of performance, security, and storage overhead.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Graph Neural Networks using Graph Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable performance in various graph-based applications. However, they are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can manipulate the graph structure to mislead the model. This paper proposes a novel detection mechanism, 'GAT-Guard', which leverages graph attention mechanisms to identify adversarial attacks on GNNs. We introduce a trainable attention module that focuses on suspicious nodes and edges, allowing the model to distinguish between genuine and tampered graph data. Experimental results on benchmarks demonstrate that GAT-Guard outperforms existing defense methods in detecting adversarial attacks with high accuracy and efficiency.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation mechanisms. This paper proposes an autonomous agent-based framework, 'AARA', that leverages multi-agent systems to optimize resource allocation in IoT networks. AARA employs a decentralized architecture, where agents representing IoT devices and network resources engage in negotiation-based decision-making. We introduce a novel utility function that incorporates device-specific QoS requirements, energy efficiency, and network latency. Simulation results demonstrate that AARA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of resource utilization, network throughput, and device satisfaction.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when queries are short or ambiguous. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, dubbed 'QDE', which selectively incorporates relevant contextual information into the document representation. QDE leverages a graph-based neural network to model the semantic relationships between query terms and document entities, thereby enriching the document's semantic space. Experimental results on the TREC-8 Ad-hoc dataset demonstrate that QDE significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, especially for difficult queries, achieving a 15% relative increase in mean average precision over state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Investigating the Effect of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of Virtual Reality (VR) technology, understanding user engagement is crucial for designing effective VR experiences. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, manipulating avatar personalization and task complexity. Results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, measured by time spent in the VR environment and self-reported enjoyment. Furthermore, we found that the effect of avatar personalization is more pronounced in complex tasks. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems, suggesting that incorporating personalized avatars can enhance user experience and motivation.

title: Gaze-Aware Adaptive Interfaces for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has immense potential for enhancing accessibility in various domains, including education and healthcare. However, existing VR systems often neglect the needs of users with disabilities, leading to a suboptimal experience. This paper presents a novel gaze-aware adaptive interface framework, 'GAIA', which utilizes machine learning-based gaze estimation to dynamically adapt VR content and interaction modalities to individual users' abilities. We evaluate GAIA through a user study involving participants with visual impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in navigation efficiency and overall user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Graphs
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but they struggle to capture complex patterns in dynamic graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages graph attention mechanisms at multiple scales to effectively model node representations in dynamic graphs. We introduce a hierarchical graph pooling strategy that adaptively selects the most informative nodes at each level, allowing HGAT to capture long-range dependencies and node correlations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art GNNs in node classification tasks, especially in scenarios with frequent graph topology changes.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of many information retrieval systems. While query expansion has been shown to improve retrieval effectiveness, existing methods often rely on hand-crafted features and heuristics. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, dubbed 'NeuroQE', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate context-aware query expansions. We demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in passage retrieval accuracy. Furthermore, we analyze the robustness of NeuroQE to query ambiguity and variability, showcasing its potential for real-world information retrieval applications.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized multi-agent planning framework that leverages hierarchical task networks (HTNs) to coordinate complex tasks among multiple agents. Our approach, called DeMA-HTN, introduces a distributed HTN representation that enables agents to reason about their local tasks and communicate with neighboring agents to resolve dependencies. We propose a hierarchical planning algorithm that iteratively refines the HTN structure to ensure consistency and optimality. Experimental results on a logistics domain demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of DeMA-HTN in solving large-scale planning problems with improved solution quality and reduced communication overhead.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for real-time traffic control. We propose a scalable architecture that leverages decentralized learning and communication protocols to enable efficient coordination among autonomous agents. Our approach, 'TrafficMAgent', incorporates graph neural networks to model complex traffic patterns and utilizes a hierarchical reinforcement learning strategy to optimize traffic flow. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulation demonstrate that TrafficMAgent outperforms state-of-the-art MARL methods in terms of reduce congestion and travel time.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Route Optimization
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) rely on efficient route planning to minimize travel time and energy consumption. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'RouteOpt', which leverages graph neural networks to learn optimal routing policies for AVs. We introduce a multi-agent environment that simulates real-world traffic patterns and demonstrate that RouteOpt outperforms traditional graph-based methods in terms of route efficiency and adaptability to changing traffic conditions. Experiments on a large-scale urban traffic dataset show that RouteOpt reduces average travel time by up to 23% compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings for Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in a text. Existing approaches suffer from scalability issues or rely on manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a novel graph-based embedding method, 'GraphED', which learns to represent entities and mentions in a shared vector space. By incorporating graph attention mechanisms and a novel graph-based objective function, GraphED achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while scaling to large knowledge graphs. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphED on a real-world knowledge graph with millions of entities.

title: Robustifying Deep Reinforcement Learning with Hindsight Experience Replay
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents often struggle with exploration-exploitation trade-offs and sample inefficiency. This paper introduces a novel experience replay mechanism, Hindsight Experience Replay (HER), which leverages hindsight knowledge to augment the agent's experience. By relabeling past experiences with the final outcome, HER enables the agent to learn from failed attempts and generalize to unseen situations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HER in various Atari games and a real-world robotic manipulation task, showcasing improved robustness and adaptability in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking Models with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model for efficient document retrieval, leveraging query expansion techniques to improve retrieval accuracy. Our approach, 'NeuRankEx', integrates a deep neural network with a query expansion module to capture nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. We evaluate NeuRankEx on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for ambiguous queries. Furthermore, we analyze the impact of query expansion on neural ranking models and provide insights into the optimization of hyperparameters for improved efficiency.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Adaptive Metrics
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification tasks require models to adapt quickly to new classes with limited data. This paper presents a novel deep meta-learning approach, 'TaskAware', which learns to adapt task-aware metrics for few-shot classification. Our method leverages a hierarchical neural network to learn a task-agnostic embedding space and a task-aware metric space. The task-aware metric space is adapted using a meta-learning objective that minimizes the classification loss on a few labeled examples. We evaluate TaskAware on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance and improved robustness to task variations.

title: Hierarchical Entity Disambiguation for Scalable Knowledge Graph Construction
paper_abstract: Large-scale knowledge graphs (KGs) are crucial for various AI applications, but their construction is hindered by the entity disambiguation problem. Existing approaches are limited by their inability to handle ambiguous entities with varying frequencies and contexts. We propose a hierarchical entity disambiguation framework, 'HEDGES', which leverages graph neural networks and hierarchical clustering to disambiguate entities at multiple scales. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the Wikidata5M benchmark, with a 22% increase in precision and 15% reduction in computational cost compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Chatbots: A Study on Emotional Expression and User Experience
paper_abstract: Chatbots have become ubiquitous in various domains, but their limited emotional expression can lead to user frustration and dissatisfaction. This study explores the impact of emotional expression on user experience in human-chatbot interactions. We designed and evaluated three chatbot prototypes with varying levels of emotional expression, from neutral to empathetic. Our findings suggest that chatbots with empathetic responses led to higher user satisfaction, trust, and perceived emotional support. We also identified cultural differences in user preferences for emotional expression in chatbots. This research contributes to the development of more inclusive and emotionally intelligent chatbots that cater to diverse user needs.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The rise of social media has made it challenging to combat fake news propagation. Existing detection methods often rely on handcrafted features or focus solely on textual information, neglecting the rich structural patterns present in news dissemination networks. We propose HAGCN, a novel hierarchical attention graph convolutional network that integrates node-level, community-level, and graph-level features to detect fake news. Our model leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant neighborhoods, enabling interpretable explanations for its predictions. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of HAGCN over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an F1-score improvement of 8.5% and 11.2%, respectively.

title: Scalable Incremental View Maintenance for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing requires efficient view maintenance to ensure timely analytics and reporting. This paper presents 'Riva', a novel incremental view maintenance approach that leverages a hybrid data structure combining in-memory caching and disk-based storage. Riva adaptively adjusts its maintenance strategy based on the arrival rate of new data and available system resources, achieving a 3x speedup over existing incremental view maintenance techniques. We evaluate Riva on a real-world IoT dataset and demonstrate its scalability and performance in supporting real-time analytics workloads.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient and adaptive control systems to navigate complex environments. This paper introduces 'HierRL', a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that leverages a two-level hierarchy of policies to control autonomous vehicles. The high-level policy selects a set of primitive actions, while the low-level policy executes these actions using a fine-grained control strategy.
