We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierRL in various driving scenarios, achieving improved performance and adaptability compared to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Meta-Learning Based Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Object Detection
paper_abstract: Object detection remains a fundamental problem in computer vision, but the quest for efficient models that balance accuracy and speed has led to a proliferation of architectural designs. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach to neural architecture search (NAS) for object detection, dubbed 'MetaOD'. By learning to adapt to diverse object detection tasks, MetaOD discovers efficient architectures that outperform state-of-the-art detectors on COCO and PASCAL VOC benchmarks. We demonstrate that our method reduces the search space by 3 orders of magnitude while achieving 2x faster inference times without compromising accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and graph-structured data. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to efficiently process graph data. HGAT adaptively focuses on relevant sub-graphs and meta-learns a robust feature extractor, enabling effective few-shot learning on large-scale graph datasets. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate HGAT's state-of-the-art performance and improved scalability compared to existing few-shot learning methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must allocate tasks to maximize global utility without centralized coordination. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We model the agent-agent and agent-task interactions as a graph and use GCNs to learn a robust and adaptive policy that can handle complex task dependencies and agent capabilities. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized allocation methods and achieves near-optimal performance.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. Existing methods often rely on centralized control or simplistic heuristics, which may not scale to large, heterogeneous teams. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn agent-agent and agent-task affinities. Our approach, called 'HetGNN', models the agent network as a heterogeneous graph and uses attention mechanisms to adaptively weigh the importance of different agents and tasks. Experimental results on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that HetGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, fairness, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their success heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. Unfortunately, this process is often time-consuming and computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization framework, 'HyperBO', which leverages a probabilistic search strategy to efficiently identify optimal hyperparameters. We introduce a new acquisition function that adaptively balances exploration and exploitation, leading to faster convergence and improved performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HyperBO outperforms existing tuning methods, including grid search and random search, while requiring significantly less computational resources.

title: Coordinated Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation is a key mechanism for resolving conflicts and achieving mutually beneficial agreements. However, in dynamic environments, agents must adapt to changing circumstances and re-negotiate to maintain cooperation. This paper presents a novel framework for coordinated negotiation strategies, incorporating machine learning-based opponent modeling and probabilistic planning. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated supply chain management scenario, showcasing improved negotiation outcomes and increased robustness to environmental changes.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution and network topology. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the distributed database system as a graph, where nodes represent data fragments and edges capture network connections. Our GNN-based query optimizer learns to predict optimal query plans by capturing complex patterns in the graph structure. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework that leverages deep graph reinforcement learning. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphMA', represents the agent-task graph as a dynamic relational structure and learns a policy that maximizes task completion while minimizing communication overhead. We demonstrate GraphMA's effectiveness in simulated environments and real-world robotics scenarios, showcasing improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: With the exponential growth of digital documents, efficient and accurate document retrieval has become a pressing need. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model (HNR) that leverages the strengths of both neural networks and traditional ranking models. HNR utilizes a hierarchical architecture to capture both local and global context, enabling more accurate document ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNR outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, while also providing insights into the importance of document structure in ranking.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Multi-Relational Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Graph embedding has emerged as a crucial technique for graph-structured data analysis. However, existing methods struggle to scale to large multi-relational graphs, which are common in real-world applications. This paper presents Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to learn distributed representations of nodes in multi-relational graphs. HGAT adaptively selects relevant relational contexts and incorporates them into a hierarchical representation, enabling efficient and effective embedding of large graphs. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods in terms of both scalability and performance.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: In cloud computing, efficient resource allocation is crucial for optimizing Quality of Service (QoS) and reducing costs. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, 'CloudAllocator', which learns to allocate resources in real-time based on dynamic workload patterns. We utilize a hybrid architecture combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to capture spatial and temporal dependencies in resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudAllocator outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods in terms of QoS satisfaction, resource utilization, and cost reduction.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated task allocation using graph-based reinforcement learning. We model the agent-task interaction as a graph and employ a decentralized Q-learning algorithm to learn optimal task assignments. Our approach leverages graph convolutional networks to capture structural dependencies between agents and tasks, enabling more effective coordination. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional auction-based methods.

title: Distributed Constraint Optimization using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed constraint optimization problems (DCOPs) using multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). We propose a framework that enables agents to learn cooperative policies to solve DCOPs in a decentralized manner. Our approach combines graph neural networks with deep Q-networks to learn effective communication and decision-making strategies. Experimental results on a set of benchmark DCOP instances demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Unsupervised Time Series Representation
paper_abstract: Unsupervised representation learning for time series data remains a challenging task. Existing methods often rely on simple aggregation operations or hand-crafted features, which may not capture complex temporal dependencies. We propose HiCLR, a hierarchical contrastive learning framework that leverages multi-scale temporal encodings to learn robust and informative representations. By contrasting local and global patterns, HiCLR encourages the model to discover meaningful structures and relationships in the data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HiCLR in improving clustering, classification, and anomaly detection performance.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized coordination framework for autonomous agents using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). We propose a novel HRL architecture that enables agents to learn both high-level goals and low-level actions in a decentralized manner, without requiring a centralized controller. Our approach leverages the concept of option learning to identify meaningful sub-goals and allocate tasks to individual agents. Experimental results in a simulated multi-agent environment demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized reinforcement learning methods in terms of coordination efficiency and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Enhancing Retrieval Effectiveness in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a neural query expansion (NQE) framework to enhance the retrieval effectiveness of ad-hoc search systems. We leverage a combination of word embeddings and neural language models to generate context-aware expansion terms that capture the semantic intent of the original query. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate that our NQE approach outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalised discounted cumulative gain.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents for Efficient Resource Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinating autonomous agents to efficiently allocate resources in dynamic environments. We propose a novel multi-agent framework, 'DynaAlloc', which integrates machine learning-based demand forecasting, decentralized decision-making, and real-time adaptation to environmental changes. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and optimize resource allocation. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that DynaAlloc outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of resource utilization, response time, and adaptability to changing demands.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Search Result Diversification
paper_abstract: Search result diversification is crucial for improving user satisfaction in information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep neural networks to generate diversified search results. Our model, called DivExpan, learns to identify relevant expansion terms by capturing semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. We employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the importance of different terms and phrases, enabling the model to adapt to varying query types and domains. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DivExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of search result diversity and relevance.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agent Teams using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in heterogeneous agent teams, where agents have diverse capabilities and tasks have varying requirements. We propose a decentralized approach based on distributed constraint optimization (DCOP), which enables agents to autonomously allocate tasks while respecting constraints and optimizing a global objective. Our DCOP-based framework, called HATOA, exploits the notion of 'virtual agents' to facilitate knowledge sharing and coordination among agents. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HATOA outperforms traditional centralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely heavily on effective query expansion techniques to bridge the vocabulary gap between users and documents. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages the ranking capabilities of deep neural networks to generate high-quality expanded queries. We propose a hierarchical neural model that captures both local and global contextual relationships between query terms and documents. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art query expansion methods, with an average precision gain of 12.5%.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Adaptive Metric
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning. Existing meta-learning approaches often rely on fixed metric spaces, which may not generalize well to novel tasks. This paper proposes a novel task-aware adaptive metric meta-learning framework, 'TAMM', which learns to adapt the metric space to each task. TAMM employs a neural network-based metric adapter that takes task embeddings as input and outputs a task-specific metric. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TAMM on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on few-shot image classification tasks. Furthermore, we show that TAMM can generalize to unseen tasks with limited labeled data.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing scale and complexity of modern database systems necessitate efficient query optimization techniques. This paper presents 'AQOra', a novel adaptive query optimization framework for distributed database systems. AQOra leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and dynamic plan refinement to optimize query execution plans in real-time. Our experimental evaluation on a large-scale distributed database cluster demonstrates that AQOra achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional query optimization techniques, while reducing optimization overhead by 40%

title: Efficient Tree-Structured Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Image Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-modal image classification tasks often involve processing large volumes of data from diverse sources. This paper proposes a novel tree-structured neural network (TNN) architecture, 'ModalTree', which adaptively selects and integrates feature representations from multiple modalities. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that learns to weight the importance of each modality and its corresponding feature extractors. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that ModalTree outperforms state-of-the-art fusion methods while reducing computational costs by up to 40%. We further analyze the interpretability of our approach, highlighting the efficacy of TNNs in identifying informative modalities for image classification.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Workload-Aware Partitioning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but query performance remains a major bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach, called AWAP, that adaptively partitions data across nodes based on workload characteristics. AWAP leverages online monitoring and machine learning-based prediction to dynamically adjust data distribution, reducing query latency and improving system throughput. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates up to 40% improvement in query performance compared to static partitioning schemes.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) are poised to revolutionize urban transportation, but their safe and efficient operation requires sophisticated coordination mechanisms. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MAV-Coord', for AV coordination in complex urban scenarios. MAV-Coord leverages graph neural networks to model inter-agent interactions and employs a novel, asynchronous Q-learning algorithm that adapts to dynamic environment changes. Experimental results on a large-scale, real-world traffic dataset demonstrate that MAV-Coord outperforms state-of-the-art, centralized approaches in terms of traffic flow efficiency and safety.

title: Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent from short, ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural query expansion (HNQE) approach that leverages both lexical and semantic relationships to generate more informative queries. Our HNQE model combines a graph-based keyword extractor with a contextualized language model to generate a set of expanded queries that better align with the user's information need. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, with an average increase of 23.5% in precision and 17.2% in recall over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Relevance Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture user intent, particularly when queries are short or ambiguous. This paper proposes a neural relevance modeling approach to query expansion, dubbed 'NeuQE'. By learning to predict relevance scores for candidate expansion terms, NeuQE dynamically adapts to the query context and document collection. Our experiments on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, with an average increase of 12.5% in mean average precision compared to state-of-the-art expansion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural search has shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks, but it often struggles with query formulation. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to improve the retrieval performance of neural search models. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroXPand', generates a set of expansion terms by analyzing the neural representations of top-ranked documents. We evaluate NeuroXPand on several TREC benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques. Our approach is computationally efficient and can be easily integrated into existing neural search pipelines.

title: Efficient Query Processing for Materialized Views in Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Materialized views (MVs) have been widely adopted in column-store databases to improve query performance. However, maintaining and querying MVs can be computationally expensive. This paper presents a novel approach, called 'MV-Opt', which leverages statistical models to predict the optimal query plan for MV maintenance and query processing. Our method considers the database workload, data distribution, and storage constraints to select the most efficient query plan. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that MV-Opt outperforms existing methods, reducing query latency by up to 50% and improving data freshness by up to 30%.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Adaptive Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has emerged as a crucial challenge in machine learning, where models must adapt to novel classes with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel deep meta-learning framework, 'AdaTask', which leverages adaptive task embeddings to effectively generalize to new tasks. Our approach integrates a meta-learner that generates task-specific embeddings, which are used to condition the base learner's weights. We demonstrate the efficacy of AdaTask on benchmark few-shot image classification datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing the need for extensive retraining.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Proactive Conflict Resolution using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, conflicts often arise due to differing goals or resource constraints. This paper proposes a novel framework for proactive conflict resolution using deep reinforcement learning. Our approach, 'ProCR', leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and anticipates potential conflicts. A deep Q-network is then employed to learn optimal conflict resolution strategies. We evaluate ProCR in a simulated traffic management scenario, demonstrating improved system efficiency and reduced conflicts compared to reactive conflict resolution methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of interpretability hinders its widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that provides explanations for DRL policies. Our approach integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to identify relevant state features, abstract representations, and action influences. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing improved transparency and controllability of the learned policies.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality Objects using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gaze-based interaction with augmented reality (AR) objects using deep learning. Our system, 'GazeAR', uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect and track the user's gaze, and a recurrent neural network (RNN) to predict the intended interaction with the AR object. We evaluate GazeAR on a dataset of 20 users interacting with 10 AR objects and demonstrate an average accuracy of 92.5% in intent recognition. Our approach enables intuitive and hands-free interaction with AR objects, and has applications in areas such as gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Data using Deep Autoencoders
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional data is a challenging task due to the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel deep autoencoder-based approach, 'HDAE', which leverages the power of hierarchical representations to identify anomalies. Our method uses a stacked denoising autoencoder to learn a robust and compact representation of the data, followed by a one-class SVM to detect anomalies. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HDAE on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of detection accuracy and F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to accurately capture users' search intent. We propose a novel approach, 'QL-Expander', which leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query expansion for improved retrieval performance. By formulating query expansion as a Markov Decision Process, our RL agent learns to select the most informative expansion terms that maximize the expected relevance of retrieved documents. Experimental results on the TREC Ad-hoc benchmark demonstrate that QL-Expander outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Hybrid Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years due to the growing need for transparency in AI-driven decision-making. This paper proposes a novel hybrid attentional graph neural network (HAGNN) framework that integrates graph convolutional networks (GCNs) with attention-based transformers for ERS. HAGNN leverages the strengths of both models to capture complex item relationships and user preferences, while providing interpretable explanations for its recommendations. Our extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HAGNN over state-of-the-art methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant barriers when interacting with technology. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of an adaptive gesture recognition system, ' GestureAid', designed to improve accessibility for users with varying levels of motor impairment. Our approach leverages machine learning to dynamically adjust gesture recognition thresholds based on user performance. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, including individuals with Parkinson's disease, cerebral palsy, and spinal cord injuries. Results show that GestureAid significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user experience, with 85% of participants reporting increased confidence in using gestural interfaces.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Virtual Reality-Based Learning Interfaces
paper_abstract: This study investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR)-based learning interfaces. We designed an immersive VR environment that simulates real-world physics and compared it to a traditional desktop-based interface. Our user study with 60 participants shows that the VR condition leads to improved understanding and retention of complex concepts in physics education. We also found that participants' body movements and gestures in the VR environment are positively correlated with their learning outcomes. Our findings have implications for the design of embodied VR-based learning interfaces that leverage the cognitive benefits of bodily engagement.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval often relies on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval performance. However, existing methods either rely on manually crafted rules or expensive neural models. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph (NQG) approach that learns to expand queries in a data-driven manner. Our NQG model incorporates both semantic and syntactic features of queries and documents, enabling more effective query expansion. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision (MAP) and normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG).

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Virtual Assistants in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for effective human-computer interaction (HCI) methods. This paper introduces 'GazeVA', a novel gaze-based interaction framework for virtual assistants in AR environments. GazeVA leverages machine learning-based gaze estimation and natural language processing to enable users to interact with virtual agents using only their gaze and voice commands. We evaluate GazeVA in a user study and demonstrate significant improvements in interaction efficiency and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based input methods.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Supervised Learning-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of information retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between user queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, 'SLQE', which leverages supervised learning to identify the most informative terms for expansion. We propose a neural network architecture that learns to predict the relevance of candidate expansion terms based on their semantic relationships with the original query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that SLQE outperforms traditional unsupervised expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Sentence Embeddings for Real-time Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Real-time information retrieval systems require efficient document filtering to reduce the latency and computational overhead of retrieving relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages sentence embeddings to filter out irrelevant documents. We introduce a hierarchical clustering algorithm that groups sentences based on their semantic meaning and uses a threshold-based filtering mechanism to eliminate non-relevant documents. Experimental results on the TREC dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves a significant reduction in latency while maintaining a high precision of retrieved documents.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but its lack of transparency hinders trust and adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to generate interpretable explanations for RL policies. By incorporating attention mechanisms at multiple levels, HAN identifies relevant state features and highlights critical decision-making steps. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate that HAN improves policy transparency while maintaining competitive performance with state-of-the-art RL algorithms.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Learning on Multimodal Data
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance on various multimodal tasks, but their lack of transparency hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) framework that integrates attention mechanisms across multiple modalities to provide insights into the decision-making process. We introduce a modular architecture that comprises modality-specific attention modules and a hierarchical fusion layer. Experiments on a benchmark multimodal dataset demonstrate that HAN improves model interpretability while maintaining competitive performance compared to existing multimodal fusion techniques.

title: Efficient Document Representation for Neural Information Retrieval using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) models rely on bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel neural IR approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to learn dense, contextualized document representations. Our method, 'KG-IR', integrates entity disambiguation and relation inference to encode documents as graph-based semantic vectors. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that KG-IR outperforms state-of-the-art neural IR models in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency, particularly for complex queries.

title: EmoReact: A Real-time Emotion-aware Chatbot for Mental Health Support
paper_abstract: This paper presents EmoReact, a real-time emotion-aware chatbot designed to provide personalized mental health support. EmoReact leverages multimodal sentiment analysis and emotional intelligence to recognize and respond to users' emotional states. We develop a novel affective computing framework that integrates natural language processing, computer vision, and machine learning to detect emotional cues from text, speech, and facial expressions. Our user study with 150 participants shows that EmoReact significantly improves users' self-reported emotional well-being and reduces feelings of loneliness and anxiety.

title: Affective Avatar-Based Feedback in Virtual Reality for Enhanced User Engagement
paper_abstract: This paper presents an innovative approach to user feedback in virtual reality (VR) environments, leveraging affective avatars to convey emotions and enhance user engagement. Our system, 'EmoAvatar', employs machine learning-based emotion recognition to generate personalized, empathetic responses from the avatar, fostering a sense of social presence and rapport-building. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that EmoAvatar significantly improves user satisfaction, self-reported emotional connection, and task performance in a VR-based learning scenario, compared to traditional, text-based feedback methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'RL-Allocator', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. RL-Allocator uses a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to learn both local and global reward functions, enabling agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that RL-Allocator outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized allocation methods, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reward-Shaping Functions
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper introduces a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reward-shaping functions to guide agent decision-making. We propose a novel reward function that incorporates both local and global task priorities, enabling agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their usability is limited for individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by impaired articulation, phonation, and fluency. This paper presents 'EasySpeak', a novel framework for designing accessible voice assistants that can accommodate the unique speech patterns of users with dysarthria. We conducted a user study with 20 participants to inform the design of EasySpeak, which incorporates personalized speech recognition, adaptive error correction, and speech output modification. Our results show that EasySpeak significantly improves the accuracy and efficiency of voice interactions for users with dysarthria, enhancing their overall user experience.

title: Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Augmented Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) systems often rely on gesture recognition to enable intuitive user interactions. However, existing approaches can be limited by their reliance on predefined gesture sets and lack of adaptability to individual users' needs. This paper presents 'GESTAR', a novel framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision to recognize and adapt to users' unique gestures in real-time. We evaluate GESTAR using a comprehensive dataset of gestures from diverse users, demonstrating significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, where query expansion techniques are often employed to improve the retrieval performance. This paper propose a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages the power of deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of queries and documents. Our approach utilizes a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query expansion and retrieval tasks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle to generalize to new classes with limited training data. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages both local and global feature representations to improve few-shot learning performance. Our approach adaptively selects the most relevant features and weights them according to their importance, resulting in improved classification accuracy and reduced computational overhead. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in both inductive and transductive few-shot learning settings.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the task allocation problem in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and resources need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a decentralized approach based on distributed constraint optimization, which enables agents to locally solve sub-problems and iteratively refine their solutions. Our method, called DCO-TA, leverages asynchronous communication and partial observability to scale to large systems. Experimental results on a realistic disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of DCO-TA in achieving near-optimal task allocations while adapting to dynamic environment changes.

title: Enriching Query Representations for Explainable Retrieval in E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: The lack of transparency in e-commerce search engines hinders users' trust and understanding of retrieval results. This paper proposes an explainable retrieval framework, 'Query2Vec+', which incorporates semantic and syntactic Knowledge Graph embeddings to enrich query representations. By learning to map queries to relevant product aspects, our approach generates interpretable explanations for retrieved products. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search accuracy and user satisfaction, while providing intuitive explanations for the retrieved products.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models in Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural passage retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often rely on simple keyword-based query representations, which may not capture the nuances of user queries. We propose a novel adaptive query expansion (AQE) framework that incorporates contextualized query embeddings and relevance feedback to refine the query representation. Our experiments on the MS MARCO passage ranking dataset demonstrate that AQE significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural models, especially for complex and ambiguous queries. We also analyze the impact of AQE on different types of queries and provide insights into its effectiveness.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing Using Column-Store Indexes
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for timely business decision-making. However, optimizing queries for low latency and high throughput remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'RtOpt', that leverages column-store indexes to accelerate query execution. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that considers both data storage and query patterns to select the most efficient indexing strategy. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RtOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in query response time while maintaining comparable storage overhead.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Accessible Virtual Reality using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have the potential to provide immersive experiences for people with disabilities. However, existing VR interfaces often rely on manual input, which can be challenging for individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for accessible VR, which leverages deep reinforcement learning to predict user intentions from eye movements. Our approach, 'GazeVR', uses a deep Q-network to learn a mapping between gaze patterns and desired actions in VR, eliminating the need for manual input. Experimental results demonstrate that GazeVR achieves high accuracy and user satisfaction in a range of VR tasks, including object manipulation and navigation.

title: Intelligent Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Distributed Smart Grids
paper_abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed energy resources in smart grids necessitates efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper proposes an intelligent agent-based framework for optimal resource allocation in distributed smart grids. The framework utilizes a multi-agent system, where each agent represents a distributed energy resource, and employs a decentralized decision-making approach based on reinforcement learning. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves significant improvements in grid stability, reduces energy losses, and enhances overall system efficiency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their usability for elderly users with cognitive impairments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an inclusive voice assistant that accommodates the needs of this population. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with mild cognitive impairment, identifying three key design principles: simplification of voice commands, provision of visual feedback, and incorporation of cognitive aids. We implemented these principles in a prototype voice assistant and evaluated its effectiveness in a controlled experiment. Results show significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing commercial voice assistants.

title: Robust Transfer Learning for Low-Resource Language Models via Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Pre-trained language models have achieved state-of-the-art results in various natural language processing tasks. However, their performance degrades significantly when fine-tuning on low-resource languages. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, 'MetaTune', which enables robust transfer learning for low-resource language models. By learning to adapt to new languages and tasks, MetaTune improves the model's ability to generalize across languages and achieves better performance on downstream tasks. We evaluate MetaTune on several low-resource languages and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving language model performance.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper presents a novel adaptive query expansion approach, dubbed AQE-DNN, which leverages deep neural networks to learn the optimal expansion strategy. AQE-DNN employs a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes the query representation, expansion term selection, and ranking functions. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AQE-DNN outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Swarm Robotics using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Swarm robotics has numerous applications in search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and agriculture. However, task allocation in such systems remains a challenging problem, particularly in dynamic and uncertain environments. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'MARL-TA', enables individual robots to learn cooperative strategies for task allocation through self-organization and adaptation. We evaluate MARL-TA using a simulated search and rescue scenario and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition is a challenging task in computer vision, where the goal is to classify actions from 3D skeletal data. Existing methods struggle to model complex relationships between joints and capture long-range dependencies. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant joints and hierarchically aggregate features from local to global levels. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an accuracy improvement of 3.5% on average.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel hierarchical neural ranking model for efficient document retrieval. Our approach leverages a multi-level representation of documents, where coarse-grained topic models are used to filter out irrelevant documents, followed by fine-grained neural ranking models to re-rank the remaining documents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and accuracy compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models. Furthermore, we analyze the impact of different hierarchical structures on retrieval performance and provide insights for future research.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but their performance degrades when faced with limited labeled data. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN architecture, HAGNet, which leverages the hierarchical structure of graph data to adaptively focus on relevant nodes and features. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art results on several benchmarks, even when only a few labeled nodes are available. We provide theoretical insights into the effectiveness of hierarchical attention and demonstrate HAGNet's robustness to varying graph structures and node degrees.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for multi-modal emotion recognition in human-robot interaction. Our approach leverages facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions in real-time. The HAN architecture incorporates a modality attention mechanism to dynamically weigh the importance of each modality and a hierarchical attention layer to capture both local and global dependencies between modalities. Experimental results on the SEMAINE dataset demonstrate improved emotion recognition accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art multi-modal fusion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, but often struggle with suboptimal query representations. This paper presents a novel query expansion method, CLQE, which leverages contrastive learning to learn a dense representation of queries and documents. By training a neural network to contrast positive and negative samples, we can generate effective query expansions that improve the retrieval performance of neural search engines. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset show that CLQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management systems require efficient decision-making strategies to optimize traffic flow and minimize congestion. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'SMART', which enables scalable and decentralized control of autonomous vehicles. SMART leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic dynamics and incorporates a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to facilitate cooperation among agents. Our experiments on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that SMART outperforms traditional traffic management approaches, reducing travel times by up to 30% while improving safety and reducing emissions.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in urban traffic management using hierarchical reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'Traffic Hierarchies' (TH), leverages a hierarchical architecture to decompose the complex traffic management problem into smaller, manageable sub-problems. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates both local and global traffic metrics, enabling agents to learn effective coordination strategies. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that TH outperforms traditional decentralized approaches, achieving significant reductions in travel time and congestion.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Node-Level Vulnerability Analysis
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have demonstrated remarkable performance in various graph-based tasks. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks has received limited attention. This paper investigates node-level vulnerabilities in GNNs, proposing a novel attack framework, 'NodeFool', which perturbs node features to deceive GNN predictions. We analyze the attack's effectiveness on several benchmark datasets, revealing that NodeFool can significantly degrade GNN performance. Furthermore, we develop a defense mechanism, 'GraphShield', which incorporates adversarial training and graph attention to improve GNN robustness against node-level attacks.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Usability Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in older adults' daily lives, but their usability and accessibility remain a concern. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the design of inclusive voice assistants for older adults. We conducted interviews, surveys, and usability testing with 30 participants aged 65+, identifying key challenges and preferences. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and concise voice feedback, intuitive command structures, and personalized assistance. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating more accessible and user-friendly voice assistants, which can improve the overall experience and independence of older adults.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) over knowledge graphs (KGs) requires capturing complex relationships between entities. Existing KG embedding methods struggle to scale to large graphs and often neglect the role of entity types in MHQA. This paper presents 'TypeHop', a novel KG embedding framework that leverages entity type information to learn more expressive and efficient representations. TypeHop consists of a hierarchical entity type encoding scheme and a knowledge graph attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant entities and relations during question answering. Experiments on popular MHQA benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in accuracy and inference time compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data processing. However, query optimization in DDS remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query execution plans based on feedback from the DDS environment. Our approach, called QOpt-RL, leverages a combination of exploration-exploitation strategies and graph neural networks to model the query optimization problem. Experimental results on a real-world DDS benchmark show that QOpt-RL outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in cloud computing is a complex problem that requires efficient optimization. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework to tackle this problem. Our approach uses a high-level policy to allocate resources to different applications, and a low-level policy to optimize the allocation within each application. We introduce a novel reward function that balances resource utilization and application performance. Experimental results on a real-world cloud computing dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of resource efficiency and application performance.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning with Adaptive Attention for Medical Image Classification
paper_abstract: Medical image classification tasks often suffer from limited annotated data, necessitating few-shot learning approaches. We propose a hierarchical few-shot learning framework, 'HFA', which leverages adaptive attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant regions of interest. Our method consists of a meta-learning phase, where a shared attention module is learned across multiple tasks, and a fine-tuning phase, where task-specific attention weights are adapted. We evaluate HFA on three medical image datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in classification accuracy over existing few-shot learning methods, particularly when faced with scarce annotated data.

title: Query-Dependent Sentence Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional sentence embeddings often rely on static representations, which may not effectively capture the nuances of ad-hoc queries. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QDSE', which generates query-dependent sentence embeddings by incorporating query-aware attention mechanisms. Our method leverages a neural ranking model to learn a joint representation space for queries and sentences, enabling more accurate retrieval results. Experimental evaluations on the TREC-8 and Robust-04 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for queries with ambiguous or nuanced semantics.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems struggle to accurately retrieve relevant documents due to the complexity of medical terminology and the scarcity of annotated data. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'MedQN', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of medical concepts. MedQN integrates a pre-trained language model with a domain-specific knowledge graph to generate high-quality expansion terms, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that MedQN outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision.

title: Eye-Gaze Based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment in Gamified Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Gamification has emerged as a promising approach to enhance learner engagement in educational settings. However, static difficulty levels can lead to boredom or frustration, negatively impacting learning outcomes. This paper presents 'GazeDiff', an eye-gaze based system that dynamically adjusts game difficulty in real-time, responding to learners' cognitive states. Our approach leverages machine learning models to analyze pupil dilation, fixation duration, and saccade velocity, correlating these metrics with learner performance and affective states. A user study involving 40 participants demonstrates that GazeDiff significantly improves learning outcomes, learner satisfaction, and overall gaming experience.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Multimodal Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MIR) has become increasingly important with the growth of multimedia data. While query expansion techniques have shown promise in improving MIR effectiveness, they often neglect the contextual information of the query. In this paper, we propose a context-aware query expansion framework that incorporates both visual and textual features of the query. Our approach leverages a graph-based neural network to model the relationships between query keywords and their corresponding visual concepts. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art MIR methods, especially in scenarios with ambiguous queries.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases with multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) enable high concurrency and low latency, but pose significant query optimization challenges. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCC-OPT', which leverages a cost-based approach to optimize query execution plans for MVCC-enabled distributed databases. We introduce a probabilistic model to estimate the likelihood of version conflicts and develop a dynamic optimization strategy that adaptively adjusts to workload changes. Experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system shows that MVCC-OPT reduces query latency by up to 35% and improves throughput by up to 25% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval (IR) systems often rely on dense document representations to facilitate efficient query processing. This paper introduces a novel query-adaptive document embedding technique, 'QADE', which leverages contextualized language models to adaptively encode documents based on the query semantics. Our approach exploits the attention mechanism to focus on query-relevant document regions, resulting in more accurate and efficient retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and speed compared to state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults, who may struggle with complex language interactions. This paper presents a participatory design study involving 20 older adults, exploring the challenges and opportunities of voice assistant design for this demographic. We identify key design recommendations, including simplified language processing, personalized feedback mechanisms, and multimodal input support. Our findings inform the development of inclusive voice assistants that can enhance the daily lives of older adults, fostering independence and social connection.

title: Towards Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making via Causal Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Explainability in multi-agent systems is crucial for trust and accountability. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CausalGraphX', which integrates causal graph attention mechanisms into deep reinforcement learning to enable interpretable decision-making in complex multi-agent scenarios. We demonstrate that CausalGraphX outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various cooperative and competitive domains, providing insights into agent interactions and causal relationships. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as autonomous vehicles and smart grids, where explainability is paramount.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component in many natural language processing applications, including question answering and text summarization. However, existing methods often rely on computationally expensive dense representations, which can limit their scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document representation (HDR) framework, which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to encode documents at multiple granularities. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HDR achieves state-of-the-art passage retrieval performance while reducing computational costs by up to 50% compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Pseudo-Relevant Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have revolutionized the field of information retrieval, but their performance can be limited by the quality of the training data. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to query expansion using pseudo-relevant feedback, which leverages the model's own predictions to generate additional training data. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroExp', iteratively refines the query representation by incorporating feedback from the top-ranked documents. Experiments on several standard benchmarks demonstrate that NeuroExp significantly improves the retrieval performance of state-of-the-art neural models, often outperforming traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of cooperative task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and limitations need to collaborate to achieve a common goal. We propose a distributed reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task allocation in a decentralized manner. Our approach leverages a novel combination of actor-critic methods and graph neural networks to model the complex interactions between agents and tasks. Simulation results on a variety of scenarios demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized planning methods and achieves near-optimal performance in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalized Accessibility Features for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their usability and accessibility limitations can alienate older adults. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create personalized accessibility features for voice assistants, catering to the diverse needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving surveys, interviews, and usability testing with 30 older adults, identifying key design recommendations for improved accessibility. Our proposed framework, 'VoiceEase', incorporates adaptable speech recognition, simplified command structures, and multimodal feedback mechanisms, resulting in a 35% reduction in error rates and a 25% increase in user satisfaction.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a user-centered design approach for developing accessible gesture-based interfaces tailored to older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving co-design workshops, user testing, and survey questionnaires to identify the needs and preferences of our target population. Our proposed interface, 'EasyGesture', incorporates a range of adaptations, including personalized gesture recognition, error correction mechanisms, and real-time feedback. Evaluation results show that EasyGesture significantly improves the usability and accessibility of gesture-based interfaces for older adults with motor impairments, enabling them to interact more confidently and effectively with digital systems.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need to design intuitive interfaces for older adults. Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have shown promise in facilitating natural human-computer interaction, but their impact on cognitive load is not well understood. This study investigates the effect of ECAs on cognitive load in older adults using a mixed-methods approach. We developed an ECA-based system for completing daily tasks and evaluated its effectiveness in reducing cognitive load compared to a traditional graphical user interface. Results show that the ECA-based system significantly reduced cognitive load and improved user satisfaction, suggesting a promising avenue for designing accessible interfaces for older adults.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential growth in time-series data, straining the capabilities of traditional database systems. This paper presents a novel indexing scheme, 'ChronoHash', designed for real-time time-series data in distributed database systems. ChronoHash leverages a combination of hash-based and tree-based indexing to achieve efficient query processing and data ingestion rates. Our experiments on a 100-node cluster demonstrate that ChronoHash outperforms existing indexing schemes by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of data ingestion throughput.

title: Multi-Modal Fusion for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) has witnessed significant advancements with the advent of deep learning models. However, these models often lack transparency and interpretability, making it challenging to understand their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel multi-modal fusion framework, 'XplainVQA', which integrates visual, linguistic, and cognitive modalities to provide explainable VQA. We introduce a hierarchical graph attention mechanism that captures complex relationships between image regions, question keywords, and answer choices. Extensive experiments on the VQA-X and COCO-QA datasets demonstrate that XplainVQA achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful explanations for its predictions.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Disabilities: A Multimodal Interaction Framework
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their interfaces often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents 'AccessibleVoice', a multimodal interaction framework that enables users with disabilities to interact with voice assistants using alternative input methods, such as gaze-based, gesture-based, or text-based inputs. We propose a novel interaction model that combines machine learning-based intent recognition with rule-based error handling to improve the accuracy and robustness of the system. A user study with 30 participants with disabilities demonstrates that AccessibleVoice significantly enhances user experience and satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning (MTL) has become increasingly popular in deep learning, as it enables models to leverage shared knowledge across related tasks. However, existing MTL approaches often suffer from task interference, where the performance of one task deteriorates due to the presence of other tasks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that mitigates task interference by adaptively allocating attention weights to different tasks. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art MTL methods in terms of overall performance and task-specific accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems Using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query performance is crucial in distributed database systems. Traditional query optimizers rely on rule-based or cost-based approaches, which can be ineffective in complex distributed settings. This paper proposes a machine learning-based approach, 'ML-QO', that leverages query execution time and resource utilization data to predict optimal query plans. We develop a novel graph neural network architecture that captures query structure and database schema information, outperforming state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of execution time and resource efficiency. Experimental evaluations on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate the efficacy of ML-QO in improving query performance.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate task allocation among agents. We propose a decentralized framework, 'CATALYST', which enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach uses a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a deep Q-network to optimize task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that CATALYST outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Chatbots: A Study on Personalization and Emotional Feedback in Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their ability to provide emotional support and personalized experiences remains limited. This study explores the effects of emotional feedback and personalization on user experience in chatbots. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, using a novel chatbot prototype that incorporates emotional intelligence and personalization features. Results show that personalized chatbots with emotional feedback mechanisms lead to increased user satisfaction, trust, and self-disclosure. Our findings inform the design of more inclusive and empathetic conversational interfaces, highlighting the importance of emotional intelligence in human-chatbot interactions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems have become ubiquitous, but their opacity hinders trust and understanding. This work proposes 'HAGN', a novel hierarchical attention graph neural network architecture that incorporates item relationships and user preferences to generate personalized recommendations. HAGN's attention mechanism enables explainability by identifying influential items and aspects in the recommendation process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGN on three real-world datasets, showcasing improved recommendation accuracy and enhanced explainability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Vehicle Fleets using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle fleets are becoming increasingly prevalent, but efficient task allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for task allocation in autonomous vehicle fleets. Our approach, 'MAVEN', leverages graph neural networks to model the complex interactions between vehicles and tasks, and employs a decentralized actor-critic algorithm to learn optimal task allocation policies. Experimental results on a real-world transportation dataset demonstrate that MAVEN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, travel time, and overall system efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on User Experience and Error Recovery
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by difficulties in user interaction and error recovery. This study investigates the design of inclusive voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, exploring their experiences with a customized voice assistant prototype. Our results highlight the importance of intuitive error recovery mechanisms, clear feedback, and personalized assistance. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating more accessible and usable voice assistants, which can enhance the quality of life for older adults.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT using Graph-based Deep Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices has introduced new challenges in anomaly detection and fault diagnosis. This paper proposes a novel graph-based deep learning framework, 'GraphAD', which leverages the structural dependencies between IIoT devices to identify real-time anomalies. We design a graph attention mechanism that integrates device-level features with graph topology, enabling the detection of complex anomalies that evade traditional machine learning approaches. Experimental results on a large-scale industrial dataset demonstrate that GraphAD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and latency.

title: Graph-Based Indexing for Scalable RDF Query Processing
paper_abstract: The growing adoption of RDF data has created a need for efficient query processing techniques. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, called GRIN, which leverages the structural properties of RDF graphs to accelerate query execution. GRIN constructs a hierarchical index that captures the relationships between RDF triples, enabling efficient query routing and optimization. Our experiments on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that GRIN outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 3x speedup in query response time and 2x reduction in memory usage.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Deep Clustering for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Unsupervised anomaly detection in time series data is a challenging task, particularly when dealing with high-dimensional and noisy data. In this paper, we propose a novel deep clustering approach, HATS, that leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to identify anomalous patterns. HATS consists of two modules: a hierarchical attention module that captures complex temporal dependencies and a clustering module that groups similar time series segments. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATS outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to noise.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
