paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a challenging task that requires integrating information from multiple modalities, such as speech, text, and vision. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAN) architecture that leverages graph-based representations to model complex relationships between modalities. Our approach incorporates attention mechanisms to selectively focus on salient features and adaptively weight modality-specific contributions. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate significant improvements in multi-modal emotion recognition accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Online Learning of Hierarchical Task Models using Deep Imitation
paper_abstract: Hierarchical task models have emerged as a powerful framework for modeling complex tasks in AI systems. However, learning these models from demonstrations is challenging, especially in online settings where new tasks and demonstrations arrive continuously. We propose a novel approach, Deep Imitation Learning of Hierarchical Tasks (DILT), that leverages deep neural networks to learn hierarchical task models from demonstrations. DILT uses a hierarchical Variational Autoencoder to learn a compact representation of tasks and a policy network to infer the task hierarchy. We evaluate DILT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to efficiently learn hierarchical task models in online settings, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving optimal performance. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn agent-specific policies. Our approach, dubbed 'TaskDRL', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to enable agents to learn from their local observations and communicate with each other through a sparse, delayed communication network. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TaskDRL in a variety of scenarios, including dynamic task arrival and departure rates, and show that it outperforms traditional, centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system efficiency.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Healthcare Communication
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have shown promise in healthcare communication, but their design often neglects the needs of marginalized populations. This paper presents a framework for designing inclusive ECAs that accommodate diverse abilities, languages, and cultural backgrounds. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants from underrepresented groups, revealing key design principles for ECAs that promote trust, understanding, and empathy. Our findings inform the development of a novel ECA prototype, 'HealthPal', which demonstrates improved user engagement and satisfaction in healthcare consultations.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Adaptive Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, finding efficient paths while avoiding collisions remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel algorithm, Adaptive Hierarchical Clustering for Multi-Agent Pathfinding (AHC-MAP), which leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to reduce the dimensionality of the search space. Our method adaptively adjusts the clustering granularity based on the agents' proximity and velocity, allowing for real-time path planning in large-scale scenarios. Experimental results on simulated urban environments demonstrate significant improvements in computational efficiency and collision avoidance rates compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: As graph databases continue to grow in scale, query optimization becomes a critical bottleneck. Existing techniques struggle to handle the complexity of distributed graph queries, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DynaGO', which leverages machine learning to predict query execution plans for distributed graph databases. DynaGO uses a graph neural network to learn a probabilistic model of query execution costs and adapts to changing data distributions. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that DynaGO achieves up to 3x improvement in query performance compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Gaze-Informed Multimodal Fusion for Enhanced Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling computers to adapt to users' affective states. This paper presents a novel gaze-informed multimodal fusion approach that combines eye-tracking, facial expressions, and speech signals to recognize emotions. Our method leverages a graph-based attention mechanism to selectively weigh the contributions of each modality, based on the user's gaze patterns. Experimental results on a multimodal emotion dataset demonstrate improved recognition accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods, with potential applications in affective computing, virtual reality, and mental health monitoring.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Network-based Language Models
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods rely on hand-crafted features and suffer from semantic gap issues. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Neural Network-based Language Model (HNN-LM) for efficient document retrieval. Our approach leverages pre-trained language models to learn hierarchical document representations, capturing both local and global contextual information. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HNN-LM on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our model also enables interpretable query-document matching, facilitating explainable IR.

title: Embodied Cognition-Inspired Gesture Recognition for Enhanced Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Traditional gesture recognition systems rely on machine learning algorithms that focus on hand or body pose features. However, embodied cognition theory suggests that gestures are deeply rooted in cognitive processes, such as attention and intention. This paper presents a novel gesture recognition framework that incorporates cognitive models to better understand user intentions. Our approach leverages multimodal sensor data, including EEG, eye-tracking, and kinematic data, to recognize gestures in a more human-centered way. Experimental results show that our embodied cognition-inspired system achieves higher accuracy and robustness in recognizing gestures compared to state-of-the-art machine learning-based approaches.

title: Optimizing Query Execution Plans for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for distributed relational databases. We design a reinforcement learning framework that learns to select the optimal execution plan by interacting with the database environment and receiving rewards based on query performance. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular in modern data management systems, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to optimize query plans for distributed databases. We develop a neural network-based model that learns to predict optimal query plans based on historical query execution data. Our approach reduces the query optimization time by up to 75% compared to traditional cost-based optimization methods, while maintaining comparable query performance. We evaluate our approach on a real-world distributed database system and demonstrate its scalability and efficiency.

title: EyeGazeAnalytics: A Novel Framework for Inferring User Intent from Gaze Patterns in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need to develop more intuitive and human-centered interfaces. In this paper, we propose EyeGazeAnalytics, a novel framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to infer user intent from gaze patterns in VR. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to model the relationships between gaze behavior, user goals, and task context. We evaluate EyeGazeAnalytics on a large-scale dataset of VR user interactions and demonstrate significant improvements in intent recognition accuracy and latency compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data analysis. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper introduces HiGAT, a novel hierarchical graph attention network that leverages a coarse-to-fine node representation strategy to reduce computational costs. By iteratively applying graph attention mechanisms at multiple scales, HiGAT learns to focus on relevant nodes and their relationships, leading to improved classification performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiGAT achieves state-of-the-art results with significant speedups over existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) faces a long-standing challenge of inadequate query representations, leading to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQE', that leverages deep neural networks to learn query expansion strategies. We design a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query representation, term weighting, and relevance ranking. Experimental results on standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in autonomous vehicle control, where trust and transparency are essential. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based reinforcement learning framework, 'HAT-RL', which learns to focus on relevant features and provide interpretable decisions. HAT-RL integrates a hierarchical attention mechanism into a deep reinforcement learning architecture, enabling the model to selectively attend to relevant sensor inputs and provide explicit explanations for its decisions. Experimental results on a realistic autonomous driving simulator demonstrate that HAT-RL achieves improved performance and provides more interpretable decisions compared to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods.

title: Autonomous Agent Coalition Formation for Decentralized Task Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created new opportunities for decentralized task allocation. However, existing approaches often rely on centralized control or simplistic heuristics, leading to suboptimal performance and limited scalability. This paper presents a novel framework for autonomous agent coalition formation, enabling decentralized task allocation in IoT networks. Our approach leverages multi-agent systems and distributed constraint optimization to facilitate the formation of coalitions that maximize utility while respecting resource constraints. Experimental results demonstrate improved task allocation efficiency and robustness in simulated IoT scenarios.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Queries using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: With the proliferation of multi-modal data, there is a growing need for efficient and effective retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for retrieving relevant documents from large-scale collections in response to multi-modal queries. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms at multiple levels to capture intricate relationships between query components and document features. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: An Exploratory Study on User Experience
paper_abstract: The widespread adoption of voice assistants has transformed the way people interact with technology. However, older adults often face significant barriers when using these systems, resulting in decreased accessibility and adoption. This paper presents an exploratory study investigating the user experience of older adults with voice assistants. We conducted in-depth interviews and usability testing with 20 participants aged 65-85, identifying key challenges and design opportunities. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and consistent feedback, personalized customization, and multimodal interaction. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating more inclusive voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Cognitive Load and Error Recovery
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a human-centered study on the impact of cognitive load on users with visual impairments when interacting with voice assistants. We developed a novel error recovery framework that incorporates personalized feedback and adaptive prompting, reducing cognitive load and improving task completion rates. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that our approach significantly outperforms existing error recovery mechanisms, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in voice assistant development.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the task allocation problem in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and constraints need to collaborate to achieve complex tasks. We propose a novel decentralized algorithm, 'ATAH', which leverages a combination of graph-based methods and constraint programming to efficiently allocate tasks to agents. Our approach takes into account the agents' capabilities, workload, and communication constraints to minimize the overall system latency and maximize task completion rates. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of ATAH compared to existing centralized and decentralized approaches.

title: Robustifying Vision Transformers with Adversarial Training for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Vision transformers have shown promising results in image classification tasks, but their robustness against adversarial attacks remains a concern, particularly in safety-critical applications like autonomous vehicles. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'AdviT', which leverages a surrogate loss function to robustify vision transformers against a wide range of attacks. Our method involves generating adversarial examples using a dynamic perturbation strategy and incorporating them into the training process. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that AdviT significantly improves the robustness of vision transformers against both white-box and black-box attacks, while maintaining state-of-the-art performance on clean images.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of coordinating autonomous agents in dynamic environments. We propose a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MA-RL-Coor', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies that adapt to changing environmental conditions. MA-RL-Coor integrates a decentralized actor-critic architecture with a communication mechanism that allows agents to share local observations and coordinate their actions. Experimental results in a simulated robotic soccer environment demonstrate that MA-RL-Coor outperforms existing decentralized and centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and adaptability to environmental changes.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a fundamental problem in many applications, where each instance is associated with multiple labels. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in this task, but they often neglect the hierarchical structure of the label space. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that incorporates label relationships into the graph attention mechanism. HGAT uses a hierarchical graph to model the label space, where each node represents a label and edges capture their semantic relationships. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in multi-label classification tasks.

title: Decentralized Cooperative Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Platooning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle platooning has the potential to significantly improve traffic efficiency and safety. This paper presents a decentralized cooperative multi-agent reinforcement learning (DCMRL) framework for platooning, where each vehicle learns to coordinate with its neighbors to achieve optimal speed and distance control. Our approach leverages a novel combination of graph neural networks and decentralized Q-learning to enable real-time decision-making in a distributed manner. Experimental results demonstrate that DCMRL outperforms traditional centralized and rule-based approaches in terms of fuel efficiency, stability, and adaptability to changing traffic conditions.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar-Based Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has emerged as a promising technology for immersive learning experiences. However, user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatar-based feedback on user engagement in VR learning environments. We designed and implemented a novel feedback system that incorporates real-time user performance data and personalized avatar expressions. Our user study involving 120 participants showed significant improvements in user engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to traditional feedback methods. The results suggest that personalized avatar-based feedback can be an effective strategy for enhancing user experience in VR learning environments.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 60 participants, using a novel avatar creation system that incorporates facial recognition and machine learning-based character generation. Our results show that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, improved sense of presence, and enhanced overall VR experience. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR-based applications in fields such as education, healthcare, and entertainment.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities face significant challenges when interacting with gesture recognition systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive gesture recognition systems that can accommodate diverse motor abilities. Our approach combines machine learning with participatory design methods to develop personalized gesture models that adapt to an individual's unique motor characteristics. We evaluate our system with 15 participants with varying levels of motor impairment, demonstrating significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction. Our findings have important implications for the development of inclusive HCI systems that can be used by people with motor disabilities.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities and the system's global objective. Our approach uses a multi-agent deep Q-network to learn the optimal task allocation policy, taking into account the agents' dynamics and the environment's uncertainty. Experimental results on a simulated robotic system demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion time and system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Reasoning for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent systems, where decisions are often made by autonomous entities. We propose a novel hierarchical reasoning framework, HREM, that integrates symbolic reasoning with probabilistic graphical models to provide transparent and justifiable decision-making in multi-agent environments. HREM enables agents to reason about context-specific goals, intentions, and causal relationships, and generates natural language explanations for their decisions. We demonstrate HREM's effectiveness in a simulated smart home scenario, where it outperforms traditional decision-theoretic approaches in terms of explainability and decision quality.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering for Multimodal Data using Deep Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multimodal data, which combines different data types such as images, text, and audio, has become increasingly prevalent in various applications. However, existing clustering algorithms struggle to handle such data due to the challenges of integrating heterogeneous features and scaling to large datasets. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'Deep Hierarchical Fusion' (DHF), which leverages deep embeddings to integrate multimodal features and enables efficient clustering through a scalable, distributed framework. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DHF in discovering meaningful clusters and outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings for Noisy Databases
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in data integration, but existing approaches struggle with noisy databases. This paper presents a novel graph-based embedding approach, called 'GDE', which leverages both entity relationships and attribute similarities to disambiguate entities. GDE employs a scalable, distributed framework that can handle large, noisy datasets. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that GDE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5% and reducing computational time by 30%. Our approach has significant implications for data quality and integration in various domains.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Temporal Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex, time-evolving relationships. However, optimizing queries for real-time analytics on these databases remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'Tempo', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and graph summarization techniques. Tempo outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization, as demonstrated on a real-world social media graph dataset.

title: Co-Designing Tangible Interfaces for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
paper_abstract: This paper presents a participatory design approach to creating tangible interfaces for children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). We collaborated with children with ASD, their caregivers, and clinicians to co-design a set of interactive, modular blocks that facilitate social skills training and emotional regulation. Our user study with 20 children with ASD shows that the tangible interface significantly improved their engagement and ability to recognize and express emotions, compared to traditional screen-based interventions. We contribute a design framework for tangible interfaces that prioritize the needs and preferences of children with ASD, and discuss implications for future HCI research in this area.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph Neural Networks for Robust AI Systems
paper_abstract: As AI systems become increasingly prevalent, they are vulnerable to sophisticated adversarial attacks that can manipulate their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel graph neural network (GNN) based approach for detecting adversarial attacks on AI systems. Our method, 'GNN-Defense', leverages graph-based representations of AI models and their inputs to identify anomalous patterns indicative of attacks. Experimental results on a range of AI models and datasets demonstrate that GNN-Defense outperforms state-of-the-art detection methods, achieving an average detection accuracy of 95.2% across various attack scenarios.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Improving Short-Text Retrieval in E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: Short-text queries are ubiquitous in e-commerce search, but their brevity often leads to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion framework that leverages product metadata, user behavior, and query intent to generate more informative queries. Our approach incorporates a graph-based method to model the relationships between query terms, products, and users, and a reinforcement learning strategy to optimize the expansion process. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in recall and precision over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Multimodal Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MMIR) systems are increasingly important for effective search and filtering of multimedia content. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'MMRank', which combines visual and textual features to improve retrieval performance. We introduce a multimodal fusion layer that adaptively weighs and combines the output of separate visual and textual encoders, allowing the model to capture complex relationships between modalities. Experimental results on a large-scale MMIR benchmark dataset demonstrate that MMRank outperforms state-of-the-art models while requiring fewer parameters and computations.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of web data has led to an explosion in the number of documents searched by modern search engines. Query expansion techniques can improve retrieval effectiveness, but they often suffer from high computational costs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HQE', that leverages both semantic and syntactic features to generate relevant expansion terms. HQE uses a graph-based approach to model query-document relationships, allowing for efficient pruning of irrelevant terms and reduction of computational overhead. Experimental results on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: EyeGazeLens: A Gaze-Driven Interface for Efficient Information Visualization
paper_abstract: Information visualization is crucial for decision-making, but traditional interfaces can be cumbersome and slow. We introduce EyeGazeLens, a novel gaze-driven interface that leverages eye-tracking technology to enable users to efficiently explore and interact with visualizations. Our approach uses machine learning to predict the user's gaze patterns and adaptively adjust the visualization to minimize visual clutter and maximize information discovery. Evaluation results show that EyeGazeLens reduces interaction time by 35% and improves user satisfaction compared to traditional mouse-based interfaces.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have transformed human-computer interaction, but users with motor impairments often face difficulties using these systems. This paper proposes an adaptive gesture recognition framework that learns to recognize gestures from users with varying abilities. Our approach leverages machine learning to identify patterns in gesture data and adjusts the recognition model in real-time. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with motor impairments and demonstrated a significant improvement in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction. Our system has the potential to enhance the accessibility and inclusivity of HCI systems for users with motor impairments.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on effective query representation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach to query expansion, leveraging semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between query terms. Our method, termed GraphExp, constructs a query graph from a knowledge base and applies graph convolutional networks to learn dense representations of query terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphExp outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for ambiguous and rare queries, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have become ubiquitous in various applications, but understanding human emotions in multimodal interactions remains a challenging task. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that jointly learns verbal and non-verbal cues from audio, text, and vision inputs. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention layers and a fusion module that adaptively weighs the importance of each modality. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal emotion recognition dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 12.5%.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Coordination for Autonomous Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized multi-agent coordination framework for autonomous urban traffic management. Our approach leverages distributed constraint optimization techniques to enable real-time communication and decision-making among autonomous vehicles, traffic signals, and roadside infrastructure. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework in reducing congestion, travel times, and emissions through extensive simulations on a realistic urban traffic network. Moreover, we provide theoretical guarantees on the stability and convergence of the proposed algorithm under various network topologies and traffic scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Efficient Query Expansion in Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in search engines to improve retrieval performance. However, existing methods often rely on term co-occurrence statistics or knowledge graphs, which can be computationally expensive and prone to overfitting. We propose a novel approach, HierDoc, which leverages hierarchical document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between documents and queries. By representing documents as hierarchical compositions of semantic concepts, we enable efficient query expansion through a combination of semantic matching and relevance feedback. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their usability for older adults with cognitive impairments remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an inclusive voice interface, 'EASE', tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults with cognitive impairments, revealing key challenges and design recommendations. EASE incorporates features such as simplified language, visual cues, and personalized feedback, resulting in improved task completion rates and user satisfaction. Our findings have implications for the development of more accessible and supportive voice-based systems for vulnerable populations.

title: Embodied Avatars for Enhancing Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown immense potential for remote social interactions, but users often report feeling disconnected from others. This paper presents an embodied avatar system, 'AvatarPlus', which incorporates subtle nonverbal cues and personalized gestural behaviors to enhance social presence in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating that AvatarPlus significantly improves perceived co-presence, social bonding, and overall VR experience. Our findings have implications for designing more engaging and empathetic virtual social interactions.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in ad-hoc retrieval for improving the retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages the semantic representation capabilities of deep neural networks. NeuroQE uses a multi-task learning framework to jointly learn query and document representations, enabling the model to capture complex contextual relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media has severe consequences for individuals, businesses, and society as a whole. Existing detection methods rely on handcrafted features or deep learning models that lack interpretability. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multiple modalities (text, images, and user metadata) to detect fake news. Our HAN architecture consists of modality-specific attention modules that learn to weigh the importance of each modality and a hierarchical fusion module that combines the modality-specific representations. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale dataset and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy, F1-score, and explainability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) approach that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to provide transparent and interpretable recommendations. HGAT models user-item interactions as a hierarchical graph, allowing it to capture complex relationships between items and users. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing explainable recommendations. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as personalized advertising and customer service chatbots.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Cooperative learning in multi-agent systems is challenging due to partial observability and high-dimensional state spaces. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information from their local observations and communicate effectively with teammates. Our HAN-based approach outperforms existing methods in various cooperative tasks, achieving improved convergence speeds and higher reward rates. We also provide theoretical analysis on the attention mechanism, demonstrating its role in reducing the complexity of the joint policy space.

title: Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series Data using Graph-Based Autoencoders
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series data is a challenging task, particularly when labeled data is scarce. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised approach, GraAE, which leverages graph-based autoencoders to identify anomalies in multivariate time series data. We represent the time series data as a graph, where each node corresponds to a variable and edges represent correlations between variables. The autoencoder is trained to reconstruct the graph, and anomalies are detected by identifying nodes with high reconstruction errors. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraAE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and speed.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have made significant progress in generating coherent responses, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that not only improves response generation but also provides interpretable explanations for the model's decisions. Our HAN model captures contextual dependencies at multiple scales, enabling it to highlight relevant input segments and generate attention-based explanations. Experimental results on two benchmark dialogue datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in producing accurate and interpretable responses.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy has become a prevalent deployment model for cloud-based database systems, where multiple tenants share the same database instance. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge due to the varying workload patterns and resource constraints of each tenant. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MTQO', which leverages machine learning-based predictive modeling to anticipate workload patterns and dynamically adjust query optimization strategies. We evaluate MTQO on a real-world multi-tenant database system and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and resource utilization compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Older Adults: A Human-Centred Approach to Healthcare Support
paper_abstract: This paper presents a human-centred design approach to developing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) for supporting older adults in healthcare settings. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults, caregivers, and healthcare professionals to identify the key requirements for ECAs in this domain. Our findings highlight the importance of empathy, trust, and personalisation in ECA design. We propose a novel ECA framework that incorporates these factors, and evaluate its effectiveness in a pilot study with older adults. The results show significant improvements in user engagement, satisfaction, and health outcomes. Our work contributes to the development of more effective and user-friendly ECAs for healthcare support.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning on Multimodal Data
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has seen significant advances in recent years, but most methods rely on single-modal data and are limited by their inability to effectively leverage multimodal information. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) framework that learns to integrate information from multiple modalities and adapt to new tasks with limited labeled data. HiGAT consists of a hierarchical graph attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and a meta-learning strategy that enables fast adaptation to new tasks. Experimental results on several multimodal benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of HiGAT in few-shot learning scenarios, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by a significant margin.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on effective query expansion techniques to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepExpan', which leverages deep learning-based document embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. We introduce a neural network architecture that jointly learns document and query representations, enabling the generation of context-aware expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key challenges and preferences. Our findings inform the development of a novel voice assistant framework that incorporates age-related adaptations, such as acoustic models tailored to older adults' speech patterns and a simplified dialogue flow. A pilot study with 20 older adults demonstrates improved user experience and task completion rates compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Graph-based Attention Mechanism
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but its lack of transparency hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel graph-based attention mechanism, dubbed GRAFT, to enhance the explainability of RL agents. By modeling the agent's observation space as a graph, GRAFT selectively focuses on relevant state features and their relationships, thereby providing insights into the decision-making process. We evaluate GRAFT on a suite of Atari games and demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to existing RL methods.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries on Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: Distributed column-stores have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large datasets. However, optimizing query performance for multi-dimensional range queries remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'Hyperion', which leverages a combination of statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to efficiently prune the search space. We introduce a novel cost model that accurately estimates the execution time of range queries and demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing optimization techniques. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that Hyperion achieves an average speedup of 3.2x over state-of-the-art query optimization methods.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MAS) is a complex task, especially in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel decentralized reinforcement learning (DRL) approach, 'HetMAS-DRL', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies without explicit communication. We introduce a graph-based attention mechanism that allows agents to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and adapt to changes in the environment. Experimental results on a variety of MAS scenarios demonstrate that HetMAS-DRL outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized learning methods in terms of coordination efficiency and adaptability.

title: Gaze-Based Cognitive Load Detection for Intelligent Tutoring Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent tutoring systems (ITS) can benefit from accurate cognitive load detection to provide personalized support. This paper presents a novel gaze-based approach that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to detect cognitive load in real-time. We developed a wearable eye-tracking device and collected a dataset of gaze patterns from students performing math problems. Our proposed model, 'GazeLearn', achieves a detection accuracy of 87.5% and outperforms state-of-the-art methods. We also demonstrate the feasibility of integrating GazeLearn with an ITS to provide adaptive feedback and improve learning outcomes.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Recognition for Adaptive User Interfaces
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to recognizing users' intentions from their gaze patterns, enabling the development of adaptive user interfaces that can dynamically adjust to users' goals. We propose a deep learning-based model that combines convolutional and recurrent neural networks to analyze eye-tracking data and infer user intentions. Our approach is evaluated on a dataset of 30 participants performing various tasks on a desktop computer, achieving an accuracy of 87.5% in intention recognition. The results demonstrate the potential of gaze-based intention recognition for enhancing user experience and improving interface adaptability.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Domain-Specific Search Engines
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines cater to users seeking information within a specific domain, requiring efficient and accurate retrieval. This paper proposes a hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages domain knowledge to generate context-dependent query terms. HQE integrates a probabilistic topic model with a hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify relevant sub-domains and expand the query accordingly. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, achieving a 25% increase in precision and a 30% reduction in query latency compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Multi-agent decision-making systems require interpretable models that can capture complex relationships between agents and their environments. We propose a novel heterogeneous graph attention network (HGAN) framework that integrates agent-centric and graph-centric representations to facilitate explainable decision-making. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents, objects, and context, enabling the model to provide transparent and interpretable outputs. Experimental results on a real-world autonomous vehicle dataset demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of decision accuracy and explainability.

title: Investigating the Effects of Haptic Feedback on Cognitive Load in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: This study explores the role of haptic feedback in alleviating cognitive load in virtual reality (VR)-based learning environments. We conducted a user study with 40 participants, who completed a series of tasks in a VR-based educational platform with and without haptic feedback. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly reduces cognitive load, as measured by electroencephalography (EEG) and self-reported metrics. Furthermore, we found that haptic feedback improves learning outcomes, particularly for complex tasks. Our findings have implications for the design of VR-based educational systems, highlighting the importance of incorporating haptic feedback to enhance user experience and learning effectiveness.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, where the join order enumeration problem is a major bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to optimize join order enumeration. We introduce a deep Q-network-based agent that learns to select the optimal join order by interacting with the database system. Our approach, called 'RLJOIN', outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and reduces the number of unnecessary joins. We evaluate RLJOIN on a real-world dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving query performance.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Entity Disambiguation in Large-Scale Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation (ED) is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches suffer from poor scalability and high latency. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'RT-Index', designed for real-time ED in large-scale knowledge graphs. RT-Index leverages a combination of graph partitioning, entity embedding, and hierarchical indexing to enable efficient querying and disambiguation. Experimental evaluations on the YAGO and DBpedia datasets demonstrate that RT-Index improves query response times by up to 5x and achieves competitive disambiguation accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Networks
paper_abstract: Node classification in dynamic networks is a challenging task due to the evolving graph structure and node features. Existing methods often fail to capture the complex relationships between nodes and their temporal dependencies. We propose a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that integrates node, edge, and graph-level attention mechanisms to learn a hierarchical representation of nodes. Our model adaptively selects the most informative neighbors and time steps to update node representations, achieving state-of-the-art performance on several real-world datasets. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in node classification tasks, particularly in scenarios with sparse and noisy data.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Stochastic Optimization
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper proposes a novel stochastic optimization framework for task allocation, which leverages the concepts of Markov decision processes and policy gradient methods. Our approach, called 'Dec-TAM', enables agents to learn optimal task assignments in a distributed manner, without relying on centralized coordination or explicit communication. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that Dec-TAM outperforms existing decentralized algorithms in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient task allocation strategies to coordinate their actions in complex urban environments. This paper proposes a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-TA', which enables distributed task allocation among autonomous vehicles. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates both local and global task dependencies, allowing agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion efficiency and reduced communication overhead.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but their computational complexity hinders scalability to large graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that reduces computational overhead while maintaining accuracy. HGAN employs a hierarchical clustering scheme to group nodes into clusters, followed by attention-based feature aggregation at each level. We demonstrate the efficacy of HGAN on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant speedups over existing GNN models while maintaining competitive performance.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on public roads necessitates efficient coordination mechanisms to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph attention to model complex interactions between AVs and their environment. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphMA', learns to optimize a set of decentralized policies that adapt to changing traffic conditions, incorporating both local and global information. Simulation results demonstrate that GraphMA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in reducing congestion, travel times, and accidents in various urban scenarios.

title: Improving Retrieval Efficiency with Hierarchical Query Expansion for Neural Search
paper_abstract: Neural search models have shown significant improvements in retrieval performance, but their computational overhead hinders their deployment in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-NS', that reduces the number of neural model invocations while maintaining retrieval effectiveness. HQE-NS leverages a multi-level representation of the query, iteratively expanding it using a combination of lexical and semantic techniques. Experiments on several benchmarks demonstrate that HQE-NS achieves significant efficiency gains, with an average reduction of 35% in neural model invocations, while retaining 95% of the original retrieval performance.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Participatory Study on Accessibility Features for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have transformed the way we interact with technology, but their potential benefits are often inaccessible to older adults. This paper reports on a participatory design study involving 20 older adults with diverse abilities, aiming to co-create accessible voice assistant features. We identified three key themes: personalized voice profiles, multimodal feedback, and contextual assistance. Our findings inform the development of inclusive voice assistants that cater to the unique needs of older adults, enhancing their autonomy and quality of life. We propose a set of design guidelines for accessible voice assistants, emphasizing the importance of user-centered design in HCI research.

title: Gesture-Based Authentication for Accessible Virtual Reality Systems
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems are increasingly being adopted for various applications, but their accessibility for users with disabilities remains a concern. This paper presents ' GestureKey', a novel gesture-based authentication system designed for accessible VR systems. GestureKey leverages machine learning algorithms to recognize and classify hand gestures, providing an alternative to traditional password-based authentication methods. Our evaluation with 20 participants, including those with motor disabilities, shows that GestureKey achieves high recognition accuracy (>95%) and usability, making it a promising solution for inclusive VR experiences.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents require accurate emotion recognition to provide empathetic and personalized responses. This paper introduces HANER, a hierarchical attention network that integrates acoustic, linguistic, and visual features to recognize emotions in multi-modal conversations. HANER employs a dynamic attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each modality based on the conversation context. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that HANER outperforms state-of-the-art methods in emotion recognition accuracy, especially in ambiguous or noisy conversations.

title: Efficient Join Order Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used to manage large-scale datasets. However, optimizing join orders in DDS remains a challenging problem due to the added complexity of data distribution and communication costs. This paper proposes a novel join order optimization algorithm, 'DJOpt', which leverages a combination of graph-based and machine learning techniques to efficiently explore the join order search space. DJOpt is designed to minimize both computational and communication costs, and experimental results on a real-world DDS testbed demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Dynamic Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem that arises in various applications, including autonomous vehicles, smart grids, and robotics. This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating multi-agent systems using dynamic partially observable Markov decision processes (D-POMDPs). Our approach leverages a hierarchical decomposition of the problem space, allowing agents to reason about their local observations and coordinate with other agents to achieve global objectives. We provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed framework and demonstrate its effectiveness in a simulated traffic management scenario, showing improved coordination and reduced congestion compared to existing methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems. We consider a scenario where agents with different capabilities and resources need to be assigned tasks with varying requirements. Our approach, based on distributed constraint optimization, allows agents to negotiate and allocate tasks without relying on a centralized authority. We introduce a novel heuristic for estimating the task allocation quality and demonstrate its effectiveness in simulations with varying numbers of agents and tasks. Our results show that the proposed framework achieves near-optimal task allocation while reducing communication overhead by up to 50% compared to existing decentralized methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous urban traffic management poses a complex problem of coordinating multiple agents to optimize traffic flow. This paper proposes a decentralized, reinforcement learning-based framework, 'CATS', that enables autonomous vehicles to learn cooperative policies for traffic signal control. We introduce a novel, attention-based mechanism that allows agents to share knowledge and adjust to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that CATS reduces congestion by 23% compared to traditional, rule-based traffic signal control systems.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-MA', which enables scalable and adaptive task allocation among agents. HRL-MA combines high-level planning with low-level execution, leveraging a hierarchical abstraction of the task space to reduce the complexity of the allocation problem. We evaluate HRL-MA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Environments
paper_abstract: As robots become increasingly integrated into our daily lives, effective human-robot collaboration is crucial. This paper investigates the role of embodiment in virtual environments on human-robot collaboration. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, who interacted with a robot in a virtual environment with varying levels of embodiment. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to improved collaboration outcomes, including reduced task completion time and increased user satisfaction. We also found that users' perceived trust in the robot and their sense of presence in the virtual environment are significant predictors of collaboration success. The implications of our findings for the design of virtual human-robot collaboration systems are discussed.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on efficient control systems to navigate complex scenarios in real-time. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'Hierarchical Autonomous Control' (HAC), which leverages a multi-level decision-making process to balance exploration and exploitation. HAC integrates a high-level policy network with a low-level control module, enabling the vehicle to adapt to changing environments while maintaining stability and safety. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAC in a simulated urban driving scenario, achieving improved control performance and reduced computational overhead compared to existing reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Virtual Reality Head-Mounted Displays
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) head-mounted displays (HMDs) have become increasingly popular, but their security remains an open challenge. This paper presents a novel gaze-based authentication system for VR HMDs, leveraging the unique characteristics of human eye movements to verify user identities. Our approach combines machine learning-based gaze pattern recognition with visual attention modeling to achieve high accuracy and robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that our system can detect and prevent unauthorized access with a mean detection rate of 95.2% and a false acceptance rate of 2.5%. We discuss the implications of our work for enhancing the security and trustworthiness of VR applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely heavily on effective query representation to retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach for query expansion, dubbed 'NeuroQE'. NeuroQE learns to predict context-aware query terms by modeling the semantic relationships between query keywords and the document collection. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, including RM3 and PRF, in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain. Furthermore, we show that NeuroQE can be seamlessly integrated into existing retrieval systems, making it a practical solution for real-world applications.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation is a crucial mechanism for agents to reach mutually beneficial agreements. However, existing negotiation strategies are often limited to static environments and assume complete information about other agents' preferences. This paper proposes a decentralized negotiation framework, 'DynaNego', which enables agents to adapt to dynamic environments and incomplete information. DynaNego incorporates a novel uncertainty-aware utility function and a probabilistic opponent modeling technique, allowing agents to make informed decisions and improve negotiation outcomes. We evaluate DynaNego in a simulated smart grid scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving efficient and fair resource allocation.

title: Hashed Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: As main-memory database systems become increasingly prevalent, optimizing query processing has become a crucial challenge. This paper proposes a novel hashed indexing technique, ' QuickHash', which leverages the properties of modern CPU architectures to accelerate query execution. QuickHash utilizes a combination of hash functions and cache-friendly data structures to minimize memory accesses and reduce query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that QuickHash outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3.5x, while maintaining comparable storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis has become increasingly important in understanding user opinions and preferences. However, existing methods often struggle to handle multi-modal data, where text, images, and audio are intertwined. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that effectively integrates and weighs the contributions of different modalities. HGAT uses a hierarchical fusion mechanism to learn modality-specific and shared representations, and incorporates graph attention to model relationships between modalities. Experimental results on a newly curated multi-modal dataset demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12% improvement in sentiment classification accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Column-Oriented Database Systems
paper_abstract: Column-oriented database systems have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to efficiently process analytical queries. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'COLOPT', which leverages statistical models to predict the most efficient query execution plan. Our approach takes into account the columnar storage layout and the underlying hardware architecture to minimize I/O overhead and maximize CPU utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that COLOPT outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 50% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Graph-based recommendation models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various domains. However, their lack of interpretability hinders their adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages attention mechanisms to provide insights into the recommendation process. HGAT consists of two stages: a local attention module that captures item relationships and a global attention module that aggregates user preferences. Experimental results on three benchmarks demonstrate that HGAT outperforms existing graph-based models while providing interpretable recommendations through visualized attention patterns.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Agents: A Study on User Experience and Emotional Intelligence
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have become ubiquitous in human-computer interaction, but their design often neglects the emotional and social nuances of human communication. This study investigates the impact of emotional intelligence on user experience with conversational agents. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment with 120 participants, using a chatbot that exhibited varying levels of emotional intelligence. Our results show that agents with higher emotional intelligence led to increased user satisfaction, trust, and empathy. We also identify key design principles for inclusive conversational agents, including contextual understanding, affective feedback, and personalized support. Our findings have implications for the development of more empathetic and effective human-agent interactions.

title: Distributed Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the problem of distributed negotiation in multi-agent systems where agents possess incomplete information about the environment and each other's preferences. We propose a novel negotiation strategy, 'INFORM', which integrates probabilistic modeling of agent preferences with iterative negotiation protocols. INFORM enables agents to learn from each other's actions and update their beliefs about the negotiation space, thereby improving the likelihood of reaching mutually beneficial agreements. We evaluate INFORM through extensive simulations, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving higher social welfare and individual utilities compared to existing state-of-the-art negotiation strategies.

title: Decentralized Planning for Multi-Agent Systems via Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In distributed multi-agent systems, planning and decision-making require coordinating actions among agents to achieve a common goal. This paper presents a decentralized planning framework that leverages distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to solve the planning problem. We propose a novel DCOP algorithm that enables agents to communicate and negotiate with each other to find a feasible plan, while respecting local constraints and minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results on a logistics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms centralized planning methods in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient decision-making to achieve global objectives. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for distributed task allocation, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communicates with neighboring agents to achieve global coordination. We introduce a hierarchical policy representation that separates task allocation from execution, enabling agents to adapt to changing environments and task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized methods in terms of task completion rate and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Re-ranking for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a fundamental challenge in information retrieval (IR). This paper proposes a novel neural re-ranking approach, dubbed 'NeuQE', which leverages query expansion to improve retrieval effectiveness. NeuQE combines a neural query expansion module with a re-ranking model that learns to predict the relevance of documents based on their semantic similarity to the expanded query. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 and ClueWeb09 datasets demonstrate that NeuQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques and achieves state-of-the-art performance.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This study investigates the design of gestural interfaces that cater to older adults with motor impairments. We developed a novel gesture recognition system that incorporates machine learning-based gesture filtering and adaptive gesture segmentation. Our user study with 20 older adults with Parkinson's disease shows that our system reduces gesture recognition errors by 35% compared to a baseline system. We also present a set of design guidelines for accessible gestural interfaces, emphasizing the importance of flexibility, adaptability, and feedback. Our work contributes to the development of more inclusive and supportive interaction technologies for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Emotional Avatar-Based Mediation for Conflict Resolution in Virtual Teams
paper_abstract: Virtual teams are increasingly prevalent, but conflict resolution remains a significant challenge. This paper presents an emotional avatar-based mediation system, 'EmpathyBot', designed to facilitate constructive conflict resolution in virtual teams. EmpathyBot leverages affective computing and social learning theories to create personalized avatars that reflect users' emotional states, enabling more effective empathy and understanding. Our user study with 30 virtual teams shows that EmpathyBot significantly improves conflict resolution outcomes, reduces conflict escalation, and enhances team satisfaction.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for traffic management using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). We propose a two-level HRL framework, where the high-level policy learns to allocate tasks to agents, and the low-level policy learns to execute tasks in a decentralized manner. Our approach is evaluated on a realistic traffic simulation environment, demonstrating significant improvements in traffic flow and reduction in congestion compared to traditional optimization methods. We also analyze the robustness of our approach under varying traffic conditions and agent failures.

title: Gaze-Based Intent Recognition for Intelligent Wheelchair Navigation
paper_abstract: Individuals with mobility impairments often rely on wheelchairs for daily navigation. This paper presents a novel gaze-based intent recognition system for intelligent wheelchair navigation. We propose a deep learning model that leverages electrooculography (EOG) signals and computer vision techniques to predict the user's intended direction. Our approach integrates a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a long short-term memory (LSTM) network to learn spatiotemporal patterns in EOG data. Experimental results demonstrate that our system achieves an average accuracy of 92.5% in recognizing user intent, outperforming existing methods and enabling more efficient and independent wheelchair navigation.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient coordination among agents to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn cooperative task allocation strategies. Our method, called GraphTask, represents the agent-task graph as a neural network and learns to predict optimal task assignments based on agent capabilities and task requirements. We evaluate GraphTask on a suite of benchmark problems and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead compared to traditional approaches.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Augmented Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) systems have become increasingly popular, but their user interfaces often rely on indirect input methods, such as controllers or voice commands. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interfaces for AR, where users interact with virtual objects using their gaze. We designed and evaluated a gaze-based AR system, examining both user experience and performance metrics. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can improve user engagement and reduce task completion time, especially for complex AR tasks. We also identify key challenges and limitations, including accuracy and calibration issues, and discuss implications for future AR interface design.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Multimodal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal dialogue systems, which combine speech, text, and vision, have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction. However, the design of effective visualizations for these systems remains an open challenge. This paper presents a novel framework for adaptive visualization in multimodal dialogue systems, which leverages machine learning to dynamically adjust the visualization strategy based on the user's preferences, goals, and interaction history. We evaluate our approach through a user study and demonstrate improved user engagement, task performance, and overall experience.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it can significantly impact the retrieval accuracy. Traditional query expansion methods rely on term co-occurrence statistics, which may not capture the nuanced relationships between terms in a query. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CAQE', which leverages context-aware embeddings to model the semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness.
