title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Empirical Study on Accessibility Features for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by accessibility barriers. This study investigates the impact of accessibility features on the usability of voice assistants for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, aged 65-85, using a customized voice assistant with varying levels of accessibility features. Our results show that features like voice.commands, screen reader integration, and simplified dialogue flows significantly improve task completion rates and user satisfaction. We provide design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants and discuss implications for future research.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Semantic Embeddings for Effective Query Expansion in Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between queries and relevant documents. Existing QE methods often rely on shallow semantic representations, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper presents a novel QE approach that leverages hierarchical semantic embeddings (HSE) to effectively capture the nuanced relationships between query terms and their expansions. Our proposed method, dubbed HSE-QE, recursively applies a graph-based neural network to encode the semantic hierarchy of the query and its expansions, resulting in more accurate and diverse expanded queries. Experimental results on several TREC benchmarks demonstrate the superiority of HSE-QE over state-of-the-art QE techniques.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Crowd Simulation for Emergency Evacuation Planning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel autonomous agent-based crowd simulation framework for emergency evacuation planning. Our approach leverages decentralized decision-making and real-time sensor data to simulate the complex behaviors of individuals in emergency scenarios. We propose a hybrid architecture that combines rule-based and machine learning-based agent decision-making, enabling more realistic and adaptive crowd simulations. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing evacuation times and improving safety in various emergency scenarios.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) has gained increasing attention in recent years, but existing methods struggle to effectively fuse and align multimodal features. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for MSA, which leverages self-attention mechanisms to learn modality-specific and cross-modal representations. Our HAN consists of a feature-level attention module, a modality-level attention module, and a sentiment fusion module. Extensive experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in sentiment accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Imbalanced Datasets using Adaptive Sampling
paper_abstract: Imbalanced datasets pose significant challenges to clustering algorithms, often leading to biased or inaccurate results. This paper introduces 'AdapCluster', a novel hierarchical clustering approach that leverages adaptive sampling to address class imbalance. By dynamically adjusting the sampling rate based on local density estimates, AdapCluster effectively reduces the impact of class imbalance and improves clustering quality. Experiments on several real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of AdapCluster over existing methods, achieving improved precision and recall for minority classes.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years due to their ability to provide transparency into the decision-making process. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical graph attention (HGA) framework that leverages both user-item interactions and item attributes to generate personalized explanations. Our approach utilizes a multi-layer graph attention mechanism to capture complex relationships between items and users, resulting in more accurate and interpretable recommendations. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGA in improving recommendation quality and explanation fidelity.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems have revolutionized real-time analytics by providing low-latency query execution. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'RTOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cardinality estimation and cost modeling to identify the most efficient query plans. Our approach incorporates a feedback loop that continuously refines the optimization process based on runtime query statistics. Experimental results on a popular real-time analytics benchmark demonstrate that RTOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query response time.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Explainable Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on machine learning models to make critical decisions, but these models are vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This paper presents a novel approach to detect such attacks using explainable reinforcement learning. Our method, 'Explain2Detect', integrates a reinforcement learning framework with model interpretability techniques to identify suspicious input patterns. We evaluate Explain2Detect on a simulated autonomous driving environment and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting targeted attacks while maintaining a low false positive rate. Our approach provides a promising direction for enhancing the security and reliability of autonomous vehicles.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval due to the limited context and ambiguity of query terms. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks, which learns to generate relevant expansion terms from a large corpus of text data. Our model, called DeepQE, incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Co-Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by impaired articulation, often face difficulties interacting with voice-based interfaces. This paper presents a co-design approach to create more accessible and usable voice-based interfaces for this population. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with individuals with dysarthria, caregivers, and speech therapists to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the development of a novel speech recognition system that incorporates personalized acoustic models, adaptive error correction, and multimodal feedback mechanisms. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in speech recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural retrieval Models using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but often struggle with lexical mismatch between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages contrastive learning to learn semantic relationships between words. Our method, CLQE, uses a contrastive objective to train a dense vector space, where semantically similar words are pulled closer together, and dissimilar words are pushed apart. We demonstrate that CLQE improves the retrieval performance of neural models, especially for queries with low term frequency, and outperforms traditional query expansion methods. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets show significant improvements in terms of nDCG and ERR metrics.

title: Query Term Importance Estimation using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to rank documents according to their relevance to a user's query. A crucial component of effective retrieval is estimating the importance of each query term. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QTI-Net', which leverages deep neural networks to learn query term importance from a large corpus of labeled data. QTI-Net consists of a term encoder, a query encoder, and a relevance predictor, which are jointly trained to optimize retrieval performance. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QTI-Net significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including those based on traditional term weighting schemes and learning-to-rank models.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Join Reordering
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in these systems. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach for join reordering, which reduces the query execution time by minimizing the communication overhead between nodes. Our approach leverages graph theoretical concepts to model the join dependencies and develop an efficient reordering algorithm. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing join reordering techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality Using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) systems require intuitive interaction modalities to enhance user experience. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction approach, leveraging deep neural networks to estimate user intent. Our method, 'Gaze2Action', utilizes a convolutional neural network (CNN) to analyze eye movement patterns and predict the desired action. We also introduce a transfer learning framework that adapts the model to individual users, improving accuracy and reducing calibration time. Experimental results demonstrate that Gaze2Action outperforms existing gaze-based interaction methods in AR environments, achieving an average accuracy of 92.5%.

title: Exploiting Hierarchical Embeddings for Efficient Document Retrieval in Large-Scale Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing scale of modern information retrieval systems necessitates the development of efficient document retrieval methods. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical embeddings to capture the semantic structure of documents. Our method, dubbed 'HierRet', employs a multi-level clustering scheme to reduce the dimensionality of the embedding space, thereby facilitating faster retrieval times. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HierRet achieves a significant reduction in retrieval latency while maintaining comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Co-Design Approach
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults, but existing VR interfaces often pose significant accessibility barriers. This paper presents a participatory co-design approach to developing accessible VR interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with 15 older adults and 5 VR designers, resulting in the development of 12 interface design guidelines. We evaluated these guidelines through a usability study with 20 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction. Our approach provides a foundation for designing inclusive VR interfaces that can be used by older adults with varying abilities.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Ranking with Neural Re-Ranking for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel neural re-ranking approach for efficient information retrieval, leveraging query-adaptive document ranking to improve the effectiveness of traditional retrieval models. Our proposed architecture, QADR, incorporates a neural re-ranker that adaptively weighs document features based on the query context, thereby enhancing the ranking accuracy and efficiency. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QADR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing the computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Autonomous Agent Systems using Blockchain
paper_abstract: Autonomous agent systems require reliable trust management mechanisms to ensure secure interactions between agents. This paper presents a decentralized trust management framework, 'BlockTrust', which leverages blockchain technology to establish a tamper-evident reputation system. BlockTrust enables agents to dynamically update their trust relationships based on observed behavior, while maintaining a transparent and immutable record of past interactions. We evaluate BlockTrust using a simulated smart city scenario, demonstrating improved system resilience and security compared to traditional centralized trust management approaches.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of cloud-based services has led to a surge in multi-tenant database systems, where numerous tenants share a common infrastructure. Query optimization in such systems is challenging due to the diverse workload characteristics of individual tenants. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MT-QOpt', which leverages machine learning to predict tenant-specific query patterns and adaptively adjusts optimization strategies. Our approach integrates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group tenants with similar query behavior, enabling more effective resource allocation and improved overall system performance. Experimental results on a real-world multi-tenant database demonstrate that MT-QOpt reduces average query latency by up to 35% compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue Generation
paper_abstract: Conversational AI models often rely on black-box neural networks, hindering their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for dialogue generation, which incorporates explainability mechanisms at multiple levels. HAN leverages attention weights to identify crucial context and utterance features, enabling transparent and interpretable response generation. We evaluate HAN on multiple benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in response quality and coherence while providing insights into the model's decision-making process.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In this paper, we address the problem of task allocation for autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized approach that leverages both local and global information to optimize task assignments. Our methodology utilizes a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, where agents learn to adapt to changing environmental conditions and collaborate to achieve shared goals. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized solutions in terms of task completion efficiency and robustness to environmental uncertainty.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in autonomous systems, where decision-making processes need to be transparent and accountable. This paper introduces HAREL, a novel hierarchical attention-based framework for explainable reinforcement learning (RL) in autonomous systems. HAREL uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant state features, providing interpretable explanations for the RL agent's decisions. We evaluate HAREL on a simulated autonomous driving scenario, demonstrating improved explainability and performance compared to state-of-the-art RL methods. The proposed framework has significant implications for the development of trustworthy autonomous systems.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between queries and documents. This paper proposes a neural QE approach, dubbed NeuroQE, which leverages pre-trained language models to generate semantically meaningful expansion terms. NeuroQE integrates a novel attention mechanism to weigh the importance of each expansion term and adaptively selects the most informative ones. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Scalable Agent-Based Framework for Distributed Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to a surge in demand for efficient resource allocation mechanisms. This paper presents a novel agent-based framework, 'ResourceHub', that leverages distributed decision-making to allocate resources in IoT networks. We design a multi-agent system comprising autonomous agents that negotiate and coordinate resource allocation using a decentralized auction-based approach. Our experiments on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that ResourceHub achieves a 30% reduction in resource allocation latency and a 25% increase in overall network utilization compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed RDF Graph Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of RDF graph databases in various domains has led to a surge in query complexity and data distribution. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RDF-QO', that leverages graph partitioning, query rewriting, and distributed query execution to improve query performance in distributed RDF graph databases. We introduce a cost-based optimization approach that considers the trade-off between query execution time and data transfer overhead. Experimental results on a real-world RDF dataset demonstrate that RDF-QO outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and 25% in terms of data transfer reduction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and facial expressions, is a challenging task. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of each modality to improve emotion recognition accuracy. HAN consists of three levels of attention: intra-modal, inter-modal, and fusion-level attention. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an F1-score of 0.83 for emotion classification. We also analyze the attention weights to gain insights into the importance of each modality for emotion recognition.

title: Intelligent Conflict Resolution in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, conflicts arise when agents with competing goals interact. Existing approaches to conflict resolution rely on hand-coded rules or limited problem-specific solutions. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to train agents to resolve conflicts intelligently. Our method, called Multi-Agent Conflict Resolution (MACR), utilizes a decentralized, self-organizing framework that adapts to diverse conflict scenarios. We evaluate MACR on a suite of benchmark problems, demonstrating improved conflict resolution rates and reduced negotiation time compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for faceted Search
paper_abstract: Faceted search, which enables users to refine their search queries using multiple filters, has become increasingly popular in modern information retrieval systems. However, the existing ranking models struggle to effectively incorporate faceted information, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'FacetNet', which leverages deep neural networks to capture the complex interactions between facets and documents. Our approach learns to represent facets and documents as dense vectors, allowing for efficient and effective ranking of documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that FacetNet significantly outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models in terms of search accuracy and efficiency.

title: Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Healthcare: A Multimodal Interaction Framework
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework for embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in healthcare settings. Our framework integrates speech, gesture, and facial recognition to facilitate more natural and inclusive interactions between ECAs and patients with diverse abilities. We evaluate our approach through a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in perceived empathy, trust, and overall user experience. Our findings have implications for the design of ECAs in healthcare, highlighting the importance of multimodal interaction and accessibility in promoting health equity.

title: Investigating the Effect of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the impact of personalized avatars on user experience in VR environments. We designed an experiment using a novel avatar creation system that incorporates user preferences and personality traits. Our results show that users who interact with personalized avatars exhibit higher levels of engagement, measured through self-reported satisfaction and physiological metrics. We also identify key design factors influencing user acceptance and provide guidelines for VR system designers.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, where agents learn to allocate tasks efficiently through distributed reinforcement learning. We propose a novel algorithm, 'DTRL', which leverages local observations and communication with neighboring agents to learn optimal task assignments. DTRL is shown to converge to near-optimal solutions in various scenarios, outperforming traditional centralized approaches. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of DTRL in a realistic disaster response scenario, highlighting its potential for real-world applications.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) must make rapid, high-stakes decisions in complex environments. While reinforcement learning (RL) has shown promise in AV control, the opacity of RL policies hinders trust and understanding. This paper presents XRL, a novel framework for explainable RL in AV decision-making. XRL integrates model-based RL with attention mechanisms and visual saliency maps to provide interpretable explanations of policy decisions. We evaluate XRL on a suite of realistic AV scenarios, demonstrating improved transparency and robustness without sacrificing control performance.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gestural interfaces for older adults with motor impairments. We propose an adaptive system that utilizes machine learning to recognize and accommodate individual users' abilities, compensating for motor limitations. Our system incorporates a gesture recognition module, a motor ability assessment framework, and a personalized interface adaptation mechanism. A user study with 20 older adults with motor impairments demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gestural interfaces. Our findings have implications for the development of inclusive and accessible HCI systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Contextualized Term Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with limited query context. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'CTXQE', which leverages contextualized term embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between query terms. By incorporating a transformer-based encoder to model query semantics, CTXQE generates high-quality expansion terms that improve retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CTXQE outperforms existing query expansion techniques, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often rely on complex interactions to achieve cooperative goals. This paper introduces HeteroGAT, a novel graph attention framework that enables explainable cooperation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. By integrating agent-specific attention mechanisms with graph neural networks, HeteroGAT captures nuanced relationships between agents and their environments. We demonstrate improved cooperation and interpretability in a variety of scenarios, including traffic management and disaster response. Our results show that HeteroGAT outperforms existing approaches in terms of both task performance and explainability.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Task Learning for Efficient and Explainable Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from speech and text is a crucial AI application, but existing models often suffer from high computational complexity and lack of interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-task learning framework, 'EMoTask', which jointly learns emotion recognition and related tasks such as sentiment analysis and speaker diarization. By sharing knowledge across tasks and leveraging task hierarchies, EMoTask achieves significant improvements in emotion recognition accuracy and efficiency while providing insights into the decision-making process through task-specific attention weights. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of EMoTask in various emotional intelligence applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of people with disabilities. This paper presents a participatory design approach to develop accessible and inclusive conversational interfaces. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with individuals with disabilities, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our resulting design framework, 'AccessibilityLens', incorporates a range of novel features, including personalized accessibility profiles, real-time transcription, and multimodal input support. A usability study with 25 participants demonstrated significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Enhancing Retrieval Performance with Deep Query Reformulation for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search engines struggle to retrieve relevant documents when user queries are ambiguous or contain nuanced intent. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'QueryRefine', which reformulates queries by modeling their semantic context. QueryRefine leverages a transformer-based architecture to generate a set of refined queries that better capture the user's information need. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for queries with low frequency terms or implicit intent. Our results show that QueryRefine can be easily integrated with existing search engines to enhance their retrieval capabilities.

title: Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Efficient YOLO-Based Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Accurate and efficient object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems. This paper presents a novel real-time object detection framework, 'YOLO-Evolve', which leverages the You Only Look Once (YOLO) architecture and incorporates several optimizations for improved speed and accuracy. We propose a hierarchical feature fusion approach that combines multi-scale feature maps, a spatial attention module, and a confidence-based non-maximum suppression technique. Experiments on the KITTI and Cityscapes datasets demonstrate that YOLO-Evolve achieves state-of-the-art performance while maintaining a processing time of under 30 ms per frame.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Explainability and interpretability are crucial in graph-based node classification tasks, particularly in high-stakes applications like social network analysis and bioinformatics. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAN) architecture that leverages self-attention mechanisms to learn node representations at multiple scales. HGAN incorporates a hierarchical clustering module to identify informative graph structures, facilitating explainable node classification. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and feature importance interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, as it enables more accurate sentiment detection from diverse data sources such as text, images, and videos. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that effectively integrates multimodal features and captures complex relationships between them. Our approach leverages a modality-specific attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and a hierarchical fusion strategy to combine the outputs from different modalities. Experiments on two benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of our HAN model over state-of-the-art multimodal sentiment analysis approaches.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Enhanced Decision-Making in Collaborative Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Collaborative virtual reality (VR) environments have the potential to revolutionize decision-making processes, but current visualization approaches often fail to effectively support group decision-making. This paper proposes an adaptive visualization framework that leverages real-time user feedback and cognitive load assessment to dynamically adjust visualization parameters. Our approach incorporates machine learning-based user modeling and multi-modal interaction techniques to facilitate more effective collaboration and decision-making. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in decision quality and user satisfaction compared to traditional visualization methods.

title: Deep Learning for Time-Series Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: Industrial IoT sensor data is prone to anomalies that can cause significant downtime and economic losses. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'AnoTS', for time-series anomaly detection in industrial IoT sensor data. AnoTS leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to model complex temporal dependencies and patterns in sensor data. We evaluate AnoTS on a real-world dataset from a manufacturing plant and demonstrate its superior performance compared to traditional statistical methods and machine learning approaches. The proposed approach can be easily integrated into existing industrial IoT systems, enabling real-time anomaly detection and predictive maintenance.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Structure-Aware Feature Learning
paper_abstract: Graph-structured data is ubiquitous in many domains, but existing graph neural networks often overlook the hierarchical structure inherent in these graphs. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and nodes at each level of the hierarchy. Our approach leverages a recursive attention mechanism to capture long-range dependencies and structural relationships, leading to improved feature learning and better performance on downstream tasks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in graph classification, node classification, and graph regression tasks.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Learning-based Eye Movement Prediction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual controllers for interaction, which can be cumbersome and limit the sense of immersion. In this paper, we propose a gaze-based interaction system for VR that leverages deep learning-based eye movement prediction. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to predict the user's gaze direction from eye movement data, and then maps the predicted gaze to a corresponding action in the virtual environment. We evaluate our system in a user study and show that it achieves high accuracy and low latency, enabling users to interact with virtual objects in a natural and intuitive way.

title: Rethinking Concurrency Control for Modern Database Systems: A Lock-Free Approach
paper_abstract: As database systems continue to scale, traditional concurrency control mechanisms face significant challenges. This paper presents a novel, lock-free approach to concurrency control that leverages a combination of hardware transactional memory and optimistic concurrency protocols. Our proposed system, 'LFCtrl', avoids the limitations of traditional locking and timestamp-based methods, achieving significant improvements in throughput and latency under high contention workloads. We evaluate LFCtrl using a range of benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in supporting high-performance, scalable database systems.

title: Designing Accessible Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing inclusive interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments is crucial. This paper presents 'ElderVoice', a voice-based interface framework tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive decline. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, combining user-centered design with cognitive assessments. Our results show that ElderVoice's simplified language model, acoustic adaptations, and personalized feedback mechanisms significantly improve task completion rates and user satisfaction. We discuss the implications of our findings for accessible HCI design and future research directions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hyperbolic Embeddings for Improving Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it helps to alleviate the vocabulary mismatch problem between queries and documents. However, existing query expansion methods often rely on Euclidean embeddings, which may not effectively capture the complex semantic relationships between words. In this paper, we propose a novel query expansion approach using hyperbolic embeddings, which can better model hierarchical and asymmetric relationships. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving up to 15% improvement in retrieval performance.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in a given context. Existing approaches rely on hand-crafted features or simple neural networks, which fail to capture complex relationships between entities. We propose a novel graph-based neural network approach, 'GED-Net', that leverages the graph structure of the knowledge graph to learn entity representations. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GED-Net outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and scalability, making it suitable for large-scale knowledge graph construction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it can significantly impact search result relevance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using context-aware word embeddings, which capture nuanced semantic relationships between words in a query. We introduce a neural network-based model that jointly learns word embeddings and query expansion weights, outperforming traditional methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in improving retrieval performance, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Enhance Accessibility for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their usability for older adults is often hindered by cognitive and sensory impairments. This paper presents a multimodal design framework for inclusive voice assistants, which combines speech, gesture, and visual cues to facilitate interaction. Our user study with 30 older adults (ages 65-85) demonstrates that the proposed framework improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces. We also discuss the implications of our findings for designing accessible HCI systems that cater to diverse user needs.

title: Efficient Explanations for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Model-Based State Abstraction
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to explaining DRL agents' decisions by abstracting the state space using a learned, probabilistic model. Our method, dubbed 'ExplainRL', leverages the abstraction to generate compact, symbolic representations of the agent's policy, which can be easily understood by humans. We evaluate ExplainRL on a suite of Atari games and demonstrate significant improvements in explanation quality and computational efficiency compared to existing methods.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition using Deep Learning and Electromyography
paper_abstract: Electromyography (EMG) signals have shown promise in gesture recognition, but existing approaches suffer from limited generalizability and high variability in user data. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework that integrates EMG signals with computer vision features to enable personalized gesture recognition. Our approach leverages a multitask learning architecture to jointly learn gesture recognition, user identification, and EMG signal denoising. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods, paving the way for practical applications in human-computer interaction.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Interaction Framework for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their adoption by users with disabilities is hindered by limitations in current interaction modalities. This paper presents 'EchoAccess', a novel multimodal framework that enables users with disabilities to interact with voice assistants using a combination of speech, gesture, and gaze inputs. We propose a probabilistic fusion model that dynamically adapts to the user's abilities and preferences, ensuring a more inclusive and personalized interaction experience. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture Recognition for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have transformative potential for individuals with motor impairments, but existing solutions often neglect accessibility considerations. This paper presents 'EasyMotion', a novel framework that incorporates participatory design and machine learning to recognize gestures from users with varying abilities. We conducted co-design workshops with individuals with motor impairments to inform the development of a gesture vocabulary and an adaptive recognition algorithm. Experimental results show that EasyMotion achieves high recognition accuracy (95.6%) and outperforms state-of-the-art systems in user satisfaction and usability metrics.

title: Efficient Document Indexing for Real-time Information Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Networks
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of digital data necessitates efficient indexing techniques for real-time information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture for document indexing, which significantly reduces the computational complexity and memory requirements of traditional indexing methods. Our HNN model leverages a hierarchical representation of documents, allowing for efficient querying and filtering of relevant documents. Experimental results on a large-scale document corpus demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query response time and accuracy.

title: Hybrid Attention Mechanisms for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper presents a novel hybrid attention mechanism that combines visual, acoustic, and linguistic features to recognize emotions in multi-modal data. Our approach leverages self-attention to model intra-modal relationships and cross-modal attention to capture inter-modal interactions. Experimental results on the SEMAINE database demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from facial expressions, speech, and text, achieving an average F1-score of 0.85.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Dense Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant texts for answer extraction. This paper presents HDRPR, a novel dense representation approach that leverages hierarchical contextualized embeddings to encode passages. By capturing multi-granular semantic relationships, HDRPR significantly reduces the dimensionality of passage representations while improving their discriminative power. Our experiments on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that HDRPR-based retrieval outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12.5% increase in top-1 passage accuracy and a 30% reduction in computational cost.

title: Designing Accessible Augmented Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize the way people interact with their surroundings, but existing AR systems often neglect the needs of users with visual impairments. This paper presents an exploratory study on designing accessible AR experiences for visually impaired users. We conducted co-design workshops with visually impaired participants to identify key challenges and opportunities for inclusive AR design. Our findings inform the development of a novel AR prototype that incorporates audio-based navigation, tactile feedback, and personalized accessibility features. A user study with 20 visually impaired participants demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of our approach in enhancing AR accessibility.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have revolutionized real-time analytics by providing low-latency query execution. However, optimizing queries for these systems remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of modern workloads. This paper presents 'MemOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and advanced indexing techniques to minimize query latency and maximize throughput. We introduce a probabilistic cost model that accurately estimates query execution times and develop a dynamic reordering mechanism to further reduce latency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that MemOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3x in query throughput and 2x in latency reduction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning has shown impressive results in autonomous vehicles, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders widespread adoption. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates explainability into reinforcement learning. Our approach uses a multi-level attention mechanism to highlight relevant sensory inputs and internal state transitions, providing insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a simulated driving environment demonstrate that our HAN-based agent achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art methods while providing interpretable explanations for its actions.

title: Gaze-Based Human-Computer Interaction for Augmented Reality Environments
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for more natural and intuitive human-computer interaction mechanisms. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework for AR environments, leveraging computer vision and machine learning techniques to detect and analyze user gaze patterns. Our approach enables users to seamlessly select and manipulate virtual objects in 3D space, eliminating the need for manual input devices. We evaluate our framework through a series of user studies, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction time, accuracy, and overall user experience.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Multimodal Approach
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults, who may face cognitive, sensory, and motor impairments. This paper presents a multimodal approach to designing inclusive conversational interfaces for older adults, incorporating speech, gesture, and gaze-based input modalities. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, evaluating the effectiveness of our approach in reducing cognitive load, improving user experience, and enhancing accessibility. Our results show significant benefits in usability, user satisfaction, and accessibility metrics, demonstrating the potential of multimodal conversational interfaces to support older adults' independence and well-being.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Neural Networks for Session-based Search
paper_abstract: Session-based search is a common scenario where users interact with a search engine multiple times to refine their search query. Traditional ranking models, however, fail to capture the contextual dependencies between queries within a session. This paper presents a novel deep neural network architecture, called SessionRank, which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to model the query-document relationships within a session. Experimental results on the TREC Session Track dataset demonstrate that SessionRank outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of nDCG and ERR metrics, especially for longer search sessions.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on the effects of gesture-based interaction on cognitive load and user experience. We designed a VR-based experiment where participants performed tasks using either gesture-based or controller-based interfaces. Our results show that gesture-based interaction reduces cognitive load and improves user engagement, particularly for tasks requiring spatial reasoning. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of intuitive and effective VR interfaces, highlighting the potential of embodied cognition principles to inform HCI research.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Latent Semantic Analysis and Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems struggle to capture the semantic relationships between documents and queries. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'LSA-DNN', which leverages latent semantic analysis (LSA) to extract high-level semantic features from documents and incorporates deep neural networks (DNNs) to model complex query-document interactions. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that LSA-DNN significantly outperforms state-of-the-art IR systems in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency, particularly for long-tail queries. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned semantic representations and their implications for IR.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating agents with different goals, constraints, and capabilities. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate heterogeneous agents, including traffic signals, autonomous vehicles, and human-driven cars. We introduce a multi-agent framework that integrates graph attention networks and deep Q-networks to learn effective policies for minimizing congestion, reducing travel times, and improving safety. Experimental results using real-world traffic data from San Francisco demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods and achieves significant improvements in traffic efficiency.

title: Real-time Human Activity Recognition using Multi-modal Fusion of Wearable Sensors and Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) is a fundamental task in various applications, including healthcare, surveillance, and human-computer interaction. This paper presents a novel multi-modal fusion framework that combines wearable sensor data with computer vision features to achieve real-time HAR. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the contributions of each modality based on the activity context. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art HAR methods on a benchmark dataset, achieving an average F1-score of 94.2% across six activities. We also demonstrate the feasibility of our approach on a wearable device, achieving real-time inference with a latency of less than 100ms.

title: Enhancing Query Representation with Graph Attention for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture complex query semantics, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query representation framework, 'GraphQRep', which leverages graph attention mechanisms to model query-document relationships. By constructing a graph of query terms and their co-occurrences, GraphQRep learns to weigh term importance and capture nuanced query semantics. Experimental results on the TREC ROBUST04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for complex queries, when compared to state-of-the-art query representation models.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize the way people interact and engage with digital information. However, people with disabilities often face significant barriers when accessing VR experiences. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive VR experiences for individuals with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with people with disabilities and developed a set of guidelines for accessible VR interaction. Our approach incorporates multimodal feedback, adaptable interfaces, and personalized profiles to ensure equal access to VR experiences. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through a case study on a VR-based education platform.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive and Accessible Healthcare Interactions
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to revolutionize healthcare interactions, but their design often neglects the needs of users with disabilities or from diverse cultural backgrounds. This paper presents a human-centered approach to designing ECAs for inclusive and accessible healthcare interactions. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with healthcare professionals, patients, and caregivers to identify key design requirements. We then developed and evaluated an ECA prototype that incorporates multimodal interaction, affective computing, and culturally sensitive dialogue management. Our results show that users with disabilities and from diverse backgrounds perceive the ECA as more trustworthy, empathetic, and effective in facilitating healthcare conversations.

title: Efficient Join Ordering for Distributed Query Optimization in Cloud-Native Databases
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of cloud-native databases, efficient query optimization is crucial for achieving low latency and high throughput. This paper tackles the join ordering problem in distributed query optimization, which is NP-hard and critical for query performance. We propose a novel, adaptive join ordering algorithm, 'DJOS', that leverages machine learning models to predict join selectivities and dynamically adjusts the join order based on runtime statistics. Our experiments on a real-world cloud-native database show that DJOS outperforms state-of-the-art join ordering algorithms by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Query Embeddings for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of accurately ranking documents for complex, natural language queries. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'Query2Vec', which learns to embed queries into a dense vector space. Our method leverages a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query embedding, document ranking, and relevance modeling. Experiments on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that Query2Vec outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 12% improvement in mean average precision and a 20% reduction in latency. We further analyze the effectiveness of Query2Vec in handling long-tail queries and provide insights into its applicability in real-world e-commerce search engines.

title: Efficient Explainability for Deep Reinforcement Learning via Model-Agnostic Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but the lack of transparency in decision-making hinders trust and adoption. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, 'EXPLAIN', which enables efficient model-agnostic explainability for DRL policies. By leveraging gradients of the policy's expected return, EXPLAIN learns to generate importance scores for state features, facilitating interpretability without requiring access to the underlying model architecture. We demonstrate the effectiveness of EXPLAIN on several Atari games and a real-world robotic control task, showcasing its ability to provide meaningful explanations for DRL policies.

title: Neural Document Ranking with Query-Specific Dense Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires accurate retrieval of relevant documents from a large corpus. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'QRDR', which leverages query-specific dense retrieval to improve the quality of retrieved documents. QRDR generates dense query embeddings using a neural encoder and uses these embeddings to search for relevant documents in the corpus. We introduce a novel ranking loss function that jointly optimizes the retrieval and ranking stages. Experiments on several ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that QRDR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving significant improvements in both retrieval recall and end-to-end question answering accuracy.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection for Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved significant success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses a major concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks on DRL policies using graph neural networks (GNNs). We design a GNN-based architecture that learns to represent the policy's decision-making process as a graph and identifies anomalies indicative of adversarial attacks. Our experiments on common DRL benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting various types of attacks, including poisoning and evasion attacks, with high accuracy and robustness.

title: Efficient Multimodal Fusion for Emotion Recognition using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs, such as speech, text, and facial expressions, remains a challenging task. Existing fusion methods often rely on complex feature engineering or concatenation of modalities, leading to increased computational costs and decreased interpretability. We propose a novel graph attention network (GAT)-based approach, 'MMEF', that efficiently fuses multimodal features by modeling their relationships as a graph. Our experiments on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that MMEF achieves state-of-the-art emotion recognition performance with reduced computational overhead compared to conventional fusion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Retrieval Performance in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. However, the performance of ad-hoc search systems can be limited by the quality of the query. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. Our approach leverages the semantic relationships between words and phrases to generate expanded queries that better capture the user's intent. We evaluate our approach on several standard datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods. Our results show that the proposed approach can be effectively integrated into existing search systems to improve their overall performance.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: Understanding the Impact of Age-Related Hearing Loss on Speech Recognition
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their effectiveness is compromised for individuals with age-related hearing loss (ARHL). This study investigates the impact of ARHL on speech recognition accuracy in voice assistants, highlighting the need for inclusive design. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, aged 65-85, to analyze the effects of ARHL on speech patterns and recognition accuracy. Our results show that ARHL significantly affects recognition accuracy, particularly for older adults with severe hearing loss. We propose a novel framework for designing voice assistants that accommodate ARHL, incorporating acoustic models tailored to age-related hearing characteristics and multimodal input support.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Mechanisms for Multi-Agent Resource Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of allocating resources among multiple autonomous agents in dynamic environments, where agents' preferences and availability of resources change over time. We propose a decentralized negotiation framework that enables agents to negotiate and reach mutually beneficial agreements. Our approach combines concepts from auction theory and machine learning to develop a novel negotiation mechanism that adapts to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient and fair resource allocations in various scenarios, including those with incomplete information and heterogeneous agents.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of NoSQL databases has led to a surge in column-oriented storage systems. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the lack of a unified cost model. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and adaptive indexing. We introduce a column-store aware cost model that captures data distribution, storage layout, and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColOpt reduces query latency by up to 3x compared to existing optimization techniques, while minimizing indexing overhead.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but users with disabilities often face barriers to accessible VR experiences. This paper presents a novel framework, 'IncluVR', that incorporates a set of design principles and guidelines for creating inclusive VR environments. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants with disabilities, identifying key challenges and opportunities for accessible VR interaction. Our findings inform the development of IncluVR, which includes features such as customizable navigation, audio descriptions, and haptic feedback. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in user experience and accessibility.

title: Hierarchical Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability in reinforcement learning (RL) is crucial for real-world applications, particularly in autonomous systems. This paper introduces 'HERO', a hierarchical framework that integrates model-based RL with interpretable decision-making. HERO employs a nested structure of models, where a high-level policy selects among low-level controllers, each explaining its decisions through attention-based visualizations. We demonstrate HERO's effectiveness in a simulated autonomous driving environment, showcasing improved performance, explainability, and safety compared to state-of-the-art RL baselines.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed resource allocation in smart grids. We model the problem as a decentralized Markov decision process, where each agent represents a distributed energy resource. Our approach leverages deep Q-networks and a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn cooperative policies that optimize energy allocation and reduce peak demand. Experimental results on a simulated grid show that our approach outperforms traditional optimization methods and improves the overall efficiency of the smart grid.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in Information Retrieval (IR), particularly when dealing with short and ambiguous queries. This paper introduces a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-Filter', which leverages a dual-encoder architecture to learn query-document relevance. Our method first generates a set of correlated sub-queries using a neural query expansion module, and then applies a filtering mechanism to prune irrelevant documents. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that NQE-Filter significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing the computational cost by up to 30%.

title: Designing Adaptive Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing voice assistants that adapt to users with dysarthria, a speech disorder that affects articulation, fluency, and intelligibility. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 20 participants, combining speech recognition, eye-tracking, and user experience surveys to investigate the impact of adaptive voice assistants on user interaction. Our findings highlight the importance of multimodal input fusion, personalized error correction, and emotional support in enhancing user engagement and satisfaction. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants that can be integrated into existing HCI frameworks.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Decision-Making in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel deep learning architecture, Hierarchical Attention Networks (HAN), for multi-agent decision-making in complex environments. HAN combines hierarchical graph attention mechanisms with reinforcement learning to enable agents to learn effective communication and cooperation strategies. We evaluate HAN on a suite of benchmarks, including autonomous vehicle coordination and smart grid management, and demonstrate significant improvements in performance and scalability compared to existing methods. Our approach has potential applications in real-world domains such as traffic management, supply chain optimization, and distributed robotics.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agent Teams via Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: We investigate the problem of decentralized task allocation for heterogeneous agent teams, where agents possess diverse capabilities and communication constraints. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'AgentGNN', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a distributed task allocation strategy. Each agent maintains a local GNN that learns to predict task assignments based on its neighbors' information, enabling the team to adapt to dynamic environments. Our experiments on a realistic urban search and rescue scenario demonstrate that AgentGNN outperforms existing decentralized methods in terms of task completion efficiency and team utility.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Environments using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) environments have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction. However, current VR systems rely on cumbersome controllers or invasive eye-tracking devices. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based interaction system, 'GazeVR', which leverages deep learning to infer user intentions from gaze patterns. We introduce a multi-task CNN architecture that jointly predicts gaze direction, fixation points, and user actions. Our experiments demonstrate that GazeVR achieves high accuracy and low latency, enabling seamless interaction in VR environments. We also explore the applicability of GazeVR in various scenarios, including gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, as it enables computers to understand and respond to human emotions more effectively. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotions. Our HAN model consists of three stages: modality-specific attention, multimodal fusion, and hierarchical attention. We evaluate our approach on the SEMAINE dataset and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multimodal data. Furthermore, we demonstrate the robustness of our model to variations in lighting conditions and individual differences.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodiment in Human-Robot Collaboration: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly share workspaces with humans, effective collaboration requires intuitive and efficient communication. This paper explores the impact of embodiment on human-robot collaboration, focusing on gesture-based interaction. We designed a user study where participants worked with a robotic arm to complete tasks, using either explicit gestures or implicit body language. Our results show that embodied interaction significantly improves task performance, reduces errors, and enhances user satisfaction. We also identify key gestural features that facilitate effective collaboration and discuss implications for designing more human-centered robot interfaces.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using a Hierarchical Index Structure
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems are increasingly used in modern search engines to index and query massive datasets. However, the query efficiency of DIR systems is often bottlenecked by the communication overhead between nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical index structure, 'HIndex', which reduces query latency by minimizing the number of node interactions. HIndex partitions the index into a hierarchical structure, where each node maintains a summary of its subtree. We evaluate HIndex on a large-scale dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query efficiency, with an average reduction of 37% in query latency compared to existing indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehouses using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach to optimize query performance in real-time data warehouses. We develop a query predictor model that leverages historical query patterns and workload characteristics to anticipate query execution times. Our approach, called 'QPML', incorporates a probabilistic cost model and a reinforcement learning framework to dynamically adjust query plans and reduce optimization overhead. Experiments on a real-world dataset show that QPML outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of average query response time.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Multi-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of modern datasets has led to a surge in query processing times, hindering the performance of database systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HyperIndex', which tackles the problem of efficient query processing for multi-dimensional data. HyperIndex leverages a combination of grid-based indexing and adaptive tree structures to minimize disk I/O and optimize query execution. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HyperIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving an average query time reduction of 35% and a storage overhead of less than 10%.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible and inclusive interface designs that cater to older adults with motor impairments. This paper presents a gesture-based interface framework, 'EasyGesture', that leverages machine learning-driven gesture recognition and real-time feedback to facilitate intuitive interaction for individuals with limited dexterity. We conducted a usability study with 20 older adults and found that EasyGesture significantly improved interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional mouse-based interfaces. Our results inform the design of accessible and empowering HCI systems for older adults.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Semantic Entities in Knowledge Graphs using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) have become a crucial component in various natural language processing and artificial intelligence applications. However, searching for semantic entities in large-scale KGs remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphAttENT', which leverages graph attention networks to efficiently retrieve semantic entities in KGs. GraphAttENT learns to focus on relevant nodes and edges in the graph, thereby reducing the search space and improving retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphAttENT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and query latency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Graph-Based Keyword Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in retrieval tasks, but their performance heavily relies on the quality of query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'GraphEmb', which leverages graph-based keyword embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms. Our approach first constructs a keyword graph using co-occurrence statistics and then applies graph convolutional networks to learn dense embeddings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphEmb significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural search engines, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Efficient Data Replication Strategies for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems require efficient data replication strategies to ensure consistency, availability, and fault tolerance. This paper presents a novel replication scheme, 'AdaptiveRep', which dynamically adjusts the replication factor based on workload characteristics and network conditions. We propose a cost-benefit model that considers factors such as data freshness, query latency, and storage overhead. Experimental results on a simulated distributed database show that AdaptiveRep outperforms existing static replication strategies in terms of overall system performance and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
paper_abstract: The proliferation of edge devices has created a growing need for efficient AI models that can operate under resource constraints. This paper presents 'EdgeNAS', a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework tailored for edge devices. EdgeNAS employs a hierarchical search space and a customized reinforcement learning algorithm to discover compact, performant models. Experimental results on several edge computing benchmarks demonstrate that EdgeNAS can identify models with up to 3.5x faster inference times and 2x smaller model sizes compared to state-of-the-art NAS methods, while maintaining competitive accuracy.

title: A Knowledge Graph-Based Approach for Query Expansion in Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval systems often struggle to accurately retrieve relevant documents due to the complexity of patent queries. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages knowledge graphs to expand patent queries. We construct a knowledge graph from a large patent corpus and develop a graph-based ranking model to select relevant expansion terms. Experimental results on a standard patent retrieval dataset show that our approach significantly improves the retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods, especially for queries with low term frequency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Distributed Query Optimization in Cloud-Based Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: As data warehouses continue to scale, distributed query optimization becomes increasingly critical. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, 'DyIndex', which leverages probabilistic data structures and adaptive sampling to efficiently process queries in cloud-based data warehouses. DyIndex reduces query latency by up to 3x compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while maintaining high accuracy and adaptability to dynamic workloads. We evaluate DyIndex using a real-world dataset from a leading e-commerce platform, demonstrating its effectiveness in reducing query processing times and improving overall system throughput.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media platforms has led to an exponential increase in data generation, driving the need for real-time analytics in distributed database systems. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck in such systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RTOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and constraint programming to efficiently optimize queries for real-time analytics. Experimental results on a simulated distributed database system demonstrate that RTOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time.
