title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with vocabulary mismatch between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep reinforcement learning, which learns to selectively expand queries based on their semantic relevance to the target documents. Our method, NeuralExpansion, utilizes a policy gradient algorithm to optimize the query expansion policy, leveraging a large-scale clickthrough dataset to learn from user behavior. Experimental results on the MSMARCO passage ranking dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Databases
paper_abstract: Time-series databases (TSDBs) are increasingly used in IoT, finance, and healthcare applications, requiring efficient indexing methods for real-time query processing. This paper presents 'AdaptiX', a novel indexing approach that combines a hierarchical, grid-based indexing structure with an adaptive sampling technique. AdaptiX dynamically adjusts the sampling rate based on query patterns, achieving a 3x improvement in query latency and a 2x reduction in storage overhead compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods. We evaluate AdaptiX on a large-scale IoT dataset and demonstrate its scalability and effectiveness in supporting real-time analytics workloads.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems heavily rely on manual input devices, limiting the sense of immersion and interaction. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework for VR, leveraging machine learning (ML) to predict user intentions from eye movements. Our approach uses a deep neural network to classify gaze patterns into distinct actions, such as selection, manipulation, and navigation. We evaluate our framework using a custom-built VR setup and demonstrate significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user experience compared to traditional manual input methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis from multi-modal data, such as text, images, and videos, is a challenging task due to the complex interactions between modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and regions to accurately predict sentiment. Our HAN consists of modality-specific attention modules that adaptively weight features from each modality, followed by a hierarchical fusion mechanism that integrates information across modalities. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 3.5% in terms of sentiment prediction accuracy.

title: Deep Hierarchical Attention for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained increasing attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to effectively integrate and reason about multimodal cues. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical attention framework, 'MHAtt', which leverages self-attention mechanisms to jointly model intra-modal and inter-modal relationships. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark datasets, outperforming prior work by up to 5.2% in terms of sentiment classification accuracy. We also provide visualizations and ablation studies to demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in capturing nuanced multimodal interactions.

title: Hybrid Reasoning for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Knowledge
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, incomplete knowledge about the environment and other agents' intentions can lead to suboptimal decision-making. This paper presents a novel hybrid reasoning framework that integrates symbolic and probabilistic methods to address this challenge. Our approach leverages answer set programming to compute logical consequences of incomplete knowledge, while probabilistic graphical models capture uncertainty and conditional dependencies. We evaluate our framework in a scenario of cooperative task allocation, demonstrating improved decision quality and robustness compared to existing approaches.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Resource Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoopRA', which enables cooperative resource allocation in IoT networks. We model the problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process, where each agent represents an IoT device. Our approach leverages a distributed actor-critic architecture to learn a coordination mechanism that maximizes the overall network utility. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that CoopRA outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized approaches, achieving significant improvements in resource utilization and network performance.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking with Query-Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models often rely on computationally expensive, multi-stage pipelines to achieve optimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel, adaptive re-ranking approach that leverages query-document embeddings to efficiently identify relevant documents. Our method, 'AdaRerank', learns to dynamically adjust the ranking threshold based on the query's semantic context, reducing the number of documents that require expensive neural scoring. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track demonstrate that AdaRerank achieves comparable retrieval accuracy to state-of-the-art methods while reducing computational overhead by up to 40%.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query terms fail to match the relevant documents. Query expansion (QE) techniques can alleviate this issue, but most existing methods rely on heuristics or manual tuning. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning (RL) framework for QE, where an agent learns to select relevant expansion terms based on the retrieval feedback. We introduce a novel reward function that balances the trade-off between precision and recall, and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art QE methods on the TREC-COVID dataset.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Voice-Assisted Technologies
paper_abstract: Voice-assisted technologies have become increasingly prevalent, but their usability and accessibility for older adults remain a concern. This study investigates the design of inclusive conversational interfaces for this demographic. We conducted user studies and surveys to identify key challenges and preferences of older adults when interacting with voice-assisted systems. Our findings inform the development of a novel interface framework that incorporates age-related considerations, such as speech recognition accommodations and cognitively accessible dialogue flows. A usability evaluation of our prototype with older adults demonstrates improved task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing commercial systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Accented Speech Recognition for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their effectiveness is often hindered by limitations in speech recognition, particularly for accented speech. This paper investigates the impact of accented speech on voice assistant interactions for older adults, a demographic that is increasingly reliant on these systems. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, employing a mixed-methods approach to analyze the effects of accent, age, and cognitive load on speech recognition accuracy. Our findings highlight the need for inclusive design principles in voice assistant development, and we propose a set of guidelines for improving accented speech recognition in these systems.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding has become a crucial task in various AI applications, such as question answering and recommender systems. However, existing methods often neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in knowledge graphs, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HATKE', which integrates hierarchical attention networks with graph neural networks to learn more informative and robust embeddings. We evaluate HATKE on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in link prediction, entity classification, and graph clustering tasks.

title: Enhancing Retrieval Efficiency with Query-Aware Document Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on efficient retrieval mechanisms to provide relevant results. This paper introduces a novel approach, Query-Aware Document Embeddings (QuADE), which leverages query information to generate dense vector representations of documents. By incorporating query-dependent contextualization, QuADE improves the precision of document ranking and reduces the computational overhead of traditional retrieval methods. Our experiments on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate a significant reduction in mean average precision error and improved retrieval efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Improved Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it directly impacts the quality of search results. However, traditional query expansion methods often rely on static, hand-crafted rules or simple statistical models. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, CAQE, which leverages reinforcement learning to dynamically adapt to the search context. CAQE learns to select the most effective expansion terms by interacting with the IR system and receiving rewards based on retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a fundamental task in many applications, but the lack of interpretability in modern neural network-based models hinders their adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates both local and global attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant temporal patterns. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while providing visually interpretable attention weights that explain the forecasting decisions.

title: Enhancing Context-Aware Retrieval with Hierarchical Aspect Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to capture nuanced contextual relationships between query terms and document contents. This paper presents a novel approach, Hierarchical Aspect Embeddings (HAE), which leverages graph-based hierarchical representations to model complex aspect dependencies in documents. By integrating HAE into a neural ranking model, we demonstrate significant improvements in context-aware retrieval tasks, achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. Our experiments highlight the effectiveness of HAE in capturing subtle contextual cues, leading to more accurate retrieval results.

title: Query Optimization for Main-Memory Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems (MMDBs) have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to provide high performance and low latency. However, query optimization in MMDBs remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We design a DRL-based query optimizer that learns to select the best execution plan for a given query by interacting with the MMDB environment. Our experimental results show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques in terms of execution time and memory usage.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in resource allocation tasks. We introduce a novel agent architecture that combines a high-level planning module with low-level execution modules, enabling agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and optimize resource allocation. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated smart grid scenario, where it achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and overall system efficiency compared to state-of-the-art decentralized control methods.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Distributed Graph Databases using Adaptive Partitioning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query processing remains a bottleneck due to the complexity of graph traversal and join operations. This paper proposes an adaptive partitioning strategy, 'GraphPart', which dynamically adjusts the data distribution and query routing based on workload characteristics and system resources. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world social network dataset demonstrates that GraphPart achieves up to 3x performance improvement compared to state-of-the-art distributed graph processing systems.

title: Decentralized Agent Communication Framework for Large-Scale Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Large-scale multi-agent systems (MAS) pose significant challenges in terms of agent communication, coordination, and scalability. This paper presents a novel decentralized communication framework, 'DAEMON', which enables efficient and adaptive information exchange among agents in MAS. DAEMON leverages a hybrid approach combining gossip protocols with distributed hash tables to facilitate robust and fault-tolerant communication. We evaluate DAEMON through extensive simulations, demonstrating improved communication latency, reduced message overhead, and enhanced system resilience compared to existing decentralized communication schemes.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Recognition from Multimodal Input for Enhanced Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate affective state recognition is crucial for creating empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper proposes EmoTract, a novel multimodal framework that fuses facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize users' emotional states. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights modalities based on their relevance to the emotional context. Our evaluations on a large, annotated dataset demonstrate EmoTract's superior performance in recognizing nuanced emotions, such as anxiety and boredom, compared to unimodal and early-fusion approaches. EmoTract has implications for developing more empathetic and personalized HCI systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Reasoning in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multimodal reasoning in visual question answering (VQA) requires models to integrate information from both visual and language modalities. While recent advances in transformer-based architectures have improved performance, they often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that incorporates multimodal attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant regions in images and words in questions. We demonstrate that HAN improves VQA performance on benchmark datasets while providing explainable attention maps that reveal the model's decision-making process. Our results show that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models on complex VQA tasks, such as counting and spatial reasoning.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) models struggle to capture complex relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks (HGNN), which leverages graph neural networks to model documents as hierarchical structures. HGNN learns to represent documents as nodes in a graph, where edges capture semantic relationships between documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HGNN outperforms state-of-the-art IR models, achieving a 12% improvement in mean average precision. Furthermore, HGNN is shown to be computationally efficient, making it a promising solution for large-scale document retrieval applications.

title: Deep Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Retrieval in Hybrid Indexing Systems
paper_abstract: Hybrid indexing systems have gained popularity for their ability to efficiently retrieve documents from large-scale datasets. However, the ranking process remains a significant bottleneck, often relying on simplistic scoring functions. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'HybridRank', which integrates neural networks with traditional indexing techniques. By learning complex patterns in document representations, HybridRank achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods. We evaluate HybridRank on the ClueWeb09 dataset, demonstrating its effectiveness in retrieving relevant documents for complex queries.

title: Understanding Gesture-Based Interaction in Virtual Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interaction is a crucial aspect of Virtual Reality (VR) systems, but its impact on user experience and performance is not yet fully understood. This study investigates the effects of gesture complexity, feedback type, and user expertise on task completion time, error rate, and subjective user experience in a VR environment. Our results show that users with prior VR experience exhibit improved performance and higher satisfaction with gestures that provide haptic feedback, whereas novices benefit from simpler gestures with visual feedback. The findings inform the design of more intuitive and effective gesture-based interfaces for VR applications.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Query Expansion on Neural Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have gained popularity in ad-hoc search due to their ability to capture complex semantic relationships. However, their performance can be limited by the quality of the input queries. This paper investigates the effectiveness of query expansion techniques on neural retrieval models, focusing on their impact on retrieval accuracy and efficiency. We conduct a comprehensive evaluation of various query expansion methods, including word embeddings, pseudo-relevance feedback, and learning-to-rank, using a range of benchmark datasets. Our results show that carefully selected query expansion strategies can significantly improve the performance of neural retrieval models, but also highlight the importance of query reformulation and term weighting in achieving optimal results.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have gained popularity due to their scalability and flexibility. However, optimizing query performance in multi-tenant environments remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to changing workloads and resource constraints. Our method, called 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan selection policy. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that RL-Optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based optimizers, achieving up to 30% improvement in query response times and 25% reduction in resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on User Experience and Error Recovery
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their user experience can be compromised by errors, leading to frustration and exclusion. This study investigates the impact of error recovery strategies on user experience and accessibility in voice assistants. We designed and evaluated an inclusive voice assistant prototype that incorporates multimodal feedback, explicit error acknowledgment, and personalized recovery options. Our user study with 40 participants revealed significant improvements in user satisfaction, engagement, and error recovery rates compared to commercial voice assistants. The findings inform the design of more inclusive and supportive voice assistants that cater to diverse user needs.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in capturing semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, they often struggle with ambiguous or underspecified queries. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages both local and global context to disambiguate queries and improve retrieval performance. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of context features based on the query semantics. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, especially in cases where the original query is vague or incomplete.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of graph queries and the need to balance latency and resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, which learns to select efficient query plans based on runtime feedback. Our approach, called 'GraphRL', integrates a deep reinforcement learning model with a distributed query optimizer to adapt to changing workloads and system conditions. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset demonstrate that GraphRL achieves significant improvements in query performance and resource efficiency compared to traditional rule-based optimizers.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Temporal Constraints
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel planning framework for multi-agent systems with temporal constraints. We propose a hierarchical task network (HTN) approach that integrates planning and scheduling to generate optimal plans. Our method exploits the structure of HTNs to efficiently reason about temporal constraints and interactions between agents. Experimental results on a logistics domain demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing planning time and improving plan quality compared to existing methods. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the computational complexity of our algorithm, showing its scalability to large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Detection for Enhanced Human-Computer Collaboration
paper_abstract: As human-computer collaboration becomes increasingly prevalent, detecting user intentions accurately and efficiently is crucial. This paper presents a novel gaze-based intention detection system, leveraging machine learning and computer vision techniques to analyze eye movements and infer user goals. Our system, 'GazeIntent', uses a convolutional neural network to classify gaze patterns and identify intention cues, achieving an accuracy of 92.1% on a dataset of 50 participants. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GazeIntent in a collaborative virtual reality environment, where it enables more efficient and natural human-computer interaction.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Coordination for Autonomous Vehicle Swarms using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle swarms require efficient coordination to achieve complex tasks. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent coordination framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn cooperative policies. Our approach, called 'GNN-Swarm', represents the swarm as a dynamic graph, where each vehicle is a node, and GNNs are used to learn node representations and edge weights. We introduce a novel message-passing scheme that enables vehicles to communicate and adapt to changing swarm configurations. Experiments on a simulated urban environment show that GNN-Swarm outperforms traditional rule-based and centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and collision avoidance.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, especially when agents have conflicting objectives. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate agent behavior and optimize resource allocation. We introduce a hierarchical framework that combines a high-level planning module with a low-level execution module, enabling agents to adapt to changing environments and negotiate resources with other agents. Experimental results on a simulated grid resource allocation problem demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of resource utilization and agent satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and fuse their representations. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention layers that extract features from each modality, followed by a hierarchical fusion layer that combines the features using attention weights. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal data, achieving an average F1-score of 83.2%.

title: Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic signal control is a complex problem that requires adaptive decision-making in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework, 'TrafficMAX', which leverages cooperative learning to optimize traffic signal phases in real-time. Our approach integrates graph neural networks with deep Q-networks to model traffic patterns and learn optimal policies. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network show that TrafficMAX outperforms traditional signal control methods, reducing average travel time by 23.4% and increasing network throughput by 17.2%. We also demonstrate the scalability of our approach in a real-world deployment.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. We propose a hierarchical deep reinforcement learning (H-DRL) framework to tackle this challenge. Our approach consists of a high-level coordinator that learns to assign tasks to agents and a low-level learner that optimizes individual agent policies. We evaluate our method in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario and demonstrate improved coordination and task completion rates compared to existing decentralized DRL methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems by leveraging hierarchical task networks (HTNs). We introduce a hierarchical planning framework that enables agents to reason about both local and global goals, and to dynamically adapt to changes in the environment. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated robot soccer domain, where we demonstrate improved team performance and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized planning methods. Theoretical analysis and empirical results show that our HTN-based coordination mechanism scales to large teams of agents and is robust to agent failures and uncertainties.

title: Faceted Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Collections
paper_abstract: The proliferation of heterogeneous document collections has led to a pressing need for efficient and effective query expansion techniques. This paper presents a novel faceted query expansion approach, which leverages semantic role labeling and entity disambiguation to selectively expand query terms. Our method, termed 'FacetQE', is designed to adapt to the specific characteristics of each document collection, thereby improving retrieval performance and reducing computational overhead. Experimental results on a diverse set of benchmark collections demonstrate the superiority of FacetQE over state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and query processing time.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems face scalability challenges as the volume of data grows exponentially. This paper presents a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'HIQ', which significantly improves query efficiency in DIR systems. HIQ leverages a multi-level index structure to prune unnecessary document collections, reducing the number of node interactions and minimizing network latency. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HIQ achieves an average query speedup of 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods, while maintaining retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Data Sources
paper_abstract: With the increasing prevalence of distributed database systems, optimizing queries across heterogeneous data sources has become a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'HDSOptimizer', which leverages a combination of machine learning and graph-based techniques to efficiently optimize queries across diverse data sources. We propose a novel cost model that captures the nuances of heterogeneity in data sources and develop a genetic algorithm-based approach to search for the optimal query plan. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that HDSOptimizer reduces query execution times by up to 40% compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Attention-Based Communication for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines reinforcement learning with attention-based communication. Our method, called MARL-ATC, enables agents to learn effective communication strategies and allocate tasks cooperatively. We evaluate MARL-ATC on a series of simulated scenarios and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and team rewards compared to existing methods. The attention mechanism is shown to be crucial in facilitating effective communication and adapting to changing environmental conditions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Word Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search query expansion is a crucial technique for improving retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages neural word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms. Our method, called 'NWEE', uses a graph-based framework to integrate word embeddings with traditional query expansion techniques. Experimental results on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that NWEE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain. We also analyze the impact of different word embedding models on retrieval performance.

title: Query Optimization for Massive-scale Time-series Data using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Time-series data has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, existing indexing techniques struggle to efficiently query massive-scale time-series data. This paper presents 'LTRee', a novel learned index structure that leverages machine learning models to predict the optimal query plan for time-series data. We demonstrate that LTRee significantly outperforms traditional indexing methods, such as B-trees and LSM-trees, in terms of query latency and throughput. Our experiments on real-world time-series datasets show that LTRee achieves up to 5x speedup in query processing while reducing storage overhead by 30%.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem in decentralized control. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-MA', that enables agents to learn coordinated policies in a decentralized manner. HRL-MA uses a two-level hierarchy, where high-level policies focus on coordination and low-level policies focus on local control. We evaluate HRL-MA in a simulated multi-agent pursuit-evasion scenario and demonstrate improved coordination and adaptability compared to flat, single-agent reinforcement learning approaches.

title: Designing Accessible Augmented Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to enhance the daily lives of older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing AR interfaces often overlook the unique needs and challenges of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating accessible AR interfaces that cater to older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and usability studies to inform the development of an AR prototype that uses simplified visual cues, auditory feedback, and gesture-based interactions to support wayfinding and object recognition tasks. Our evaluation results show significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional screen-based interfaces.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gestural interfaces that can accommodate a wide range of motor abilities. Our system, 'GestAid', uses a machine learning-based framework to analyze the user's gestures and adapt the interface in real-time to their capabilities. We evaluate GestAid with a user study involving 20 participants with varying levels of motor impairment, demonstrating improved interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional interface designs.

title: Scalable Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to allocate tasks to heterogeneous agents with varying capabilities and preferences. Our method, called 'AgentQL', uses a decentralized, model-free algorithm that learns to optimize task assignments based on agent interactions and environmental feedback. Experimental results on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that AgentQL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Scalable Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Imbalanced Classification
paper_abstract: Online learning algorithms are often plagued by concept drift, noisy data, and class imbalance, leading to degraded performance over time. This paper proposes a novel online learning framework, 'AdaReg', which adaptively regularizes the model to mitigate these issues. We introduce a dynamic regularization scheme that incorporates uncertainty estimates and class balancing techniques to improve robustness and fairness. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that AdaReg achieves state-of-the-art performance on imbalanced classification tasks, while being computationally efficient and scalable to large datasets.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, traditional centralized approaches are often limited by scalability and robustness issues. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to enable autonomous agents to learn optimal allocation strategies. Our approach, called 'AgentRL', utilizes a multi-agent Q-learning algorithm that incorporates graph-based representations of task relationships and agent capabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentRL outperforms traditional auction-based methods in terms of task completion time and robustness to agent failures in a simulated warehouse management scenario.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Medical Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in document retrieval systems, particularly in the medical domain where precise querying is essential for accurate diagnosis and treatment. This paper proposes a novel neural-based query expansion framework, 'MedQN', which leverages deep neural networks to capture complex semantic relationships between medical entities. MedQN incorporates domain-specific knowledge graphs and contextualized word embeddings to generate expanded queries that better capture the intent of the original query. Experimental evaluation on a large medical document collection shows that MedQN significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their usability by individuals with dyslexia is often overlooked. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an inclusive voice assistant, 'DysAssist', tailored to the needs of users with dyslexia. We conducted interviews and surveys with dyslexic individuals to identify specific challenges and preferences, and incorporated these insights into the development of DysAssist. Our prototype features adaptive speech recognition, visual prompts, and personalized feedback mechanisms to enhance user experience and accuracy. A user study with 20 participants showed significant improvements in task completion rate and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Graph-based Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on hand-crafted features and ranking models, which may not capture complex document relationships. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural network approach, GraphRank, which learns to represent documents as nodes in a graph and captures their semantic relationships. We leverage graph attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of neighboring documents and adapt to varying query contexts. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that GraphRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving a 12% improvement in NDCG@10.

title: Investigating the Impact of Colorblind-Friendly Design on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly prevalent, but colorblind users often face difficulties with color-based interfaces. This study examines the effects of colorblind-friendly design on user experience in VR. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, including 10 colorblind individuals, to evaluate the performance and subjective experience of users interacting with colorblind-friendly and traditional VR interfaces. Our results show that colorblind-friendly design significantly improves task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction for colorblind users, while also benefiting non-colorblind users. We provide guidelines for designers and developers to create more inclusive VR experiences.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly prevalent in modern data centers, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to predict optimal query execution plans. We develop a graph neural network model that learns to represent database schema and query patterns, and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing query latency by up to 30% compared to traditional query optimization techniques. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach can adapt to varying workloads and database configurations, making it a promising solution for large-scale distributed databases.

title: Gaze-based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely on precise and efficient user input methods. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework for VR, leveraging deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to predict user intentions from eye-tracking data. Our approach, 'GazeRL', utilizes a hybrid architecture combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for feature extraction and a deep Q-network (DQN) for policy optimization. Experimental results demonstrate that GazeRL outperforms traditional gaze-based methods in terms of accuracy and latency, enabling seamless interactions in immersive VR environments.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper proposes a decentralized approach using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks among autonomous agents. We introduce a novel DCOP-based algorithm that leverages local negotiation and conflict resolution to find near-optimal task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms centralized methods in terms of scalability, flexibility, and adaptability to dynamic task environments.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various domains, but its adoption is hindered by a lack of understanding of user experience. This paper explores the role of embodiment, the sense of owning a virtual body, on user experience in VR. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform with varying levels of embodiment. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to higher user satisfaction, presence, and emotional engagement. However, we also found that individual differences in body ownership and agency play a crucial role in moderating these effects. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems that prioritize user experience and emotional resonance.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on large-scale datasets has become increasingly important in various domains. Distributed column stores (DCS) have emerged as a popular architecture for storing and processing big data. However, query optimization for DCS remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages machine learning and column-store specific features to optimize query plans. We introduce a hybrid cost model that combines traditional query optimization techniques with machine learning-based predictions of query execution times. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that ColOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Conversational Strategies for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational strategies often overlook the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the impact of conversational design on user experience and accessibility. We propose a novel framework, 'ConverseIn', which incorporates disability-specific design guidelines and user testing. Our evaluation with 30 participants with disabilities reveals that ConverseIn significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces frustration, and enhances overall accessibility. We discuss implications for designing inclusive voice assistants that cater to diverse user needs.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document retrieval, integrating hierarchical neural ranking with query expansion. Our proposed model, HierQR, employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture multi-level semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. Additionally, we incorporate a query expansion module that adaptively selects and weights expansion terms based on their relevance to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierQR achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art neural ranking models. Furthermore, our approach reduces the computational overhead associated with traditional query expansion techniques.

title: EmoReact: Affective State Recognition from Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Affective state recognition from human-computer interaction (HCI) is crucial for developing empathetic and personalized systems. This paper presents EmoReact, a novel multimodal framework that recognizes users' emotional states from their interactions with computers. EmoReact combines facial expression analysis, speech pattern recognition, and physiological signal processing to detect emotions. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, showing that EmoReact achieves an overall accuracy of 87.2% in recognizing six basic emotions. The proposed framework has implications for affective computing, human-centered AI, and HCI applications.

title: Incremental View Maintenance for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Maintaining materialized views in distributed database systems is crucial for efficient query processing. However, existing approaches are often limited by high maintenance costs and inadequate support for incremental updates. This paper presents 'DynaView', a novel framework that leverages incremental view maintenance and distributed processing to achieve efficient and scalable view updates. DynaView utilizes a delta-based approach to identify and propagate only the necessary changes, reducing maintenance overhead by up to 75%. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate DynaView's superiority over traditional approaches in terms of update latency and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Dialogue State Tracking in Multi-Domain Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of task-oriented dialogue systems, but it remains a challenging problem in multi-domain settings. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs) to model the hierarchical structure of dialogue states and capture dependencies between domains. Our approach leverages a novel attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant dialogue context and domain-specific knowledge graphs. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ dataset demonstrate that HANs outperform state-of-the-art DST models in terms of joint goal accuracy and scalability, while reducing model parameters by 30%

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents Using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In distributed multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel decentralized approach, 'Distributed Constraint Optimization for Task Allocation' (DCOTA), which leverages distributed constraint optimization to allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. DCOTA utilizes a combination of local search and message-passing algorithms to enable agents to negotiate and agree on task assignments, ensuring feasibility, optimality, and scalability. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of DCOTA in various scenarios, including dynamic environments with changing task requirements and agent availability.

title: Designing Inclusive Augmented Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing AR systems often neglect the needs of this population, leading to frustration and disengagement. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'CARE', an inclusive AR interface tailored to the cognitive and perceptual abilities of older adults. We conducted a participatory design process with caregivers and older adults to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our interface incorporates visual and auditory cues, simplified interactions, and personalized feedback to support wayfinding, memory recall, and social interaction. A usability study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments demonstrates the efficacy of CARE in improving task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Causal Reasoning for Multi-Agent Systems using Probabilistic Graphical Models
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to causal reasoning in multi-agent systems using probabilistic graphical models (PGMs). We introduce a probabilistic framework that enables agents to reason about the causal relationships between their actions and the environment. Our approach leverages Bayesian networks to model the causal dependencies between agents' actions and the environment, and performs inference using variational Bayesian inference. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated multi-agent domain, showing improved decision-making and coordination among agents compared to traditional rule-based approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'HierGAT-QE', which leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to model complex relationships between query terms and their expansions. We introduce a multi-level attention mechanism that adaptively weights term importance at both the local and global levels, enabling more effective query refinement. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierGAT-QE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving improved retrieval precision and recall.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, especially when faced with novel classes and limited training data. This paper introduces a meta-learning approach, Hierarchical Task Embeddings (HTE), which learns to represent tasks as hierarchical embeddings that capture both inter-class and intra-class relationships. By leveraging these embeddings, our model can adapt to new classes with only a few examples, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets. We also provide theoretical insights into the effectiveness of HTE and its ability to generalize to unseen tasks.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Learning-based Relevance Feedback for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Relevance feedback is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it enables users to provide explicit judgments on retrieved documents, leading to improved search results. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to document filtering, which leverages user feedback to adaptively update the retrieval model. Our method, dubbed 'DeepRF', incorporates a neural network to learn a document representation that integrates both semantic and relevance information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepRF significantly outperforms traditional relevance feedback methods, achieving higher precision and recall rates while reducing the number of required feedback iterations.

title: Robust Deep Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis with Noisy Labels
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to predict sentiment from heterogeneous data sources, such as text, images, and audio. However, real-world datasets often contain noisy labels, which can significantly degrade the performance of deep learning models. This paper proposes a robust MSA framework, 'NoiseShield', that leverages meta-learning and attention mechanisms to mitigate the impact of noisy labels. We introduce a novel label cleaning strategy that adaptively selects reliable samples for training, and demonstrate the effectiveness of NoiseShield on three benchmark datasets.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Context-Aware Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages context-aware reinforcement learning to adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach, called CARTA, uses a hierarchical policy framework that integrates local and global decision-making, enabling agents to learn from their experiences and adjust their behavior in response to changing task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that CARTA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems pose significant query optimization challenges due to the variability in workload patterns and resource constraints. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for multi-tenant databases. Our proposed framework, 'QTune', uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy that adapts to changing workload conditions and resource availability. Experimental results on a real-world database workload demonstrate that QTune outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Gaze-Based Multimodal Interaction for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with disabilities, but existing interaction methods can be limiting. This paper presents a novel gaze-based multimodal interaction framework, 'GazeVR', which leverages eye-tracking, voice commands, and hand gestures to enable more intuitive and inclusive user experiences in VR. We evaluate GazeVR using a user study with participants with and without disabilities, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction. Our approach has implications for enhancing accessibility in various VR applications, including education, healthcare, and entertainment.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI Decision-Making
paper_abstract: As AI systems become increasingly pervasive, there is a growing need to understand their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture for explainable AI decision-making. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to identify relevant nodes and edges in complex graph-structured data, and hierarchically aggregates attention weights to generate interpretable explanations for AI-driven decisions. We evaluate HGAT on a suite of benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in providing transparent and trustworthy AI decision-making in various applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often involves intricate interactions among agents. To improve transparency and accountability, we propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent environments. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions, generating interpretable explanations for collective decisions. Experimental results on a simulated traffic management scenario demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of decision quality and explanation accuracy.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants, focusing on users with visual, hearing, and motor impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with disability advocates and users, identifying key barriers and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed system, 'AccessibleVoice', incorporates personalized interfaces, multimodal feedback, and adaptive error correction to enhance accessibility and user experience. A pilot study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-based Indexing
paper_abstract: As large-scale distributed database systems become increasingly prevalent, query optimization plays a critical role in ensuring efficient data retrieval. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach, 'GraphOpt', which leverages the structural properties of query graphs to optimize query plans. GraphOpt utilizes a hierarchical indexing scheme to prune unnecessary subqueries, reducing the search space and improving query performance. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Passage Retrieval with BERT-based Re-Ranking
paper_abstract: The increasing amount of online information necessitates efficient and effective document retrieval systems. This paper proposes a neural passage retrieval model that leverages BERT-based re-ranking to improve the ranking quality of top retrieved documents. Our approach combines a dense passage retriever with a BERT-based re-ranker, which fine-tunes the model to capture semantic relationships between queries and passages. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art retrieval models.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Inductive Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but most existing methods rely on transductive learning, which requires access to the entire graph during training. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, HAGNN, that enables inductive node classification. HAGNN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant neighboring nodes and subgraphs, allowing it to generalize well to unseen graphs. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in inductive node classification tasks, achieving an average accuracy improvement of 5.2%.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval using Graph-based Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval systems struggle to effectively integrate textual and visual cues, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel adaptive query expansion approach, 'GraphSEM', which leverages graph-based semantic embeddings to capture the intricate relationships between query terms and multimodal features. Our method dynamically updates the query representation by incorporating contextual information from the graph, allowing for more accurate retrieval of relevant documents. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness to query ambiguity.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their potential to increase user trust and transparency. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that generates personalized explanations for recommended items. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex item relationships and incorporates hierarchical pooling to selectively focus on relevant features. We conduct extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Document Classification
paper_abstract: Document classification is a fundamental task in natural language processing, but existing deep learning models often require significant computational resources and memory. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global document semantics to improve classification efficiency. Our HAN model consists of a two-level attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant sentences and words, reducing the input dimensionality and computational cost. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves competitive accuracy with state-of-the-art methods while requiring up to 50% fewer parameters and 30% less computation.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in distributed artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel framework that combines reinforcement learning with graph attention mechanisms to learn effective coordination strategies. We model the agent interactions as a graph and use attention weights to focus on the most critical agents and their relationships. Our approach is evaluated on a series of complex coordination tasks, demonstrating improved performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art methods. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence of our algorithm and its robustness to agent failures.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Users with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have become pervasive in HCI applications, but their performance often degrades for users with motor disabilities. This paper presents a novel approach to designing inclusive gesture recognition systems that accommodate users with varying motor abilities. We propose a multi-modal fusion framework that combines computer vision, machine learning, and electromyography (EMG) signals to recognize gestures. Our approach is evaluated on a dataset of 20 users with motor disabilities, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and reduced latency compared to existing systems.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Sparse Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant texts for answer extraction. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'SparseGNN', which leverages sparse graph neural networks to model the semantic relationships between passages and questions. By exploiting the sparsity patterns in the graph, SparseGNN reduces the computational complexity of passage retrieval, achieving a 3x speedup over state-of-the-art dense graph models. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that SparseGNN maintains comparable answer accuracy to dense models while significantly reducing the retrieval time.

title: Adaptive Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized reinforcement learning framework for adaptive task allocation, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities and environmental constraints. We introduce a novel decentralized Q-learning algorithm that enables agents to learn from their local observations and communicate with neighboring agents to achieve global optimality. Experimental results on a simulated robotics domain demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient cooperation among agents to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'CATALYST', which enables agents to learn cooperative task allocation policies in decentralized and dynamic environments. Our approach combines graph neural networks with multi-agent Q-learning to enable agents to reason about task dependencies and allocate tasks effectively. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation domains demonstrate that CATALYST outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing task requirements.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent task allocation, leveraging deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in large-scale agent networks. Our proposed framework, 'MARL-Allocator', utilizes a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn effective allocation policies that maximize overall system utility. We evaluate MARL-Allocator on a range of simulated scenarios, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional, heuristic-based allocation methods. Our results have important implications for real-world applications, such as drone swarm coordination and autonomous logistics.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Fusion in Medical Image Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal medical image analysis has become increasingly important for accurate disease diagnosis. However, the fusion of heterogeneous data sources (e.g., MRI, CT, and PET scans) remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to adaptively weigh and combine features from different modalities. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to capture complex relationships between modalities and utilizes a hierarchical fusion strategy to reduce computational overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale brain tumor segmentation dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art fusion methods, achieving a 12.5% improvement in Dice similarity coefficient.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Decision Making
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of AI-driven decision-making systems, particularly in high-stakes applications. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that generates interpretable explanations for AI-driven decisions. Our approach leverages multi-level attention mechanisms to identify relevant input features and their relationships, providing a hierarchical understanding of the decision-making process. Experimental results on a healthcare dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art explainability methods in terms of accuracy and interpretability, while maintaining decision-making performance.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Augmented Reality Systems Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) systems become increasingly ubiquitous, ensuring secure user authentication is crucial. We propose a novel gaze-based authentication approach, 'GazeAuth', which leverages deep learning to classify users based on their gaze patterns. Our method uses a convolutional neural network to extract features from eye-tracking data and a recurrent neural network to model the temporal dependencies of gaze movements. Experimental results on a dataset of 50 users show that GazeAuth achieves an accuracy of 97.5% and an equal error rate of 2.1%, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods. We also demonstrate the feasibility of our approach on a commercial AR headset.

title: Gaze-Based Gesture Recognition for Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility for individuals with disabilities. However, current VR systems often rely on manual controllers, which can be limiting for users with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel gaze-based gesture recognition system, 'GazeVR', which enables users to interact with VR environments using only their gaze. We employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) to classify gaze patterns into distinct gestures, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% in our user study. GazeVR demonstrates significant potential for enhancing accessibility and promoting inclusive VR experiences.

title: Efficient Document Indexing with Neural Hashing for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional indexing methods for information retrieval systems are limited by their reliance on exact matching, leading to inefficient query processing and poor scalability. This paper proposes a novel neural hashing approach, 'NeuroIndex', which learns compact binary representations of documents and queries. By leveraging the density-aware attention mechanism, NeuroIndex achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, outperforming traditional indexing methods by up to 3x in query processing speed while maintaining comparable retrieval quality. We also present an efficient online indexing algorithm, enabling NeuroIndex to accommodate large-scale document collections and support real-time querying.

title: Co-Creative Designing with Humans and Machines: A Study on AI-Driven Sketching Tools for Enhanced Collaboration
paper_abstract: This paper explores the potential of AI-driven sketching tools in facilitating co-creative design processes between humans and machines. We present 'Sketch Buddy', a novel system that leverages generative adversarial networks (GANs) to assist designers in generating and refining 2D sketches. Our user study with 20 professional designers reveals that Sketch Buddy enhances design quality, reduces cognitive load, and fosters more effective collaboration. We also identify key factors influencing human-AI collaboration, including trust, communication, and feedback mechanisms. Our findings have implications for the development of more effective AI-driven design tools that support human-centered design processes.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalized Pronunciation Modeling for Non-Native Speakers
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their utility is hindered for non-native speakers due to difficulties in pronunciation recognition. This paper explores the design of inclusive voice assistants by developing a personalized pronunciation modeling approach tailored to individual non-native speakers' linguistic backgrounds. We propose a novel deep learning architecture that integrates phonetic, lexical, and prosodic features to improve pronunciation recognition. Our user study with 50 non-native speakers demonstrates significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction, highlighting the potential for more inclusive voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in image classification tasks, but their lack of transparency and interpretability hinders trust and adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to learn feature importance and generate explainable classification results. Our experiments on the ImageNet dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms existing attention-based methods in terms of accuracy and attribution quality, while providing insights into the decision-making process of the model.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn cooperative task allocation strategies. We model the agent-task interactions as a graph and propose a GCN-based architecture that incorporates agent features, task requirements, and environmental constraints. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods, achieving higher task completion rates and reduced communication overhead. We also analyze the learned GCN embeddings to provide insights into the emergent coordination patterns among agents.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but existing VR systems often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework, 'AccessibleVR', which incorporates tactile, auditory, and olfactory feedback to provide an immersive experience for visually impaired users. Our approach leverages machine learning-based object recognition and 3D audio spatialization to convey spatial information. We conducted a user study with 20 visually impaired participants, demonstrating significant improvements in navigation and object interaction using AccessibleVR compared to traditional screen-reader-based interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Semantic Search
paper_abstract: Semantic search has become increasingly important in modern information retrieval systems. However, query expansion techniques often rely on manual feature engineering and heuristics. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using reinforcement learning, where an agent learns to select relevant expansion terms based on the semantic context of the query. We develop a customized reward function that incorporates both relevance and diversity metrics, and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets. Our approach is particularly effective for long-tail queries, where traditional methods often struggle.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Learned Index Structures in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Traditional B-tree indexes are often suboptimal for main-memory databases, where memory access patterns and data distributions can be highly irregular. This paper explores the application of learned index structures, which leverage machine learning models to optimize query performance. We propose a novel technique, 'ML-Index', that integrates a learned model with a traditional B-tree to improve query latency and reduce memory accesses. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that ML-Index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x, while requiring minimal additional memory overhead.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'Graph-MARL', which leverages graph reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments for heterogeneous agents. By modeling agent interactions as a graph, we can capture complex dependencies and constraints, and learn effective allocation policies that adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our experiments on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that Graph-MARL outperforms state-of-the-art decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and system efficiency.

title: Efficient Adversarial Training for Robustness against Backdoor Attacks in Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to backdoor attacks, where maliciously crafted inputs can manipulate the model's predictions. Adversarial training is a promising defense strategy, but existing methods are computationally expensive and often require large datasets.
