This paper proposes a novel efficient adversarial training framework, 'EfficientBackdoor', which leverages a surrogate model-based approach to generate adversarial examples. We introduce a gradient-based optimization technique that reduces the computational overhead while maintaining the robustness of the trained model. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that EfficientBackdoor achieves state-of-the-art robustness against backdoor attacks with significantly reduced training time.

title: EyeTrackingUI: A Gaze-Based Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information, but existing interfaces often rely on manual input methods that can be cumbersome and detract from the immersive experience. This paper presents EyeTrackingUI, a novel gaze-based interface that leverages eye tracking technology to enable users to navigate and interact with virtual objects in a more natural and intuitive way. We evaluate EyeTrackingUI in a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. Our approach has important implications for enhancing user experience in VR applications.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic management is a critical application of autonomous agents, but existing approaches struggle to balance individual agent objectives with system-wide efficiency. This paper introduces HRL-Traffic, a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that coordinates agents to optimize traffic flow. Our approach decomposes the traffic network into a hierarchy of zones, each managed by an autonomous agent that learns to balance local and global objectives. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulator demonstrate that HRL-Traffic reduces congestion by 23% and travel times by 17% compared to state-of-the-art decentralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) has garnered significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often lack transparency in their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for MSA, which incorporates both intra-modal and inter-modal attention mechanisms to selectively focus on salient features from textual, visual, and acoustic inputs. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on three benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results while providing interpretable insights into the sentiment analysis process.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Expert Search
paper_abstract: Expert search systems struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the complexity of user queries. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-ES', which leverages a deep learning model to generate context-aware query expansions. NQE-ES learns to identify relevant terms and phrases from a large corpus of expert-annotated documents, and incorporates these into the original query. Experimental results on the TREC Expert Search dataset demonstrate that NQE-ES significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 23% increase in retrieval precision and a 17% decrease in query latency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recent advances in graph neural networks (GNNs) have led to significant improvements in recommendation systems. However, the lack of explainability in these models hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical GNN architecture, 'HierExplain', which integrates attention-based feature importance and graph-based explanations to provide transparent recommendations. We conduct experiments on three real-world datasets, demonstrating that HierExplain outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Enhancing Explainability in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of explainability hinders trust and adoption. This paper presents a novel approach to enhance explainability in DRL using hierarchical attention mechanisms. Our method, HierAttn, disentangles the decision-making process into multiple levels, enabling the identification of critical state features and action influences. We evaluate HierAttn on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, demonstrating improved explainability without compromising policy performance. Furthermore, we provide a theoretical analysis of the attention mechanisms, shedding light on their role in promoting interpretability.

title: EyeTracking-based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Intelligent Tutoring Systems
paper_abstract: Intelligent tutoring systems (ITS) often struggle to adapt to individual learners' needs, leading to frustration and disengagement. This paper introduces 'EyeGuide', an innovative ITS that leverages eye-tracking data to dynamically adjust problem difficulty in real-time. Our approach uses machine learning to analyze pupil dilation, fixation duration, and scanpath patterns to infer learners' cognitive load and knowledge gaps. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates that EyeGuide significantly improves learning outcomes, reduces time-on-task, and enhances user experience compared to traditional ITS approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to improve the retrieval effectiveness by reformulating the original query. In this paper, we propose a novel neural retrieval model-based query expansion approach, dubbed NeuroQE. NeuroQE leverages the power of deep learning to learn semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Our approach uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant terms from the top-retrieved documents, leading to more informative and diverse query expansions. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc IR benchmark dataset demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing demands efficient indexing mechanisms to support high-performance query processing. This paper presents 'RTIndex', a novel indexing framework that adapts to dynamic data distributions and query workloads. RTIndex employs a hierarchical indexing structure, combining Bloom filters and learned indexes, to minimize indexing overhead and optimize query response times. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrates that RTIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query throughput and 2x in indexing speed.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning of Rare Diseases
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning of rare diseases is a challenging task due to the scarcity of training data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages the hierarchical structure of medical ontologies to improve the learning of rare disease classifiers. Our HAN model adaptively focuses on relevant features and ontological concepts, enabling effective learning from limited data. We evaluate our approach on a realistic dataset of rare diseases and demonstrate significant improvements in classification accuracy compared to state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods.

title: Adversarial Training for Robust Explainability in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Explainability techniques for deep neural networks (DNNs) are crucial for building trust in AI systems. However, recent studies have shown that these techniques can be vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'AdvEx', which aims to improve the robustness of explainability methods against such attacks. We introduce a novel loss function that jointly optimizes the model's performance and explainability, while incorporating adversarial perturbations to simulate real-world attacks. Experimental results on popular image classification datasets demonstrate that AdvEx significantly improves the robustness of feature attribution methods, such as saliency maps and feature importance, against state-of-the-art attacks.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in High-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Self-Organizing Maps
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional data is a challenging task due to the curse of dimensionality. Existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity or poor detection accuracy. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Self-Organizing Maps (HiSOM), which leverages the strengths of self-organizing maps and hierarchical clustering. HiSOM efficiently identifies anomalies in high-dimensional data by iteratively applying SOMs to local clusters and adaptively adjusting the number of clusters. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiSOM outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Revisiting User Experience in Virtual Reality: A Multimodal Interaction Framework
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding user experience is crucial for designing effective interfaces. This paper proposes a multimodal interaction framework that integrates gaze, gesture, and voice inputs to facilitate seamless user interaction in VR environments. We conducted a user study to evaluate the framework's performance and usability, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. Our framework provides a foundation for developing more immersive and accessible VR experiences.

title: Query Expansion via Deep Semantic Embeddings for Natural Language Search
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on surface-level term co-occurrences, often failing to capture nuanced semantic relationships. We propose 'SemExp', a novel approach that leverages deep learning to learn dense semantic embeddings of queries and documents. Our method incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively weigh term importance and a graph-based propagation scheme to refine embeddings. Experimental results on a large-scale IR benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for ambiguous and under-specified queries.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestures for Inclusive Virtual Reality Interactions
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on standardized gestures that may not be accessible or intuitive for users with diverse abilities. This paper presents an adaptive gesture recognition framework that leverages machine learning and user modeling to personalize VR interactions. Our approach incorporates a probabilistic gesture recognition algorithm that adapts to individual users' motor abilities, learning styles, and preferences. We evaluate our framework through a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience, task completion time, and overall system usability.

title: Reinforced Relevance Feedback for Context-Aware Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional relevance feedback methods in information retrieval (IR) systems rely on user interactions, which can be sparse and unreliable. This paper proposes a novel reinforced learning framework, 'CoRIF', that leverages contextual information to adaptively refine the retrieval model. We formulate the feedback process as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to optimize the retrieval policy. Experiments on a large-scale news dataset demonstrate that CoRIF significantly improves retrieval accuracy and reduces the number of required feedback iterations compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). Our approach, called Hierarchical Task Allocator (HTA), consists of a high-level coordinator that sets task priorities and a low-level scheduler that assigns tasks to individual agents. HTA is trained using a hierarchical reward function that balances task completion with agent utilities. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HTA outperforms traditional decentralized approaches in terms of task completion time and agent satisfaction.

title: Neural Retrieval with Document Expansion for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models struggle to retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus, especially when the question is ambiguous or has multiple answers. We propose a neural retrieval approach, called NERD, which incorporates document expansion to enrich the context of relevant passages. Our model uses a transformer-based encoder to jointly learn question and passage representations, and a neural ranker to re-score the passages based on their expanded contexts. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that NERD outperforms state-of-the-art ODQA models, achieving a 12% improvement in retrieval recall and a 9% improvement in answer accuracy.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation approach for multi-agent systems, leveraging auction-based mechanisms to efficiently allocate tasks among agents. Our proposed method, called Distributed Auction-based Task Allocation (DATA), utilizes a decentralized Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auction to incentivize agents to reveal their true capabilities and preferences. We prove that DATA is strategy-proof, ensuring that agents have no incentive to misreport their capabilities. Experimental results on a simulated multi-agent system demonstrate that DATA outperforms existing centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and system efficiency.

title: Towards Efficient Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention framework, 'HierAttn', which leverages the structural properties of agent relationships to allocate tasks effectively. By recursively applying graph attention mechanisms, HierAttn captures both local and global dependencies between agents, enabling the identification of optimal task assignments. Experimental results on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization compared to existing allocation strategies.

title: Designing Accessible Visualizations for Individuals with Color Vision Deficiency
paper_abstract: Individuals with color vision deficiency (CVD) often struggle to interpret visualizations that rely on color cues. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible visualizations that are optimized for users with CVD. We conducted a user study to identify common visualization pitfalls and developed a set of guidelines for creating CVD-friendly visualizations. Our approach leverages machine learning-based color palette optimization and adaptive visualization rendering to ensure that visualizations are perceivable and understandable by users with CVD. Evaluation results show significant improvement in visualization comprehension and user experience.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents for Real-time Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: As the world transitions to renewable energy sources, smart grids face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources in real-time. This paper presents a novel multi-agent system, 'SmartAllocator', that coordinates autonomous agents to optimize resource allocation in smart grids. Our approach leverages advanced negotiation protocols and decentralized decision-making to minimize energy waste and reduce peak demand. We validate our approach through extensive simulations, demonstrating improved performance compared to traditional centralized approaches. SmartAllocator has the potential to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve the reliability of smart grids.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing query execution plans in such systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a reinforcement learning framework that learns to optimize query plans based on the feedback from the database. Our approach leverages the exploration-exploitation trade-off to balance the optimization of query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Dynamic Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel dynamic query expansion approach, 'DREx', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to adaptively refine the search query based on user behavior and relevance feedback. We introduce a multi-agent framework that simulates user interactions and optimizes query expansion policies using a reward function that balances precision and recall. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search effectiveness and efficiency using DREx compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Dialogue Management for Conversational AI
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel dialogue management framework for conversational AI, HADM, which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to model multi-turn dialogues. HADM uses a graph-based representation to capture the conversation context and incorporates a hierarchical attention module to selectively focus on relevant dialogue history. We evaluate HADM on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in dialogue coherence, fluency, and overall user satisfaction. Our results show that HADM outperforms state-of-the-art models in generating contextually relevant and engaging responses.

title: Decentralized Timed Commitment Protocols for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, ensuring timely commitment to actions is crucial for achieving global goals. This paper presents a decentralized timed commitment protocol, 'ChronoCommit', which enables agents to make reliable commitments while respecting real-time constraints. We introduce a novel distributed clock synchronization mechanism that adapts to network delays and agent heterogeneity. Our protocol ensures that agents commit to actions within a bounded time interval, thereby preventing unnecessary rollbacks and improving system efficiency. Experimental evaluations on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of ChronoCommit in reducing commitment latency and increasing system resilience.

title: Efficient Multi-Modal Dialogue State Tracking using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Accurate dialogue state tracking is crucial for task-oriented conversational AI systems. Existing approaches often rely on hand-crafted features or complex pipeline models, which can be brittle and computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) framework for multi-modal dialogue state tracking, which integrates visual, spoken, and textual cues. Our model leverages graph-based representation learning to capture subtle dependencies between entities and context, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the DSTC2 benchmark. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in real-world conversational scenarios, showcasing its potential for deployment in human-AI interaction systems.

title: RAID-Tree: A Novel Indexing Scheme for Efficient Range Queries in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have become increasingly popular due to their ability to process queries at high speeds. However, range queries remain a bottleneck in these systems. This paper presents RAID-Tree, a novel indexing scheme designed to efficiently handle range queries in main-memory databases. Our approach combines a hierarchical tree structure with a novel partitioning strategy, allowing for fast query execution and efficient maintenance. Experimental results demonstrate that RAID-Tree outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques, achieving up to 5x speedup for range queries on real-world datasets.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Resource Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In complex systems, multiple agents often compete for shared resources, necessitating effective negotiation strategies to ensure efficiency and fairness. This paper presents a novel adaptive negotiation framework, 'ANREA', which integrates machine learning and game-theoretic concepts to optimize resource allocation in dynamic environments. ANREA enables agents to learn from experience, adapt to changing context, and negotiate with each other to achieve Pareto-optimal outcomes. Experimental results in a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that ANREA outperforms traditional auction-based approaches in terms of resource utilization, fairness, and robustness to uncertainty.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning (RL) to query expansion, where the goal is to learn an optimal expansion policy that maximizes retrieval effectiveness. We propose a novel RL framework, 'QueryExRL', which leverages a combination of lexical and semantic features to guide the expansion process. Experimental results on the TREC Ad-Hoc dataset demonstrate that QueryExRL outperforms state-of-the-art expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gamification in Promoting Healthy Behavior through Mobile Applications
paper_abstract: Mobile health applications have become increasingly popular for promoting healthy behavior. This study investigates the effectiveness of gamification in encouraging users to adopt healthy habits through mobile apps. We designed and developed a mobile app that incorporated gamification elements, such as points, badges, and leaderboards, to motivate users to engage in physical activity and healthy eating. Our results show that gamification significantly increased user engagement and retention, resulting in improved physical activity levels and healthier dietary choices. However, we also found that the effectiveness of gamification varied depending on individual differences in motivation and personality traits.

title: Scalable Indexing for Distributed Time-Series Databases using Adaptive Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and sensor networks has led to an explosion in time-series data, posing significant challenges for scalable and efficient data indexing. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, AdaptiveBloomTS, which leverages Bloom filters to accelerate range queries in distributed time-series databases. Our approach dynamically adjusts the filter size and hash functions based on the underlying data distribution, ensuring optimal performance and storage efficiency. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that AdaptiveBloomTS outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage savings.

title: Efficient Document Expansion using Query-Dependent Contextualized Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query-dependent document expansion is a crucial step in many information retrieval systems. Existing methods rely on static word embeddings, which may not capture the nuanced relationships between query terms and document content. We propose a novel approach that leverages contextualized embeddings, specifically designed to incorporate query-dependent semantics. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for verbose queries. We also show that our method can be seamlessly integrated into existing retrieval frameworks, making it a practical solution for real-world IR systems.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent task allocation is a fundamental problem in distributed artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HiMAL', which enables efficient task allocation in large-scale multi-agent systems. HiMAL utilizes a two-level hierarchy, where high-level agents learn to allocate tasks to low-level agents based on their capabilities and availability. We demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of HiMAL through extensive simulations on a variety of task allocation scenarios, showcasing significant improvements over traditionalflat allocation methods.

title: Scalable Agent-Based Distributed Resource Allocation using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed resource allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, especially in large-scale networks. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn efficient resource allocation strategies. Our framework, 'AgentGNN', represents the agent network as a graph and uses GNNs to learn node representations that capture complex dependencies between agents. We develop a decentralized allocation algorithm that uses these representations to allocate resources in a scalable and efficient manner. Experimental results on various synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentGNN in achieving near-optimal allocation while reducing communication overhead.

title: Gaze-Informed Adaptive Interface for Enhanced User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but current interfaces often neglect the user's gaze as a valuable input modality. We propose a novel gaze-informed adaptive interface (GIAI) that leverages eye-tracking data to dynamically adjust the VR environment, enhancing user experience and reducing cognitive load. Our approach integrates a machine learning-based gaze classification model with a real-time VR rendering engine, enabling personalized interface adaptations. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time, error rate, and user satisfaction using GIAI compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Databases using Adaptive Data Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used to support large-scale applications, but query performance remains a major bottleneck. This paper presents a novel adaptive data replication strategy, 'ADRep', which dynamically adjusts data placement based on query patterns and workload characteristics. ADRep leverages machine learning-based forecasting to predict query hotspots and proactively replicates data to reduce latency and improve throughput. Experimental results on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate that ADRep achieves up to 3x query performance improvement compared to existing replication strategies while minimizing storage overhead.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: As Augmented Reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for more intuitive and natural interaction methods. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system for AR using deep learning. We propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) that detects and tracks the user's gaze, allowing for precise and hands-free interaction with virtual objects. Our approach leverages a large-scale dataset of eye movement patterns and achieves a high level of accuracy in gaze estimation. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of our system in various AR scenarios.

title: Interpretable Attention Mechanisms for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) systems become increasingly prevalent in real-world applications, there is a growing need for transparent and interpretable decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel attention mechanism, 'AttrAction', which enables explainable policy learning in cooperative MARL settings. By incorporating attention weights into the policy update rules, AttrAction provides insights into the interactions between agents and their environment. We evaluate AttrAction on a range of MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved transparency and performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Robots
paper_abstract: Hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) has shown great promise in autonomous robotics, but its application is often hindered by high computational costs and sample inefficiency. This paper introduces a novel HRL framework, 'HiRLayer', which leverages a hierarchical abstraction of the state-space to reduce the complexity of the exploration-exploitation trade-off. We propose a multi-level attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant sub-goals, allowing the agent to learn more efficiently and effectively. Experimental results on a robotic grasping task demonstrate that HiRLayer outperforms state-of-the-art HRL methods in terms of both sample efficiency and task performance.

title: Distilling Knowledge from Pre-trained Language Models via Contrastive Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Pre-trained language models have achieved state-of-the-art results in various natural language processing tasks. However, their large size and complexity hinder their deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper presents a novel knowledge distillation approach that leverages contrastive representation learning to transfer knowledge from pre-trained language models to smaller models. Our method, called 'ContraDistill', learns to align the representations of the teacher and student models using a contrastive loss function. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ContraDistill outperforms existing knowledge distillation methods, achieving up to 3% improvement in accuracy while reducing the model size by 75%.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding is a complex problem in AI, with applications in robotics, video games, and autonomous systems. This paper introduces a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'MAP-RL', which leverages graph neural networks to efficiently find near-optimal paths for multiple agents in dynamic environments. We propose a hierarchical planning strategy that decomposes the problem into sub-tasks, enabling faster computation and improved scalability. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that MAP-RL outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: AUTOSIG, a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, is presented to autonomously control traffic signals in real-time. AUTOSIG leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to optimize signal timings based on local traffic conditions and communicates with neighboring agents to minimize congestion. We propose a novel graph attention mechanism to efficiently handle high-dimensional state spaces and demonstrate significant reductions in travel times and queues compared to traditional TCP/IP and state-of-the-art MARL methods. AUTOSIG is evaluated on a large-scale traffic simulator, showcasing its scalability and adaptability to diverse traffic scenarios.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but their accessibility for users with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents a novel framework, 'InConverse', which incorporates participatory design principles to develop inclusive conversational interfaces. We conducted co-design sessions with users with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive disabilities to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our framework includes a set of design guidelines and a prototype system that provides real-time accommodations, such as speech-to-text, text-to-speech, and gesture recognition. A user study demonstrates that InConverse significantly improves interaction experience and reduces frustration for users with disabilities.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph (NQG) framework for efficient query expansion. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model query-term relationships and generates a robust set of expansion terms. We demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness on multiple benchmark datasets, including the TREC-8 and Robust-04 collections. Furthermore, our experiments show that NQG-based query expansion outperforms traditional methods in terms of computational efficiency and scalability.

title: Designing Inclusive Chatbots: A Study on Emotional Intelligence and Empathy in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the role of emotional intelligence and empathy in chatbot design, with a focus on creating more inclusive and supportive human-computer interactions. We conducted a user study with 100 participants, analyzing their interactions with a chatbot prototype that employed empathetic responses and emotional intelligence-based dialogue management. Our results show that users perceived the empathetic chatbot as more trustworthy and helpful, particularly among participants with anxiety or depression. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more empathetic and supportive chatbots that cater to diverse user needs and abilities.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph-Based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) algorithms are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can compromise their performance and stability. This paper proposes a novel graph-based anomaly detection framework, 'DRL-Guard', to identify and mitigate such attacks in real-time. By modeling the agent's interaction with the environment as a graph, we leverage graph convolutional networks to detect anomalies in the state-action trajectory. Our experiments on popular DRL benchmarks demonstrate that DRL-Guard can detect a wide range of adversarial attacks with high accuracy, while incurring minimal overhead on the agent's policy.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval has seen significant improvements with the advent of deep learning-based methods. However, query expansion remains a crucial component in enhancing retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion, leveraging knowledge graph embeddings learned through a deep neural network. Our model, 'KG-QE', effectively captures semantic relationships between entities and expands queries to improve retrieval recall. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that KG-QE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a 12.5% increase in mean average precision.

title: _efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Context-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search has gained popularity due to its ability to capture semantic relationships in queries and documents. However, the effectiveness of neural search models relies heavily on the quality of query embeddings. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages context-aware embeddings to refine query representations. By incorporating contextual information from the query, CAQE improves the retrieval performance of neural search models. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Join Ordering
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used to support large-scale data analytics. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel adaptive join ordering algorithm, 'AJO', which dynamically adjusts the join order based on runtime statistics and data distribution. AJO leverages a combination of machine learning-based prediction models and cost-based optimization to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world benchmark dataset show that AJO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: Coordinating autonomous vehicles in complex urban environments requires efficient communication and decision-making among agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HierAttn-MARL', which enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information from neighboring vehicles and the environment. We demonstrate improved coordination and reduced collisions in simulated urban scenarios, outperforming existing decentralized and centralized approaches. HierAttn-MARL's adaptability to changing traffic patterns and its ability to handle partial observability make it a promising solution for real-world autonomous vehicle deployment.

title: Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Hierarchical Task Allocation for Real-Time Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent pathfinding approach for real-time urban traffic management. We propose a hierarchical task allocation framework that decomposes complex traffic management tasks into smaller, manageable sub-tasks, which are then assigned to individual agents. Each agent employs a probabilistic roadmap method to compute optimal routes, while a central coordinator ensures global optimality and resolves conflicts between agents. Experiments on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate significant reductions in congestion and travel times compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Motion Planning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient motion planning to navigate complex environments. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (DHRL) framework that integrates high-level planning with low-level control. Our approach leverages a hierarchical policy structure, where a high-level planner generates waypoints and a low-level controller executes them. We introduce a new exploration strategy that encourages the agent to visit diverse scenarios, improving the overall robustness of the motion planning policy. Experimental results on a realistic simulation platform demonstrate that our DHRL approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of safety, efficiency, and adaptability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Context-Aware Term Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often struggle with query ambiguity and limited contextual understanding. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages context-aware term embeddings to improve the retrieval performance. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture both local and global context, enabling the model to better disambiguate query terms and identify relevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Towards Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent task allocation is a fundamental problem in distributed artificial intelligence, where agents must efficiently allocate tasks to achieve a common goal. This paper proposes a novel graph neural network (GNN) framework, 'GATA', which learns to represent agent-task relationships as a graph and outputs an optimal allocation. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that captures both local and global dependencies between agents and tasks, leading to improved allocation efficiency and Adaptability. Experimental results on two real-world domains demonstrate that GATA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of allocation quality and computational efficiency.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Real-time IoT Sensor Streams
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has generated an exponential increase in sensor data, making real-time anomaly detection a critical task. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework, 'IoTAD', which leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to identify anomalies in high-dimensional, high-frequency IoT sensor streams. Our approach incorporates a transfer learning mechanism that adapts to new devices and environments, thereby reducing the need for extensive retraining. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that IoTAD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and latency.

title: Exploring Gestural Interaction for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance accessibility and inclusivity, but traditional controllers can be challenging for users with motor impairments. This paper investigates the design and evaluation of gestural interaction techniques for VR, focusing on users with limited mobility. We propose a novel machine learning-based hand-tracking system that recognizes and interprets a range of gestures, allowing users to interact with virtual objects in a more intuitive and accessible manner. Our user study demonstrates improved engagement and task completion rates for participants with motor impairments, highlighting the potential of gestural interaction to increase VR inclusivity.

title: Scalable Data Partitioning for High-Performance Transactional Databases
paper_abstract: As transactional databases grow in scale and complexity, efficient data partitioning becomes crucial for maintaining high performance and low latency. This paper presents a novel data partitioning algorithm, 'ParTx', which leverages graph-based clustering and load balancing to minimize transactional conflicts and optimize resource utilization. We evaluate ParTx on a real-world e-commerce dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in throughput, latency, and resource efficiency compared to existing partitioning schemes.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing database queries is crucial for efficient data retrieval in distributed databases. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, which can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans. Our method, called 'RL-QOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal plan from a set of possible plans, taking into account the database's dynamic workload and resource constraints. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that RL-QOpt achieves an average speedup of 2.5x over state-of-the-art optimization techniques while reducing the optimization time by 75%.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Sentence Embeddings for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to reduce the search space for answer extraction. This paper introduces HierSent, a novel method for learning hierarchical sentence embeddings that capture both local and global semantic relationships within passages. Our approach leverages a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes sentence embeddings for retrieval and answer extraction. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HierSent outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 15% improvement in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy while reducing computational overhead by 30%

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Document-Oriented Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed document-oriented databases (DDODs) are increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale semi-structured data. However, query optimization in DDODs remains a challenging task due to the complexity of document schema and the distributed nature of the system. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'DQO', which leverages a combination of machine learning-based cost modeling and graph-based query rewriting to minimize query latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world DDOD system demonstrate that DQO achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering using Deep Neural Networks for High-Dimensional Data
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but it becomes computationally expensive for high-dimensional data. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn hierarchical representations of data. Our method, called 'HierNet', uses a stacked autoencoder to learn a compact representation of the input data, followed by a hierarchical clustering algorithm. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierNet on several benchmark datasets, showing significant improvements in clustering quality and computational efficiency compared to traditional methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed resource allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents must coordinate to maximize global utility. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-MA', which enables agents to learn both local and global policies. The framework consists of two layers: a lower layer where agents learn to allocate resources based on local observations, and an upper layer where agents coordinate to share resources and optimize global utility. Experimental results on a simulated grid network demonstrate that HRL-MA outperforms traditional methods in terms of resource utilization and overall system performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years. However, most existing methods rely on feature attribution or model-based explanations, which may not fully capture the complex relationships between users and items. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) model for recommendation systems. HAGNN learns to represent users and items as hierarchical graphs, incorporating both local and global dependencies. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different graph layers and nodes. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering using Deep Neural Networks for Large-scale Customer Segmentation
paper_abstract: Customer segmentation is a crucial task in marketing and customer relationship management. However, traditional clustering algorithms struggle to scale with large datasets and often fail to capture complex relationships between customers. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn effective representations of customers. Our method, 'DeepSeg', uses a stacked autoencoder to compress high-dimensional customer data and a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group customers based on their learned representations. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that DeepSeg outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: With the increasing demand for real-time analytics, traditional query optimization techniques fall short in handling large volumes of data. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'QRaptor', that leverages machine learning to predict optimal query execution plans for real-time data warehousing. QRaptor employs a hybrid approach, combining reinforcement learning with cost-based optimization, to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that QRaptor achieves an average query response time reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Scalable Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries on Modern Storage Devices
paper_abstract: The advent of modern storage devices, such as flash and hybrid storage systems, has transformed the landscape of query processing. However, traditional indexing techniques are often inefficient or ineffective in these environments. This paper presents a novel indexing strategy, 'FlexIndex', designed specifically for multi-dimensional range queries on modern storage devices. FlexIndex leverages the inherent characteristics of these devices to achieve significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art indexing techniques. Our experimental evaluation on real-world datasets demonstrates that FlexIndex reduces query latency by up to 70% and improves throughput by a factor of 3.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network planning approach for multi-agent systems. We extend the traditional HTN framework to accommodate the complexities of multi-agent coordination, introducing a decentralized planning algorithm that allows agents to reason about their own tasks and goals while considering the plans of other agents. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a variety of scenarios, including disaster response and smart city applications. We show that our method outperforms existing decentralized planning techniques in terms of plan quality and scalability.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) approach to model the semantic relationships between passages and questions. Our HGNN architecture leverages both local and global contextual information to compute a dense representation of each passage, allowing for more accurate similarity measurements. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art passage retrieval methods, achieving a 12% improvement in top-1 accuracy and a 30% reduction in compute time.

title: Enhancing Keyword Extraction with Hierarchical Attention Networks for Short Texts
paper_abstract: Keyword extraction is a fundamental task in information retrieval, particularly challenging for short texts due to limited context. This paper introduces HAN-KEX, a novel hierarchical attention network that effectively captures keyword relationships and contextual dependencies. HAN-KEX consists of a word-level attention module to identify important terms and a sentence-level attention module to integrate sentence representations. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN-KEX outperforms state-of-the-art keyword extraction methods, especially for short texts. Our approach has promising applications in search engines, sentiment analysis, and text summarization.

title: Eye-Gaze Driven Adaptive Interface for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but users often experience fatigue and discomfort due to inadequate interface designs. This paper presents an innovative eye-gaze driven adaptive interface, called 'EyeGuide', which leverages machine learning-based gaze tracking to dynamically adjust the VR environment. EyeGuide predicts user intent and preferences, allowing for personalized adjustments to font sizes, color schemes, and navigation. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in user experience, with reduced eye strain and increased overall satisfaction. The results have implications for designing more accessible and engaging VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Analytics on IoT Sensor Data Streams
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential growth in sensor data, making real-time analytics a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'SensorIX', designed to efficiently process high-velocity IoT data streams. By leveraging a combination of Bloom filters and Hilbert curve-based indexing, SensorIX achieves a 3x improvement in query response time and a 2x reduction in storage requirements compared to existing indexing methods. We evaluate SensorIX on a large-scale IoT dataset and demonstrate its feasibility for real-time analytics on resource-constrained devices.

title: Hierarchical Task Decomposition for Efficient Multi-Agent Planning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning in dynamic environments is a challenging problem due to the curse of dimensionality and the need for real-time decision-making. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task decomposition approach, 'HierPlan', which enables efficient planning for teams of agents in partially observable environments. HierPlan leverages a hierarchical task representation and a probabilistic inference mechanism to recursively decompose complex tasks into smaller sub-tasks, allowing agents to focus on local decision-making while maintaining global coherence. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate significant improvements in planning efficiency and team performance compared to state-of-the-art decentralized planning methods.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Identification using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Effective retrieval of relevant documents in search engines relies on accurately identifying the intent behind a user query. While existing approaches rely on manual annotation or supervised learning, we propose an unsupervised method using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGATs). Our approach models the query-document interaction as a graph, where entities and keywords are nodes, and their relationships are edges. HGATs enable the capture of complex contextual dependencies between entities, leading to improved intent identification. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art unsupervised methods.

title: EyeGazeAuth: A Gaze-Driven Authentication System for Public Displays
paper_abstract: Public displays are increasingly prevalent in urban spaces, but existing authentication methods are often cumbersome or vulnerable to shoulder-surfing attacks. We present EyeGazeAuth, a novel gaze-driven authentication system that leverages users' eye movements to securely authenticate them. Our approach utilizes a deep learning-based gaze estimation model, which is trained on a large dataset of eye movement patterns. We evaluate EyeGazeAuth on a public display prototype and demonstrate its effectiveness in accurately verifying users while maintaining a high level of security and usability.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in smart homes, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to develop an inclusive voice assistant tailored to the requirements of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with 15 older adults, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings led to the development of 'ElderVoice', a voice assistant that incorporates age-related accommodations, such as slower speech recognition, personalized feedback, and simplified dialogue flows. A usability study with 10 older adults demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing commercial voice assistants.

title: Designing Emotionally Intelligent Conversational Agents for Mental Health Support
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to provide accessible mental health support, but their effectiveness hinges on their ability to understand and respond empathetically to users' emotional needs. This paper presents a novel framework for designing emotionally intelligent conversational agents, which integrates cognitive architectures with affective computing and natural language processing techniques. We evaluate our approach through a user study, demonstrating that agents trained with our framework exhibit higher empathetic accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional chatbot designs.

title: Eye Movement Analysis for User Experience Enhancement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way users interact with digital information, but understanding user experience in VR environments remains a challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to analyzing eye movement patterns to infer user experience in VR. We propose a machine learning-based framework, 'EyeUX', which leverages a combination of eye tracking data, head movement, and user feedback to predict user satisfaction. Our results show that EyeUX can accurately identify areas of high visual attention and disengagement, enabling designers to optimize VR interfaces for enhanced user experience. We demonstrate the effectiveness of EyeUX in a case study on a popular VR game.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Core Architectures using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of multi-core architectures in database systems has created new opportunities for query optimization. However, traditional optimization techniques often fail to fully utilize the available processing resources. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for multi-core architectures. Our method, called 'CoreOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan for a given workload and hardware configuration. Experimental results on a real-world database benchmark show that CoreOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 3.5x in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient control policies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HierCtrl', which leverages a layered policy structure to balance exploration and exploitation. Our approach combines a high-level goal-directed policy with low-level, adaptive motion planners, enabling the vehicle to adapt to changing environments while minimizing compute resources. We demonstrate HierCtrl's effectiveness in simulated urban driving scenarios, showcasing improved navigation and reduced computation time compared to flat RL baselines.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic control is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents to optimize traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to train a multi-agent system for autonomous traffic control. We introduce a decentralized, hierarchical framework that enables agents to learn from local observations and communicate with each other to achieve global optimization. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional, rule-based methods in terms of reducing congestion and travel time.

title: Coordinated Exploration for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, coordinated exploration is crucial to achieve efficient learning and optimal policy convergence. However, in partially observable environments, agents must balance individual exploration with coordination to overcome the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel algorithm, CEPO (Coordinated Exploration with Partial Observability), which leverages graph-based communication structures to facilitate information sharing among agents. CEPO adaptively adjusts exploration rates based on the observed environment dynamics, enabling agents to focus on informative regions while mitigating the effects of partial observability. Experimental results on a range of benchmark problems demonstrate CEPO's improved learning efficiency and policy quality compared to state-of-the-art decentralized exploration methods.

title: Hierarchical Knowledge Graph Embedding for Explainable AI Reasoning
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of trustworthy AI systems. We propose a novel hierarchical knowledge graph embedding framework, 'HiKE', which captures complex relationships between entities and provides interpretable reasoning paths. HiKE leverages a multi-level attention mechanism to focus on relevant graph regions and adaptively aggregate entity representations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HiKE in a variety of AI reasoning tasks, including question answering, semantic role labeling, and event forecasting, outperforming state-of-the-art models in terms of both accuracy and explainability.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Skew-Tolerant Hashing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing (RTDW) demands efficient indexing techniques to support fast query processing. Existing indexing methods often struggle with skewed data distributions, leading to poor performance. We propose a novel skew-tolerant hashing scheme, 'STH-index', which adapts to the underlying data skew using a combination of min-wise independent permutations and robust Bloom filters. Our experiments on various real-world datasets demonstrate that STH-index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of query response time and storage efficiency, making it an attractive solution for RTDW applications.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective negotiation is crucial for achieving optimal outcomes in dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel framework for adaptive negotiation strategies, where agents learn to adjust their behavior based on environmental changes and opponent responses. We introduce a hybrid approach combining game-theoretic analysis with machine learning techniques, enabling agents to balance cooperation and competition. Experimental results demonstrate improved negotiation outcomes and adaptability in various scenarios, including supply chain management and resource allocation.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Market-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents in dynamic environments. We design a market-based mechanism, called 'AgentMarket', which enables agents to bid for tasks based on their capabilities, preferences, and available resources. AgentMarket uses a combinatorial auction protocol to efficiently allocate tasks to agents, ensuring that the overall system utility is maximized. We evaluate AgentMarket using a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate its effectiveness in adapting to changing environmental conditions and agent availability. The results show that AgentMarket outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and agent satisfaction.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Systems for Efficient Resource Allocation in Multi-Agent Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient resource allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. However, centralized approaches are often limited by scalability and robustness issues. This paper presents a decentralized autonomous system (DAS) that enables agents to self-organize and adapt to dynamic environments. We propose a novel negotiation protocol that leverages machine learning-based preference modeling and iterative bargaining to allocate resources efficiently. Simulation results on a smart city scenario demonstrate that DAS outperforms traditional centralized and distributed approaches in terms of resource utilization and response time.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it significantly impacts the performance and scalability of complex data analytics workloads. This paper presents DeepQOpt, a novel query optimization framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to efficiently explore the vast space of possible query plans. We design a customized DRL agent that learns to navigate the query optimization landscape, leveraging domain-specific knowledge and feedback from the database system. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that DeepQOpt outperforms traditional query optimization techniques, achieving up to 3x speedup and 2x improvement in resource utilization.

title: Designing Accessible Voice-Based Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation, face significant barriers when interacting with voice-based interfaces. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an accessible voice-based interface, 'EasyVoice', tailored to the needs of users with dysarthria. We employed a participatory design approach, involving users with dysarthria in the design process, to create a novel speech recognition system that leverages error correction and personalized feedback mechanisms. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates that EasyVoice significantly improves the accuracy and confidence of voice-based interactions for users with dysarthria, compared to commercial speech recognition systems.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Neural Networks for Noisy Databases
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in data integration and cleaning for noisy databases. Existing approaches often rely on handcrafted features or simple machine learning models, which struggle to capture complex relationships between entities. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural network approach, 'GraphDisamb', which learns to represent entities as nodes in a graph and utilizes attention mechanisms to disambiguate entities based on their relationships. Our experiments on several real-world datasets demonstrate that GraphDisamb outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and scalability, even in the presence of high noise levels.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Column-Store Databases using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for big data analytics, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach to optimizing query performance by integrating learned index structures with distributed query execution. We propose a hybrid indexing scheme that combines traditional B-tree indexing with learned index models, trained on query workload patterns. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset shows that the proposed approach can achieve up to 3x improvement in query response time and 2x reduction in storage overhead, compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR environments. We designed and implemented a VR platform that incorporates machine learning-based avatar generation, allowing users to create personalized avatars that reflect their physical appearance and personality traits. A user study involving 120 participants revealed that personalized avatars significantly increased user engagement, as measured by time spent in the VR environment and self-reported satisfaction. Our findings have implications for the design of future VR systems and applications.

title: Gaze-Informed Adaptive Interface for Improving Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessible computing, but existing interfaces often neglect the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents 'GazeAid', a novel gaze-informed adaptive interface that leverages eye-tracking data to facilitate intuitive interaction in VR environments. Our approach dynamically adjusts the interface layout, font size, and color scheme based on the user's gaze patterns, reducing cognitive load and improving overall usability. A user study with 20 participants, including individuals with visual impairments, demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction.

title: Optimizing Query Workloads with Learned Index Structures in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Traditional indexing techniques in main-memory databases can lead to suboptimal query performance due to the complexity of modern query workloads. This paper proposes a novel approach to indexing, dubbed 'Lix', which leverages machine learning to learn adaptive index structures that optimize query execution. Our method uses a neural network to predict the optimal index configuration based on the query workload, and adaptively reconfigures the index as the workload evolves. Experimental results on a real-world database show that Lix achieves an average query speedup of 2.5x compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while reducing memory overhead by 30%.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to efficiently scale to large numbers of agents. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphMARL', incorporates a hierarchical graph structure to model complex agent interactions and enables adaptive attention weights to focus on relevant agent relationships. We evaluate GraphMARL on a range of cooperative and competitive tasks, demonstrating significant improvements in both learning speed and final policy performance compared to existing methods. Our results have important implications for real-world applications such as autonomous traffic management and smart grid control.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification in graph-structured data is a crucial task in various applications, such as social network analysis and bioinformatics. However, most existing methods require a large amount of labeled data, which is often scarce in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that tackles the few-shot node classification problem. HGAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and features at multiple scales, enabling it to learn effective node representations with limited supervision. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods and achieves competitive performance with fully supervised baselines.

title: Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Framework for Real-Time Traffic Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel heterogeneous multi-agent framework for real-time traffic optimization. Our approach integrates agent-based modeling with deep reinforcement learning to optimize traffic signal control, route planning, and autonomous vehicle coordination. We propose a hierarchical architecture that combines macro-level traffic management with micro-level agent decision-making, enabling real-time adaptation to dynamic traffic conditions. Experimental results using a large-scale traffic simulator demonstrate significant reductions in congestion, travel time, and emissions compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Streams in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time data streams pose significant challenges for traditional indexing techniques in distributed database systems. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, called 'StreamIndex', which leverages a combination of bloom filters and min-hash functions to efficiently index high-volume, high-velocity data streams. We demonstrate the effectiveness of StreamIndex in reducing query latency and improving throughput in experiments on a real-world IoT dataset. Furthermore, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the trade-offs between index construction time, query performance, and memory usage.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MAS) remains a challenging problem in distributed artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CoMA', which enables heterogeneous agents to learn coordinated policies in complex, dynamic environments. CoMA leverages a graph attention mechanism to model inter-agent relationships and a hierarchical policy architecture to adapt to diverse agent capabilities. Experimental results on a suite of benchmarks demonstrate that CoMA outperforms state-of-the-art MAS algorithms in terms of coordination efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Vibrotactile Feedback in Gesture-Based Authentication Systems
paper_abstract: Gesture-based authentication systems have gained popularity in recent years, but they often rely on visual and auditory cues, which can be compromised by shoulder-surfing attacks or auditory eavesdropping. This paper explores the use of vibrotactile feedback as an additional authentication factor. We designed a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of vibrotactile feedback in improving the security and usability of gesture-based authentication systems. Our results show that the use of vibrotactile feedback can significantly reduce error rates and improve user satisfaction, while also providing a higher level of security against shoulder-surfing attacks.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to allocate tasks in heterogeneous agent teams. Our method, called 'GraphTask', represents the agent team as a graph and leverages GNNs to learn task assignments based on agent capabilities, task requirements, and communication constraints. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphTask in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, showing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional optimization-based methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) to improve retrieval accuracy. However, existing methods rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages dense neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. NeuroQE adaptively generates expansion terms by predicting relevance scores between query and document embeddings. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness to out-of-vocabulary queries, compared to state-of-the-art expansion methods.

title: Efficient Bayesian Neural Networks for Resource-Constrained IoT Devices
paper_abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) devices often have limited computing resources, making it challenging to deploy complex machine learning models.
