This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural network (BNN) framework, 'LightBayes', which leverages probabilistic uncertainty estimation to reduce computational overhead. By incorporating a sparse, hierarchical prior distribution, LightBayes achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computations compared to traditional BNNs. Our experiments demonstrate the feasibility of deploying LightBayes on resource-constrained IoT devices, enabling real-time inference and decision-making in various applications.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Learning Models via Geometric Perturbations
paper_abstract: Despite their impressive performance, deep learning models remain vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This paper explores a novel approach to improve the robustness of deep neural networks by leveraging geometric perturbations. We propose a new family of adversarial attacks based on differential geometry, which can be used to craft perturbations that are imperceptible to humans yet effective in misleading the model. We also develop a defense mechanism that incorporates these perturbations into the training process, yielding models with state-of-the-art robustness to various types of attacks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of our approach.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task, especially when no labeled data is available for a target domain. This paper introduces 'HGAN-ZSL', a novel zero-shot learning framework that leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to capture complex relationships between modalities. Our approach learns to generate domain-invariant representations by jointly optimizing a graph-based attention mechanism and a modality-agnostic emotion classification objective. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of HGAN-ZSL compared to state-of-the-art zero-shot learning methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.4% in recognition accuracy.

title: Real-time Emotion Recognition using Transfer Learning and Multimodal Fusion
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals is crucial for human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel multimodal fusion approach, 'EmoFuse', which leverages transfer learning from pre-trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to recognize emotions in real-time. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the modalities based on their relevance to the emotion being recognized. Experimental results on the benchmark RECOLA dataset demonstrate that EmoFuse outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and latency, making it suitable for real-world affective computing applications.

title: Dynamic Coalition Formation for Task-Oriented Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In task-oriented multi-agent systems, forming coalitions dynamically is crucial for efficient task allocation and execution. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'DynaCoal', which leverages graph neural networks to model agent relationships and predicts optimal coalition structures in real-time. DynaCoal integrates a decentralized decision-making mechanism, enabling agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DynaCoal outperforms existing coalition formation methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utility, and communication overhead.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality Displays using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for more natural and intuitive interaction methods. This paper proposes a machine learning-based approach for gaze-based interaction with AR displays. We present a novel deep learning model that leverages user gaze patterns to predict their intended interactions with virtual objects. Our approach achieves high accuracy and low latency, enabling seamless interaction with AR environments. We evaluate our method on a dataset of user interactions and demonstrate its effectiveness in various AR applications.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Neural Approximation of Sparse Term Frequency Vectors
paper_abstract: Sparse term frequency vectors are widely used in information retrieval (IR) systems for efficient document representation. However, computing exact sparse representations can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a neural approximation framework, 'NeuSparse', which learns to approximate sparse term frequency vectors using a deep neural network. We demonstrate that NeuSparse achieves comparable retrieval performance to exact sparse representations while reducing computational costs by up to 70%. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that NeuSparse outperforms state-of-the-art approximate methods, enabling faster and more efficient document retrieval systems.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Task Learning for Efficient Emotion Recognition in Conversational Systems
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial component of conversational systems, but it remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the scarcity of annotated data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-task learning framework, 'EmoHMTL', which jointly learns to recognize emotions, sentiment, and speaker traits from conversational text. We introduce a task-adaptive attention mechanism that dynamically weights the importance of each task-specific feature, leading to improved performance and robustness. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of EmoHMTL in recognizing emotions and sentiment in conversational systems, outperforming state-of-the-art single-task models.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Robot Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous robot navigation in dynamic environments remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of dealing with changing obstacles and goals. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that enables robots to adapt to dynamic environments. Our approach consists of a high-level policy that selects sub-goals and a low-level policy that executes actions to achieve the selected sub-goals. We introduce a novel sub-goal discovery mechanism that leverages graph-based clustering to identify meaningful regions in the environment. Experimental results in simulated and real-world scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving navigation efficiency and adapting to changing environments.

title: Deep Ranking Model for Multi-Modal Retrieval with Heterogeneous Feedback
paper_abstract: Existing deep ranking models for multi-modal retrieval rely on homogeneous feedback signals, neglecting the diversity of user interactions. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'HeteRank', which incorporates heterogeneous feedback from various sources, including clicks, dwell time, and explicit ratings. We develop a multi-task learning approach that jointly optimizes ranking, click prediction, and rating regression tasks. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HeteRank significantly outperforms state-of-the-art models, achieving a 12.3% improvement in NDCG@10 and a 9.5% increase in user engagement.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-Hoc Retrieval with Limited Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, particularly when relevance feedback is limited. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-ARF', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to generate context-aware query expansions. Our method incorporates a novel attention mechanism that selectively weights relevance feedback to adaptively refine query representations. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate that NQE-ARF outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Dialogue management is a crucial component of multi-agent systems, where agents interact with each other to achieve a common goal. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for efficient multi-agent dialogue management. Our HAN model leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents and utterances, reducing the computational overhead while improving dialogue coherence. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-agent dialogue dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of response accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: A Study on Query Expansion using Word Embeddings for Improving Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging problem in information retrieval due to the limited context available for query representation. This paper explores the use of word embeddings for query expansion to improve the retrieval performance of short-text queries. We propose a novel method that leverages the semantic relationships encoded in word embeddings to generate expanded queries. Our approach is evaluated on several benchmark datasets, and the results show significant improvements in retrieval accuracy compared to traditional query expansion techniques. Furthermore, we analyze the impact of different word embedding models and query expansion strategies on retrieval performance.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Relational Databases using Adaptive indexing
paper_abstract: As data grows in scale and distribution, traditional indexing techniques struggle to maintain query performance in distributed relational databases. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing framework, 'AdapIndex', which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distribution. AdapIndex incorporates a machine learning-based query pattern recognition module to predict query hotspots and optimize index creation accordingly. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database setup show that AdapIndex achieves an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to static indexing techniques.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. Our approach, dubbed 'Dec-TARL', enables agents to learn optimal task assignments in a distributed manner, without relying on a centralized controller. We formulate the task allocation problem as a Markov game and employ a decentralized actor-critic algorithm to learn effective policies. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that Dec-TARL outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Scalable Multi-Task Learning with Meta-Learned Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning has shown promising results in various applications, but scaling it to a large number of tasks remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach, Meta-TOME, which leverages meta-learning to learn task embeddings that capture task relationships and similarities. By doing so, Meta-TOME enables efficient task clustering and adaptive task weighting, leading to improved performance and scalability in multi-task learning scenarios. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of Meta-TOME in improving model performance and reducing computational costs.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and resource constraints need to collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a distributed auction-based mechanism that leverages graph neural networks to learn agent-specific utility functions and dynamically allocate tasks to maximize system-wide efficiency. Our approach is validated through extensive simulations on a variety of task allocation scenarios, demonstrating improved performance and robustness compared to existing centralized and decentralized methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control with Multi-Modal Sensor Fusion
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) rely on multi-modal sensor fusion to perceive their environment. However, integrating and processing this diverse data in real-time remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that leverages a novel, attention-based sensor fusion mechanism to optimize AV control. Our approach combines a high-level, goal-oriented policy with low-level, reactive control modules, enabling efficient exploration and adaptation to complex scenarios. Experimental results on a simulated AV platform demonstrate improved performance and robustness compared to traditional, monolithic RL methods, particularly in the presence of sensor noise and uncertainty.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Skew-Tolerant Hashing
paper_abstract: As data warehouses continue to grow in size and complexity, efficient indexing techniques are critical for real-time query performance. This paper presents a novel indexing approach, 'SkewHash', which leverages skew-tolerant hashing to mitigate the impact of data skew on indexing performance. By adaptively adjusting the hash function to the underlying data distribution, SkewHash achieves significant improvements in query response time and storage efficiency compared to traditional indexing methods. Evaluation on a large-scale data warehousing benchmark demonstrates the scalability and effectiveness of SkewHash in supporting real-time analytical workloads.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Dynamic Task Assignment using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require coordinating heterogeneous agents to accomplish complex tasks. Existing approaches rely on manual task assignment or limited adaptability to changing environmental conditions. We propose a novel framework, 'HTA-DRL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to dynamically assign tasks to agents based on their capabilities, current workload, and environmental factors. HTA-DRL is evaluated in a simulated rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates, reduced response times, and enhanced system adaptability compared to traditional approaches. Our method enables more efficient and effective coordination of heterogeneous agents in dynamic environments.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering Using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents for answer extraction. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) approach that leverages a two-stage retrieval strategy to reduce the search space. We first use a coarse-grained retriever to identify top-ranked documents and then apply a fine-grained retriever to identify relevant passages within those documents. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDR achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and accuracy compared to state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods, while also reducing computational costs.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Neural Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to enrich the original query with relevant terms to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel neural-based approach, 'NDE-QE', which leverages document embeddings to generate expansion terms. We employ a deep neural network to learn dense vector representations of documents, capturing semantic relationships between terms and documents. The experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NDE-QE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, yielding significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Few-shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has garnered significant attention in recent years, but most existing methods rely on complex architectures or large datasets. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages graph-structured data to tackle few-shot learning in a scalable and efficient manner. HGAT utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to adaptively weight the importance of different graph nodes and edges, thereby capturing complex relationships between classes. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance in few-shot settings while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computations compared to existing methods.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'MTS-AD', which leverages the strengths of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to identify anomalies in high-dimensional time series data. Our approach involves learning a robust representation of normal patterns using CNNs and then feeding these representations into an LSTM network to capture temporal dependencies. We evaluate MTS-AD on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) that aims to refine the original query to better capture the user's intent. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and suffer from limited generalizability. This paper proposes a novel approach, NeuralQE, which leverages deep neural networks to learn query expansion strategies from large-scale datasets. We design a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query expansion and relevance ranking, and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance over state-of-the-art baselines on several standard IR benchmarks. Our results highlight the potential of neural networks in advancing the field of IR.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Reinforcement Learning for Resource-Constrained Devices
paper_abstract: The surge in deep learning model complexity poses significant challenges for deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) method, 'RL-NAS', which leverages reinforcement learning to efficiently explore the vast search space of potential architectures. By incorporating a reward function that balances model accuracy and resource efficiency, RL-NAS discovers compact and accurate models tailored to specific device constraints. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-NAS outperforms existing NAS methods in terms of search efficiency and model performance on resource-limited devices.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, as they provide insights into the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) framework, which incorporates both item-level and user-level attention mechanisms to generate personalized explanations for recommended items. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model complex relationships between users and items, and hierarchical attention to selectively focus on relevant features. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art ERS models in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection for Voice-Controlled Interfaces in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: Voice-controlled interfaces in augmented reality (AR) are prone to errors, negatively impacting user experience. This paper presents a novel approach to error detection using gaze tracking, which leverages the user's visual attention to identify potential errors. Our method, 'GazeCorrect', utilizes a machine learning model to analyze the user's gaze patterns and detect anomalies that may indicate incorrect voice commands. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating a significant reduction in error rates (28.5%) and improvement in user satisfaction (35%) when using GazeCorrect. Our results have implications for the design of more robust and user-friendly voice-controlled interfaces in AR applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using auction-based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized auction-based mechanism, called 'Distributed Auction for Task Allocation' (DATA), which enables autonomous agents to bid for tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We theoretically analyze the properties of DATA, including its incentive compatibility and allocative efficiency, and demonstrate its effectiveness through extensive simulations on a variety of task allocation scenarios. Our results show that DATA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of both task completion time and agent satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Clustering for Multi-Modal Representation Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Multi-modal representation learning has emerged as a crucial aspect of computer vision, enabling models to jointly process and correlate disparate data sources. However, existing methods often struggle to effectively integrate and cluster features from diverse modalities. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical clustering framework, 'ModalTree', which adaptively partitions and merges features from individual modalities to form a unified, hierarchical representation. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ModalTree outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality, feature correlation, and downstream task performance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: The proliferation of fake news on social media platforms has severe consequences for individuals and society. While existing detection methods rely on shallow feature engineering or vanilla graph neural networks, we propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that captures complex relationships between news articles, users, and entities. HGAT incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to identify suspicious patterns and provide interpretable explanations for its predictions. Our experiments on a large-scale fake news dataset demonstrate HGAT's superior performance and ability to generalize to unseen news topics.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Oriented Storage
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become crucial for businesses to make timely decisions. However, existing indexing techniques struggle with the high volume and velocity of incoming data. This paper proposes a novel, adaptive indexing framework, 'RTIX', which leverages column-oriented storage to efficiently manage real-time data streams. RTIX dynamically adjusts the index structure based on data distribution and query patterns, minimizing storage overhead and query latency. Experimental results on a simulated IoT dataset demonstrate that RTIX outperforms traditional indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query response time and 2x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Novel Word Embeddings for Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on outdated thesauri or cumbersome manual tuning. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using word embeddings, which capture subtle semantic relationships between terms. We introduce 'EmbedExpan', a framework that leverages a new type of word embedding, 'semantically-aware' embeddings, to generate high-quality expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbedExpan outperforms state-of-the-art methods in retrieval effectiveness, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Agents for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational agents have the potential to support older adults with cognitive impairments, but existing designs often neglect their unique needs. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing accessible conversational agents, focusing on simplifying language, using multimodal interaction, and incorporating cognitive support. We conducted a series of usability studies with older adults with mild cognitive impairment, identifying key design recommendations and evaluating the effectiveness of our proposed design framework. Our results show improved task completion rates and user satisfaction, demonstrating the feasibility of accessible conversational agents for this population.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for coordinating autonomous vehicles in complex traffic scenarios. Our approach, named 'DMARL-Ctrl', enables vehicles to learn cooperative policies in a decentralized manner, without relying on a central controller or explicit communication. We introduce a novel reward function that incorporates both local and global objectives, and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing congestion and improving safety in simulated traffic environments. Experimental results show that DMARL-Ctrl outperforms traditional rule-based control methods and centralized optimization approaches in realistic traffic scenarios.

title: Designing Empathetic Virtual Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Recognizing User Frustration
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but their lack of emotional intelligence can lead to user frustration. This paper presents a novel framework for recognizing and responding to user frustration in VAs, using a multimodal approach that combines speech, facial expression, and physiological signal analysis. Our system, 'EmpathyVA', employs machine learning models to detect early signs of frustration and adapt the VA's response to mitigate user annoyance. A user study involving 30 participants demonstrates that EmpathyVA significantly reduces user frustration and improves overall interaction experience.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Trust in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As robots become increasingly integrated into our daily lives, understanding human-robot trust is crucial. This study explores the role of embodiment in virtual reality (VR) on human trust in robots. We conducted a user study with 60 participants, randomly assigning them to one of three conditions: (1) disembodied VR, (2) embodied VR with a robotic avatar, or (3) embodied VR with a humanoid avatar. Our results show that embodied VR with a humanoid avatar significantly increases trust in robots, particularly among participants with low prior experience with robots. We discuss the implications of these findings for designing trustworthy human-robot interfaces and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Attention for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely on passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. Existing methods employ a single-level attention mechanism, which can be computationally expensive and limited in capturing complex contextual relationships. We propose a hierarchical attention framework, 'HierAtt', which leverages sentence-level and document-level attention to efficiently retrieve relevant passages. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HierAtt achieves a 15% improvement in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods, while reducing computational costs by 30%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Coordination in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in decentralized AI systems. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical reinforcement learning to facilitate effective multi-agent coordination. HGAT learns to represent complex agent interactions and adapt to changing environmental conditions by recursively applying attention weights to graph-structured state representations. Experimental results in simulated robot soccer and traffic management scenarios demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, decentralized coordination is essential for efficient decision-making. This paper proposes a novel approach to decentralized coordination using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). We introduce a hierarchical DCOP framework, where agents negotiate and exchange information to satisfy constraints and optimize global objectives. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to learn constraint relations and approximate the optimal solution. Experimental results demonstrate that our method outperforms existing decentralized coordination algorithms in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of information retrieval systems, as it helps to disambiguate user queries and retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach for query expansion, dubbed 'DeepQE'. Our method leverages the semantic relationships between words in the query and the document collection to generate effective expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance. We also analyze the impact of different neural network architectures on the query expansion process.

title: Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Speech and Language Disorders
paper_abstract: Individuals with speech and language disorders often face significant barriers when interacting with voice-based interfaces. This paper presents a novel design framework, 'AccessibleVoice', which incorporates insights from speech-language pathology and human-computer interaction to improve the accessibility of voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants with speech and language disorders, resulting in the identification of key design principles for enhancing interface intelligibility, error tolerance, and user experience. A prototype voice-based interface implementing these principles was evaluated, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are increasingly used to manage large-scale data, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper explores the application of learned index structures to optimize query performance in such systems. We propose a novel learned index framework, 'QOpt', which leverages neural networks to predict the optimal index configuration for a given query workload. Our approach adaptively adjusts the index structure based on query patterns and data distributions, resulting in significant improvements in query response times and resource utilization. Experimental evaluation on a real-world distributed database system demonstrates the efficacy of QOpt in reducing query latency by up to 3x compared to traditional indexing techniques.

title: Attention-Based Multimodal Fusion for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models often struggle to provide interpretable explanations for their predictions. We propose a novel attention-based multimodal fusion framework, 'ExplainVQA', which integrates visual and linguistic features to generate transparent and accurate answers. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of different visual regions and linguistic tokens, enabling the model to focus on relevant input features. Experiments on the VQA-X dataset demonstrate that ExplainVQA outperforms state-of-the-art VQA models while providing insightful visual and linguistic explanations for its predictions.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Diversified Search Results using Continuous Query Embeddings
paper_abstract: Modern search engines often prioritize relevance over diversity, leading to redundant results. This paper proposes a novel approach to diversified search ranking, employing continuous query embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. Our Adaptive Re-ranking (AR) model iteratively updates the query embedding based on the initial retrieval results, allowing for more effective diversification of the top-ranked documents. Experiments on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in novelty and diversity metrics, while maintaining competitive relevance performance compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Relational Databases using Column Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy is becoming increasingly popular in cloud-based relational databases, where multiple tenants share a common database instance. However, this architecture introduces query optimization challenges, as each tenant's workload may have distinct performance characteristics. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach that leverages column store indexing to improve query performance in multi-tenant relational databases. Our proposed algorithm, 'TenantAware', adapts to the dynamic workload patterns of each tenant and optimizes query plans accordingly. Experimental results on a real-world benchmark dataset demonstrate significant query performance improvements compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for accomplishing complex tasks. This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments among agents. Our approach, called 'DRL-TA', utilizes a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn effective task allocation policies that balance task workload, agent capabilities, and communication costs. Experimental results on a simulated urban search and rescue scenario demonstrate that DRL-TA outperforms traditional, rule-based allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Efficient Document Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a fundamental task in information retrieval. Document expansion, a crucial step in this process, aims to enrich the original query by incorporating relevant terms from the top-ranked documents. Existing methods rely on statistical techniques, which can be limited by their inability to capture complex semantic relationships. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'DeepExpand', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn a dense representation of the query and documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that DeepExpand outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and recall, while reducing the computational overhead by an order of magnitude.

title: Scalable and Secure Data Processing using Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular for cloud-based services, but they pose significant challenges in terms of scalability, security, and performance isolation. This paper presents a novel architecture, 'MT-DB', that leverages a combination of data partitioning, encryption, and access control mechanisms to ensure secure and efficient data processing in multi-tenant environments. We evaluate MT-DB using a real-world e-commerce dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance, data security, and resource utilization compared to existing approaches.

title: Understanding User Frustration in Voice-Based interfaces: A Multimodal Analysis
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but user frustration remains a significant barrier to adoption. This paper presents a multimodal analysis of user frustration in voice-based interfaces, combining acoustic, linguistic, and physiological features to identify early indicators of frustration. We collected a novel dataset of 100 participants interacting with a voice-based virtual assistant and developed a machine learning model that achieves an F1-score of 0.85 in detecting frustration. Our results show that acoustic features, such as speech rate and pitch, are strong predictors of user frustration, and that incorporating physiological features, such as heart rate and skin conductance, improves model performance. We discuss implications for design and highlight opportunities for real-time frustration detection and mitigation.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Parallel Distributed Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, query optimization in parallel distributed databases becomes increasingly complex. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'ParOpt', that leverages machine learning to predict optimal query plans. We design a neural network that learns from database statistics, query patterns, and execution times to generate efficient query plans. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that ParOpt outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of execution time, while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained increasing attention in recent years, leveraging the complementary information from text, image, and audio inputs. However, most existing approaches treat each modality separately or rely on early fusion, neglecting the complex interactions between them. In this paper, we propose a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and their interactions. Our HAN model consists of two stages: intra-modal attention and inter-modal attention, enabling the capture of both local and global dependencies. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI and ICT-MMM datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach over state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 5.3% improvement in sentiment prediction accuracy.

title: Investigating the Effects of Vibrotactile Feedback on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on visual and auditory cues to provide users with feedback. However, these modalities can be limited in their ability to convey information in complex, dynamic environments. This study explores the use of vibrotactile feedback to enhance gesture recognition in VR. We conducted a user study with 24 participants, comparing the performance of a gesture recognition system with and without vibrotactile feedback. Our results show that the addition of vibrotactile feedback significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and reduces user error. Furthermore, we found that users reported higher levels of immersion and engagement when vibrotactile feedback was present.

title: Adaptive Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'RL-TA', that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively allocate tasks to agents based on their dynamic capabilities and environmental changes. We introduce a decentralized, model-free approach that enables agents to learn from their interactions and adjust task assignments in real-time. Experimental results demonstrate that RL-TA outperforms traditional, planning-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization, even in the presence of agent failures and communication disruptions.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Gradient Boosting for Tabular Data Analysis
paper_abstract: Despite the success of gradient boosting machines in tabular data analysis, they often struggle to capture complex interactions between features. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant feature subsets during gradient boosting. Our approach, 'HierAttnGB', adaptively learns attention weights at multiple scales, enabling the model to capture both local and global patterns. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierAttnGB on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in terms of mean squared error and feature importance interpretability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval using Deep Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval due to the limited context and ambiguity of short queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep semantic embeddings to capture the underlying semantics of short queries. Our approach uses a graph-based method to integrate term relationships and semantic associations, resulting in more effective expansion terms. Experimental results on several short-text retrieval datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search queries often suffer from vocabulary mismatch, leading to poor retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE', which leverages a combination of lexical, semantic, and contextual cues to enhance query representation. HQE first identifies key terms and their relationships using a graph-based method, then iteratively expands the query through a hierarchical clustering process. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets show that HQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while maintaining efficiency and scalability.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality Displays using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) displays are increasingly used in various domains, but traditional interaction methods often detract from the user experience. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based interaction approach for AR displays using deep learning. We develop a convolutional neural network (CNN) that accurately detects gaze direction from eye-tracking data, and integrate it with a sensor fusion framework to enable seamless user interaction. Our experimental results show that the proposed approach outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for High-Dimensional Data using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data clustering is a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when dealing with large datasets. Traditional hierarchical clustering methods suffer from the curse of dimensionality, leading to poor clustering quality and high computational costs. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Deep Hierarchical Clustering' (DHC), which leverages the representational power of deep neural networks to learn hierarchical cluster structures. We introduce a new loss function that encourages cluster separability and a self-supervised training strategy that eliminates the need for labeled data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DHC outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods in terms of clustering accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Scalable Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Learned Hash Functions
paper_abstract: Indexing high-dimensional data is a crucial task in many applications, including similarity search and nearest-neighbor retrieval. Traditional indexing methods often suffer from the curse of dimensionality, leading to poor performance and scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel approach, dubbed 'LHash', which leverages learned hash functions to efficiently index high-dimensional data. We demonstrate that LHash can significantly outperform state-of-the-art indexing methods, such as locality-sensitive hashing and ball trees, in terms of query efficiency and accuracy. Our experiments on several real-world datasets show that LHash achieves a 3-5x speedup over traditional methods while maintaining high retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, aiming to enrich the original query with relevant terms to improve retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, HierGNN-QE, which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks to model the complex relationships between query terms, documents, and their semantic representations. By incorporating both local and global graph structures, HierGNN-QE captures nuanced context-dependent dependencies and yields more effective expanded queries. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient QueryExpansion using Neural Embeddings for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. Traditional methods employ handcrafted rules or statistical models, which can be time-consuming and suboptimal. We propose 'NeuroXE', a novel neural query expansion framework that leverages pre-trained language models to generate semantically coherent expansion terms. NeuroXE integrates a neural embeddings-based query representation with a probabilistic scoring function, enabling efficient and effective expansion. Our experiments on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in recall and precision over state-of-the-art methods, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in IoT Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for dynamic task allocation in IoT networks. We propose a novel algorithm, 'DMA-RL', which enables agents to learn and adapt to changing network conditions and task requirements in real-time. DMA-RL utilizes a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where agents communicate with their neighbors to share knowledge and coordinate their actions. Experimental results on a simulation platform demonstrate that DMA-RL outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate, latency, and energy efficiency.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Hierarchical Graph Decomposition
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent pathfinding, a fundamental problem in artificial intelligence and robotics. Our method, called HGD-MAPF, leverages hierarchical graph decomposition to reduce the computational complexity of finding collision-free paths for multiple agents in large, dynamic environments. We propose a two-level hierarchy, where agents are first clustered into groups and then solved independently using a decentralized planning framework. Experimental results on various benchmarks demonstrate that HGD-MAPF outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of scalability, solution quality, and computational efficiency.

title: Intelligent Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents to maximize overall performance. This paper presents a novel approach to coalition formation for task allocation in dynamic environments, where agents have varying capabilities and tasks have different priorities. We propose an intelligent coalition formation algorithm that uses machine learning-based negotiation protocols to adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our approach is evaluated through extensive simulations, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced agent idle time compared to traditional coalition formation methods.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving retrieves in Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, which aims to reformulate the original query to better match the relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep neural networks. Our method leverages a multi-layer perceptron to learn the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion terms. We also introduce a novel ranking mechanism that incorporates both the original query and expanded query to re-rank the documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that our approach significantly outperforms existing query expansion methods, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis with Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) is a challenging task that involves analyzing sentiment from heterogeneous data sources such as text, images, and audio. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates uncertainty estimation to improve the robustness of MSA models. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention layers that learn to weight the importance of different modalities, followed by a hierarchical fusion layer that aggregates the modality-specific features. We further incorporate Bayesian neural networks to estimate the uncertainty of the sentiment predictions, enabling the model to provide confidence scores for its predictions. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art MSA models in terms of accuracy and robustness.

title: Neural Ranking Models for Session-based Search with Behavioral Graph Attention
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for search have primarily focused on individual queries, neglecting the rich contextual information available in user sessions. This paper proposes a novel behavioral graph attention mechanism to incorporate session history into ranking models. Our approach jointly learns user behavior graphs and neural ranking models, enabling the capture of complex query dependencies and user preferences. Experimental results on the TREC 2020 Session Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking quality and user satisfaction metrics compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Heterogeneous Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in heterogeneous graphs is a challenging task due to the varying importance of different node types and relationships. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages the hierarchical structure of graphs to learn node representations. HGAT uses a multi-level attention mechanism to capture both local and global context, and a type-aware aggregation strategy to combine information from different node types. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 5.2% in node classification accuracy.

title: Emotive Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but users with disabilities often face barriers to access. This paper presents an emotive gesture recognition system, 'EmoGest', which enables users to control VR environments using subtle hand and finger movements. Our approach leverages machine learning and computer vision to identify emotional states from gesture patterns, facilitating more intuitive and inclusive interaction. We evaluate EmoGest with a diverse group of users, demonstrating improved accessibility and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies with Hierarchical State Abstractions
paper_abstract: Recent advances in deep reinforcement learning (DRL) have led to the development of complex policies capable of solving challenging tasks. However, these policies remain vulnerable to adversarial attacks that manipulate the state observations to induce suboptimal behavior. This paper presents a novel attack framework, 'HierAttack', which targets DRL policies with hierarchical state abstractions. We demonstrate that our attack can significantly degrade the policy's performance by injecting carefully crafted perturbations into the abstracted state representations. Furthermore, we evaluate the robustness of various DRL algorithms and provide insights into the design of more resilient policies.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable AI for Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT
paper_abstract: Industrial IoT systems generate vast amounts of data, making anomaly detection a crucial task. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable AI (HAXAI) framework for real-time anomaly detection. HAXAI leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant sensor readings and time-steps, while providing interpretable explanations for detected anomalies. We evaluate HAXAI on a real-world industrial dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting anomalies with high accuracy and latency, outperforming state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Blockchain-based Consensus Protocols
paper_abstract: The increasing use of autonomous agents in various applications has raised the need for efficient coordination mechanisms. This paper proposes a decentralized framework for coordinating autonomous agents using blockchain-based consensus protocols. Our approach leverages the immutability and transparency properties of blockchain to enable agents to reach consensus on a shared goal without relying on a centralized authority. We evaluate our framework through simulations and demonstrate its effectiveness in scenarios involving multiple agents with conflicting goals. The results show that our approach can significantly improve the coordination efficiency and robustness of autonomous agent systems.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Sparse Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Sparse document retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents from a large corpus given a query. Traditional sparse retrieval methods rely on bag-of-words representations, which ignore the semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'SparseNRM', that leverages pre-trained language models to capture the contextualized semantic meaning of query terms. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each query term based on its relevance to the document. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that SparseNRM outperforms state-of-the-art sparse retrieval methods by a significant margin, achieving higher mean average precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Attention Mechanisms for Efficient Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) has become increasingly important for human-computer interaction. However, existing approaches struggle to effectively fuse features from diverse modalities, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HydraNet', which adaptively weighs the importance of different modalities and features at multiple levels of abstraction. Our approach enables more efficient and accurate MER by selectively focusing on the most informative inputs. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate the superiority of HydraNet over state-of-the-art models, achieving a 12.5% improvement in F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Ranking Models for Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in document retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a neural ranking model-based approach, 'NeuroXPand', which learns to expand queries by incorporating semantic relationships between words and documents. We utilize a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query expansion and document ranking, enabling our model to adapt to varying query lengths and styles. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Multimodal Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multimodal information retrieval (MMIR) systems struggle to bridge the semantic gap between text and visual features. We propose a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroEmb', which leverages neural embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and relevant visual concepts. Our method integrates a visual-semantic embedding space with a neural ranking model, enabling the system to generate more effective query expansions. Experimental results on the WikipediaMM dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, especially for queries with ambiguous or abstract concepts.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Multi-Agent Systems using Blockchain-based Reputation Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust management is crucial for ensuring cooperation and preventing malicious behavior. This paper proposes a decentralized trust management framework, 'Blockchain for Agents' (BFA), which leverages blockchain technology to establish a transparent and tamper-proof reputation system. BFA enables agents to rate each other's behavior and store these ratings on a blockchain, allowing for the calculation of reputation scores that reflect an agent's trustworthiness. We evaluate BFA through simulations and demonstrate its effectiveness in promoting trust and cooperation in a variety of scenarios.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) is a crucial technique for ensuring data consistency in distributed databases. However, existing indexing methods struggle to efficiently support MVCC, leading to performance degradation. This paper presents 'DynIndex', a novel indexing approach that leverages a combination of versioned B-trees and delta-encoding to minimize storage overhead and optimize query performance. We demonstrate through extensive experiments on a real-world dataset that DynIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in MVCC environments, achieving up to 35% improvement in query latency and 25% reduction in storage costs.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Drone Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous drone navigation in dynamic environments poses significant challenges due to the need to adapt to changing obstacles and goals. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HDRL-Drone', which combines high-level planning with low-level control. Our approach utilizes a graph-based abstraction of the environment to plan feasible paths, while a deep reinforcement learning module refines the control policy to accommodate real-time sensor inputs. Experimental results in a simulated urban setting demonstrate the effectiveness of HDRL-Drone in navigating complex scenarios with improved efficiency and safety.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Fusion in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Effective human-robot interaction (HRI) relies on seamless fusion of multimodal inputs, including vision, speech, and gesture. However, existing approaches often lack interpretability, raising concerns about trust and safety. We propose a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates these modalities while providing explicit attention weights for explainability. Our HAN framework consists of a feature-level attention module for early fusion and a decision-level attention module for late fusion. Experimental results on the HRI-Dataset demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but often fail to capture hierarchical relationships between nodes. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, 'HAGNN', which leverages multi-scale attention mechanisms to model complex dependencies between nodes at different granularities. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms existing GNN architectures, especially in scenarios with sparse node labels or complex graph structures.

title: Query Expansion using Graph-based Semantic Embeddings for Improving Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Search engines often struggle to provide diverse results, leading to a poor user experience. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using graph-based semantic embeddings. We represent queries and documents as nodes in a graph, and leverage graph convolutional networks to learn semantic embeddings that capture nuanced relationships between them. Our approach, 'DiversiGraph', adaptively expands the query by incorporating relevant terms from the graph, resulting in more diverse search results. Experimental evaluations on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search result diversity and relevance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Clustering-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. Traditional methods often struggle to capture complex patterns and relationships in the data. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HierCon', which leverages contrastive learning to learn robust representations of time series data. We employ hierarchical clustering to identify anomalies at multiple scales, allowing for the detection of both local and global anomalies. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HierCon in improving detection accuracy and reducing false positives compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative reinforcement learning in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, as agents must learn to coordinate their actions to achieve a common goal. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables agents to selectively focus on relevant teammates and learn effective communication strategies. Our approach improves upon existing methods by incorporating a hierarchical structure that captures both local and global relationships between agents. Experimental results on a range of multi-agent environments demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in achieving higher rewards and better coordination compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Proximity-Aware Re-ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face significant challenges in efficiently retrieving relevant documents from a large corpus. This paper proposes a novel proximity-aware re-ranking approach that leverages the spatial proximity of documents in the index to speed up the retrieval process. Our approach, dubbed 'ProxRank', incorporates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group documents based on their semantic similarity and spatial proximity. Experiments on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate that ProxRank achieves a 30% reduction in query latency while maintaining a comparable level of retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Vibrotactile Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has seen significant advancements in recent years, but the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of vibrotactile feedback on user satisfaction, presence, and performance in VR. We designed a series of experiments using a custom-built VR setup, incorporating a vibrotactile feedback system. Our results show that vibrotactile feedback significantly improves user experience, particularly in tasks requiring fine motor skills. We also identify key factors influencing user perception of vibrotactile feedback, including device type, vibration frequency, and individual differences in haptic sensitivity.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Gesture Recognition and User Experience
paper_abstract: This study investigates the design of accessible gestural interfaces for older adults, focusing on gesture recognition and user experience. We developed a novel gesture recognition system that leverages machine learning and computer vision to recognize gestures from older adults. Our user study with 30 participants aged 65-85 reveals that our system achieves an accuracy of 92% and outperforms existing systems. We also identify key design principles for accessible gestural interfaces, including simplicity, consistency, and feedback. Our findings have implications for the design of assistive technologies and gesture-based interfaces for older adults.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing has become a ubiquitous platform for deploying large-scale applications, but efficient resource allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudOptimizer', that learns to allocate resources in real-time based on workload patterns and system dynamics. Our approach combines a deep neural network with a Q-network to optimize resource utilization and minimize latency. Experimental results on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that CloudOptimizer outperforms state-of-the-art heuristic-based methods by up to 30% in terms of resource efficiency and 25% in terms of latency reduction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT) to address the challenges of multi-agent reinforcement learning in complex, dynamic environments. By incorporating graph attention mechanisms into a hierarchical framework, HGAT enables agents to selectively focus on relevant neighboring agents and learn effective communication strategies. We evaluate HGAT on a range of multi-agent benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and scalability compared to existing methods. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as autonomous traffic management and robotic teams.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized multi-agent planning is a challenging problem, particularly when agents have incomplete information about the environment. This paper proposes a novel approach using hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to facilitate information sharing and coordination among agents. Our method, called Dec-HGNN, consists of a hierarchical architecture that integrates local observation models with a global planning module. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Dec-HGNN in a variety of scenarios, including robotic search and rescue, and resource allocation in smart grids. Experimental results show that Dec-HGNN outperforms existing decentralized planning methods, even with incomplete information.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Multi-hop question answering (MHQA) has gained significant attention due to its ability to reason over multiple sentences. However, existing models often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand their decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that incorporates explainability into MHQA. Our model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant sentences, entities, and relationships, providing a transparent understanding of the reasoning process. Experimental results on the HotPotQA dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance while offering improved interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Protein-Ligand Binding Affinity Prediction
paper_abstract: Predicting protein-ligand binding affinity is a crucial task in drug discovery and design. Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promise in this domain, but often struggle to capture complex interactions between protein and ligand structures. We propose a hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, AttentiveGNN, which leverages multi-scale graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant substructures and interactions. Our experiments on a benchmark dataset of protein-ligand complexes demonstrate that AttentiveGNN significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a mean absolute error of 1.23 kcal/mol.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Anxiety in Virtual Reality Exposure Therapy
paper_abstract: Virtual reality exposure therapy (VRET) is a promising treatment for anxiety disorders, but patient engagement and comfort remain significant challenges. This study investigates the role of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in enhancing the therapeutic experience in VRET. We designed and tested an ECA-based VRET system, where a virtual therapist guides patients through exposure exercises. Our user study with 30 participants shows that the ECA condition resulted in significantly lower anxiety levels and higher self-reported comfort compared to a text-based interface. We also found that the ECA's emotional expressions and empathetic responses positively correlated with patient engagement and satisfaction.

title: Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Flow Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent deep reinforcement learning framework for real-time traffic flow optimization in complex road networks. Our approach, dubbed 'TrafficMaster', leverages graph neural networks to model the dynamic interactions between agents, and introduces a novel attention-based mechanism to adaptively prioritize traffic signals at key intersections. Experimental results on a large-scale simulation platform demonstrate that TrafficMaster achieves significant reductions in travel time, congestion, and emissions compared to traditional traffic management systems, while maintaining scalability and robustness in the face of uncertain traffic conditions.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Real-time Analytics with Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics has become increasingly important in various domains, but traditional indexing techniques often struggle to keep up with the velocity and variety of modern data. This paper presents an adaptive indexing framework, 'AIQ', which dynamically adjusts its indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. AIQ leverages a novel cost-benefit model that considers both query performance and indexing overhead, enabling real-time analytics on large-scale datasets. Experimental results on a popular benchmark dataset demonstrate that AIQ outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time while maintaining a comparable storage footprint.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal dialogue systems have shown great promise in human-computer interaction, but their lack of transparency and explainability hinders their adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates visual, acoustic, and linguistic features to generate interpretable responses. Our HAN model comprises two stages: 1) a multimodal feature fusion layer that learns to weigh the importance of each modality, and 2) a hierarchical attention mechanism that focuses on relevant input segments and generates attention visualizations. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dialogue dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of response accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Fusion in Medical Image Analysis
paper_abstract: Medical image analysis often involves fusion of multi-modal data from various sources. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that effectively integrates features from different modalities. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between modalities and uses a hierarchical structure to capture both local and global features. Experimental results on a large-scale brain tumor segmentation dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art fusion methods, achieving improved accuracy and robustness in the presence of noisy or missing data.

title: Enhancing Query Driven Summarization using Hierarchical Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Query-driven summarization is a critical task in information retrieval, where the goal is to generate a concise summary of a document set in response to a user query. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical neural network architecture, HierSum, which leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and document sentences to improve summarization performance. Our model consists of a query encoder, sentence encoder, and a hierarchical summarizer that generates a summary by selecting and ranking sentences based on their relevance to the query. Experimental results on the TREC news dataset demonstrate that HierSum outperforms state-of-the-art summarization models in terms of ROUGE scores and human evaluation metrics.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval: A Comparative Study on Deep Learning Architectures
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it enables the system to better capture the user's information need. Recent studies have explored the use of deep learning models for query expansion, but a comprehensive comparison of different architectures remains lacking. This paper conducts an in-depth evaluation of various neural query expansion models, including recurrent neural networks, transformers, and graph convolutional networks. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that a hybrid approach combining the strengths of these architectures yields significant improvements in retrieval performance, outperforming traditional query expansion methods and state-of-the-art neural models.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Neural Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multi-modal emotion recognition has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and limited interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based neural network (HAN) framework for efficient multi-modal emotion recognition. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and regions, reducing computational overhead while improving recognition accuracy. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HAN over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in F1-score with 30% reduction in inference time.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agents using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation strategies to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes a decentralized framework for heterogeneous agents, where each agent learns to allocate tasks using graph-based reinforcement learning. We model the agent communication network as a graph and employ a novel graph convolutional policy to learn task allocation decisions.
