Our approach is evaluated on a simulated logistics scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their usability for older adults is often limited due to cognitive, sensory, and motor impairments. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework for voice assistants that incorporates visual, tactile, and gestural interfaces to support older adults. We conducted a user-centered design study with 20 older adults and developed a prototype that integrates spoken language, gesture recognition, and haptic feedback. Our evaluation results show significant improvements in task completion rates, user satisfaction, and accessibility for older adults with varying abilities.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-robot interaction, as it enables robots to respond empathetically and build trust with users. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for multi-modal emotion recognition, which integrates speech, facial expression, and body language cues. Our HAN model learns to focus on relevant modalities and time segments, improving emotion recognition accuracy in real-world scenarios. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale human-robot interaction dataset and demonstrate significant performance gains over state-of-the-art uni-modal and multi-modal baselines.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Hop Reasoning
paper_abstract: Reasoning over knowledge graphs (KGs) with multi-hop dependencies is a challenging task, as it requires capturing complex semantic relationships between entities. We propose a novel approach, HierAttnKG, which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant KG components during inference. Our method learns efficient entity and relation embeddings by jointly optimizing a knowledge graph embedding objective and a hierarchical attention objective. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that HierAttnKG outperforms state-of-the-art methods on multi-hop reasoning tasks, while reducing the number of parameters and inference time.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Effective Passage Retrieval in Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to provide accurate and relevant passages in response to user queries. However, the limited context and ambiguity in natural language queries pose significant challenges to passage retrieval. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE-CS', that leverages pre-trained language models to expand queries with semantically relevant keywords. Our approach involves fine-tuning a BERT-based model on a large conversational search dataset and incorporating a novel keyword selection mechanism based on attention weights. Experimental results on the TREC Conversational Assistance Track dataset demonstrate that NQE-CS significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of passage retrieval accuracy and relevance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Dense Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on effective retrieval of relevant passages from a large corpus. While dense retrieval methods have shown promise, their computational cost hinders their applicability. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach, 'NQE', which leverages a lightweight dense retriever to generate context-aware query expansions. By incorporating a learned passage encoder and a query reformulator, NQE achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and accuracy. Experimental results on popular ODQA benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of NQE in reducing the number of required passages while maintaining state-of-the-art performance.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Graph Neural Networks via Hierarchical Graph Refinement
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable performance in various graph-based applications. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised concerns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph refinement approach to enhance the robustness of GNNs. We introduce a graph coarsening strategy that iteratively merges nodes and edges, thereby creating a hierarchy of refined graphs. Our method, 'HierGARD', adaptively selects the most informative nodes and edges at each level, resulting in a more robust representation of the graph structure. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierGARD improves the adversarial robustness of GNNs while maintaining their performance on clean data.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities, available resources, and environmental constraints. Our approach leverages a variant of deep Q-networks to learn optimal task allocation policies that maximize system-level performance. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing response times compared to traditional allocation strategies.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics. However, existing indexing techniques for time-series data are not optimized for main-memory scenarios, resulting in poor query performance. This paper presents 'TS-Index', a novel indexing scheme specifically designed for real-time time-series data in main-memory database systems. TS-Index leverages the properties of main memory to reduce index creation time and improve query performance. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that TS-Index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x in query latency and 3x in index creation time.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Real-time Analytics with Skew-Tolerant Columnar Storage
paper_abstract: Emerging applications in IoT, finance, and healthcare demand real-time analytics capabilities. However, traditional row-store databases struggle to handle the high velocity and variability of modern data. This paper presents 'SkewCol', a novel columnar storage architecture designed to mitigate performance degradation under data skew. By adaptively reorganizing column groups based on frequency and cardinality, SkewCol reduces query latency by up to 40% compared to state-of-the-art column stores. We evaluate SkewCol using a range of real-world datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in supporting interactive analytics workloads.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Thompson Sampling
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel cooperative task allocation approach based on Thompson sampling, a Bayesian heuristic for multi-armed bandits. Our algorithm, 'CATS', adaptively allocates tasks to agents by balancing exploration and exploitation, considering both individual agent capabilities and global system constraints. We demonstrate the efficacy of CATS through extensive simulations, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized task allocation methods.

title: EyeGaze Keyboard: A Gaze-Based Text Entry System for People with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with computers. This paper presents EyeGaze Keyboard, a novel gaze-based text entry system that enables users to type using their eye movements. Our system leverages a deep learning-based approach to accurately detect and classify gaze patterns, achieving an average typing speed of 15 words per minute with an error rate of 5%. A user study with 15 participants with motor impairments demonstrates the effectiveness of EyeGaze Keyboard in enhancing their computing experience. We also discuss the implications of our system for improving accessibility in human-computer interaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) is a key task in natural language processing, where the goal is to identify sentiment polarities towards specific aspects or entities in text. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture for ABSA, which leverages the graph structure of aspect-entity relationships to capture complex contextual dependencies. Our model consists of two stages: (1) aspect extraction using a graph attention mechanism, and (2) sentiment prediction via a hierarchical graph neural network. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of aspect extraction F1-score and sentiment accuracy, achieving a new state-of-the-art on the SemEval 2014 dataset.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Adaptive Iconography on User Experience in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: As Augmented Reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, user experience (UX) design plays a critical role in ensuring effective interaction and information comprehension. This study investigates the effects of adaptive iconography on user performance and satisfaction in AR environments. We designed and implemented an AR-based experiment, incorporating icons with varying levels of abstraction and animation. Our results show that adaptive iconography significantly improves task completion time, reduces error rates, and enhances user satisfaction. Furthermore, we identify key factors influencing user preference for icon styles and provide guidelines for AR designers to optimize their iconography.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to transform various aspects of our lives, but user experience remains a significant barrier to widespread adoption. This paper explores the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR environments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, who interacted with either a generic or personalized avatar in a social VR scenario. Our results show that users interacting with personalized avatars reported higher levels of presence, engagement, and overall satisfaction, while also exhibiting reduced symptoms of VR-induced anxiety and motion sickness. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of future VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Protein-Ligand Binding Affinity Prediction
paper_abstract: Predicting protein-ligand binding affinity is crucial for drug discovery, but existing methods often struggle to capture complex interactions between proteins and ligands. We propose a hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) that leverages both local and global structural features of protein-ligand complexes. HAGNN employs a novel attention mechanism to selectively focus on key residues and interactions, leading to improved prediction accuracy and interpretability. Extensive experiments on the PDBbind dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a mean absolute error of 1.23 kcal/mol.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In autonomous multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize agent behavior. We introduce a decentralized, asynchronous learning approach that enables agents to adapt to dynamic task environments and learn effective allocation strategies. Our experiments demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utility compared to traditional, hand-designed allocation methods. We also provide guarantees on the convergence of our algorithm under varying levels of agent communication and environmental uncertainty.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents from a massive corpus. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical document embedding approach, 'HDemb', which captures both local and global semantic relationships between passages. By learning a hierarchical representation of documents, HDemb enables fast and accurate passage retrieval using a combination of coarse-grained and fine-grained similarity metrics. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDemb outperforms state-of-the-art dense retrieval models in terms of recall and inference speed.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems, such as self-driving cars or drones, require efficient multi-agent planning to execute complex tasks. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network (HTN) approach for scalable multi-agent planning, where agents decompose high-level tasks into smaller, manageable subtasks. We introduce a distributed planning algorithm that leverages a hierarchical representation of tasks to reduce communication overhead and improve planning efficiency. Experimental results on a multi-drone surveillance scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing decentralized planning methods, achieving a 3x speedup in planning time while maintaining equivalent solution quality.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings and Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches struggle with scalability and ambiguity resolution. We propose a novel framework, 'GraphDE', which leverages graph-based embeddings and hierarchical clustering to disambiguate entities. Our approach captures complex relationships between entities and their contexts, enabling accurate disambiguation even in the presence of ambiguous mentions. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that GraphDE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Proximity-based Document Retrieval for Efficient Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) has seen significant advancements with the advent of dense passage retrieval (DPR) models. However, these models often rely on computationally expensive similarity scoring mechanisms, limiting their applicability in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes ProxIR, a novel proximity-based document retrieval framework that leverages geometric relationships between passage embeddings to efficiently identify relevant documents. We introduce a hierarchical clustering approach that prunes the search space and reduces the number of similarity computations required. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that ProxIR achieves comparable retrieval performance to state-of-the-art DPR models while reducing computational costs by up to 60%.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Modern Database Systems using Hybrid Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of modern database systems necessitates efficient query optimization techniques. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'HIRO', which combines the benefits of B-Tree and hash-based indexing. HIRO dynamically adapts to varying query workloads and data distributions, thereby minimizing query latency and improving overall system throughput. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HIRO outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 35% in terms of query response time, while maintaining a competitive storage overhead.

title: Scalable Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Dynamic IoT Environments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper introduces 'ARA', a scalable agent-based framework that dynamically allocates resources in IoT environments. ARA leverages a multi-agent system to model the interactions between devices and resources, and employs a novel auction-based mechanism to optimize resource allocation. We evaluate ARA through simulations and experiments on a real-world IoT testbed, demonstrating significant improvements in resource utilization and device satisfaction compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity and ambiguity of patent documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages deep semantic embeddings to capture the nuanced relationships between patent concepts. Our approach, called PatentSE, uses a combination of word embeddings and graph convolutional networks to learn a dense representation of patent documents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of PatentSE on a large-scale patent dataset, showing significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach has important implications for patent search and innovation management.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Multi-Objective Reinforcement Learning for Smart Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents in smart traffic management systems using multi-objective reinforcement learning. Our framework, 'TrafficMA', integrates multiple agents with diverse objectives, such as minimizing travel time, reducing congestion, and prioritizing emergency vehicles. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture that balances individual agent objectives while ensuring global system optimality. Experimental results using a simulated traffic network demonstrate that TrafficMA outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods, reducing average travel time by 23% and decreasing congestion by 17%.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Error Recovery Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but older adults often struggle with error recovery due to cognitive and motor impairments. This study investigates the effectiveness of various error recovery strategies in voice assistants designed for older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65+, evaluating three recovery strategies: explicit error messages, implicit guidance, and adaptive hinting. Our results show that adaptive hinting significantly improves task completion rates and reduces user frustration. We provide design recommendations for accessible voice assistants and discuss implications for future research on error recovery in HCI.

title: Adaptive Coalition Formation for Autonomous Vehicle Platooning using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicle platooning can significantly improve road safety and efficiency. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for adaptive coalition formation among autonomous vehicles. Our algorithm, 'AdaptPlato', enables vehicles to dynamically form and reform platoons based on their speed, position, and communication range. We demonstrate that AdaptPlato outperforms existing platooning strategies in terms of fuel efficiency, travel time, and accident rate reduction. Experimental results using SUMO simulations show that our approach can adapt to varying traffic conditions and vehicle mixes.

title: Scalable Few-Shot Learning with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning (FSL) has gained popularity in recent years, but existing methods struggle with scalability and robustness. This paper presents Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), a novel FSL framework that leverages hierarchical clustering and prototypical representations to improve performance and efficiency. HPN learns a hierarchy of prototypes from a few labeled examples, enabling fast adaptation to new classes and robustness to noisy data. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HPN on multiple benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in few-shot image classification and outperforming existing methods by a significant margin.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Robot Navigation
paper_abstract: Autonomous robot navigation in complex environments remains a challenging task. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HierNav', which leverages a multi-level abstraction of the environment to improve navigation efficiency. HierNav decomposes the navigation task into a hierarchy of sub-tasks, each solved using a separate reinforcement learning agent. We introduce a new attention-based mechanism to adaptively select the most relevant sub-task based on the current environment state, reducing the exploration-exploitation trade-off. Experimental results on a simulated robotics platform demonstrate that HierNav outperforms existing flat RL methods in terms of navigation success rate and computational efficiency.

title: Task-Oriented Dialogue Management using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents require effective dialogue management to engage users in productive conversations. This paper proposes a task-oriented dialogue management framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to optimize conversation flow. Our approach decomposes the dialogue management problem into two levels: a high-level task manager that selects the next dialogue act, and a low-level response generator that produces the corresponding utterance. We evaluate our framework on a suite of benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in task success rate and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning for Autonomous Vehicles in Urban Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent planning approach for autonomous vehicles operating in urban environments. Our framework, called 'MAP-Urban', enables vehicles to coordinate and make decisions in real-time, taking into account dynamic traffic patterns, pedestrian behavior, and infrastructure constraints. We propose a novel distributed constraint optimization algorithm that leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and optimize global objectives. Experimental results in a simulated urban scenario demonstrate that MAP-Urban improves navigation efficiency, reduces congestion, and enhances safety compared to traditional centralized planning methods.

title: Accelerating Deep Learning Inference with Hierarchical Neural Architecture Search
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their computational complexity and memory requirements hinder their deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper presents HierNAS, a novel hierarchical neural architecture search framework that efficiently explores the vast search space of possible neural architectures. By leveraging a combination of reinforcement learning and gradient-based optimization, HierNAS discovers compact and accurate models that can be executed on edge devices. Our experiments demonstrate that HierNAS achieves a 3.2x speedup in inference time on mobile devices while maintaining comparable accuracy to state-of-the-art models.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the task allocation problem in IoT networks, where a large number of devices need to be assigned tasks to maximize overall network utility. We propose a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARL-TA', which enables devices to learn and adapt to changing network conditions. Our approach leverages a novel decentralized actor-critic algorithm, which allows agents to share experiences and learn from each other without requiring a centralized controller. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods in terms of task allocation efficiency and network robustness.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Multi-Modal Representation
paper_abstract: Multi-modal learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, 'HiCLR', which leverages a hierarchical representation learning strategy to efficiently learn multi-modal representations. By exploiting the inherent structures in different modalities, HiCLR can adapt to various modalities and tasks while reducing the computational overhead. Our experiments on several benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of HiCLR in learning robust and transferable multi-modal representations, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in various downstream tasks.

title: Exhaustive Query Expansion for Efficient Semantic Search in Unstructured Data
paper_abstract: Semantic search in unstructured data often relies on query expansion to improve retrieval accuracy. However, existing methods struggle to balance query scope and computational efficiency. This paper presents a novel exhaustive query expansion (EQE) approach, which leverages hierarchical semantic indexing and probabilistic query modeling to generate a comprehensive set of candidate queries. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art expansion methods, achieving up to 25% improvement in mean average precision while reducing computational overhead by 30%

title: Efficient Indexing for Proximity Search in High-Dimensional Spaces
paper_abstract: Proximity search is a fundamental problem in information retrieval, where the goal is to efficiently retrieve the nearest neighbors to a query point in a high-dimensional space. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'Hypersphere++,' which leverages the concept of hyperspheres to reduce the search space and improve query efficiency. We demonstrate that Hypersphere++ outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, including HNSW and Annoy, on several benchmark datasets, achieving up to 3x speedup while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Clustering-Based Anomaly Detection for Time-Series Data using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical clustering and graph neural networks (GNNs) to identify anomalies in time-series data. Our method, HierGNN, represents time-series data as a graph, where each node corresponds to a time step, and edges capture temporal dependencies. Hierarchical clustering is applied to identify dense regions in the graph, and GNNs are used to learn a robust representation of the data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to noise.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Elderly Users with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system, 'EasyGesture', designed specifically for elderly users with cognitive impairments. EasyGesture employs a multimodal approach, combining computer vision and machine learning algorithms to recognize gestures. We propose an adaptive framework that dynamically adjusts the system's sensitivity and accuracy based on the user's cognitive abilities and environmental factors. A user study with 30 elderly participants demonstrated that EasyGesture significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems. Our findings suggest that EasyGesture has the potential to enhance the quality of life for elderly individuals with cognitive impairments.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coordinated exploration is crucial for efficient decision-making. However, the complexity of agent interactions and the large state space make it challenging to design effective exploration strategies. This paper introduces a novel approach, Graph Attention-based Coordinated Exploration (GACE), which leverages graph attention networks to model agent interactions and learn a coordinated exploration policy. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GACE in a variety of multi-agent environments, including robotic swarms and smart traffic management, and show improved performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to scale and handle large amounts of data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using machine learning techniques. We develop a framework that utilizes neural networks to learn the optimization strategies from historical query data and adapt to changing workloads. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach can reduce query execution time by up to 30% compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems require efficient query processing to handle large-scale data and high query loads. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, combining the benefits of term-based and document-based indexing. Our method, called HyIx, uses a hierarchical index structure to facilitate fast query routing and reduce network communication costs. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that HyIx outperforms existing indexing techniques, achieving up to 30% improvement in query response time and 25% reduction in network bandwidth usage.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Healthcare: A Study on Trust and Emotional Intelligence
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to revolutionize healthcare by providing personalized support and companionship to patients. However, the effectiveness of ECAs depends on patients' trust and emotional connection with these agents. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an ECA for healthcare, focusing on trust-building strategies and emotional intelligence. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 patients and 15 healthcare professionals, revealing that ECAs with empathetic responses and nonverbal cues can establish higher trust and emotional connection with patients. Our findings provide insights into the design of ECAs that can improve patient engagement and outcomes in healthcare settings.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Systems for Real-Time Resource Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Resource allocation in decentralized systems is a complex problem, particularly in real-time environments. This paper proposes a novel approach using multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize resource allocation in decentralized autonomous systems. We introduce a hierarchical framework, 'MARLA', that leverages decentralized POMDPs and deep reinforcement learning to learn effective allocation strategies. Experimental results on a real-world grid management scenario demonstrate that MARLA outperforms traditional optimization methods, achieving significant improvements in resource utilization and response time.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, it is essential to ensure that VR experiences are accessible and enjoyable for users with diverse abilities. This paper presents a novel adaptive gesture recognition system that can be integrated into VR applications to improve the user experience for individuals with motor impairments. Our system utilizes machine learning algorithms to dynamically adjust gesture recognition thresholds based on a user's performance and preferences. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that our system significantly reduced error rates and improved user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture recognition systems.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents for dynamic task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized, multi-agent framework that enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task assignment and execution. Our method leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and incorporates a curriculum-based learning strategy to handle varying task complexities. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced agent collisions compared to traditional, rule-based allocation methods.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but individuals with visual impairments are often excluded from these experiences. This paper presents an investigation into the design of accessible VR interfaces for visually impaired individuals. We conducted a series of user studies to identify key challenges and opportunities, and developed a set of design guidelines and recommendations. Our findings highlight the importance of multimodal feedback, assistive navigation, and personalized customization. We also developed a prototype VR system that incorporates these principles, demonstrating improved usability and accessibility for visually impaired users.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Multi-Task Learning for Explainable AI Diagnosis in Healthcare
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has gained significant attention in healthcare, where model interpretability is crucial for trust and adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based multi-task learning framework, 'HierXAI', which simultaneously learns diagnostic predictions and explanations for medical images. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to identify relevant regions of interest and generate explanations via visual and textual features. Experimental results on a large-scale medical imaging dataset demonstrate that HierXAI outperforms state-of-the-art models in both diagnosis accuracy and explanation quality, providing actionable insights for clinicians.

title: Efficient Join Ordering for Distributed Query Optimization in Heterogeneous Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed query optimization in heterogeneous database systems is a complex problem, and join ordering is a crucial step in this process. This paper proposes a novel approach, called 'HetJoin', that leverages a combination of statistical and machine learning techniques to efficiently order joins in distributed queries. HetJoin adapts to varying data distributions, network latencies, and hardware heterogeneities, thereby optimizing query performance. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HetJoin outperforms state-of-the-art join ordering algorithms by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Latent Semantic Analysis for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval due to the scarcity of relevant terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, LSA-TE, which leverages latent semantic analysis to capture the underlying semantic relationships between terms. Our method incorporates a term embedding module that learns to represent terms in a high-dimensional space, enabling the discovery of nuanced term associations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that LSA-TE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness to query variations.

title: Deep Hierarchical Clustering for Unsupervised Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Unsupervised anomaly detection in time series data is a challenging task due to the lack of labeled data. Existing methods often rely on density-based or distance-based approaches, which may not capture complex patterns in the data. This paper proposes a novel deep hierarchical clustering framework, 'DeepHC', which leverages the representational power of deep neural networks to learn a hierarchical clustering structure from time series data. Our approach enables the detection of anomalies at multiple scales and resolutions, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on several benchmark datasets.

title: EyeGazeType: Enhancing Text Entry on Mobile Devices with Gaze-Based Predictive Modeling
paper_abstract: Mobile text entry remains a significant bottleneck in human-computer interaction. This paper introduces EyeGazeType, a novel system that leverages gaze-based predictive modeling to improve text entry efficiency on mobile devices. By integrating eye-tracking with machine learning, EyeGazeType accurately predicts the user's intended characters and words, reducing the need for manual corrections. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrated a significant increase in text entry speed and accuracy, with an average reduction of 23.5% in keystrokes and 17.2% in error rate compared to traditional touch-based input methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to efficiently optimize queries in distributed graph databases. Our method, called GNN-Opt, learns to predict the optimal query plan based on the graph structure and query characteristics. We evaluate GNN-Opt on a variety of graph datasets and show that it outperforms traditional query optimization techniques in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, coordinating task allocation is crucial for efficient performance. This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MADRL', which learns to allocate tasks dynamically based on agent capabilities, task priorities, and environmental constraints. We utilize a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to optimize its local policy while communicating with neighbors to achieve global coordination. Experimental results on a realistic disaster response scenario demonstrate that MADRL outperforms traditional planning-based approaches in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component of task-oriented dialogue systems. While recent advances in graph neural networks have improved DST performance, they often lack interpretability. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) architecture that incorporates graph attention mechanisms at multiple scales to capture complex contextual relationships between dialogue turns. We propose a novel explainability module that generates attention-based visualizations of the model's reasoning process, enabling developers to identify errors and improve model performance. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ benchmark demonstrate that HiGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful explanations for its predictions.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Intelligent Wheelchair Navigation
paper_abstract: Wheelchair users often face difficulties navigating through cluttered environments. This paper presents 'GazeNav', a novel gaze-based interaction system that enables intelligent wheelchair navigation. We leverage a machine learning model to predict the user's gaze direction and intent, allowing the wheelchair to autonomously avoid obstacles and follow desired paths. Our user study with 15 participants demonstrates that GazeNav reduces navigation time by 30% and improves overall user experience. We also discuss the system's limitations and potential applications in assistive technologies.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Learning-based Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Conventional indexing techniques for document retrieval often struggle to balance query latency and retrieval quality. We propose a novel hierarchical indexing approach, 'DeepIR', which leverages deep learning to learn a hierarchical representation of documents. This enables efficient pruning of irrelevant documents at multiple levels, resulting in significant reductions in query latency. Our experiments on large-scale document collections demonstrate that DeepIR outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of both retrieval effectiveness and query efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has gained significant attention in recent years, but scaling to complex scenarios remains a challenge. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that efficiently handles varying numbers of agents and state dimensions. HAN incorporates both intra-agent and inter-agent attention mechanisms, enabling agents to selectively focus on relevant information and coordinate their actions. Experimental results on several MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HAN achieves state-of-the-art performance and improves robustness in diverse environments.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommender systems have garnered increasing attention in recent years, as users seek transparency into the reasoning behind suggested items. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture, which captures both local and global relationships between users, items, and their attributes. By incorporating attention mechanisms at multiple scales, our model generates interpretable explanations for recommendation results, improving user trust and satisfaction. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in terms of recommendation accuracy, diversity, and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Bayesian Neural Networks for Uncertainty-Aware Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in image classification tasks, but they often lack robustness to out-of-distribution inputs and neglect aleatoric uncertainty. This paper proposes a Bayesian neural network (BNN) framework that leverages sparse Gaussian processes to model uncertainty in neural network weights. We introduce a novel Variational Bayes-based inference method that enables efficient and scalable uncertainty estimation. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets demonstrate that our approach improves classification accuracy and provides calibrated uncertainty estimates, outperforming state-of-the-art deterministic and Bayesian models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Attributed Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in attributed graphs is a crucial task in various applications, including social network analysis and bioinformatics. However, existing graph neural network models often suffer from limited scalability and neglect the importance of node attributes. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that effectively incorporates node attributes and leverages hierarchical graph structures to capture long-range dependencies. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of node classification accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical reinforcement learning for autonomous navigation in dynamic environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous navigation in dynamic environments poses significant challenges due to the need to adapt to changing circumstances. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that enables robots to learn both high-level navigation policies and low-level control skills. Our approach leverages a novel hierarchical abstraction of the environment, allowing the agent to focus on relevant aspects of the state space. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in a series of experiments involving a robotic vehicle navigating through crowded streets and construction zones, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and safety.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-tenant database systems, query optimization is crucial for efficient resource allocation and improved performance. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for diverse workloads. We design a deep Q-network that learns to predict optimal query plans based on runtime statistics and database characteristics. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates significant improvements in query response time and system throughput compared to traditional rule-based optimization techniques.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning-based Index Selection
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large volumes of data and high query throughput. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to select the most effective indexes for a given query workload. We develop a framework that uses query execution statistics and database schema information to train a predictive model, which then recommends an optimal index configuration. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach can improve query performance by up to 30% compared to traditional indexing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Session-based Search
paper_abstract: Session-based search has become increasingly popular, but it poses significant challenges for query understanding and document ranking. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs). Our model captures complex query-document relationships by hierarchically aggregating node representations from a graph constructed from the session history. We introduce a new attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each query term based on its context and relevance to the search session. Experimental results on the TREC Session Track dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and nDCG.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems. This paper presents a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoopHRL', which enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task allocation. CoopHRL consists of a high-level coordinator that allocates tasks to agents and a low-level learner that updates the coordinator's policy. We employ a decentralized actor-critic method to update the agents' policies, allowing them to adapt to changing task requirements. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse environment demonstrate that CoopHRL outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neuralword Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, as it enables the incorporation of relevant terms to improve the retrieval performance. However, traditional query expansion methods rely on manual feature engineering and often fail to capture semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a neural-based query expansion approach, NeuralQE, which leverages pre-trained word embeddings to learn a dense representation of query terms. We demonstrate that NeuralQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, including Robust04 and ClueWeb09, and achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to urban traffic management using autonomous agents coordinated through deep reinforcement learning. Our proposed framework, 'TrafficIQ', consists of a network of agents that learn to optimize traffic signal control in real-time, taking into account dynamic traffic patterns, pedestrian and cyclist safety, and environmental impact. We evaluate TrafficIQ in a simulated urban environment and demonstrate significant reductions in congestion, travel time, and emissions compared to traditional traffic management systems. The proposed framework has potential for large-scale deployment in smart cities.

title: Hierarchical Neural Re-Ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The increasing volume of online documents has made efficient document retrieval a crucial component in modern search engines. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural re-ranking approach, 'HNR', which leverages the strengths of both lexical and semantic matching techniques. HNR first employs a coarse-grained lexical matching module to filter out irrelevant documents, followed by a fine-grained semantic re-ranking module that incorporates contextualized embeddings. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that HNR outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of both retrieval accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph Neural Networks and Dictionary-based Indexing
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in various natural language processing and information retrieval applications. However, existing approaches suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large knowledge graphs and dictionaries. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'GEDIS', which leverages graph neural networks to learn entity representations and dictionary-based indexing to efficiently prune the search space. Our experiments on the Wikidata dataset demonstrate that GEDIS achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the average query time by an order of magnitude compared to existing methods.

title: EyeGaze+: A Gaze-Based Interface for Hands-Free Navigation in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often require users to dedicate one hand for navigation, limiting their freedom of movement and immersion. We present EyeGaze+, a novel gaze-based interface that enables hands-free navigation in VR. Our approach leverages machine learning-driven eye-tracking and object detection to infer user intent, allowing users to navigate through virtual environments using only their gaze. We evaluate EyeGaze+ in a user study, demonstrating improved navigation efficiency and reduced user fatigue compared to traditional controller-based methods.

title: Efficient Hybrid Indexing for Scalable Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: With the increasing volume and velocity of big data, real-time data warehousing (RTDW) has become a crucial requirement for various applications. However, existing indexing techniques struggle to provide efficient query processing and data ingestion in RTDW systems. This paper presents a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'HierIndex', which combines the benefits of column-store and row-store indexing. HierIndex leverages a hierarchical data structure to facilitate fast query processing, while adaptively adjusting the indexing granularity based on data distribution and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that HierIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query performance and data ingestion rates.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Scheduling in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Task scheduling in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly when agents have diverse capabilities and tasks have varying priorities. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that leverages both macro- and micro-level decision-making to optimize task scheduling. Our approach, 'HierSched', decomposes the scheduling problem into a hierarchical structure, where high-level policies select tasks and low-level policies allocate agents. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierSched in a simulated logistics domain, showing significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Task Planning with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Warehouses
paper_abstract: Autonomous warehouses are increasingly relying on multi-agent systems to optimize task allocation and execution. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task planning framework that leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to coordinate agents in dynamic warehouse environments. Our approach integrates a high-level task planner with a low-level motion planner, enabling agents to learn complex task dependencies and adapt to changing warehouse conditions. Experimental results demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced agent collisions compared to traditional rule-based approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Multimodal Error Recovery
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their limitations can lead to frustration and exclusion for users with disabilities. This paper investigates multimodal error recovery strategies for voice assistants, focusing on individuals with visual impairments. We designed and evaluated a novel interface that combines speech, touch, and vibration cues to facilitate error correction. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional speech-only interfaces. The findings inform the development of more inclusive and accessible voice assistants.

title: A Hierarchical Query Expansion Framework for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval systems face the challenge of anticipating the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, 'PatentQuest', which leverages both lexical and semantic relationships to enrich user queries. We introduce a two-stage approach, where an initial query expansion phase is followed by a re-ranking phase that incorporates patent-specific features, such as citations and claims. Experimental results on a large patent corpus demonstrate that PatentQuest outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities need to be assigned tasks to maximize overall efficiency. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model complex agent-task interactions. Our approach, called HTA-GNN, represents the agent-task graph as a hierarchical structure, allowing the GNN to capture both local and global dependencies. Experimental results on a variety of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that HTA-GNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Sparse Document Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents for answer extraction. This paper proposes a novel approach to passage retrieval using sparse document representations, which reduces the dimensionality of the document embedding space while preserving semantic information. Our method, dubbed 'SparseRetriever', leverages a combination of sparse autoencoders and document frequency-based weighting to generate compact document representations. Experimental results on the Natural Questions benchmark demonstrate that SparseRetriever outperforms state-of-the-art dense retrieval methods in terms of both retrieval efficiency and ODQA performance.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems in dynamic task allocation scenarios. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, termed HRL-MA, which enables agents to learn both high-level task assignment policies and low-level action execution strategies. HRL-MA incorporates a layered decomposition of the task space, allowing agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. Experimental results in a simulated smart factory domain demonstrate that HRL-MA outperforms state-of-the-art coordination methods in terms of task completion rates and overall system efficiency.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Databases with Hierarchical Partitioning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel hierarchical partitioning approach, called 'HierPart', which leverages a combination of vertical and horizontal partitioning to minimize data redundancy and improve query execution times. We propose a cost-based optimization model that considers query patterns, data distribution, and system resources to dynamically adjust the partitioning scheme. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HierPart can reduce query latency by up to 40% compared to state-of-the-art partitioning techniques.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Neural Networks using Attention-based Feature Importance
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and adoption. This paper proposes a novel attention-based feature importance (ABFI) method for explaining deep neural network decisions. ABFI leverages attention mechanisms to identify crucial input features contributing to the model's predictions. We demonstrate the efficacy of ABFI on various benchmark datasets, showing that it outperforms existing explainability techniques in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency. Furthermore, we integrate ABFI with a visual analytics framework to facilitate human-in-the-loop model debugging and improvement.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly prevalent in modern data centers, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel adaptive indexing technique that dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distributions. Our approach, called 'ADAPTIX', leverages machine learning models to predict query access patterns and adaptively reorganize indexes to minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that ADAPTIX achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional static indexing methods.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize control policies, but the lack of transparency in RL decision-making hinders trust and safety. This paper proposes 'XRL', a novel framework that integrates model-based RL with attention-based explainability techniques. XRL generates visual explanations for the control actions taken by the autonomous vehicle, enabling human understanding of the decision-making process. We evaluate XRL on a realistic simulation environment and demonstrate improved interpretability without compromising control performance.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Hierarchical Topic Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval techniques often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of user queries, resulting in suboptimal document rankings. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages hierarchical topic modeling to refine query representations. By incorporating topic hierarchies, our approach can better capture the semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision. We further analyze the impact of topic hierarchy depth on retrieval performance, providing insights into the optimal configuration for different query types.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education by providing immersive and interactive learning experiences. However, the effectiveness of VR-based learning environments can be influenced by various factors, including personalization. This study explores the impact of personalized VR experiences on user experience, engagement, and learning outcomes. We designed and evaluated a VR-based learning platform that incorporates user modeling and adaptive content presentation. Our results show that personalized VR experiences lead to increased user satisfaction, engagement, and knowledge retention compared to non-personalized experiences. The findings of this study have implications for the design of VR-based learning environments and highlight the importance of considering personalization in HCI research.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its accessibility for users with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR interfaces that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with users with disabilities and developed a set of accessibility guidelines for VR interface design. Our results show that the proposed guidelines significantly improve the usability and user experience of VR systems for users with disabilities.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach to cooperative task allocation using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). We formulate the task allocation problem as a DCOP, where agents negotiate to assign tasks while respecting constraints on resource availability, task dependencies, and agent capabilities. Our algorithm, called CATS, leverages a hybrid of centralized and decentralized optimization techniques to find near-optimal solutions. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that CATS outperforms existing decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous traffic management. Our approach, dubbed 'HMRAT', consists of a two-level hierarchy: a high-level controller that allocates traffic signals to individual intersections and a low-level controller that optimizes traffic flow at each intersection. We employ a decentralized actor-critic algorithm to learn cooperative policies among agents, leveraging graph attention mechanisms to model complex traffic dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that HMRAT significantly reduces congestion and travel times compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Robots using Dynamic Coalition Formation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation approach for autonomous robots using dynamic coalition formation. Our method, called 'Coalition-Robot', allows robots to form and dissolve coalitions dynamically to allocate tasks efficiently. We model the task allocation problem as a decentralized multi-agent system and propose a algorithm that integrates reinforcement learning with graph theory to optimize coalition formation. Experimental results show that Coalition-Robot outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using auctions
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that affects the overall performance and efficiency of the system. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using auctions, where agents bid for tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We introduce a novel bidding strategy, called 'adaptive bid scaling', which adapts to the dynamic environment and ensures that tasks are allocated efficiently. We evaluate our approach using a simulated robotic swarm scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing centralized approaches.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomic Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing resources are often underutilized, leading to inefficiencies and increased costs. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARLA', which enables autonomic resource allocation in cloud data centers. MARLA employs a decentralized, cooperative approach, where agents learn to optimize resource allocation based on local observations and reward signals. We evaluate MARLA on a real-world cloud workload dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to traditional, rule-based allocation strategies.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Efficient Document Ranking with Deep Query Embeddings
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'HQER', which integrates the strengths of traditional term-based retrieval and neural ranking models. HQER employs deep query embeddings to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents, while leveraging a term-based retrieval component to efficiently filter out irrelevant documents. Our experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that HQER achieves significant improvements in ranking effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models, with a 23% increase in MRR@10 and a 40% reduction in computational cost.

title: Distributed Reasoning for Multi-Agent Systems using Logical Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) are increasingly used in real-world applications, but their complexity poses significant challenges for reasoning and decision-making. This paper introduces a novel distributed reasoning framework, 'LogiMAS', which leverages logical networks to facilitate scalable and efficient inference among agents. By representing agent knowledge as logical formulas and exploiting the structural properties of networks, LogiMAS enables agents to reason about global states and make collective decisions without requiring a centralized controller. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of LogiMAS in reducing communication overhead and improving system resilience.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on Foveated Rendering and Visual Attention
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems can benefit from gaze-based interaction, but current approaches are limited by high computational costs and inaccurate gaze tracking. This paper presents a novel foveated rendering technique that leverages visual attention models to optimize rendering resources. We conducted a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of our approach, which combines machine learning-based gaze prediction with a foveated rendering pipeline. Results show a significant reduction in computational overhead while maintaining user experience quality. Our approach enables efficient and accurate gaze-based interaction for VR applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework, 'Hierarchical-Agent', which leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning to enable agents to adapt to changing environments. We introduce a novel hierarchical architecture that consists of a high-level task allocator and low-level agent controllers, which are trained using a decentralized, model-free reinforcement learning algorithm. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that Hierarchical-Agent outperforms traditional, centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and adaptability to unexpected events.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture Recognition and Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: This paper explores the relationship between embodied cognition and cognitive load in virtual reality (VR) environments. We designed an experiment to investigate how gesture recognition affects cognitive load in VR-based learning tasks. Our results show that the use of embodied gestures can reduce cognitive load and improve learning outcomes in VR. We also propose a novel gesture recognition model that leverages machine learning techniques to classify gestures in real-time. The implications of our findings are discussed in the context of HCI and education.

title: Efficient Online Learning of Hierarchical Task Networks with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Hierarchical task networks (HTNs) are a popular formalism for representing complex tasks in AI planning. However, learning HTNs from experience remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel online learning framework that integrates deep reinforcement learning with HTN planning. Our approach, called HTN-DRL, uses a hierarchical actor-critic architecture to learn both the HTN structure and the underlying primitive actions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HTN-DRL on a set of challenging robotic manipulation tasks, showing improved learning efficiency and generalization capabilities compared to existing methods.

title: Heterogeneous Agent Collaboration for Adaptive Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel framework for heterogeneous agent collaboration in dynamic environments, where agents with diverse capabilities and expertise need to adaptively allocate tasks to achieve common goals. We propose a multi-layered architecture that integrates machine learning-based task prediction, real-time agent profiling, and distributed decision-making. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Survey and New Benchmark
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved remarkable success in various applications, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a critical concern. This survey provides a comprehensive review of existing attack methods on GNNs, including graph structure perturbations, node feature manipulation, and black-box attacks. We also introduce a new benchmark dataset, GNN-Bench, which includes a diverse set of graph structures and attack scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed benchmark is more challenging than existing datasets, highlighting the need for further research in this area. Finally, we discuss potential defense strategies and open challenges in adversarial robustness for GNNs.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Scalable Unsupervised Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Unsupervised representation learning has become a crucial component in many machine learning pipelines. However, existing clustering-based methods suffer from scalability issues, limiting their applicability to large datasets. We propose a novel hierarchical clustering algorithm, 'HierClus', which leverages a divide-and-conquer strategy to efficiently identify dense regions in high-dimensional spaces. Our approach adaptively selects the most informative features at each level of the hierarchy, enabling the discovery of nuanced patterns in the data. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that HierClus outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Adaptive Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coalition formation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to form coalitions to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a novel adaptive coalition formation framework using reinforcement learning. Our approach, called Adaptive Coalition Formation Algorithm (ACFA), uses Q-learning to learn the optimal coalition formation strategy based on the agents' interactions and rewards. We show that ACFA outperforms existing methods in terms of coalition stability and individual agent utility, and is robust to changes in the environment and agent preferences. We evaluate our approach using a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating its effectiveness in real-world applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for People with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Individuals with dyslexia often face barriers when interacting with conversational interfaces, such as chatbots and voice assistants. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create more inclusive conversational interfaces for people with dyslexia. We conducted a mixed-methods study, involving surveys, interviews, and usability testing, to identify the specific challenges and needs of this population. Our findings inform the development of a set of design guidelines and a prototype system that incorporates adaptations such as text-to-speech, phonetic spell-checking, and semantic error correction. Evaluation results show significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for participants with dyslexia.

title: Investigating the Effect of Personalized Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various industries, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalized haptic feedback on user experience and immersion in VR environments. We designed a novel haptic feedback system that adapts to individual users' preferences and tactile sensitivity, and evaluated its effectiveness in a controlled experiment. Our results show that personalized haptic feedback significantly enhances user engagement, presence, and enjoyment in VR, particularly for users with higher tactile sensitivity. The findings have implications for the design of more effective and engaging VR interfaces.

title: Real-time Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings and Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in information retrieval, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in unstructured text. Existing approaches often rely on hand-crafted features or traditional machine learning methods, which can be computationally expensive and lack flexibility. This paper proposes a novel real-time entity disambiguation framework that leverages knowledge graph embeddings and hierarchical attention mechanisms. Our approach learns to represent entities as dense vectors, enabling efficient similarity calculations, and incorporates hierarchical attention to model complex relationships between entities and context. Experiments on benchmark datasets show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and inference time, making it suitable for real-time applications.

title: Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing using Deep Reinforcement Learning
