paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become crucial in modern analytics, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQOpt', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in real-time data warehouses. We design a customized neural network architecture that learns to predict optimal query plans from a vast space of possible plans. Our experiments on a real-world data warehouse demonstrate that DeepQOpt achieves an average query response time reduction of 37% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Uncertainty using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, planning with uncertainty remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a decentralized approach, 'MA-DRUL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn policies for individual agents that account for uncertain outcomes. We introduce a novel hierarchical architecture that combines a high-level, graph-based planner with low-level, policy-based controllers. Experimental results on a real-world traffic management scenario demonstrate that MA-DRUL outperforms state-of-the-art decentralized planning methods, achieving a 25% reduction in average travel time while handling uncertain traffic patterns.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Explainable Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks often suffer from a lack of transparency, making it challenging to understand the reasoning behind their predictions. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'HCLUST-EX', to identify and visualize meaningful feature representations in deep learning models. By recursively grouping neurons with similar activation patterns, HCLUST-EX provides a hierarchical abstraction of the feature space, enabling the identification of explainable clusters and improving model interpretability. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HCLUST-EX in revealing insightful relationships between input features and model predictions.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face the challenge of optimizing query execution plans to minimize response time and resource utilization. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, which learns to adapt to changing workloads and system conditions. Our proposed framework, 'RL-Optimizer', employs a deep Q-network to select the optimal execution plan based on a reward function that balances query latency and system resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that RL-Optimizer outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of average query response time.

title: Efficient Multimodal Fusion for Explainable Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep learning models for image classification often rely on unimodal feature extractors, neglecting the complementary information provided by other modalities. This paper introduces a novel multimodal fusion framework, 'MMFusion', which combines visual, semantic, and spatial features to improve classification accuracy and model explainability. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the contribution of each modality, allowing for interpretable feature importance scores. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that MMFusion outperforms state-of-the-art unimodal models while providing meaningful insights into the decision-making process.

title: Towards Efficient Explainability in Deep Neural Networks using Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: The widespread adoption of deep neural networks (DNNs) in high-stakes applications has sparked a growing need for explainability. This paper presents a novel approach to explaining DNN decisions using hierarchical attention mechanisms. Our method, HierAtt, recursively applies attention weights to capture complex patterns in feature interactions. We demonstrate that HierAtt outperforms existing explainability methods in terms of faithfulness and interpretability on a range of benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we provide theoretical insights into the conditions under which HierAtt is guaranteed to produce faithful explanations.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Autonomous Agents via Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The efficient allocation of tasks to autonomous agents in decentralized systems is a challenging problem, particularly when agents have heterogeneous capabilities and preferences. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn a decentralized task allocation policy. Our method, called HATPA, uses a multi-agent Q-network to learn the optimal task allocation strategy based on the agents' capabilities, task requirements, and environmental constraints. We evaluate HATPA in a simulated warehouse scenario with heterogeneous robots and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion efficiency and fairness compared to traditional methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Disease Diagnosis
paper_abstract: Accurate disease diagnosis relies on the effective integration of multi-modal data, including medical images, clinical text, and genomic data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant features across different modalities. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to model complex relationships between modalities and identify discriminative features for disease diagnosis. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of diagnosis accuracy and robustness to noisy or missing data.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Machine Learning-based Eye Movement Prediction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual input devices, which can be cumbersome and disrupt the immersive experience. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction approach that leverages machine learning-based eye movement prediction to enable hands-free interaction in VR. Our method uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to predict the user's gaze direction based on eye movement data, achieving a mean angular error of 2.4 degrees. We integrate this approach with a VR platform and demonstrate its effectiveness in various interactive tasks, including object selection and menu navigation.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Navigation in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous navigation in partially observable environments is a challenging problem in robotics and AI research. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'DeepPOMDP', which leverages hierarchical abstraction and attention mechanisms to learn effective navigation policies in complex, dynamic environments. We demonstrate the efficacy of DeepPOMDP in a series of simulated and real-world experiments, including navigation in warehouse and office environments with varying levels of observability. Our results show significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of navigation efficiency and adaptability.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Adaptive Graph-Based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but existing approaches struggle with scalability and ambiguity in large datasets. This paper presents 'AdaGEM', a novel graph-based embedding method that adaptively incorporates contextual information to disambiguate entities. AdaGEM leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant graph neighborhoods, enabling efficient handling of large-scale datasets. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaGEM outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Scalable and Secure Data Warehousing with Blockchain-based Provenance
paper_abstract: Data warehousing has become a critical component of modern data analytics, but ensuring data integrity and provenance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel blockchain-based approach to scalable and secure data warehousing, 'BlockDW'. We design a distributed ledger architecture that enables tamper-evident and transparent data provenance, while ensuring efficient query processing and data aggregation. Our experiments on a large-scale synthetic dataset demonstrate that BlockDW achieves significant performance improvements over traditional data warehousing solutions, while providing strong guarantees of data integrity and provenance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graphs for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely on effective query expansion techniques to retrieve relevant products. In this paper, we propose a novel neural query graph (NQG) model that learns to expand queries by incorporating semantic relationships between entities and attributes. Our approach leverages a graph attention mechanism to identify important nodes and edges in the query graph, allowing for more accurate and diverse expansion terms. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that NQG outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 12% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Goals
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of planning for multi-agent systems with uncertain goals in dynamic environments. We propose a hierarchical task network planning (HTNP) framework that integrates probabilistic goal reasoning and plan adaptation. Our approach enables agents to reason about uncertain goals, generate feasible plans, and adapt to changing environments. We evaluate the effectiveness of our approach using a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved plan flexibility and robustness compared to traditional HTNP methods.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Inference for Adaptive Assistive Systems
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities often rely on assistive systems to communicate and interact with their environment. However, these systems can be improved by incorporating user intention inference. This paper presents a novel approach to inferring user intentions using gaze patterns. We propose a machine learning model that leverages eye-tracking data to predict user goals and adapt the assistive system's behavior accordingly. Our approach is evaluated in a case study with 20 participants, showing significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction. The results demonstrate the potential of gaze-based intention inference for enhancing the usability and effectiveness of adaptive assistive systems.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality: A Multimodal Fusion Approach
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has transformed human-computer interaction, but existing input methods are limited. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction framework for AR environments, leveraging multimodal fusion of eye-tracking, head-pose, and hand-tracking data. Our approach enables intuitive and precise manipulation of virtual objects, exploiting the strengths of each modality to overcome individual limitations. We evaluate our system through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Efficient Adversarial Training for Robust Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks in autonomous vehicles are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can lead to catastrophic consequences. This paper presents a novel adversarial training approach, 'AdvDet', that improves the robustness of object detection models against physical-world attacks. We propose a hybrid method combining virtual and real-world adversarial examples, and introduce a novel loss function that balances detection accuracy and robustness. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that AdvDet outperforms state-of-the-art adversarial training methods, achieving a 25% reduction in detection errors under attack.

title: Gaze-Based Interactive Visualization of Multimodal Brain-Computer Interface Data
paper_abstract: Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems generate vast amounts of multimodal data, making it challenging for users to interpret and interact with the data. This paper presents 'GazeVista', a novel gaze-based interactive visualization framework that enables users to explore and analyze BCI data in real-time. We utilize machine learning algorithms to predict user intent from gaze patterns, allowing users to select and inspect data segments of interest. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates that GazeVista improves data exploration efficiency by 35% and reduces cognitive load by 28% compared to traditional visualization methods.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing Environments
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to diverse workloads. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudAllocator', which leverages a hybrid actor-critic architecture to optimize resource allocation decisions. By incorporating a graph neural network to model workload dependencies and a proactive exploration strategy to handle uncertainty, CloudAllocator achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Experiments on a real-world cloud platform demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in dynamic, large-scale environments.

title: Self-Supervised Representation Learning for Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Existing time-series anomaly detection methods often rely on labeled data, which can be scarce and expensive to obtain. This paper proposes a self-supervised representation learning framework, 'TSR', that leverages the inherent temporal structure of time-series data to learn effective representations for anomaly detection. TSR employs a contrastive loss function that encourages the model to distinguish between normal and anomalous patterns, without requiring explicit labels. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TSR on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in unsupervised anomaly detection.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive User Modeling for Enhanced Virtual Reality Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized various domains, but users' diverse visual attention patterns and preferences remain a significant challenge. This paper presents 'GazeFit', a novel gaze-based adaptive user modeling framework that dynamically tailors VR experiences to individual users. By leveraging machine learning-based gaze analysis and real-time user feedback, GazeFit optimizes VR content presentation, navigation, and interaction to enhance user engagement and comfort. Our user study demonstrates significant improvements in VR experience quality and reduced user fatigue compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but their design often neglects the needs of users with visual impairments. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive conversational interfaces that cater to visually impaired users. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with visually impaired participants to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the development of a novel conversation flow management system, 'VoiceGuide', which utilizes multimodal feedback and adaptive prompts to facilitate more efficient and enjoyable interactions. A user study demonstrates that VoiceGuide significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Scalable Data Integration for Heterogeneous IoT Devices using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of heterogeneous data sources, making data integration a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to scalable data integration using knowledge graph embeddings. We design a distributed framework that leverages graph neural networks to learn entity embeddings from large-scale IoT datasets. Our approach enables efficient data integration by identifying and reconciling entities across disparate data sources. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving data integration accuracy and scalability.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used to manage large-scale data, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, which can be ineffective in complex distributed settings. This paper proposes a novel approach that applies reinforcement learning to query optimization. We design a Markov decision process that models the query optimization problem and train an agent to learn optimal query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of execution time, while achieving comparable query accuracy.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but existing interaction methods can be inaccessible to individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interface, 'GazeVR', which enables users to interact with VR environments using only their gaze. We develop a machine learning model that accurately predicts user intentions from eye movement data, and integrate it with a VR platform to provide an immersive and inclusive experience. Our user study with participants with and without disabilities demonstrates the effectiveness of GazeVR in facilitating accessible VR interactions.

title: Efficient In-Memory Join Processing for Real-Time Data Analytics
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, efficient join processing is crucial for real-time data analytics. This paper proposes 'QuickJoin', an in-memory join processing framework that leverages novel indexing and caching techniques to accelerate join operations. QuickJoin utilizes a hybrid indexing approach that combines bitmap indexing with learned indexes, reducing memory footprint while maintaining high query performance. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that QuickJoin outperforms state-of-the-art in-memory join algorithms by up to 3x, making it an attractive solution for real-time data analytics workloads.

title: Efficient Multi-Modal Fusion with Attention Mechanism for Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual Question Answering (VQA) tasks require the integration of visual and textual information to generate accurate answers. While recent approaches have utilized multi-modal fusion techniques, they often suffer from inefficiencies in processing and representing the diverse input modalities. This paper presents a novel attention-based fusion mechanism, 'MMFusion', which adaptively weights and combines the visual and textual features based on their relevance to the question. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MMFusion on several VQA benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 30%.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Ad-Hoc Retrieval using Graph-Based Document Representation
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in Information Retrieval (IR) due to the inherent complexity of natural language queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to improve retrieval effectiveness by incorporating query-driven document expansion using graph-based document representation. Our method, dubbed 'GraphExpan', leverages a graph neural network to encode semantic relationships between documents and expands the query context by incorporating relevant terms from neighboring documents. Experimental results on the TREC dataset demonstrate a significant improvement in retrieval performance, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, showcasing the potential of GraphExpan for real-world IR applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable AI-Driven Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for various applications, including predictive maintenance, healthcare, and finance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph convolutional network (HGCN) architecture for explainable AI-driven anomaly detection. Our approach leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and hierarchical representations to capture complex patterns in time-series data. We introduce a novel explainability module that provides feature importance scores, enabling the identification of contributing factors to detected anomalies. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting anomalies and improving explainability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Document Representation for Neural Retrieval Models using Hierarchical Attention
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art results in information retrieval tasks, but their document representation schemes often suffer from high computational costs and ignore the hierarchical structure of documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HAttDoc', which encodes documents as hierarchical representations, capturing both local and global contextual information. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAttDoc outperforms existing document representation methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Enhanced Document Retrieval in Medical Domain
paper_abstract: Medical document retrieval systems often struggle to accurately retrieve relevant documents due to the limitations of bag-of-words representations. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, leveraging domain-specific knowledge graphs to enrich query representations. Our model, MedQE, injects semantic relationships between medical entities and concepts into the query expansion process, resulting in improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-CDS dataset demonstrate significant gains in precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Deep Hierarchical Query Reformulation for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query reformulation is a crucial step in document retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the relevance and efficiency of search results. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'HierReform', which leverages hierarchical query representations to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. Our method uses a combination of word embeddings and graph attention mechanisms to identify key query components and generate effective reformulations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierReform outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation techniques in terms of both retrieval accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Processing for Big Data Analytics using Distributed Hash Tables
paper_abstract: As big data continues to grow, scalable and efficient query processing becomes crucial for data analytics. This paper proposes a novel query processing framework, 'DHTEQ', which leverages distributed hash tables (DHTs) to partition and process large datasets in parallel. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that dynamically reconfigures the DHT-based query plan to minimize network communication and reduce query latency. Experimental results on a real-world genomic dataset demonstrate that DHTEQ outperforms traditional distributed query processing approaches by up to 3x in terms of query response time and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture user intent from short, ambiguous queries. We propose a neural query expansion framework that incorporates pseudo-relevance feedback to improve retrieval performance. Our approach leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn contextualized representations of query terms and pseudo-relevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for verbose queries. We also show that our approach can be effectively combined with traditional retrieval models to achieve state-of-the-art performance.

title: Gaze-based Intention Detection for Adaptive Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems can significantly benefit from understanding users' intentions to provide more natural and efficient interactions. This paper presents a novel approach to detect users' intentions in VR environments using gaze-based analysis. Our system, called 'GazeIntent', leverages machine learning models to classify users' gaze patterns into distinct intention categories, such as selection, navigation, or exploration. We evaluate GazeIntent in a user study involving a VR gaming application and demonstrate a significant reduction in user frustration and improvement in task completion times.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Hashing for Efficient Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion methods rely on term co-occurrence analysis, which can be ineffective in capturing nuanced semantic relationships. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepHash', which leverages deep semantic hashing to encode query terms and documents into a compact binary representation. By learning a non-linear transformation of the term-document matrix, DeepHash enables efficient retrieval of semantically similar documents. Experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that DeepHash outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision and recall, while reducing the index size by an order of magnitude.

title: Adaptive Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: We propose a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for real-time traffic signal control. Our approach, dubbed 'SMART', enables agents to adapt to changing traffic patterns and optimize traffic flow in real-time. By integrating graph neural networks and attention mechanisms, SMART agents can effectively communicate and coordinate with each other, reducing congestion and minimizing travel times. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that SMART outperforms traditional rule-based and centralized optimization methods, achieving an average reduction of 25% in travel time and 30% in congestion.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases (DRDBs) have become a cornerstone of modern data management. However, optimizing query performance in DRDBs remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to dynamically adjust query execution plans based on real-time system and workload conditions. Our RL agent learns to optimize query execution through trial and error, resulting in significant performance gains. Experimental results on a real-world DRDB setup demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 35% in terms of query response time.

title: Designing Emotion-Aware Conversational Interfaces for Mental Health Support
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have the potential to provide accessible mental health support, but their effectiveness is hindered by the lack of emotional understanding. This paper presents a novel framework for designing emotion-aware conversational interfaces that can recognize and respond to users' emotional states. We propose a multimodal approach that combines natural language processing, sentiment analysis, and affective computing to create empathetic and personalized interactions. A user study with 100 participants demonstrates that our approach leads to increased user engagement, trust, and self-disclosure, ultimately improving the overall effectiveness of mental health support.

title: Efficient Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Non-Stationary Environments
paper_abstract: In many real-world applications, machine learning models face non-stationary environments, where the underlying data distribution changes over time. This paper proposes an efficient online learning algorithm, 'AdaReg', that leverages adaptive regularization to tackle concept drift. By dynamically adjusting the regularization strength based on the local error landscape, AdaReg achieves improved stability and adaptability in non-stationary settings. We provide theoretical guarantees for AdaReg's convergence and demonstrate its effectiveness on several benchmarks, including weather forecasting and traffic prediction.

title: Latent Semantic Analysis with Graph Attention for Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods rely on bag-of-words representations, which neglect document structure and semantic relationships. This paper presents a novel document retrieval framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model latent semantic relationships between document entities. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphLDA', represents documents as graphs and applies attention weights to capture contextual dependencies between entities. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that GraphLDA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and recall, particularly for long-tail queries.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in High-Dimensional Spaces
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to document embeddings, tailored to efficient retrieval in high-dimensional spaces. Our method, dubbed 'QADE', adaptively updates document representations based on the query context, leveraging both local and global semantic relationships. By incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism and a query-aware sampling strategy, QADE reduces the retrieval complexity while maintaining retrieval quality. Experimental evaluations on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehouses using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become crucial for timely business insights, but optimizing complex queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'QRex', a novel query optimization framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to efficiently explore the vast space of possible query execution plans. QRex utilizes a custom-designed DRL agent that incorporates domain knowledge and feedback from the underlying database system, achieving up to 3x improvement in query execution time and 2x reduction in resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the quality of life for older adults, but current systems often struggle to accurately recognize gestures from this demographic. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to developing a gesture recognition system that is inclusive of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key design requirements and developed a novel gesture recognition algorithm that incorporates age-related factors such as reduced dexterity and flexibility. Our evaluation results show that our system achieves a 25% improvement in gesture recognition accuracy compared to existing systems, with high user satisfaction and engagement.

title: Efficient Query Rewriting for Optimizing Join Orders in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDBS) have become increasingly prevalent in modern data processing. However, optimizing join orders in DDBS remains a challenging task due to the complexities of data distribution and network communication. This paper proposes a novel query rewriting framework, 'QRewrite', which leverages machine learning-based join order optimization techniques to minimize query execution time. We introduce a cost-based model that incorporates both data locality and network latency factors, enabling QRewrite to generate efficient join orders that reduce query latency by up to 30% compared to existing state-of-the-art approaches. Experimental results on a real-world DDBS demonstrate the effectiveness and scalability of QRewrite.

title: Exploiting Query Reformulation for Improved Document Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents when users pose ambiguous or incomplete queries. We propose a novel approach that leverages query reformulation to improve document retrieval. Our method, 'QR-DR', uses a neural query rewriting model to generate a set of paraphrased queries from the original user query. We then combine the results from each paraphrased query using a novel ranking fusion technique. Experiments on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that QR-DR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, particularly for queries with low lexical overlap with relevant documents.

title: Efficient Document Filtering with Deep Neural Ranking Models for Real-time Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Real-time information retrieval (RTIR) systems face the challenge of efficiently filtering large document collections to retrieve relevant documents within strict time constraints. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'DNRM-FILTER', which leverages a hierarchical neural architecture to learn robust document representations and filter out irrelevant documents in a single pass. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DNRM-FILTER on three benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in filtering efficiency and retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art filtering methods.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Non-Stationary Targets
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification has seen significant advancements with the advent of meta-learning. However, most existing methods assume that the target classes are stationary across episodes. In real-world scenarios, this assumption is often violated, and the target classes may change over time. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'HMTL', which adapts to non-stationary target classes by learning a hierarchical representation of task embeddings. We introduce a task-aware attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant task embeddings to improve adaptation to new classes. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HMTL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot classification with non-stationary targets.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Learned Graph Representations
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to decentralized task allocation for multi-agent systems using learned graph representations. We propose a graph neural network-based framework that learns to represent the problem domain as a graph, and then uses this representation to allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. Our approach is evaluated on a range of scenarios, including search and rescue, and surveillance, and is shown to outperform traditional methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environment conditions. The proposed framework has the potential to be applied in a wide range of domains, including robotics, smart cities, and IoT.

title: Scalable Join Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for business intelligence and analytics. However, join optimization remains a major bottleneck in achieving low-latency query performance. This paper presents a novel join optimization technique, 'JoinFlex', which leverages a combination of machine learning-based cost estimation and dynamic reordering of join operations. We demonstrate that JoinFlex can reduce query response times by up to 60% compared to state-of-the-art optimization methods, while maintaining high accuracy and robustness. Experimental evaluation is performed on a large-scale dataset from a real-world e-commerce platform.

title: Elderly-Friendly Gestural Interfaces for Smart Home Automation
paper_abstract: Smart home automation systems often rely on complex interfaces, which can be challenging for elderly individuals. This paper presents a novel gestural interface, 'EasyHome', designed specifically for elderly users. EasyHome utilizes a combination of computer vision and machine learning to recognize and interpret elderly-friendly gestures, such as waving, pointing, and grasping. We conducted a user study with 20 elderly participants and found that EasyHome significantly reduced error rates and improved overall user experience compared to traditional touchscreen interfaces. Our approach has the potential to promote independent living and improve quality of life for elderly individuals.

title: Designing Intelligible Gestural Interfaces for Augmented Reality-Based Museum Exhibitions
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) museum exhibitions have the potential to enhance visitor engagement, but the design of gestural interfaces can significantly impact user experience. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating intelligible gestural interfaces for AR museum exhibitions. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving user observations, interviews, and experiments to develop a set of design guidelines for AR gestures. Our evaluation of a prototype AR exhibit showed that participants using our designed gestures reported higher levels of satisfaction and understanding compared to a baseline condition. We discuss implications for future AR museum exhibitions and highlight the importance of considering user cognition and behavior in gestural interface design.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but designing effective user interfaces remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user engagement in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, comparing three avatar customization levels: minimal, moderate, and extensive. Our results show that moderate customization leads to significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion time, and perceived immersion. We also identify key factors influencing avatar design, including facial similarity, body type, and clothing style. Our findings have important implications for the development of more engaging and effective VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series Using Graph-Based Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. However, existing methods often struggle with high-dimensional data and limited labeled anomalies. This paper proposes a novel graph-based contrastive learning approach, 'GraphCon', which learns to identify anomalies by contrasting the behavior of normal and abnormal samples in a graph-structured representation. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphCon on several real-world datasets, achieving significant improvements in detection accuracy and speed over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: We propose a novel approach for distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). Our method, called GraphTask, leverages the structural properties of the agent communication graph to learn effective task assignments. By incorporating node and edge features, GraphTask can capture complex dependencies between agents and tasks, outperforming traditional methods based on greedy allocation and coalition formation. We evaluate our approach on a variety of scenarios, including robotic search and rescue, and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving complex goals. This paper introduces a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HTA', which enables autonomous task allocation among agents. HTA consists of a high-level task allocator that assigns tasks to agents based on their capabilities and a low-level controller that executes tasks using reinforcement learning policies. We propose a novel curriculum-based learning approach that adaptively adjusts the task difficulty and reward functions to facilitate efficient learning. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HTA outperforms traditional manual allocation methods and achieves near-optimal task completion rates.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to learn control policies from interactions with their environment. However, existing methods often neglect uncertainty in the policy, leading to overconfidence and suboptimal decisions. We propose a novel uncertainty-aware RL framework, 'UARL', that incorporates Bayesian neural networks to model epistemic uncertainty in the policy. We demonstrate that UARL improves safety and robustness in simulated autonomous driving scenarios, particularly in situations with incomplete or noisy sensor data. Our results show that UARL outperforms state-of-the-art RL methods in terms of crash avoidance and smoothness of control.

title: Designing Voice-Based Interfaces for Enhanced Accessibility in Smart Homes
paper_abstract: Smart home devices have transformed the way we live, but individuals with disabilities often face significant barriers in interacting with these systems. This paper presents a novel voice-based interface, 'VocalEase', designed to improve accessibility in smart home environments. We conducted a series of user studies to inform the design of VocalEase, which incorporates personalized speech recognition, natural language understanding, and multimodal feedback. Our evaluation shows that VocalEase significantly reduces error rates and enhances user satisfaction for individuals with mobility and visual impairments. We also discuss the implications of our findings for the development of inclusive smart home systems.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, but existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and limited performance gains. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural query expansion approach, which leverages the strengths of both traditional term-based expansion and deep learning-based semantic matching. Our method uses a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant terms and concepts from the query context, leading to significant improvements in document retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in retrieving relevant documents, especially for complex, multi-faceted queries.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in enhancing learning experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of personalized avatars on user motivation and interaction in VR-based learning environments. We designed and developed an adaptive avatar system that incorporates user preferences and learning style to create personalized virtual representations. Our user study with 120 participants indicates that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, self-efficacy, and knowledge retention compared to generic avatars. The results have implications for the design of VR-based learning systems and highlight the potential of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience.

title: Scalable Multi-Version Concurrency Control for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: As distributed database systems (DDS) become increasingly prevalent, ensuring consistency and concurrency control across multiple nodes remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) protocol, 'DynaVer', designed to scale with the growing demands of modern DDS. DynaVer leverages a hybrid approach, combining optimistic and pessimistic concurrency control techniques to minimize aborts and reduce latency. Our evaluation on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrates that DynaVer outperforms existing MVCC protocols, achieving up to 30% improvement in transaction throughput and 25% reduction in latency.

title: Adaptive Batch Normalization for Efficient Deep Learning on Resource-Constrained Devices
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have become increasingly computationally expensive, making them challenging to deploy on resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes an adaptive batch normalization (AdaBN) technique that dynamically adjusts the batch normalization statistics based on the input data distribution. By doing so, AdaBN reduces the computational overhead of batch normalization, leading to significant speedups on devices with limited resources. We evaluate AdaBN on various deep learning architectures and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving inference speed while maintaining model accuracy.

title: Deep Neural Ranking Models for Personalized Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models for document retrieval rely on sparse, hand-crafted features that fail to capture user preferences and contextual nuances. We propose a neural ranking framework, 'DeepRank', which leverages deep learning to learn dense, personalized representations of documents and users. Our approach integrates a multi-task learning objective that jointly optimizes relevance, novelty, and diversity metrics. Experimental results on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that DeepRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Clustering
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems are increasingly popular for large-scale data processing. However, query efficiency remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach, 'HierDir', to optimize query processing in DIR systems. HierDir leverages a combination of k-means and hierarchical agglomerative clustering to group similar documents and reduce the search space. Our experiments on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HierDir achieves up to 35% improvement in query response time compared to state-of-the-art methods, while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Task Decomposition and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex tasks is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper presents a novel approach that combines hierarchical task decomposition with reinforcement learning to enable efficient and effective coordination. Our method, called HTR-RL, decomposes tasks into sub-tasks and allocates them to agents based on their capabilities. The agents learn to coordinate through reinforcement learning, receiving rewards for successful task completion. We evaluate HTR-RL in a simulated robotic soccer domain and demonstrate improved performance compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely heavily on natural and intuitive user interfaces. Gesture recognition is a crucial component, but existing systems often struggle with variability in user gestures, leading to reduced accuracy and user frustration. This paper presents a novel adaptive gesture recognition framework, 'AdaptGest', which leverages machine learning and human-computer interaction principles to personalize gesture recognition models to individual users. We conduct a user study to evaluate AdaptGest's performance and demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Scalable Data Partitioning for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: As relational databases continue to grow in size and complexity, distributing data across multiple nodes becomes a crucial scalability strategy. This paper presents a novel data partitioning algorithm, 'Hydra', which leverages a combination of vertical and horizontal partitioning to minimize cross-node communication and optimize query performance. Hydra incorporates a cost-based optimization framework that adaptively adjusts partitioning schemes based on workload characteristics and node availability. Experimental results on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate that Hydra achieves up to 3x improvement in query throughput compared to existing partitioning strategies.

title: Optimizing Subquery Processing in Distributed Relational Databases with Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly important for handling large-scale data processing. However, optimizing subquery processing in such systems remains a challenging problem. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize subquery execution plans. Our method, called 'RL-SubQ', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal execution order of subqueries based on the system's current workload and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RL-SubQ outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques, reducing query execution time by up to 35% and improving system throughput by 20%.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding via Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has emerged as a crucial technique for AI applications. However, existing KGE methods struggle to capture complex relationships and hierarchical structures in large-scale graphs. We propose a novel approach, Hierarchical Attention-based Knowledge Embedding (HAKE), which leverages attention mechanisms to learn representations that preserve both local and global structural information. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAKE achieves state-of-the-art performance in link prediction and entity classification tasks, outperforming popular KGE methods such as TransE and DistMult.

title: Designing Inclusive Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, it is essential to design interfaces that are accessible and usable by older adults. This paper presents a participatory study on gesture-based interaction, where we collaborated with 20 older adults to co-design and evaluate a gesture-based system for smart home devices. Our results show that older adults preferred simple, intuitive gestures and valued feedback mechanisms that confirmed their actions. We also identified design recommendations for gesture-based interfaces that cater to the needs and abilities of older adults, including the use of larger targets, slower gesture recognition, and multimodal feedback.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Analytics in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented NoSQL databases have become increasingly popular for big data analytics due to their high storage efficiency and fast query performance. However, indexing mechanisms in these systems are often optimized for batch processing, leading to poor performance in real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'ColIndex', which leverages the column-store layout to create a hierarchical, compressed index that supports efficient range queries and aggregations. Our experiments on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that ColIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 5x in query latency and 3x in storage efficiency.

title: Efficient Online Learning for Imbalanced Data Streams via Adaptive Ensemble Methods
paper_abstract: Imbalanced data streams, where the majority class dominates the minority class, pose significant challenges to online learning algorithms. We propose an adaptive ensemble method, 'AdaStream', which dynamically adjusts the contribution of each base learner based on their performance on the current data chunk. Our approach leverages a novel metric, 'stream-wise F1-score', to monitor the classification performance and adapt the ensemble weights. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaStream outperforms state-of-the-art online learning algorithms in terms of F1-score, G-mean, and AUC, while maintaining a low computational overhead.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for real-time traffic signal control. Our approach, dubbed 'TrafficSync', leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic dynamics and learn cooperative policies for multiple intersections. By incorporating a novel attention mechanism, TrafficSync efficiently handles high-dimensional state and action spaces, achieving better performance and scalability compared to existing MARL methods. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that TrafficSync reduces average travel time by up to 23% and decreases congestion by 17% compared to traditional traffic signal control strategies.

title: Exploring Embodiment and Social Presence in Virtual Reality Mediated Collaboration
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize remote collaboration by providing an immersive and interactive environment. However, the impact of VR on social presence and embodiment in collaborative tasks is not well understood. In this study, we investigate the effects of VR-mediated collaboration on user experience, communication patterns, and task performance. Our results show that VR significantly enhances social presence and embodiment compared to traditional video conferencing, leading to improved collaboration outcomes. We also identify key design factors that influence user experience and provide guidelines for VR-mediated collaboration systems.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a novel decentralized framework for task allocation in heterogeneous agent teams, leveraging graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model agent interactions and task dependencies. Our approach, called HetMAT, uses a hierarchical GCN architecture to learn a comprehensive representation of the agent-task graph, enabling agents to make informed decisions about task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HetMAT outperforms traditional distributed constraint optimization methods, achieving higher task completion rates and improved robustness to agent failures.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between the user's query and relevant documents. This paper presents a neural approach to query expansion, leveraging semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. We propose a novel architecture, 'NeuroXpand', which jointly learns to predict expansion terms and their weights based on the query context. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that NeuroXpand outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and robustness.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in Domain-Specific Search
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines require effective query expansion techniques to retrieve relevant results. This paper proposes a context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which incorporates domain knowledge and user preferences into the expansion process. CAQE utilizes a multi-layered neural network to learn context embeddings from query logs and domain-specific ontologies. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and response time, making it a promising solution for efficient information retrieval in domain-specific search.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and limited exploration capabilities. This paper proposes a novel graph-based reinforcement learning framework, 'GraphNAS', which utilizes graph neural networks to represent the search space and reinforcement learning to guide the search process. We demonstrate that GraphNAS achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing search time by up to 3x compared to existing methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for older adults with cognitive impairments remains a significant concern. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'EASE', a novel voice-based interface tailored to the needs of this population. We employ a participatory design approach, involving older adults with cognitive impairments in the design process. Our interface incorporates cognitive support features, such as semantic cueing and error correction, to facilitate user interaction. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Scalable Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in real-world autonomous systems, where decision-making processes must be transparent and trustworthy. This paper presents 'XRL', a scalable framework for explainable reinforcement learning that combines model-agnostic explanations with attention-based feature importance. We demonstrate XRL on a challenging autonomous driving scenario, showing that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance while providing real-time explanations for critical decisions. Our framework is highly modular, enabling seamless integration with various reinforcement learning algorithms and autonomous system architectures.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Sparse Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus to answer a given question. While dense neural retrievers have shown promising results, they can be computationally expensive and memory-intensive. This paper proposes a novel sparse representation approach, termed 'SparsePass', which leverages sparse linear algebra to efficiently index and retrieve passages. We demonstrate that SparsePass achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art dense retrievers while reducing memory usage by 90% and inference time by 75%. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset show that SparsePass is particularly effective for longer passages and complex questions.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face barriers when interacting with computers, limiting their ability to fully engage with digital technologies. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive gestural interfaces that can accommodate diverse motor abilities. We propose a machine learning-based framework that leverages user behavior data to dynamically adjust gesture recognition models, enabling more accurate and efficient input. Our user study with 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional gestural interfaces. The findings have implications for promoting inclusivity in human-computer interaction design.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Graph Attention Networks with Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in a given context. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph attention networks and knowledge graph embeddings to disambiguate entities. Our model, called GraphED, represents entities as nodes in a graph and utilizes attention mechanisms to weigh the importance of neighboring entities. We also incorporate knowledge graph embeddings to capture semantic relationships between entities. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and F1-score.

title: Real-Time Entity Disambiguation for Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various applications, such as question answering and recommender systems. However, entity ambiguity hinders the performance of these embeddings. We propose a novel real-time entity disambiguation approach, 'RTED', which leverages graph attention mechanisms and semantic similarity measures to resolve ambiguities. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that RTED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of disambiguation accuracy and embedding quality, while maintaining a low computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Real-time Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data has numerous applications in human-computer interaction, healthcare, and affective computing. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for real-time multimodal emotion recognition. Our approach leverages modality-specific attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant input features, and a hierarchical fusion strategy to integrate information across modalities. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from audio, video, and physiological signals, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% in real-time settings.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel approach using hierarchical graph attention networks (HGANs) to learn effective coordination strategies. Our method represents the agent interaction graph as a hierarchical structure, allowing the model to capture both local and global dependencies between agents. We evaluate our approach on several benchmarks, including traffic management and robotic soccer, and show significant improvements in coordination performance compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, dubbed 'AgentDRL', leverages a decentralized, communication-avoiding architecture to enable agents to learn optimal task assignments in complex, dynamic environments. We demonstrate the effectiveness of AgentDRL through extensive simulations on a variety of task allocation problems, showcasing improved solution quality and scalability compared to traditional, centralized optimization techniques.

title: Interpretable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles become increasingly prevalent, their ability to cooperate and make joint decisions is crucial for safe and efficient operation. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MAVERIC', which enables interpretable decision-making in cooperative autonomous vehicle systems. MAVERIC incorporates a attention-based neural network architecture that learns to identify relevant contextual information and communicate effectively between agents. Experimental results on a simulated highway scenario demonstrate that MAVERIC achieves improved cooperative behavior and reduced collision rates compared to existing decentralized RL approaches.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning with Adaptive Prototype Graphs for Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing approaches rely on manually crafted prototypes or meta-learning techniques that require extensive computational resources. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical few-shot learning framework, 'AdaProto', which leverages adaptive prototype graphs to effectively capture the underlying structure of the data. By dynamically adjusting the graph topology and prototype distances during training, AdaProto achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark image classification datasets, including mini-ImageNet and CIFAR-FS, with minimal computational overhead. We also provide a thorough analysis of the robustness and interpretability of our approach.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Retrieval of Short Texts
paper_abstract: Short text retrieval remains a challenging task due to the scarcity of relevant keywords. Query expansion techniques have been widely used to address this issue, but they often rely on manual feature engineering and suffer from high computational costs. In this paper, we propose a novel deep neural network-based approach for query expansion, dubbed 'DeepQE'. DeepQE leverages the capabilities of transformer-based architectures to learn contextualized representations of query terms and documents. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets show that DeepQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for cooperative multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and preferences need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. We design an auction-based mechanism that enables agents to bid for tasks based on their expected utilities, and a sealed-bid Vickrey auction protocol is employed to determine the assignment of tasks to agents. Our approach ensures that agents are incentivized to report their true preferences, leading to efficient task allocation. We evaluate our method through simulations, demonstrating improved system performance and fairness compared to existing decentralized allocation methods.

title: Scalable Indexing for Multi-Attribute Range Queries in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale data. However, efficient indexing techniques for multi-attribute range queries remain a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, called 'Dexi', which leverages a combination of hierarchical clustering and spatial decomposition to facilitate fast query processing. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that Dexi outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time, while maintaining a reasonable indexing overhead.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking for Diverse Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for document retrieval often sacrifice diversity for relevance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DiversiRank', which incorporates a diversity-promoting regularizer into the ranking loss function. We reformulate the ranking problem as a heterogeneous graph learning task, allowing our model to capture both document relevance and semantic similarity. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that DiversiRank outperforms existing methods in terms of both relevance and diversity metrics, while maintaining efficient query response times.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using auctions
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a decentralized auction-based mechanism for task allocation, where agents bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We introduce a novel bidding strategy that incorporates task dependencies and agent heterogeneity, ensuring efficient allocation while minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced latency compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to balance retrieval efficiency with query understanding. We propose a neural query expansion approach, 'NeuQE', which learns to generate context-aware query refinements from a few relevant documents. NeuQE combines a BERT-based query encoder with a graph attention network to capture document relationships and generate cohesive expansions. Our experiments on the TREC-8 and Robust04 benchmarks demonstrate that NeuQE improves retrieval effectiveness by up to 15% while reducing query latency by 30% compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Decomposition and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, especially when tasks are complex and interdependent. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task decomposition framework, 'HTD-RL', which integrates reinforcement learning to optimize task allocation and execution. HTD-RL represents tasks as a hierarchical graph and uses a distributed Q-network to learn optimal task assignments. We evaluate HTD-RL on a simulated warehouse management scenario, demonstrating improved coordination efficiency and reduced task completion time compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation in distributed systems is a challenging problem, particularly in scenarios with complex dependencies and constraints. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph neural networks to learn optimal task allocation policies. We introduce a new graph-based state representation that captures task dependencies and agent capabilities, and demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods in simulated environments. Experimental results on a real-world logistics dataset show that our framework can improve task allocation efficiency by up to 25% compared to baseline methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks forSkeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained popularity due to its applications in human-computer interaction and healthcare. However, existing methods struggle to capture complex spatial-temporal relationships between body joints. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages multi-scale graph attention to model joint interactions at various semantic levels. Our experiments on the NTU-RGB+D and Kinetics datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing actions from skeleton data, especially in scenarios with partial occlusions or noisy data.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. We propose a novel algorithm, 'DAMA', which enables agents to learn from local observations and adapt to changing task requirements. DAMA uses a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to coordinate agent actions and minimize task allocation conflicts. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that DAMA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system responsiveness.

title: Decentralized Task Assignment for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Decentralized task assignment is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn decentralized task assignment policies. We model the agent interactions as a graph and leverage GNNs to learn a distributed task assignment algorithm that adapts to changing task requirements and agent capabilities. Our approach outperforms traditional decentralized task assignment algorithms in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through extensive simulations on various multi-agent systems.

title: Hybrid Attention-Based Neural Networks for Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is crucial for various applications, but most existing methods lack interpretability. This paper introduces a novel hybrid attention-based neural network, 'HATS', which leverages both temporal and spatial attention mechanisms to identify anomalies. HATS incorporates a feature importance module to provide explanations for its predictions. We evaluate HATS on several real-world datasets, demonstrating its superior performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach has significant implications for real-time monitoring and decision-making in domains such as finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity.

title: Deep Anomaly Detection in Graph-Structured Data using Hierarchical Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in graph-structured data is a crucial task in various domains, including social networks, bioinformatics, and cybersecurity. Existing methods often rely on shallow graph representations, neglecting the complex hierarchies present in real-world graphs. This paper introduces 'HierCon', a novel deep learning framework that leverages hierarchical contrastive learning to identify anomalies in graph-structured data. By recursively applying contrastive learning at multiple scales, HierCon captures rich contextual information and detects anomalies more effectively than state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HierCon in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to graph perturbations.

title: Hierarchical Task Networks for Explainable Planning in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable planning is crucial for trustworthy autonomous systems, yet existing methods often lack transparency and flexibility. This paper introduces Hierarchical Task Networks (HTN-XP), a novel planning framework that integrates symbolic task planning with neural network-based plan recognition. HTN-XP represents plans as hierarchical graphs, enabling explicit modeling of task dependencies and abstraction levels. We demonstrate that HTN-XP outperforms state-of-the-art planning methods in explainability, scalability, and plan quality on a range of autonomous driving scenarios. Our approach has significant implications for real-world autonomous systems, where transparency and accountability are essential.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of big data and cloud computing has led to the widespread adoption of distributed database systems. However, the complexity of query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'DistOpt', which leverages a combination of machine learning and database-specific heuristics to optimize query plans. We introduce a probabilistic cost model that accurately estimates the execution time of query plans and a reinforcement learning-based optimizer that adaptively adjusts the query plan based on runtime feedback. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that DistOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph Convolutional Networks
