paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises significant concerns. This paper proposes a novel adversarial attack detection framework for DRL systems, leveraging graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model the complex relationships between states, actions, and rewards. Our approach, dubbed 'GCAD', can accurately detect both query-based and poisoning-based attacks, outperforming existing detection methods. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GCAD on several DRL benchmarks, including Atari games and robotic control tasks.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal dialogue systems have gained popularity in various applications, including virtual assistants and human-robot interaction. However, effectively integrating and processing multimodal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant input modalities and contextual elements during dialogue processing. Our experiments on the Multimodal Dialogue Dataset (MMD) demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in dialogue act recognition, intent detection, and response generation tasks, while providing interpretable attention patterns.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental problem in graph-structured data, where the goal is to predict the label of a node based on its features and graph structure. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant neighbors at multiple graph scales. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on node classification tasks. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the learned attention patterns, revealing insights into the underlying graph structure and node relationships.

title: Autonomous Agent Coordination for Real-Time Resource Allocation in Smart Cities
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous agent coordination for real-time resource allocation in smart cities. We introduce a decentralized multi-agent system that utilizes artificial potential fields to coordinate agents' actions and optimize resource allocation in dynamic environments. Our approach is evaluated through simulations of a smart traffic management system, demonstrating improved response times and reduced congestion compared to traditional centralized approaches. The proposed framework has significant implications for the efficient management of urban resources and services.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents for Efficient Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed systems, autonomous agents can optimize resource allocation by adapting to dynamic environmental conditions. However, coordination among agents remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a decentralized coordination framework, 'DynaCoord', which leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize resource allocation in real-time. DynaCoord integrates a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group agents based on their resource requirements, enabling efficient communication and decision-making. Simulation results on a realistic cloud computing scenario demonstrate that DynaCoord outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods, achieving up to 35% improvement in system throughput and 25% reduction in resource waste.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems require effective cooperation to achieve complex tasks. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables agents to learn cooperative strategies from raw observation data. HAN integrates intra-agent attention to focus on relevant observations and inter-agent attention to model relationships between agents. We evaluate HAN on a suite of cooperative navigation tasks and demonstrate improved team performance compared to existing multi-agent reinforcement learning methods. Our approach paves the way for more sophisticated AI systems that can seamlessly coordinate with human agents.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, but the lack of interpretability in existing models limits their adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages the structural relationships between time series to improve forecasting accuracy and interpretability. Our approach learns to extract relevant features from local and global graph structures, enabling the model to focus on the most informative temporal dependencies. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAN in capturing complex patterns and providing interpretable insights into the forecasting process.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize the way people interact with digital information, but existing VR interfaces often exclude users with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible VR interfaces that can be controlled using alternative input methods, such as gaze, speech, or electromyography (EMG) signals. We evaluate our approach through a user study with 20 participants with motor impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction time and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. Our findings provide insights into the design of inclusive VR experiences that can benefit a broader range of users.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on complex control systems to navigate diverse scenarios. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework that improves the efficiency and adaptability of autonomous vehicle control. Our approach consists of a high-level policy that selects primitive actions and a low-level controller that executes these actions. We introduce a multi-agent formulation that enables the HRL framework to learn from both expert demonstrations and online experiences, resulting in faster learning and improved robustness. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving platform demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing energy consumption and improving overall vehicle performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-hop Reasoning in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models often struggle to provide interpretable explanations for their predictions, particularly when requiring multi-hop reasoning. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages visual and linguistic cues to generate attention weights at multiple levels of abstraction. Our approach enables the model to focus on relevant regions of the image and corresponding question words, leading to improved performance on VQA tasks that demand complex reasoning. Experimental results on the CLEVR and GQA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in generating accurate and explainable answers.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become essential for businesses to make timely decisions. However, optimizing queries for low latency remains a significant challenge, especially when dealing with large datasets. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ColumnOpt', that leverages column stores to accelerate query processing. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that takes into account the storage layout, data distribution, and query patterns to select the most efficient execution plan. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColumnOpt achieves an average speedup of 3.5x compared to traditional row-store-based query optimization techniques.

title: Investigating the Impact of Emotional Feedback on User Engagement in Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent in various applications, but understanding user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the role of emotional feedback in enhancing user engagement in conversational interfaces. We designed an intelligent chatbot that incorporates emotional feedback mechanisms, such as affective responses and empathetic statements, to investigate their impact on user experience. Our user study involving 100 participants reveals that emotional feedback significantly increases user engagement, with participants reporting higher satisfaction and perceived social presence. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more effective conversational interfaces.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults using Machine Learning-based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: This paper presents a study on designing inclusive gestural interfaces for older adults, leveraging machine learning-based gesture recognition. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults to identify common gesture patterns and challenges. We developed a custom gesture recognition system using a convolutional neural network (CNN) and evaluated its performance on a dataset of gestures from older adults. Our results show that the system achieves an accuracy of 92.5% and significantly outperforms existing gesture recognition systems. We provide design recommendations for creating accessible and usable gestural interfaces for older adults, highlighting the importance of personalized gesture recognition and feedback mechanisms.

title: Scalable Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that affects overall system performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to task allocation using graph neural networks (GNNs) that can efficiently handle heterogeneous agent capabilities and dynamic task requirements. Our method, dubbed 'GNN-TA', represents the agent-task interaction as a graph and leverages GNNs to learn a task allocation policy that minimizes system latency and maximizes task completion rates. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that GNN-TA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of scalability, adaptability, and robustness.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of cooperative task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and resources must work together to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a graph-based reinforcement learning approach, 'Graph-MARL', which learns to allocate tasks by modeling the agents' interactions as a graph. Graph-MARL uses a decentralized policy gradient method to optimize the task allocation policy, taking into account the agents' individual preferences and the global system constraints. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that Graph-MARL outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a pervasive problem that can be alleviated by optimizing traffic signal control. This paper proposes a decentralized, multi-agent system that leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate traffic signals in real-time. Our approach, dubbed 'TrafficMAgent', uses graph neural networks to model traffic flow dynamics and learn cooperative policies for adaptive traffic signal control. We evaluate TrafficMAgent in a realistic simulation environment and demonstrate significant reductions in travel time and congestion compared to traditional, rule-based control strategies.

title: Investigating the Effect of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This study examines the role of embodiment in fostering social presence in virtual reality (VR) environments. We conducted a user study with 48 participants, randomly assigning them to either a embodied or non-embodied condition. Our results show that users in the embodied condition reported higher levels of social presence, cooperative behavior, and emotional arousal when interacting with a virtual agent. We also found that the sense of embodiment was mediated by the user's perceived agency and self-representation in the virtual environment. The findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to facilitate social interaction and collaboration.

title: Optimizing Query Processing in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As data continues to grow, distributed database systems face significant challenges in optimizing query processing. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query planning and execution in distributed databases. Our proposed framework, 'RL-QueryOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan based on the database workload and system dynamics. We demonstrate that RL-QueryOpt outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 50% in reducing query latency and improving system throughput. Experiment results on a real-world distributed database benchmark show the effectiveness of our approach in various query workloads.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodied Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but the impact of embodied avatars on user experience remains poorly understood. This study investigates how the design of embodied avatars influences user presence, agency, and overall experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a mixed-methods approach combining quantitative surveys, qualitative interviews, and behavioral data. Our results show that users who interacted with more humanoid avatars reported higher levels of presence and agency, while those with more abstract avatars reported increased feelings of frustration. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of embodied avatars in VR applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to improve the retrieval performance by augmenting the original query with relevant terms. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, leveraging semantic embeddings to capture the contextual relationships between words. Our method, called DeepQE, employs a graph neural network to learn a dense representation of the query and its expansion terms, outperforming traditional methods based on term frequency and co-occurrence analysis. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepQE in enhancing the retrieval precision and recall.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Diverse Documents using Aspect-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion techniques are widely used in information retrieval to improve the effectiveness of keyword-based search systems. However, existing methods often suffer from the problem of retrieving redundant or similar documents, which can lead to a poor user experience. This paper proposes a novel aspect-based query expansion approach that incorporates semantic role labeling and entity recognition to identify diverse aspects of the query. Our experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method can significantly improve the retrieval of diverse documents, leading to a more comprehensive search result.

title: Approximation Algorithms for Query Optimization in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become ubiquitous in modern data management, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using approximation algorithms, which leverage the structure of the underlying data distribution to reduce the search space. We propose two new algorithms, 'DistOpt' and 'ApproxJoin', which achieve near-optimal query plans with provable bounds on approximation error. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of execution time and plan quality.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Semantic Search using Hierarchical Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on handcrafted features and heuristics, often failing to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. We propose a neural query expansion approach that leverages hierarchical graph attention to model the contextual dependencies between query terms and their relevance to the target document. Our model, HierGATE, learns to recursively refine the query representation by aggregating attention weights across multiple graph layers. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness to query ambiguity.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, but the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of haptic feedback on user performance, satisfaction, and presence in VR interfaces. We conducted a user study with 40 participants, comparing three conditions: no haptic feedback, vibrotactile feedback, and electroencephalography (EEG)-based feedback. Results show that haptic feedback significantly improves task completion time and user satisfaction, while EEG-based feedback enhances sense of presence. Our findings provide insights for the design of effective haptic feedback mechanisms in VR interfaces.

title: Rethinking Indexing for High-Dimensional Data: A Novel Approach to Efficient Query Processing
paper_abstract: The proliferation of high-dimensional data has exposed the limitations of traditional indexing techniques, leading to inefficient query processing. This paper proposes a novel indexing method, 'HiDex', which leverages the inherent structural properties of high-dimensional data to enable fast and accurate query execution. HiDex combines a hierarchical clustering-based indexing scheme with a probabilistic query optimization framework, resulting in significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art indexing methods. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HiDex in supporting a wide range of queries, including range, k-NN, and similarity searches.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed resource allocation in complex systems. We introduce a hierarchical agent architecture that combines local and global decision-making, enabling efficient allocation of resources in large-scale networks. Our approach leverages a decentralized actor-critic algorithm with experience sharing and asynchronous updates, allowing agents to adapt to changing system conditions. Experimental results on a simulated grid network demonstrate significant improvements in resource utilization and system performance compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Scalable Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Hash Tables
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is a fundamental problem in various domains, including computer vision, recommender systems, and scientific computing. Existing indexing methods often suffer from poor scalability, high memory overhead, or inadequate query performance. This paper presents HiHT, a novel hierarchical hash table indexing scheme that tackles these challenges. HiHT leverages a hierarchical structure to efficiently prune the search space and reduces memory requirements through compact hash representations. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HiHT outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of query performance, memory efficiency, and scalability for high-dimensional data.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance older adults' quality of life, but existing systems often struggle to accommodate users with motor impairments. This paper presents a participatory design approach to develop an inclusive gesture recognition system tailored to the needs of older adults with motor impairments. We conducted co-design workshops with 15 older adults and 5 caregivers to identify key design requirements. Our proposed system, 'EasyGesture', utilizes machine learning algorithms to recognize gestures from skeletal data, and incorporates adaptive feedback mechanisms to assist users with varying motor abilities. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates that EasyGesture achieves higher gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has shown great promise in complex real-world applications, but the lack of transparency and explainability in these systems hinders their adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that enables explainable decision-making in MARL. Our approach, 'HierAttn', applies attention weights to agent interactions, allowing the identification of influential agents and their contributions to the collective reward. We evaluate HierAttn on a range of benchmark environments, demonstrating improved explainability and interpretability without compromising task performance.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly accessible, there is a growing need to ensure that VR experiences are inclusive and accessible to diverse user populations. This paper explores the design of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) that can facilitate social interaction and support users with disabilities in VR environments. We present a user-centered design approach that incorporates co-design workshops with users with disabilities, and evaluate the effectiveness of our ECA design in enhancing user experience and social presence in VR. Our findings highlight the importance of considering accessibility and inclusivity in ECA design for VR, and provide insights for the development of more inclusive VR experiences.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Auction-based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using auction-based mechanisms. We propose a novel auction protocol that enables agents to bid for tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. Our approach ensures efficient task allocation while minimizing communication overhead and promoting fairness among agents. We evaluate our framework through simulations and demonstrate its effectiveness in scenarios involving heterogeneous agents and varying task complexities.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used in large-scale applications, but optimizing query execution plans remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed settings. Our method, called 'DROPS', uses a graph neural network to model the query plan space and a deep Q-network to learn an optimization policy. We evaluate DROPS on the TPC-DS benchmark and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 3.2x over the baseline.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Intelligent traffic signal control is crucial for mitigating urban congestion. This paper presents a novel multi-agent system, 'TRAFFICSYNC', which coordinates heterogeneous agents to optimize real-time traffic signal control. Our approach integrates machine learning-based traffic prediction with decentralized decision-making, enabling agents to adapt to dynamic traffic conditions. We evaluate TRAFFICSYNC in a simulation environment and demonstrate significant reductions in travel time and congestion compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Online Reviews
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis in online reviews is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the diversity of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that effectively integrates textual, visual, and acoustic features to predict sentiment. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and aspects of the input data, leading to improved performance and interpretability. Experiments on a large-scale multimodal review dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods and provides valuable insights into the role of each modality in sentiment analysis.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly popular for handling massive datasets, but optimizing query performance in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, 'QueryOptRL', leverages a DRL agent to learn an optimal query plan policy from a large dataset of query-execution experiences. We evaluate QueryOptRL on a real-world DDS benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults using Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults, but existing interfaces are often inaccessible due to cognitive and physical decline. This paper presents a novel VR interface design that leverages gesture recognition to facilitate interaction. We conducted a user study with 20 older adults (ages 65-85) to evaluate the effectiveness of our approach. Results show significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. We also present a set of design guidelines for accessible VR interfaces that can be applied to various applications.

title: Exploring Embodied Interaction Design for Virtual Reality-based Stroke Rehabilitation
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in stroke rehabilitation, but current systems often rely on simplistic interfaces that neglect the embodied aspects of human experience. This paper presents an embodied interaction design framework for VR-based stroke rehabilitation, focusing on the role of gesture, movement, and haptic feedback in enhancing motor learning and user engagement. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in motor function and cognitive load reduction compared to traditional desktop-based systems. Our findings inform the design of more effective, human-centered VR rehabilitation systems that leverage the unique affordances of embodied interaction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (IR) models have demonstrated superior performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks. However, they often struggle with lexical gaps between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuQE', which leverages the semantic representation capabilities of neural models to generate context-aware expansion terms. We introduce a reinforcement learning-based framework that optimizes the query expansion process by maximizing the expected retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that NeuQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods and improves the overall retrieval effectiveness of neural IR models.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in node classification tasks, but their performance degrades significantly in few-shot settings. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, 'HAT-GNN', which leverages both node and graph-level attention mechanisms to adaptively select the most informative nodes and subgraphs for few-shot learning. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAT-GNN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in few-shot node classification tasks while requiring minimal labeled data.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses a significant threat. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in DRL using graph attention networks (GATs). Our method, called 'GAT-Defender', leverages the graph structure of the state-action space to identify anomalies in the policy's decision-making process. We evaluate GAT-Defender on several DRL benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting a wide range of attack types, including poisoning, evasion, and trojan attacks. Our results show that GAT-Defender outperforms existing detection methods, achieving an average detection accuracy of 92.5%.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks for Disaster Response
paper_abstract: Responding to natural disasters requires coordinated efforts from multiple agents, including first responders, emergency services, and volunteers. This paper presents a novel framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in disaster response scenarios using hierarchical task networks (HTNs). Our approach enables agents to reason about complex tasks, allocate resources, and adapt to changing environmental conditions. We evaluate our framework using a realistic disaster simulation, demonstrating improved response times and resource allocation compared to traditional decentralized approaches. The proposed framework has the potential to save lives and reduce damage in disaster scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Sparse Retrieval
paper_abstract: Sparse retrieval models have gained popularity in information retrieval due to their efficiency and effectiveness. However, they often struggle with vocabulary mismatch, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepExp', which leverages deep neural networks to generate context-aware expansion terms. Our method utilizes a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to capture semantic relationships between query terms and the document collection. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepExp significantly improves the retrieval performance of sparse models, outperforming traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Representation Learning for Multi-Modal Event Extraction
paper_abstract: Event extraction from unstructured data is a crucial task in various applications, including information retrieval and natural language processing. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical representation learning framework for multi-modal event extraction, leveraging both textual and visual features. We introduce a graph-based attention mechanism to capture contextual relationships between entities and events, and a hierarchical encoder to learn representations at different levels of abstraction. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of event detection and argument role identification accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, allocating tasks efficiently is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation framework, 'HTA-DRL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn effective task assignment policies. HTA-DRL consists of two hierarchical layers: a high-level layer that allocates tasks to agent groups, and a low-level layer that assigns tasks to individual agents within each group. We evaluate HTA-DRL on a variety of task allocation scenarios and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and resource utilization compared to existing approaches.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Modal Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing popularity of multi-modal data, such as images, videos, and sensors, has led to the development of specialized database systems. However, query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MultiOpt', that leverages the characteristics of multi-modal data to reduce query execution time. We propose a cost-based optimization approach that incorporates domain-specific knowledge and exploits the parallel processing capabilities of modern hardware. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that MultiOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 3x, making it an attractive solution for large-scale multi-modal database systems.

title: Deep Re-ranking with Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Diversified Search Results
paper_abstract: Current search engines often prioritize relevance over diversity, leading to homogeneous search results. This paper proposes a novel deep re-ranking approach, 'HierDiv', which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks to capture complex relationships between query, documents, and entities. HierDiv jointly optimizes relevance, diversity, and novelty metrics, resulting in more comprehensive and informative search results. Experimental evaluations on a large-scale web search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search result diversity and user satisfaction.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data storage systems, but optimizing query execution remains a challenging problem. In this paper, we propose a novel adaptive query optimization framework, 'AQO-R', that leverages reinforcement learning to dynamically adjust query execution plans based on runtime statistics. We employ a Deep Q-Network (DQN) to learn an optimized query plan policy, which is trained on a simulated environment and fine-tuned on real-world workloads. Experimental results demonstrate that AQO-R outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles operating in dynamic environments require efficient and adaptive control strategies to ensure safety and efficiency. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that integrates a high-level task planner with a low-level motion controller. Our approach leverages a deep neural network to learn a hierarchical policy that adaptively adjusts to changing environmental conditions, such as pedestrian movement or road closures. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through simulations and experiments on a real-world autonomous vehicle platform, showcasing improved performance and robustness compared to traditional reinforcement learning methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal cues is a challenging task, particularly when dealing with real-world datasets exhibiting diverse emotional expressions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that facilitates explainable emotion recognition by learning to focus on relevant modalities and temporal segments. Our approach integrates a hierarchical attention mechanism with a multimodal fusion module, enabling the model to selectively weigh and combine features from speech, text, and visual cues. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and SEMAINE datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of emotion recognition accuracy and provide insights into the decision-making process.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex systems is a challenging problem, requiring efficient communication, negotiation, and decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach, Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning (DGRL), which leverages graph neural networks to learn effective coordination policies in multi-agent systems. DGRL enables agents to reason about their interactions and adapt to changing environments, outperforming traditional methods in simulated traffic management and resource allocation scenarios. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the convergence and stability of DGRL, facilitating its deployment in real-world applications.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking Models for Multimedia Search
paper_abstract: Multimedia search engines face the challenge of retrieving relevant documents from large collections. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'MultiRank', which leverages multimodal fusion and self-attention mechanisms to capture semantic relationships between query and document features. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MultiRank on a large-scale dataset, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall over state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we show that our approach can be efficiently deployed on modern GPU architectures, making it suitable for real-time search applications.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases with Skew Handling
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used in modern data analytics, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach, 'SkewOpt', which tackles the problem of skew in distributed query optimization. We propose a probabilistic model to estimate the skew in data distribution and develop a cost-based optimization framework that adapts to the skew. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that SkewOpt improves query performance by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Deconfliction Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems with Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation and deconfliction are critical to ensure efficient and safe operation. This paper addresses the problem of dynamic task allocation in the presence of conflicting constraints. We propose a novel deconfliction strategy based on graph theory and model predictive control, which can adapt to changing task priorities and agent capabilities. Our approach is evaluated through simulations of a search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced conflicts compared to existing methods. Theoretical bounds on the complexity and scalability of our approach are also provided.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Attention-Based Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various AI applications. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel attention-based graph convolutional network (AGCN) architecture for efficient knowledge graph embeddings. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and filter out noisy information, reducing the computational overhead. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AGCN achieves state-of-the-art performance while requiring significantly fewer parameters and computations compared to existing methods.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Embeddings for Efficient Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a popular paradigm for open-domain question answering, but its computational requirements can be prohibitive for large-scale datasets. This paper introduces a novel query-adaptive document embedding (QA-DE) method that learns to dynamically adjust document representations based on the input query. Our approach leverages a lightweight query-document interaction module to compute context-aware document embeddings, reducing the need for exhaustive similarity computations. Experimental results on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that QA-DE achieves comparable retrieval accuracy to state-of-the-art DPR methods while reducing inference time by up to 3.5x.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems face significant challenges in optimizing query performance for diverse workloads. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We propose a Deep Q-Network (DQN) that learns to select optimal query plans based on runtime statistics and system constraints. Our experiments on a commercial multi-tenant database system demonstrate that the RL-based optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization, while adapting to changing workload conditions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis on multi-modal data, such as text, images, and videos, is a challenging task due to the complexity of integrating and modeling heterogeneous features. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that learns to jointly represent and align modalities. HGAT employs a hierarchical structure to capture both local and global dependencies, and incorporates attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multi-modal sentiment analysis, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and F1-score.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) are increasingly used in real-world applications, but their decision-making processes often lack transparency. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for explainable decision-making in MAS. HAN leverages attention mechanisms to capture complex dependencies between agents and their environment, enabling the generation of interpretable explanations for joint actions. Experimental results on a simulated traffic management scenario demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art MAS methods while providing meaningful insights into agent decision-making processes.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Emotional Support in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) for emotional support in virtual reality (VR) environments. We propose an ECA framework that integrates emotional intelligence, empathy, and social presence to provide users with a sense of comfort and trust. Our system utilizes machine learning-based sentiment analysis and natural language processing to respond to users' emotional cues, and a 3D avatar with expressive gestures and facial expressions to convey empathy. A user study demonstrates the efficacy of our ECA in reducing stress and anxiety levels in VR, highlighting its potential for mental health support and therapy.

title: EmoTouch: Affective Gesture Recognition for Virtual Reality Using Multimodal Fusion
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but current interfaces often neglect the emotional aspects of human communication. This paper presents EmoTouch, a novel affective gesture recognition system that leverages multimodal fusion of hand tracking, electromyography (EMG), and computer vision. Our approach enables accurate recognition of users' emotional states (e.g., excitement, frustration) in VR environments, enhancing the overall user experience. We evaluate EmoTouch on a dataset of 30 participants, achieving a recognition accuracy of 87.4% and demonstrating its potential for applications in gaming, education, and therapy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis is a challenging task that requires effectively fusing and interpreting information from diverse modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of both visual and textual features to improve sentiment prediction. The HAN model employs a novel multimodal attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions of interest in images and corresponding textual segments. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of sentiment accuracy and provides interpretable insights into the decision-making process.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Unknown Attacks in Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be crafted to mislead the model's predictions. Existing adversarial training methods primarily focus on defending against known attacks. However, it is essential to develop strategies that can generalize to unknown attacks. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'Adversarially Robust Unknown-Attack Training' (ARUAT), which leverages a meta-learning approach to adapt to new, unseen attacks. Our experiments on ImageNet demonstrate that ARUAT significantly improves the robustness of image classification models against a wide range of unknown attacks, outperforming state-of-the-art adversarial training methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Conversational Strategies for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational interfaces often exclude users with speech and language disabilities, such as dysarthria. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop inclusive conversational strategies for voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 20 participants with dysarthria, exploring their experiences and preferences when interacting with voice assistants. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptive response timing, explicit error handling, and personalized feedback. We propose a set of design guidelines and implement a prototype voice assistant, 'IncluVoice', which demonstrates improved usability and user satisfaction for users with dysarthria.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Passage Retrieval using Neural Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of open-domain question answering systems. However, the effectiveness of passage retrieval algorithms is often hindered by the vocabulary mismatch between the query and relevant passages. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages neural document embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between terms. NeuroQE uses a dense passage retrieval model to generate a set of relevant passages, and then applies a neural-based query expansion technique to expand the query. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that NeuroQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 12% improvement in terms of passage retrieval accuracy.

title: Robust Few-Shot Learning with Adaptive Margin Loss for Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning (FSL) has made significant progress in recent years, but its robustness to distribution shifts and noisy data remains a major concern. This paper introduces a novel approach to FSL, dubbed 'AdaptiveMargin', which leverages a self-adaptive margin loss function to improve model robustness. Our method dynamically adjusts the margin based on the support set's similarity to the query images, allowing the model to generalize better to unseen classes. We conduct extensive experiments on popular FSL benchmarks, demonstrating that AdaptiveMargin outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Vision Transformers via Knowledge Distillation
paper_abstract: Vision Transformers (ViTs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various computer vision tasks, but their robustness to adversarial attacks remains a concern. This paper proposes a novel knowledge distillation approach, 'ViT-KD', to improve the adversarial robustness of ViTs. By transferring knowledge from a robust teacher model to a student ViT, our method enhances the model's ability to recognize and resist adversarial perturbations. Experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that ViT-KD outperforms existing adversarial training methods, achieving higher accuracy and robustness under various attack scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Data Cubes using GPU-Accelerated Aggregation
paper_abstract: Multidimensional data cubes are crucial for fast query processing in data warehouses. However, optimizing queries on these cubes is computationally expensive, especially for large datasets. This paper presents a novel approach, 'CubeGPU', which leverages Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) to accelerate aggregation operations in query optimization. By exploiting the massively parallel architecture of modern GPUs, CubeGPU achieves significant speedups over traditional CPU-based optimization techniques. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach using a real-world dataset and various query workloads, showcasing up to 10x performance improvement.

title: Hierarchical Attention Neural Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis involves identifying sentiment from multiple sources such as text, images, and audio. Existing approaches often rely on early fusion or late fusion, which can lead to information loss or misaligned feature representations. We propose a novel hierarchical attention neural network (HATNet) that leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSI and Multimodal Sentiment Analysis datasets demonstrate that HATNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness, particularly in scenarios with noisy or missing modalities.

title: Optimizing Query Workload Performance using Learned Index Structures in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have revolutionized query performance, but optimizing query workloads remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the application of learned index structures to improve query performance in main-memory databases. We propose a novel learned index framework, 'QuickIndex', which leverages machine learning models to predict and adapt to query patterns. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that QuickIndex achieves up to 3x performance improvement compared to traditional indexing techniques, while reducing index construction time by up to 50%. We also analyze the trade-offs between query performance, index maintenance, and model accuracy.

title: Efficient Incremental View Maintenance for Dynamic Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Data warehousing is a crucial component of business intelligence, but maintaining materialized views in the face of continuous data updates remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel incremental view maintenance (IVM) approach, 'DynIVM', that leverages a hybrid of incremental query processing and dynamic indexing. DynIVM efficiently handles insertions, deletions, and updates by selectively re-computing only affected view fragments, thereby minimizing recomputation overhead. Extensive experiments on the TPC-DS benchmark reveal that DynIVM outperforms state-of-the-art IVM techniques by up to 3x in terms of refresh latency and 2x in terms of storage savings.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents via Hierarchical Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments remains a significant challenge. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph reinforcement learning (HGRL) framework that enables agents to learn effective coordination strategies. By representing the agent interactions as a hierarchical graph, HGRL can capture both local and global dependencies, leading to improved coordination and adaptability. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGRL in a simulated disaster response scenario, where agents must collaborate to rescue victims and allocate resources. Our results show that HGRL outperforms existing methods in terms of response time, resource utilization, and overall mission success rate.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings and Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in natural language processing and information retrieval. Existing approaches often struggle with scalability and accuracy when dealing with large knowledge graphs. This paper introduces 'KG-ED', a novel entity disambiguation framework that leverages knowledge graph embeddings and graph attention networks. KG-ED represents entities as dense vectors and captures their relationships using graph attention, enabling efficient and effective disambiguation. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that KG-ED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and speed, making it suitable for large-scale applications.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including education, entertainment, and therapy. However, current gesture recognition systems often struggle to accurately recognize user intentions, leading to frustration and decreased user experience. This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in VR gesture recognition, examining how users' physical movements influence their mental representations of actions. We present a novel VR-based experiment that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to analyze user gestures and corresponding cognitive processes. Our results show that incorporating embodied cognition principles into gesture recognition models leads to improved accuracy and reduced latency, with implications for enhancing overall VR usability.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Systems for Real-Time Traffic Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent system for real-time traffic optimization, designed to tackle the scalability challenges of large-scale traffic networks. Our approach leverages a hierarchical architecture, where agents are organized into clusters and communicate with each other through a distributed blackboard. We propose a probabilistic decision-making framework that enables agents to adapt to changing traffic conditions and optimize traffic flow in real-time. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate a significant reduction in travel time and congestion compared to existing approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively expand user queries, leading to suboptimal search results. We propose a novel context-aware embedding approach, 'CAQE', which leverages semantic relationships between query terms and their contextual neighbors. By incorporating a graph-based attention mechanism, CAQE generates more informative and diverse expansion terms, improving retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate a significant increase in mean average precision and NDCG scores compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Dialogue
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational dialogue is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of expression across different modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates acoustic, linguistic, and visual features to recognize emotions in multi-modal dialogue. Our HAN model employs a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and time segments, leading to improved emotion recognition accuracy. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from conversational dialogue.

title: Reinforcing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the gap between the user's query and the relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages neural embeddings to reinforce query expansion. Our method, dubbed 'NeuQE', uses a neural network to learn semantic representations of query terms and expands them using a reinforcement learning framework. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that NeuQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for RDF Graph Databases using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: RDF graph databases are increasingly used to store and query large-scale semantic data. However, query optimization for these databases remains a challenging problem due to the complex nature of RDF data and the variability of query workloads. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize query plans based on a reward function that captures the trade-off between query execution time and memory usage. Our experiments on a real-world RDF dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, achieving an average query execution time reduction of 34% and a memory usage reduction of 27%.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework for autonomous agents using reinforcement learning. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized Markov decision process, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on its local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our approach leverages a multi-agent deep Q-network to learn a decentralized policy that adapts to dynamic task arrivals and agent failures. Experimental results on a simulated robot swarm scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system robustness.

title: Efficient Bayesian Neural Networks for Uncertainty Estimation in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Estimating uncertainty in deep neural networks is crucial for reliable decision-making in computer vision applications. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural network (BNN) framework that leverages efficient Monte Carlo dropout and stochastic variational inference to approximate the posterior distribution over model weights. We introduce a new uncertainty metric, 'Aleatoric Uncertainty Score', which better captures epistemic uncertainty compared to existing methods. Experimental results on image classification and object detection tasks demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art uncertainty estimation while maintaining competitive predictive performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Embeddings for Enhanced Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it aims to capture the underlying intent of a user's query. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and hand-crafted rules, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel neural embedding-based approach, 'NeuroQE', which learns to expand queries in a dense vector space. We leverage a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query representation, expansion, and ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Learning in Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Multi-modal learning has become increasingly important in computer vision tasks, where models need to process and integrate information from disparate sources such as images, text, and audio. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages self-attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Our HAN model achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmarks, including the multimodal sentiment analysis and visual question answering tasks, while reducing computational overhead by up to 40% compared to existing methods.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic signal control is a complex problem that requires adaptability to dynamic traffic conditions. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'SmartSignal', which enables decentralized control of traffic signals. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that combines local agents with a central coordinator, allowing for real-time optimization of traffic flow. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic patterns and incorporates domain knowledge to ensure safety and efficiency. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulator demonstrate significant improvements in traffic throughput and reductions in congestion.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed RDF Graph Databases
paper_abstract: With the increasing popularity of RDF graph databases, query optimization becomes a critical challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel query optimization framework, 'RDF-Optimizer', specifically designed for distributed RDF graph databases. RDF-Optimizer leverages a combination of graph partitioning, subquery rewriting, and parallel execution to significantly reduce query response times. We evaluate RDF-Optimizer on a real-world dataset and demonstrate an average speedup of 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing platforms face the challenge of dynamically allocating resources to meet fluctuating workload demands. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'CloudOpt', which learns to optimize resource allocation policies in a decentralized manner. Our approach leverages a hierarchical architecture to balance exploration and exploitation, and incorporates a novel reward function that considers both performance and energy efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that CloudOpt outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of response time, resource utilization, and energy consumption.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Older adults with motor impairments face significant barriers when interacting with gestural interfaces. This paper presents a novel design framework that integrates accessibility principles with machine learning-based gesture recognition. We conducted a participatory design study with 20 older adults, resulting in a set of inclusive design recommendations for gesture sets, feedback mechanisms, and adaptive difficulty adjustment. Our prototype, 'EasyGesture', was evaluated in a controlled experiment, showing significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to existing gestural interfaces. The proposed framework has implications for designing more accessible and usable interfaces for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning: A Hierarchical Attention Framework for Policy Interpretation
paper_abstract: As reinforcement learning (RL) agents become increasingly prevalent in real-world applications, understanding their decision-making processes is crucial for trust and reliability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HierAtt', for interpreting RL policies. HierAtt incorporates both spatial and temporal attention mechanisms to identify critical state features and actions that contribute to the agent's behavior. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HierAtt on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing improved interpretability and transparency in RL policy decisions.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Conversational Search using Context-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems require effective query expansion techniques to capture the nuances of natural language queries. We propose a novel approach, 'ConvEx', which leverages context-aware embeddings to model the relationships between query terms, entities, and user intent. By incorporating contextualized language models and knowledge graph embeddings, ConvEx generates expanded queries that better capture the user's information need. Experimental results on a large conversational search dataset demonstrate that ConvEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, improving retrieval accuracy and reducing computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Goals
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) often require efficient task planning to achieve complex goals. However, in real-world scenarios, agent goals may be uncertain or probabilistic. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Task Network (HTN) planning framework, 'U-Plan', that can handle uncertain goals in MAS. U-Plan integrates probabilistic goal models with HTN planning to generate robust and adaptive plans. We propose a probabilistic plan evaluation metric, 'Expected Plan Quality', to quantify the likelihood of achieving uncertain goals. Experimental results on a simulated robotic soccer domain demonstrate that U-Plan outperforms existing HTN planners in uncertain goal settings.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Unknown Attacks in Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable successes in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised concerns. Existing defenses often focus on known attack types, leaving DRL systems susceptible to unknown threats. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'RobustRL', which leverages a dual-agent approach to generate diverse, unknown perturbations. By incorporating these perturbations into the training process, we significantly improve the robustness of DRL policies against a wide range of attacks. Experimental results on multiple Atari games demonstrate that RobustRL outperforms state-of-the-art defenses in terms of resistance to unknown attacks, while maintaining competitive performance on clean data.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Physiological and Behavioral Cues
paper_abstract: Accurate affective state recognition is crucial in human-computer interaction. This paper presents EmoTract, a multimodal framework that integrates physiological signals (EEG, ECG, and skin conductance) with behavioral cues (facial expressions and body language) to recognize emotions. We propose a novel fusion technique that leverages the strengths of each modality, achieving improved recognition accuracy and robustness. Our approach is evaluated on a diverse dataset of 200 participants, demonstrating superior performance compared to unimodal and traditional multimodal approaches. EmoTract has implications for affective computing, mental health monitoring, and personalized human-computer interaction.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Task-oriented dialogue systems aim to efficiently complete tasks through natural language interactions. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HiTRL', that leverages a two-level hierarchical structure to learn both dialogue management and response generation policies. The upper level learns to select relevant intent-specific sub-policies, while the lower level refines the response generation using a novel intent-aware attention mechanism. Our experiments on the DSTC2 benchmark demonstrate that HiTRL outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of task success rate, average reward, and response quality.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion via Deep Learning-based Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel deep learning-based approach for pseudo-relevance feedback, which leverages a neural ranking model to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroPRF', learns to identify relevant documents and extracts informative terms using a multi-task learning framework. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroPRF outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Coordination
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has created a need for efficient multi-agent coordination. This paper presents a novel decentralized reinforcement learning framework for AV coordination, which leverages graph neural networks to model complex interactions between agents. Our approach, 'MARL-GNN', incorporates a hierarchical reward function that balances individual and global objectives, enabling AVs to navigate complex scenarios while minimizing collisions and congestion. Experimental results demonstrate that MARL-GNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various traffic scenarios, achieving improved safety and efficiency.

title: Deep Multimodal Fusion for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing ERS models often rely on shallow fusion of multimodal data, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel deep multimodal fusion framework, 'MMF-ERS', which leverages transformers to jointly model user-item interactions, visual, and textual features. Our approach enables the generation of interpretable explanations for recommended items, improving user trust and satisfaction. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of MMF-ERS in enhancing recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Graph-Based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with sparse query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages graph-based embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphExpand', uses a graph convolutional network to learn dense embeddings of query terms and their co-occurrences in a large corpus. We demonstrate that GraphExpand outperforms existing query expansion techniques on several benchmark datasets, leading to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness. Furthermore, we show that GraphExpand can be seamlessly integrated with existing neural search architectures, making it a practical solution for real-world search engines.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems require efficient query optimization to ensure satisfactory performance for diverse workloads. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQuery', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in multi-tenant environments. We design a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that adapts to changing workloads and learn optimal query plans using a combination of graph neural networks and Q-networks. Experiments on a real-world benchmark demonstrate that DeepQuery outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults using Multimodal Fusion
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have the potential to improve older adults' access to information and services. However, existing systems often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this demographic. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion approach that integrates speech, gaze, and gesture inputs to create a more inclusive and accessible conversational interface. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults and found that our system improved task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional speech-only interfaces. Our results highlight the importance of considering the diverse abilities and preferences of older adults in the design of conversational interfaces.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Cognitive Load and Emotional Experience
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their design often neglects the needs of users with disabilities. This study investigates the impact of cognitive load and emotional experience on the usability of voice assistants for individuals with visual impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, using both quantitative and qualitative measures to assess user experience. Our findings suggest that existing voice assistants can be overwhelming and frustrating, leading to high cognitive load and negative emotional responses. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the importance of customizable interfaces, clear feedback, and emotional support.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems operating in dynamic environments require effective negotiation strategies to achieve cooperative goals. This paper presents a novel autonomous negotiation framework, 'DynaNeg', which integrates machine learning and game theory to adapt to changing environmental conditions. DynaNeg employs a deep reinforcement learning approach to learn negotiation strategies from historical data and updates them in real-time using a graph-based attention mechanism. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that DynaNeg outperforms existing negotiation strategies in terms of cooperation rate, conflict resolution, and overall system utility.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component in task-oriented dialogue systems, and explainability is essential for building trustworthy AI systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAT) for DST, which incorporates both local and global attention mechanisms to capture complex contextual relationships in dialogues. We introduce a novel explainability module that generates visualizations of attention weights, enabling users to understand the model's decision-making process. Experimental results on two benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAT outperforms state-of-the-art DST models while providing interpretable explanations for its predictions.

title: Investigating the Effectiveness of Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: This study explores the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) learning environments. We designed an immersive VR platform that integrates gestural interfaces and spatial awareness to facilitate deeper understanding of complex concepts in physics education. Our user study with 120 participants shows significant improvements in knowledge retention and transfer compared to traditional desktop-based learning. We also analyze the impact of embodiment on user engagement, cognitive load, and emotional experience. The results provide insights into the design of effective VR-based learning systems that leverage the strengths of embodied cognition.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Stores using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed column-stores have become increasingly popular for big data analytics. However, optimizing query execution plans for such systems remains a complex problem.
