This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans. Our framework, 'ColumnRL', uses a deep Q-network to learn an efficient exploration-exploitation strategy for query optimization. We evaluate ColumnRL on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy in Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms has led to increased resource contention and degraded query performance. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to minimize query latency and resource utilization. Our approach, called 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan selection policy based on workload characteristics and resource availability. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform show that RL-Optimizer outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in improving the performance of search systems, especially in the medical domain where precise retrieval is paramount. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach for query expansion, dubbed 'MedExpand'. MedExpand leverages a combination of word embeddings and convolutional neural networks to capture the semantic relationships between medical terms and generate high-quality expansion terms. Our experiments on the TREC Medical Retrieval dataset demonstrate that MedExpand outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Hop Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering over knowledge graphs (KGs) often requires multi-hop reasoning, which can be challenging due to the complexity of KG structures. This paper presents a novel approach, HATKE, that leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to learn more informative entity and relation embeddings. Our method adaptively focuses on relevant KG subgraphs and captures nuanced semantic relationships, enabling more accurate question answering. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HATKE, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 12% in terms of answer accuracy.

title: Robustness Analysis of Self-Supervised Representation Learning against Adversarial Attacks
paper_abstract: Self-supervised representation learning has shown promising results in various computer vision tasks. However, the robustness of these models against adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the robustness of state-of-the-art self-supervised methods, including contrastive learning and generative models, against various types of adversarial attacks. Our experiments reveal that these models are vulnerable to attacks, leading to significant performance degradation. We further propose a novel defense strategy, 'AdvReg', which incorporates adversarial training into the self-supervised learning pipeline, resulting in improved robustness and generalizability.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems, such as swarms of drones or robots, require efficient task allocation to achieve complex goals. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach, 'Distributed Task Assignment using Reinforcement Learning' (DTARL), which enables agents to learn cooperative task allocation policies in a decentralized manner. DTARL utilizes a graph neural network to model agent interactions and environmental dynamics, allowing agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environment conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that DTARL outperforms traditional task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it aims to bridge the gap between the user's query and the relevant documents. Traditional methods rely on manual feature engineering and relevance feedback, which can be time-consuming and ineffective. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DLQE', which leverages transformer architectures to learn contextualized query and document representations. Our results on the TREC dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, while reducing the need for manual intervention.

title: Enhancing Retrieval Efficiency with Neural Query Expansion for Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Retrieval efficiency remains a significant challenge in specialized domains, where query intent is often complex and nuanced. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE-Specialist', that leverages domain-specific knowledge graphs to generate context-aware query representations. Our approach involves training a graph neural network to learn domain-specific entity relationships and incorporating these into a probabilistic query expansion model. Experimental results on a biomedical dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and F1-score compared to traditional keyword-based expansion methods.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Symbolic Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly compromise their performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, Bayesian Neural Symbolic Learning (BNSL), to robustify DNNs against such attacks. BNSL integrates Bayesian neural networks with symbolic reasoning to learn robust and interpretable representations. We demonstrate that BNSL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in defending against various types of attacks, including projected gradient descent and Carlini and Wagner attacks, on multiple benchmark datasets.

title: Deep Graph Contrastive Learning for Node Representation in Heterogeneous Networks
paper_abstract: Heterogeneous networks, which contain nodes and edges of different types, are ubiquitous in real-world applications. However, existing node representation methods often fail to capture the complex relationships between nodes. This paper proposes a novel deep graph contrastive learning framework, 'HetGraphCL', which leverages the structural information in heterogeneous networks to learn robust node representations. We introduce a graph-aware contrastive loss function that encourages nodes to be close to their similar nodes and far from dissimilar ones. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HetGraphCL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification and graph clustering tasks.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Ad Hoc Retrieval via Graph-Based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Ad hoc retrieval systems often struggle with capturing the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel context-aware query expansion approach that leverages graph-based embeddings to model the relationships between query terms and their surrounding context. Our method, dubbed 'CAQE', incorporates a graph convolutional network to encode query-dependent context features, which are then used to expand the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for queries with ambiguous or heterogeneous terms.

title: Optimizing Index Selection for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have gained popularity due to their improved performance and low latency. However, optimizing index selection for multi-dimensional range queries remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel cost-based approach, 'DIMON', which leverages statistical models to estimate query selectivity and identify the most effective index configuration. We develop a set of heuristics to prune the search space and reduce the optimization time. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that DIMON outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 30% in terms of query response time and I/O efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Low-Literacy Users
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but their complexity and assumptions of high literacy levels often exclude marginalized populations. This paper presents a framework for designing inclusive conversational interfaces that cater to low-literacy users. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving user interviews, usability testing, and cognitive walkthroughs to identify key challenges and opportunities. Our results inform the development of a set of design guidelines and a prototype interface that leverages multimedia, simplification, and error tolerance to facilitate more accessible human-computer interaction. A pilot study with low-literacy participants demonstrates improved interaction outcomes and user satisfaction.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Armed Bandits
paper_abstract: We propose a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging multi-armed bandit (MAB) algorithms to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. Our approach, 'AgentMAB', allows agents to learn from their interactions with the environment and adapt to changes in task availability and agent capabilities. We introduce a novel reward function that balances exploration and exploitation, and demonstrate through simulations that AgentMAB outperforms traditional assignment algorithms in terms of overall system efficiency and fairness.

title: Adaptive Gradient Clipping for Efficient and Robust Neural Network Training
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are often vulnerable to exploding gradients during training, leading to poor convergence or divergence. This paper introduces a novel adaptive gradient clipping (AGC) technique that dynamically adjusts the clipping threshold based on the gradient norm distribution. Our approach significantly improves training stability and robustness, while also reducing the computational overhead associated with traditional gradient clipping methods. Experimental results on various benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AGC in achieving faster convergence and better generalization performance.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient task allocation strategies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning approach, 'MATRL', that enables distributed task allocation among autonomous vehicles. MATRL combines decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes with graph neural networks to learn task allocation policies. We evaluate MATRL in a simulated urban environment, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized approaches. The proposed framework has potential applications in autonomous delivery, surveillance, and search-and-rescue missions.

title: Query Expansion Using Neural Graph-Based Entity Disambiguation for Short Texts
paper_abstract: Short texts often lack contextual information, leading to ambiguity in entity disambiguation. This paper proposes a novel neural graph-based approach, GraphED, which expands queries by incorporating entity relationships and semantic knowledge. GraphED represents entities as nodes in a graph and learns to disambiguate them using a graph attention mechanism. Experimental results on short text datasets show that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, improving retrieval effectiveness by up to 15%. Our approach has significant implications for search engines, question answering, and natural language processing applications.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph Neural Networks and Active Learning
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in a text. Existing approaches often suffer from scalability issues or require extensive manual annotation. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'GEDAL', which leverages graph neural networks and active learning to efficiently disambiguate entities in large-scale knowledge graphs. We introduce a hierarchical graph attention mechanism that captures both local and global context, and an active learning strategy that selects the most informative samples for annotation. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of GEDAL, achieving state-of-the-art performance with significantly reduced annotation costs.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MATRL', which learns to allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. MATRL utilizes a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to optimize task allocation. Experimental results show that MATRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization, demonstrating its potential for real-world applications such as warehouse management and disaster response.

title: Scalable Query Optimization using Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have become increasingly popular for real-time analytics and transactional workloads. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck, particularly for complex queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization that leverages learned index structures, which can adapt to the underlying data distribution and workload patterns. We introduce a hierarchical indexing framework that integrates traditional B-tree indexes with learned models, enabling efficient query execution and optimization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis in social media has become increasingly important for businesses and organizations to understand public opinions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual and textual features from social media posts to improve sentiment analysis accuracy. Our approach employs a multimodal fusion module to combine convolutional neural network (CNN) and recurrent neural network (RNN) features, followed by a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant input features. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of social media posts demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal sentiment analysis methods and provides interpretable insights into the importance of different input features.

title: Efficient Coalition Formation for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments often require forming coalitions to achieve complex tasks. This paper presents a novel algorithm, 'DCFA', that leverages a combination of distributed constraint satisfaction and graph-based clustering to efficiently form coalitions in real-time. DCFA adapts to changing environmental conditions by iteratively refining the coalition structure, ensuring robustness and scalability. Experimental evaluations on a realistic robotic rescue scenario demonstrate significant improvements in coalition formation speed and task completion rates compared to existing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models often rely on complex neural architectures, making it challenging to interpret their decision-making process. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that incorporates both visual and linguistic attention mechanisms. Our approach enables the model to focus on relevant regions of the image and question phrases, providing insights into its reasoning process. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that our HAN model achieves state-of-the-art performance while offering improved explainability through visualizations of attention weights.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational costs and limited generalizability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning (HCL) framework that leverages a multi-level representation hierarchy to learn effective few-shot classifiers. By combining contrastive learning with a hierarchical attention mechanism, HCL achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing computational costs by up to 50%. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of HCL in adapting to novel classes and unseen domains.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Filtering with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to efficiently retrieve relevant documents from large collections. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document filtering approach, QADF, which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize the filtering process. QADF learns to dynamically adjust the filtering threshold based on the query complexity and document features, resulting in significant reductions in retrieval time and improved precision. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of QADF in improving the efficiency and accuracy of IR systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of heterogeneous storage systems in distributed databases, query optimization has become a critical challenge. Existing solutions either neglect storage heterogeneity or rely on naive and inefficient optimization techniques. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'HeteOpt', which leverages statistical models and machine learning algorithms to adapt to diverse storage configurations. HeteOpt introduces a cost-based optimization approach that considers storage characteristics, query patterns, and system workload to minimize query execution time. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that HeteOpt achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from a massive index. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, dubbed 'HQE', which leverages semantic clustering and term weighting to reduce the search space. HQE iteratively refines the query by incorporating context-aware expansion terms, resulting in improved precision and recall. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that HQE outperforms existing query expansion methods, reducing query latency by up to 40% while maintaining comparable retrieval quality.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Dynamic Task Dependences
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task allocation framework, 'HTDA', that handles dynamic task dependences and resource constraints. HTDA combines a decentralized task decomposition approach with a centralized constraint optimization mechanism, enabling agents to adapt to changing task relationships and resource availability. Experimental results on a logistics scenario demonstrate that HTDA outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate, resource utilization, and system flexibility.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults, but their design often neglects the unique needs and abilities of this demographic. This paper presents a participatory design study with 20 older adults, exploring their preferences and challenges when interacting with voice-based conversational agents. We identify key design recommendations, including the use of simple and consistent language, explicit error handling, and personalized feedback. Our findings inform the development of more accessible and usable conversational interfaces that support older adults' autonomy and independence.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Clustering-based Document Representation
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval to improve the retrieval performance. Existing methods often rely on term-based representation, which may not capture the semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel clustering-based document representation approach, ClusRep, which leverages document clustering to identify latent topics and enrich the query representation. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ClusRep outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision and recall, while reducing the computational overhead.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Query-Aware Neural Sentence Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural sentence embeddings have shown promise in natural language processing tasks, but their application to document ranking remains limited. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QRank', which leverages query-aware neural sentence embeddings to improve the effectiveness of document ranking. QRank learns to capture the semantic relationships between query sentences and document sentences, enabling more accurate ranking of relevant documents. Our experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that QRank outperforms state-of-the-art document ranking models, particularly for complex queries.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel approach to document retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT). HGAT leverages the graph structure of documents to model relationships between entities, and incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on relevant contexts. Our experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to traditional keyword-based methods. Furthermore, we show that HGAT can be effectively applied to multi-hop question answering tasks, achieving state-of-the-art results on the HotPotQA benchmark.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud-Native Applications
paper_abstract: Cloud-native applications require efficient resource allocation to ensure scalability and performance. This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach to optimize resource allocation in cloud environments. We propose a novel DRL framework, 'CloudOpt', which leverages a combination of actor-critic methods and graph neural networks to learn resource allocation policies. Our experiments on a cloud-based simulation platform demonstrate that CloudOpt achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and cost reduction compared to traditional rule-based allocation methods.

title: EmoReact: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition System for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling systems to respond empathetically to users. This paper presents EmoReact, a multimodal emotion recognition system that fuses facial expressions, speech tone, and physiological signals to recognize emotions. We propose a novel attention-based fusion mechanism that adaptively weighs the modalities based on their reliability and emotional relevance. Our evaluations on a large, publicly available dataset demonstrate that EmoReact achieves state-of-the-art emotion recognition accuracy, outperforming unimodal and fusion-based baselines. We also explore the applicability of EmoReact in a real-world HCI scenario, showcasing its potential to enhance user experience.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Search Engines using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in search engines, aiming to reformulate user queries to improve retrieval performance. Existing QE methods often rely on handcrafted rules or supervised learning, which can be suboptimal. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning (RL) to QE, where an agent learns to select expansion terms that maximize retrieval effectiveness. We propose a novel RL framework, 'QE-RL', which incorporates a reward function that balances query similarity and diversity. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QE-RL outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and robustness to query variations.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Hierarchical Clustering and Keyword Extraction
paper_abstract: Modern information retrieval systems are plagued by the curse of dimensionality, leading to inefficient document filtering and retrieval. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach that leverages keyword extraction to reduce the dimensionality of high-dimensional document vectors. Our method, called Hierarchical Keyword-based Filtering (HKF), uses a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group similar documents based on their keyword distributions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HKF on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in filtering efficiency and retrieval accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Data Partitioning for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems require efficient data partitioning to minimize communication overhead and ensure scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn data partitioning strategies. We model the database as a graph and utilize GNNs to learn a partitioning scheme that minimizes cut edges while balancing data distribution across nodes. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional data partitioning techniques, achieving up to 30% reduction in communication overhead and 25% improvement in query response time.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for autonomous agents in complex environments. We propose a Graph Neural Network (GNN) based framework that learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, environment dynamics, and inter-agent dependencies. Our approach leverages the structural properties of the agent communication graph to improve task allocation efficiency and adaptability. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that our method outperforms traditional optimization-based approaches in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Learned Index Structures for RDF Datasets
paper_abstract: The growing scale of RDF datasets poses significant challenges for query performance. Traditional indexing techniques often struggle to efficiently handle the complex, graph-structured data inherent in RDF. This paper introduces 'LIX', a novel learned index structure that leverages machine learning models to optimize query execution. By learning the underlying data distribution and query patterns, LIX achieves significant reductions in query latency and memory usage compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of LIX in improving query performance and scalability.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of sensor data, necessitating efficient query optimization techniques for real-time analytics. This paper proposes 'SenseOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages statistical modeling and machine learning to predict query execution times. SenseOpt integrates a cost-based optimizer with a learning-based cardinality estimator, enabling accurate query planning and efficient resource allocation. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that SenseOpt achieves up to 3x faster query execution times compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data and high-workload applications. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query execution plans in DDS. We design an RL agent that learns to select the optimal query plan based on the system's workload and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques, achieving an average query response time reduction of 30%.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Networks for Short-Text Queries
paper_abstract: Short-text queries pose significant challenges for traditional information retrieval systems due to the scarcity of relevant terms. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture that learns to represent short-text queries and documents in a shared semantic space. Our approach leverages a attention-based mechanism to selectively focus on relevant keywords and phrases in the query, and a hierarchical aggregation strategy to capture nuanced relationships between document sections. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HNN-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of retrieval precision and efficiency.

title: Efficient Adversarial Training for Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are susceptible to adversarial attacks, which can have devastating consequences in safety-critical applications like autonomous driving. This paper presents a novel adversarial training framework, 'RobustDet', designed for real-time object detection in autonomous systems. RobustDet leverages a combination of input preprocessing, loss function regularization, and a custom-designed adversarial attack algorithm to improve the robustness of object detectors against a wide range of attacks. Our experiments demonstrate that RobustDet achieves state-of-the-art performance on the KITTI benchmark while reducing the computational overhead by 30% compared to existing approaches.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Networks for Domain-Specific Search
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines require efficient and accurate document retrieval mechanisms to cater to the diverse information needs of users. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network architecture, 'HNN-DR', that leverages semantic embeddings and domain knowledge to improve retrieval performance. We introduce a two-stage retrieval framework that combines a coarse-grained relevance scoring model with a fine-grained ranking model, enabling efficient filtering and ranking of documents. Experimental results on a large-scale domain-specific dataset demonstrate that HNN-DR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision and a 30% reduction in retrieval time.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Expansion for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on effective document retrieval to answer user queries. However, the traditional approach of fixed-length document snippets often leads to suboptimal performance. This paper presents a novel query-adaptive document expansion (QADE) method that dynamically selects relevant sentences from retrieved documents based on query-specific importance weights. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to estimate the relevance of each sentence to the query, and then generates a weighted document representation for improved answer extraction. Experimental results on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art ODQA systems by 3.5% in terms of exact match score.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Dementia
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system designed specifically for older adults with dementia. Our approach incorporates machine learning algorithms and cognitive models to adapt to the unique needs and abilities of this population. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that our system achieved an average recognition accuracy of 92%, outperforming existing systems. We also explored the role of cognitive load in gesture recognition and provide design recommendations for future systems. Our work has implications for the development of assistive technologies that support independence and quality of life for older adults with dementia.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Relational Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Relational reinforcement learning (RRL) has shown promise in complex decision-making tasks, but existing methods lack interpretability. We introduce Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel architecture that integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical reinforcement learning. HGAT learns to focus on relevant relational structures and abstract away irrelevant information, enabling explainable decision-making. We evaluate HGAT on several RRL benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have seen significant advancements in recent years, but user interaction remains a major bottleneck. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction in VR, leveraging eye-tracking technology to enable users to select and manipulate virtual objects. We conducted a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of our gaze-based interaction system, comparing it to traditional controller-based interaction. Results show that gaze-based interaction improves user experience and reduces task completion time, particularly for tasks requiring precision. We also identify key factors influencing user performance, including gaze accuracy and cognitive load.

title: Efficient Secondary Indexing for Time-Series Data in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Time-series data has become increasingly prominent in various applications, from IoT to financial analytics. However, existing main-memory database systems struggle to efficiently support secondary indexing for time-series data, leading to poor query performance. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, called TS-Index, which leverages the inherent temporal locality of time-series data to reduce indexing overhead. TS-Index integrates a compact in-memory data structure with a lazy update mechanism, achieving significant improvements in query throughput and memory efficiency. Our experimental evaluation on real-world time-series datasets demonstrates that TS-Index outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x.

title: Neural Query Graph Generation for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods rely on keyword-based matching, which often fails to capture the semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel neural query graph generation framework, 'NQG', which represents queries as graph structures to better model their compositional semantics. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to encode the query graph and a dense passage retriever to rank documents based on their relevance to the query graph. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that NQG outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning of Novel Classes
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has made significant progress in recent years, but most existing methods rely on a fixed set of classes seen during training. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that can learn novel classes with limited labeled data. Our approach combines a class-agnostic attention mechanism with a hierarchical class embedding strategy, enabling the model to focus on relevant features and adapt to new classes quickly. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in few-shot learning scenarios, especially when dealing with novel classes.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data using Graph-based Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in many applications, including industrial monitoring and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel approach, GraAD, which leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to capture complex patterns in time-series data. We model the data as a graph, where each node represents a time step, and edges encode temporal dependencies. Our approach uses self-attention to weigh the importance of neighboring nodes, enabling the detection of anomalies in real-time. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraAD in detecting anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art techniques.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Representation for Efficient Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component of many information retrieval systems. However, existing methods often rely on fixed document representations, which can lead to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document representation approach, 'QADR', which dynamically adjusts the document encoding based on the query context. We introduce a neural network-based framework that learns to weight and combine different document features in response to the query, resulting in more accurate passage retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking with Document Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively rank documents when the query contains ambiguous or nuanced terms. This paper proposes a hierarchical neural ranking model, 'DocEx', which incorporates document expansion techniques to capture semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Our approach leverages a novel graph-based neural network architecture that jointly learns term weights, document representations, and query-document interactions. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and robustness to query ambiguity compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Relevance-based Document Expansion for Improving Retrieval Accuracy in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the lexical gap between query terms and document content. This paper proposes a novel relevance-based document expansion approach, 'RDE', which selectively incorporates relevant terms from top-ranked documents into the original query. Our method leverages a neural ranking model to estimate the relevance of each term and adaptively adjusts the expansion weights based on the query's semantic context. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate that RDE significantly improves retrieval accuracy, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often neglect the context in which queries are issued. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'ConEx', which leverages context-aware embeddings to capture the nuances of user intent. By incorporating contextual information, such as user location and search history, ConEx generates more informative and diverse expansion terms, leading to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of ConEx over state-of-the-art QE methods, particularly in scenarios with ambiguous or underspecified queries.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Real-time object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems. This paper presents a novel attention mechanism, 'FastFocus', which significantly reduces computational overhead while maintaining detection accuracy. FastFocus adaptively adjusts attention weights based on object saliency and spatial relationships, allowing for efficient processing of high-resolution video feeds. We evaluate FastFocus on the KITTI and Waymo Open datasets, demonstrating a 30% reduction in inference time compared to state-of-the-art methods while achieving comparable mAP scores.

title: Real-Time Data Warehousing with Materialized View Maintenance for Big Data Analytics
paper_abstract: The increasing volume and velocity of big data pose significant challenges to traditional data warehousing approaches. This paper presents a novel real-time data warehousing framework that leverages materialized view maintenance to ensure up-to-date analytics. We propose a hybrid indexing approach that combines bitmap indexing with a Delta- encoding scheme to efficiently store and update materialized views. Experimental results on a large-scale analytics workload demonstrate that our approach achieves an average query response time of 2.5 seconds, outperforming existing real-time data warehousing solutions by up to 3.2x.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Networks for Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems are crucial for building trust with users. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Convolutional Network (HAGCN) architecture that integrates both item-level and user-level explanations. HAGCN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex relationships between users and items, and leverages graph convolutional networks to model high-order interactions. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HAGCN outperforms state-of-the-art explainable recommendation models in terms of accuracy and informativeness of explanations.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important in various applications, including finance, healthcare, and e-commerce. However, query optimization for real-time data warehousing remains a significant challenge, particularly when using column stores. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RTCOL', which leverages the column-store architecture to minimize query latency. We introduce a column-based data partitioning strategy that reduces the number of disk I/O operations, and develop a cost-based optimization algorithm that considers both query latency and data freshness. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RTCOL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 40% in terms of query latency.

title: Debiasing Neural Retrieval Models for Fair Document Ranking
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown significant improvements in document ranking tasks, but they often inherit biases from the training data, leading to unfair ranking results. This paper proposes a novel debiasing approach, 'FairRank', which incorporates a bias-aware regularization term into the neural ranking model. We introduce a new bias metric, 'Ranking Disparity', to measure the unfairness of the ranking results and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting biases. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that FairRank significantly reduces ranking biases while maintaining comparable ranking performance to state-of-the-art models.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Augmented Reality for Inclusive Design
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has vast potential for enhancing human-computer interaction, but existing interfaces often neglect users with disabilities. This paper presents 'GazeAR', a novel framework that leverages gaze-based interaction to enable individuals with mobility impairments to seamlessly interact with AR environments. We develop a machine learning model that accurately detects and interprets gaze patterns, facilitating intuitive object selection and manipulation in 3D space. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and overall user experience, highlighting the promise of gaze-based AR interfaces for inclusive design.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents often struggle to generalize across tasks and provide insights into their decision-making processes. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs) for Explainable Multi-Task Reinforcement Learning (EMTRL). HANs leverage hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant task-specific features and provide visual explanations for the agent's actions. We evaluate HANs on a suite of multi-task RL benchmarks and demonstrate improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Our approach has implications for real-world applications where transparency and accountability are crucial, such as autonomous driving and robotics.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding has become a crucial task in various applications, including question answering and recommendation systems. However, entity disambiguation remains a significant challenge due to the inherent ambiguity of entity names. This paper proposes a novel approach, HGA-KE, which leverages hierarchical graph attention networks to disambiguate entities in knowledge graphs. Our method exploits the hierarchical structure of the graph to capture complex relationships between entities and their contexts. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGA-KE outperforms state-of-the-art models in entity disambiguation tasks, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in F1-score.

title: Context-Aware Document Representation for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document representation methods in information retrieval (IR) systems often neglect the importance of contextual information. This paper proposes a novel context-aware document representation model, 'CADET', which incorporates both local and global contextual features to capture the nuances of document semantics. CADET leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the importance of different contextual elements, improving the retrieval performance by 15% compared to state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of CADET in scenarios with limited training data, making it a promising approach for real-world IR applications.

title: Proximity-Aware Document Ranking with Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Document ranking is a crucial component of modern information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel proximity-aware document ranking model, 'GraphRank', which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks to capture complex relationships between query terms and document structures. By incorporating proximity features into the graph representation, GraphRank can effectively model term dependencies and contextual relevance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking performance compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Attention-Based Explainable Recommendation with Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing methods rely on hand-crafted features or shallow model interpretations. This paper proposes a novel attention-based framework, 'KG-Attr', that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to provide personalized explanations for recommended items. Our approach incorporates a multi-task learning objective that jointly optimizes recommendation accuracy and explanation quality. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that KG-Attr outperforms state-of-the-art explainable recommendation methods while providing intuitive and interpretable explanations.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Voice Assistants Using Emotion-Aware Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces for voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for users with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper presents an emotion-aware dialogue management approach to improve the interaction experience for users with emotional or cognitive impairments. Our proposed framework, 'EmpaDia', incorporates affective computing and machine learning techniques to recognize and respond to user emotions, adapting the conversation flow to accommodate individual needs. Experimental results with 50 participants demonstrate that EmpaDia enhances user satisfaction, reduces frustration, and promotes more effective task completion compared to traditional dialogue management systems.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but the impact of embodiment on user experience remains poorly understood. This study examines how embodiment, or the sense of owning a virtual body, affects user engagement, presence, and task performance in VR. We conducted a within-subjects experiment with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR platform with varying levels of embodiment. Results show that increased embodiment leads to higher user engagement, presence, and task performance, but also increases simulator sickness. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems that prioritize user experience.

title: Efficient Explainability for Transformer-based Natural Language Processing Models
paper_abstract: Transformer-based models have achieved state-of-the-art results in various natural language processing (NLP) tasks, but their opacity hinders model interpretability and trustworthiness. This paper proposes a novel technique, 'TransExplainer', which leverages attention weights and gradient-based saliency maps to provide insights into the decision-making process of transformer models. We evaluate TransExplainer on several NLP benchmarks and demonstrate its effectiveness in identifying salient input features, visualizing attention patterns, and explaining model predictions. Our approach enables developers to better understand and refine complex NLP models, ultimately leading to more accurate and reliable AI systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and User Experience
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in many households, but their effectiveness for older adults is often hindered by speech recognition inaccuracies and usability issues. This study investigates the design of inclusive voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65+, examining the impact of speech recognition algorithms and user interface design on user experience. Our results show that incorporating age-specific speech patterns and adapting dialogue flows to accommodate cognitive decline can significantly improve user satisfaction and task completion rates. We provide design guidelines for creating more accessible and user-friendly voice assistants for older adults.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent-Based Decision Support Systems for Real-Time Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex systems, decision-making under uncertainty is a challenging task, especially when real-time resource allocation is required. This paper presents a decentralized autonomous agent-based decision support system (DSS) that leverages multi-agent coordination and negotiation to optimize resource allocation in dynamic environments. Our approach integrates machine learning-based predictive models with agent-based reasoning to enable proactive decision-making. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed DSS outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods in terms of response time and resource utilization efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Information retrieval systems rely on accurate document ranking to retrieve relevant results. This paper proposes a novel approach to document ranking using hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs). Our method represents documents as graphs, capturing semantic relationships between entities and keywords. A hierarchical attention mechanism is employed to learn node representations at multiple scales, enabling the model to capture both local and global context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Decentralized Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the need for agents to coordinate and adapt to changing environments. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'Dec-MARL', which combines multi-agent reinforcement learning with decentralized communication protocols. We introduce a hierarchical architecture where agents learn to allocate tasks based on local observations and communicate with neighbors to resolve conflicts. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that Dec-MARL outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and adaptability to changing agent availability.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Disabilities: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework that enables users with disabilities to interact with voice assistants more effectively. We propose a novel fusion of speech, gesture, and gaze-based input modalities, which are processed using machine learning algorithms to improve recognition accuracy. Our user study with 30 participants with disabilities shows that our approach significantly reduces error rates and improves user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Incremental View Maintenance
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing poses significant query optimization challenges, particularly when dealing with rapidly changing data and complex queries. This paper introduces 'RTOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages incremental view maintenance to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. We propose a cost-based optimization approach that dynamically adjusts view maintenance schedules based on query patterns and data updates. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RTOpt achieves an average query latency reduction of 35% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering (QA) models have achieved remarkable success, but their opacity hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for explainable QA, which disentangles the reasoning process into attention weights and semantic role identification. Our approach leverages a novel hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant contextual information and identifies the most informative spans. Experimental results on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art QA models while providing interpretable attention patterns and semantic role-based explanations.

title: Efficient Secondary Index Maintenance for Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: Modern analytical workloads often rely on distributed column-stores to process massive datasets. However, maintaining secondary indexes in these systems becomes increasingly challenging due to the high volume of updates and the need for concurrent query execution. This paper presents 'DynaIndex', a novel approach to efficient secondary index maintenance in distributed column-stores. DynaIndex employs a hybrid indexing technique that combines trie-based and bitmap-based indexing, allowing for adaptive index reorganization and minimized index maintenance overhead. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DynaIndex reduces index maintenance time by up to 70% compared to state-of-the-art approaches, while maintaining query performance and scalability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Few-Shot Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction (FSRE) aims to extract novel relations from a limited number of examples. Existing FSRE models rely on complex meta-learning strategies or rely heavily on pre-trained language models. We propose a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages both entity-level and relation-level attention mechanisms to effectively capture contextual dependencies. Our experiments on the FewRel benchmark show that HAN achieves state-of-the-art performance on FSRE tasks, outperforming existing models by up to 15% in accuracy. We further analyze the effectiveness of our approach on different types of relations and datasets.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: As robots become increasingly prevalent in industrial environments, effective human-robot collaboration (HRC) is crucial for productivity and safety. This paper explores the role of embodiment in HRC, examining how a robot's physical appearance and behavior influence human trust and cooperation. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants in a realistic industrial setting, comparing interactions with a humanoid robot, a robotic arm, and a virtual agent. Our results show that the humanoid robot's embodied presence enhances trust and cooperation, particularly in tasks requiring close proximity and physical interaction. We discuss implications for HRC system design and future research directions.

title: Goal-Oriented Task Planning for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments face the challenge of adapting to changing circumstances while pursuing their goals. This paper presents a novel task planning framework, 'DynaPlan', which integrates goal-oriented planning with online learning to enable agents to respond effectively to environment changes. DynaPlan utilizes a probabilistic graphical model to represent the agent's beliefs about the environment and updates its planning policy through reinforcement learning. Experimental results demonstrate that DynaPlan outperforms existing planning approaches in complex, dynamic scenarios, such as search-and-rescue operations and autonomous driving.

title: Distributed Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Systems using Stochastic Graph Theory
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is a critical problem that involves grouping agents to achieve a common goal. This paper presents a novel distributed coalition formation algorithm using stochastic graph theory. We model the agent interactions as a stochastic graph and propose a decentralized approach to identify the optimal coalition structure. Our algorithm leverages the theory of random graph models to efficiently explore the exponentially large space of possible coalitions. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of coalition quality and convergence speed.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems require efficient query optimization to minimize resource contention and improve overall system performance. This paper presents GraphOpt, a novel query optimization framework that leverages graph-based indexing to identify optimal query plans. GraphOpt constructs a graph representation of the query workload and uses community detection algorithms to identify subgraphs with similar query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world multi-tenant database system demonstrate that GraphOpt reduces query latency by up to 35% and improves system throughput by up to 25% compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Designing Emotional Intelligence in Voice Assistants for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interaction modalities often neglect the needs of people with disabilities. This paper presents an empathetic design approach for integrating emotional intelligence into voice assistants, focusing on users with visual impairments and autism spectrum disorder. We develop a multimodal affect recognition system that combines speech, prosody, and sentiment analysis to detect user emotions. Our user-centered evaluation with 20 participants shows that the proposed system improves the overall user experience, reduces frustration, and increases trust in voice assistants. We discuss implications for inclusive HCI design and future research directions.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in urban traffic control. We model the traffic network as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process, where each agent represents an intersection. Our approach, called 'TrafficCoor', leverages graph neural networks to learn a shared policy that optimizes traffic flow and reduces congestion. We evaluate TrafficCoor on a realistic simulation of the Pittsburgh traffic network and demonstrate significant improvements in travel time reduction and traffic signal coordination compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial task in distributed database systems, as it directly affects the performance and scalability of the system. Traditional query optimization techniques rely on rule-based or cost-based models, which may not adapt well to changing workloads and system dynamics. This paper proposes a novel adaptive query optimization approach using reinforcement learning, which learns to optimize queries based on feedback from the system. We design a reinforcement learning framework that incorporates a query optimizer agent, which interacts with the database system to learn the optimal query plan. Our experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Healthcare Interactions
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to improve healthcare outcomes by facilitating more empathetic and personalized interactions. However, existing ECAs often neglect the needs of diverse user populations. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive ECAs, incorporating insights from human-centered design and social psychology. We conducted a user study with 30 participants from diverse backgrounds, informing the development of a culturally sensitive and adaptive ECA prototype. Our results demonstrate that our ECA design can increase user trust and satisfaction in healthcare interactions, particularly for underserved populations.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Column-Store Databases using Hybrid Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for big data analytics, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach, 'Colix', which combines the benefits of column-store indexing with those of row-store indexing. Colix adaptively selects the most suitable indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution, reducing query latency by up to 30% compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques. We evaluate Colix on a real-world dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving query performance, scalability, and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Data Warehouses using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of column-store databases for multidimensional data warehousing, query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization that leverages the benefits of column-store indexing. We introduce a cost-based optimizer that takes into account the storage and retrieval patterns of column-store databases, reducing query execution times by up to 30%. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in improving query performance and scalability.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but users with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and pronunciation, often struggle to interact with these systems. This paper presents a novel approach to design inclusive voice assistants that can better understand and respond to users with dysarthria. We conducted a user study with 20 participants to gather speech patterns and develop a customized acoustic model that improves recognition accuracy by 35%. We also designed an adaptive dialogue system that adjusts its response time and feedback based on the user's speech characteristics. Our results show that the proposed approach significantly enhances the user experience and interaction success rate for individuals with dysarthria.

title: Enhancing Query Efficiency in Distributed Search Engines using Latent Semantic Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines have revolutionized the way we retrieve information from large-scale datasets. However, query efficiency remains a significant bottleneck, particularly when dealing with complex queries. This paper proposes an innovative approach to improve query efficiency by incorporating Latent Semantic Indexing (LSI) into distributed search engines. We develop a novel indexing technique that leverages the semantic relationships between terms to reduce the dimensionality of the search space. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that our approach achieves an average query speedup of 3.2x compared to traditional indexing methods, while maintaining a high level of retrieval accuracy.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics in distributed database systems faces significant performance challenges due to dynamic workload and data distribution. This paper presents an adaptive query optimization framework, 'Aurora', that leverages online machine learning and statistical modeling to predict query performance and adjust optimization strategies accordingly. We introduce a novel cost model that incorporates data locality, node heterogeneity, and query complexity factors, enabling Aurora to optimize query plans for improved response time and throughput. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database testbed demonstrate that Aurora outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Explainable Gradient Analysis
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can lead to misclassification and security breaches. Existing detection methods rely on input preprocessing, anomaly detection, or statistical analysis. This paper proposes a novel approach, GradientExplanation (GE), which leverages explainable AI techniques to identify adversarial attacks. GE analyzes the gradient patterns of the target model during inference to detect abnormal behavior indicative of an attack. Our experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that GE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detecting adversarial attacks while maintaining high accuracy on clean data.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Coordination using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments remains a challenging problem in AI research. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture to address this issue. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model agent relationships and hierarchical representations to capture long-range dependencies. Our approach is scalable to large numbers of agents and can be applied to various multi-agent coordination tasks. Experimental results on a series of benchmarks demonstrate HGAT's effectiveness in improving coordination efficiency and task completion rates compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Beliefs using Bayesian Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinating multi-agent systems in the presence of uncertain beliefs. We propose a novel Bayesian learning approach that enables agents to update their beliefs about the environment and other agents' intentions. Our framework, called BayesCoord, uses a probabilistic graphical model to represent the joint distribution of agent beliefs and incorporates a distributed optimization algorithm to maximize the global utility. We evaluate BayesCoord in a simulated robotic soccer domain and demonstrate improved coordination and decision-making compared to traditional planning-based approaches.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing methods rely on simplistic user-item interaction models. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding approach, 'KGExplain', which incorporates semantic relationships between entities to provide more accurate and interpretable recommendations. KGExplain leverages a graph attention mechanism to capture complex dependencies between users, items, and attributes, and integrates a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize recommendation and explanation objectives. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of KGExplain in improving recommendation accuracy and generating coherent explanations.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Persona-Based Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: This paper explores the design of voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted a user study to investigate the effectiveness of persona-based conversational interfaces in enhancing user experience and accessibility. Our results show that older adults prefer interfaces that incorporate personalized personas, leading to increased engagement and reduced cognitive load. We propose a set of design guidelines for developing inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the importance of empathy, simplicity, and customization. Our work contributes to the development of more accessible and user-friendly conversational AI systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis has become a crucial task in natural language processing, but existing methods often struggle to effectively combine multiple modalities, such as text and images. This paper proposes Hierarchical Attention Networks (HAN), a novel deep learning architecture that leverages hierarchical representations to jointly model cross-modal interactions and sentiment cues. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Cognitive Load and Intentionality
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly popular, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the impact of cognitive load on the intentionality of older adults when interacting with voice assistants. We designed an experiment where participants completed tasks with varying levels of complexity while using a custom-built voice assistant. Our results show that older adults experience higher cognitive load when interacting with voice assistants, leading to decreased intentionality. We propose a set of design guidelines to mitigate this effect, including simplifying language, reducing ambiguity, and providing explicit feedback. Our findings have implications for the design of inclusive voice assistants that cater to the needs of older adults.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Decentralized Reinforcement Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Decentralized control of autonomous agents in real-world scenarios often involves partial observability and stochasticity. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating agents using decentralized reinforcement learning (DRL) in partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs). We propose a communication-efficient algorithm, 'DRL-COM', that leverages local observations and intermittent communication to learn effective policies for multi-agent tasks. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the superior performance of DRL-COM compared to centralized and independent-learning baselines, showcasing its potential for real-world applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search query expansion is a crucial step to improve retrieval effectiveness in information retrieval systems. Existing methods rely on handcrafted rules or supervised learning, which can be suboptimal and require extensive labeled data. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning framework, 'RL-QE', which formulates query expansion as a sequential decision-making problem. By leveraging a reward function that balances precision and recall, RL-QE adaptively generates effective expansion terms and outperforms state-of-the-art methods on multiple benchmark datasets. We also investigate the impact of different reward functions and exploration strategies on the query expansion process.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans in distributed graph databases is a challenging problem due to the complex interplay between graph structure, data distribution, and query patterns. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a hierarchical graph representation to learn efficient query plans. Our approach leverages a combination of graph convolutional networks and Q-learning to adapt to changing query workloads and optimize query execution times. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT using Graph-based Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices has led to a surge in sensor data, making real-time anomaly detection a critical task. This paper proposes a novel graph-based attention mechanism, 'GAT-AD', which leverages the complex relationships between IIoT devices to identify anomalies in real-time. Our approach combines graph convolutional networks with attention weights to focus on the most informative device interactions. Experimental results on a large-scale IIoT dataset demonstrate that GAT-AD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and latency, enabling timely interventions to prevent equipment failures and maintain production efficiency.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
