paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex, dynamic environments is a fundamental challenge in artificial intelligence. We propose a novel framework for decentralized decision-making, which leverages partially observable Markov decision processes (POMDPs) to model individual agents' interactions. Our approach, dubbed 'Dec-POMDP-MA', enables agents to reason about incomplete information and coordinate their actions without centralized control. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Dec-POMDP-MA in a simulated disaster response scenario, where multiple agents must navigate uncertain environments to achieve a common goal.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-powered Cybersecurity
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI-powered cybersecurity systems necessitates transparency and interpretability to build trust and identify vulnerabilities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph-based representations to model complex system interactions. By incorporating explainable attention mechanisms, HGAT provides insights into the decision-making process, enabling the identification of critical nodes and edges in the system. We evaluate HGAT on a real-world cyber-attack dataset, demonstrating improved performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art AI-powered cybersecurity systems.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms has led to a growing need for efficient query optimization techniques. Existing approaches often focus on single-tenant databases, neglecting the unique challenges of multi-tenancy. This paper presents a novel, scalable query optimization framework, 'MQO', designed specifically for multi-tenant DBaaS platforms. MQO leverages a combination of machine learning-based workload classification and dynamic resource allocation to minimize query latency and improve overall system throughput. Experimental results on a large-scale, real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate that MQO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 35% in terms of query response time.

title: Query Optimization for Efficient Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in DDS, as it directly affects the performance and efficiency of data retrieval. This paper proposes a novel query optimization technique, 'Distributed Query Rewriter' (DQR), which leverages statistical modeling and machine learning to identify optimal query execution plans. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DQR through extensive experiments on a real-world dataset, showcasing significant improvements in query response times and resource utilization compared to existing query optimization methods.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Cold Start Problem in Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: The cold start problem in recommendation systems occurs when there is insufficient interaction data for new users or items. This paper proposes a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'Hyperion', which combines the strengths of collaborative filtering and natural language processing. Hyperion leverages item embeddings and contextualized user representations to generate personalized recommendations. Our experiments on two real-world datasets demonstrate a significant improvement in recommendation accuracy and diversity compared to state-of-the-art methods. We also show that Hyperion is robust to sparse interactions and outperforms existing cold start solutions.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) approach to coordinate autonomous vehicles in complex urban scenarios. We propose a decentralized framework, 'CoAV', where each vehicle learns to optimize its navigation policy based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Our method integrates a attention-based neural network to model inter-agent relationships and a hierarchical reward function to balance individual and collective objectives. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that CoAV outperforms traditional decentralized control methods in terms of traffic flow and safety.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Learned Index Structures for Real-Time Data Analytics
paper_abstract: The surge in real-time data analytics has rendered traditional query optimization techniques insufficient. This paper presents 'QLearn', a novel framework that leverages learned index structures to accelerate query optimization. By integrating a neural network-based index with a traditional query optimizer, QLearn reduces query latency by up to 70% on real-world datasets. We introduce a novel indexing technique, 'Hist-Index', which adapts to dynamic data distributions and efficiently handles range queries. Experimental results on a popular data analytics benchmark demonstrate QLearn's ability to scale to large datasets while maintaining high performance.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing User Cognitive Load
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have been increasingly used in human-computer interaction to facilitate user engagement and understanding. However, their impact on user cognitive load remains understudied. This paper investigates the effectiveness of ECAs in reducing cognitive load in complex tasks. We conducted a user study with 60 participants, comparing a traditional graphical user interface with an ECA-mediated interface. Our results show that the ECA condition resulted in significantly lower cognitive load, as measured by pupillometry and self-reported metrics. We also found that users' perceived workload and task performance improved with the ECA interface. The findings have implications for the design of cognitive-supportive interfaces in various domains, including education and healthcare.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in modern search engines, aiming to improve retrieval accuracy by reformulating the original query. While traditional QE methods rely on hand-crafted rules or supervised learning, we propose a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize the QE process. Our framework, RLQE, learns to select the most effective expansion terms by interacting with a simulated environment that mimics user behavior. Experimental results on the TREC Web Track dataset demonstrate that RLQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving a 12% increase in mean average precision.

title: Hybrid Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval in Large-Scale Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Recent advancements in neural ranking models have significantly improved the performance of information retrieval systems. However, these models often come with high computational costs, limiting their applicability to large-scale systems. This paper proposes a novel hybrid neural ranking model, 'HNRM', which combines the strengths of traditional term-based retrieval methods with the learning capabilities of neural networks. HNRM leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively integrate term-based features and neural embeddings, enabling efficient and effective document retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that HNRM outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational overhead by up to 40%.

title: Designing Adaptive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments becomes increasingly important. This paper presents a novel approach to gestural interface design, 'GestAlt', which uses machine learning to adapt to individual users' abilities and preferences. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults with mild cognitive impairment, demonstrating that GestAlt significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional gestural interfaces. Our approach has implications for the development of more inclusive and supportive technologies for aging populations.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization with Gaussian Processes
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their complexity makes hyperparameter tuning a daunting task. Bayesian optimization with Gaussian processes has emerged as a promising approach, but its computational cost hinders its applicability to large datasets. This paper proposes an efficient Bayesian optimization method, 'GP-BO+', which leverages a surrogate model to approximate the objective function and adaptively selects the most informative hyperparameter configurations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GP-BO+ on several benchmark datasets, showing significant speedups over existing methods while maintaining competitive performance.

title: Real-time Human-AI Collaboration for Efficient Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on accurate object detection to ensure safety and efficiency. This paper introduces 'Co-Detect', a novel framework that enables real-time human-AI collaboration for object detection. Co-Detect leverages active learning to selectively request human annotations for uncertain or ambiguous objects, thereby improving detection accuracy. We propose a novel uncertainty quantification method, 'U-Net+', which outperforms existing approaches in identifying uncertain regions. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that Co-Detect achieves a 25% reduction in annotation time and a 15% increase in detection accuracy compared to state-of-the-art object detection models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Relation Extraction
paper_abstract: Few-shot relation extraction (FSRE) is a challenging task that requires models to generalize to new relations with limited labeled data. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages graph structure to model complex relationships between entities. HGAT consists of a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global context, and a graph-based meta-learning approach that adapts to new relations. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in FSRE, achieving an average F1-score improvement of 4.5%. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in real-world applications such as knowledge graph construction.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection for Assistive Communication Interfaces
paper_abstract: Individuals with severe motor impairments rely on assistive communication interfaces, such as eye-tracking systems, to express themselves. However, these systems can be prone to errors, leading to frustration and decreased user satisfaction. This paper presents 'GazeCheck', a novel error detection framework that leverages machine learning and computer vision techniques to identify and correct gaze-based errors in real-time. GazeCheck utilizes a combination of gaze features, including fixation duration, blink rate, and pupil size, to detect anomalies and alert the user. Our evaluation with 20 participants shows that GazeCheck reduces error rates by 35% compared to existing systems, while maintaining a high degree of user satisfaction.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Graph Attention Networks for Knowledge Graph Completion
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) are often incomplete, which hinders their applicability in various domains. Entity disambiguation is a crucial step towards KG completion, as it resolves ambiguity in entity references. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) based approach for entity disambiguation, which leverages the graph structure of KGs to capture both local and global context. Our model, 'GAT-ED', outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets, achieving a 12.5% relative improvement in disambiguation accuracy. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of GAT-ED in improving KG completion tasks, such as link prediction and entity classification.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture the nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural embeddings to encode query terms and documents in a shared vector space. Our method, 'NeuroXPand', uses a graph-based neural network to model the relationships between query terms and expand the query with relevant synonyms and related concepts. Experiments on several standard TREC datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for queries with ambiguous or rare terms, compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Query Routing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However,query performance remains a major bottleneck. This paper proposes an adaptive query routing (AQR) framework that dynamically adjusts query routing decisions based on real-time system metrics, such as node utilization and network latency. We present a novel cost model that incorporates query complexity, data locality, and system load, enabling the AQR framework to optimize query execution. Experimental results on a real-world DDS deployment demonstrate significant improvements in query response times and system throughput.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems via Graph-Based Document Clustering
paper_abstract: Distributed Information Retrieval (DIR) systems face the challenge of efficiently processing queries across multiple machines. This paper presents a novel graph-based document clustering approach, termed GraphIR, which reduces the query processing time in DIR systems. GraphIR represents documents as nodes in a graph, where edges denote semantic relationships between documents. By clustering densely connected nodes, GraphIR identifies a set of representative documents that can efficiently answer queries. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate that GraphIR outperforms state-of-the-art clustering methods, reducing query processing time by up to 30% while maintaining retrieval effectiveness.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time-Series Anomaly Detection in IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in time-series sensor data, making anomaly detection a crucial task. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global patterns in IoT sensor data to detect anomalies. Our approach exploits the hierarchical structure of IoT sensors to learn attention weights, which enables the model to focus on the most informative features and timestamps. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness to concept drift.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks to agents. Our approach models the task allocation problem as a hierarchical DCOP, where agents are organized into clusters and sub-clusters to reduce the problem size. We develop a novel algorithm that uses a combination of constraint propagation and local search to find high-quality solutions. Experimental results on a variety of benchmark domains demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinated task allocation in multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'CATRL', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task assignment and execution. Our method leverages a graph neural network to represent agent interactions and a deep Q-network to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that CATRL outperforms traditional auction-based approaches in terms of task completion rate and resource utilization.

title: Designing Accessible Gestural Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing accessible gestural interfaces for individuals with motor disabilities. We propose a machine learning-based framework that learns to recognize and adapt to the unique gesture patterns of users with mobility impairments. Our approach leverages a combination of computer vision and human-computer interaction techniques to enable users to interact with digital systems using intuitive and personalized gestures. We evaluate our approach through a user study with participants with motor disabilities, demonstrating improved accuracy and usability compared to traditional gestural interfaces.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Gamification on User Engagement in Intelligent Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Intelligent virtual assistants (IVAs) have become ubiquitous in modern computing, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the impact of gamification on user interaction with IVAs. We design and implement a gamified IVA system, incorporating elements such as points, badges, and leaderboards. A user study with 100 participants reveals that gamification significantly increases user engagement, task completion rates, and overall satisfaction. We also identify key design factors influencing user behavior, including personalized feedback and social sharing. Our findings have implications for the development of more engaging and effective IVAs in various domains.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Entity Retrieval
paper_abstract: Entity retrieval is a crucial component of many information retrieval systems. However, the performance of these systems is often hindered by the vocabulary mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between entities. Our approach, dubbed NeuroQE, uses a graph-based neural network to learn entity representations and expand queries with relevant terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Decision Support Systems
paper_abstract: Explainability is a critical aspect of AI-driven decision support systems, as it enables trust and accountability in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to provide transparent and interpretable decision-making processes. We evaluate our approach on a real-world credit risk assessment dataset and demonstrate improved performance and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art models. Our results show that HAN can effectively identify relevant features and relationships, leading to more informed decision-making and enhanced trust in AI systems.

title: Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly prevalent, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach, Qurel, that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query execution plans in DDS. We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and train an RL agent to learn an optimal policy that minimizes query latency. Experimental results on a real-world DDS dataset demonstrate that Qurel outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency, while also adapting to changing workload patterns.

title: Unsupervised Query Intent Identification for Domain-Specific Search Engines
paper_abstract: Identifying the intent behind a user's query is crucial for effective search results. While machine learning-based approaches have shown promise, they often rely on labeled datasets, which are expensive to create and domain-specific. This paper proposes an unsupervised query intent identification framework, 'IntentMine', that leverages domain knowledge graphs to categorize queries into fine-grained intent types. We develop a novel graph-based clustering algorithm that captures semantic relationships between queries and entities in the knowledge graph. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset from a domain-specific search engine demonstrate that IntentMine outperforms state-of-the-art methods in intent accuracy and scalability.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-time Data Warehousing with Multi-Dimensional SKYLINES
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, but existing indexing techniques struggle to handle the high-dimensional and dynamic nature of contemporary datasets. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'SkyIndex', which leverages multi-dimensional SKYLINES to efficiently process range queries and aggregations. By exploiting the inherent structure of SKYLINES, SkyIndex achieves superior query performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods. Experimental results on a real-world financial dataset demonstrate that SkyIndex reduces query latency by up to 5x and improves data freshness by up to 3x.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) has become a de facto standard in modern distributed databases. However, query optimization in MVCC systems remains a challenging problem due to the complexities of version management and concurrency control. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCC-Opt', that leverages a probabilistic cost model to efficiently explore the search space of possible query plans. We introduce a set of novel optimization techniques, including version-aware index selection and adaptive sampling, to minimize the overhead of MVCC while maintaining high transactional throughput. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that MVCC-Opt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in MVCC environments.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel approach, 'GraphMA', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn scalable and adaptive task allocation policies. We model the agent-task interaction as a graph, where agents and tasks are nodes, and edges represent feasibility and desirability. Our GNN-based algorithm learns to optimize task assignments based on local and global graph features, outperforming traditional methods in terms of both allocation efficiency and solution quality. Experimental evaluations on various multi-agent scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of GraphMA.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but the impact of embodiment on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating how embodied avatar representations influence user presence, engagement, and cognitive load in VR environments. Our results show that embodied avatars significantly enhance user presence and engagement, but also increase cognitive load due to the added complexity of motor control. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Systematic Evaluation
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-structured data tasks. However, their robustness to adversarial attacks remains largely unexplored. This paper presents a comprehensive evaluation of the vulnerability of GNNs to different types of attacks, including node-level, edge-level, and graph-level perturbations. Our experiments demonstrate that GNNs are susceptible to these attacks, leading to significant performance degradation. We also investigate the effectiveness of various defense strategies, including input preprocessing, graph denoising, and adversarial training. Our results highlight the need for developing more robust GNN models and provide insights for designing effective defense mechanisms.

title: Efficient Query Reformulation using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper introduces CAQE, a novel query reformulation approach that leverages context-aware embeddings to better capture query intent. Our method represents queries as dense vectors that incorporate semantic, syntactic, and pragmatic contextual features. We demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation techniques on several benchmark datasets, achieving improvements of up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Efficient Join Order Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: Join order optimization is a crucial task in relational databases, as it significantly affects query performance. However, existing approaches often fail to consider the unique challenges of distributed databases, leading to suboptimal plans. This paper presents a novel join order optimization algorithm, 'Distributed-JO', which leverages a hybrid of machine learning and dynamic programming to efficiently explore the vast search space of possible join orders. Our approach takes into account data distribution, network latency, and processing power to generate optimal plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database demonstrate that Distributed-JO outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recent advances in graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in recommendation systems. However, most existing methods suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, 'HAT', which leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to reduce the graph size while preserving crucial structural information. We introduce a attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different clusters based on user preferences. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HAT achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 60% compared to existing GNN-based methods.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation for Knowledge Graph Completion using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph completion, but existing methods struggle to scale with large graphs and diverse entity mentions. We propose a novel approach, 'GraphAttentiveDisambig', which leverages graph attention networks to model complex relationships between entities and their mentions. Our method jointly learns entity representations and attention weights, enabling efficient disambiguation of entities in the presence of noisy or ambiguous mentions. Experimental results on large-scale knowledge graphs demonstrate significant improvements in disambiguation accuracy and scalability over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gestural Interfaces for Enhanced Spatial Reasoning
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to improve spatial reasoning skills. We designed a gestural interface, 'SpatialGest', that leverages users' bodily experiences to facilitate 3D spatial problem-solving. In a user study with 30 participants, we found that SpatialGest significantly enhanced spatial reasoning abilities compared to traditional keyboard-and-mouse interfaces. Our findings suggest that embodied cognition can be effectively utilized in VR-based learning environments to improve cognitive skills, with implications for fields such as architecture, engineering, and computer-aided design.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized autonomous agent-based resource allocation framework for multi-agent systems. Our approach leverages game-theoretic mechanisms to facilitate coordination among agents, ensuring efficient allocation of shared resources. We introduce a novel algorithm, 'AgentRA', which utilizes iterative auctions and adaptive learning to optimize resource utilization. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that AgentRA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of fairness, efficiency, and scalability.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Neural Networks with Query-Document Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'QRank', that leverages query-document interaction to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of document ranking in information retrieval. QRank employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture fine-grained semantic relationships between query terms and document passages. We also introduce a novel training objective that combines both pointwise and pairwise losses to optimize ranking performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QRank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Mechanisms for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) has gained popularity with the increasing availability of multimedia data. However, existing MSA models suffer from a lack of interpretability, making it challenging to understand the decision-making process. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention mechanism (HAM) that integrates visual and textual features to generate explainable sentiment predictions. Our approach utilizes a novel attention hierarchy that captures both local and global feature interactions, enabling the model to focus on relevant multimodal cues. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAM outperforms state-of-the-art MSA models in terms of accuracy and provides meaningful visualizations for sentiment explanation.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but its lack of interpretability hinders trust and adoption. This paper presents a novel, model-agnostic explainability framework for DRL, dubbed 'DeepShapley'. By integrating Shapley values with feature importance metrics, DeepShapley quantifies the contribution of individual state features to the agent's policy decisions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepShapley on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing its ability to provide meaningful explanations without sacrificing performance.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Perception in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, it is essential to understand how their embodiment affects social perception. This study explores how people perceive and respond to robots with different levels of embodiment, from abstract avatars to humanoid robots. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment, combining behavioral data with subjective reports, to investigate the impact of embodiment on perceived trustworthiness, likability, and anthropomorphism. Our results show that robots with higher embodiment are perceived as more trustworthy and likable, but also more prone to anthropomorphism. We discuss the implications of these findings for designing robots that effectively interact with humans in various contexts.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, leveraging auction-based mechanisms to efficiently assign tasks to agents in dynamic environments. Our approach, called 'AuctionAgent', enables agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities, preferences, and local contextual information. We introduce a novel bidding strategy that incorporates temporal and spatial constraints, ensuring that tasks are allocated to agents that can complete them effectively. Experimental results demonstrate that AuctionAgent outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rates, agent satisfaction, and communication overhead.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-based Interactions for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents an adaptive gesture-based interaction system designed specifically for older adults with cognitive impairments. We propose a machine learning-based approach that leverages user behavior and cognitive ability to personalize the interaction experience. Our system adaptively adjusts gesture recognition thresholds, feedback mechanisms, and error tolerance to accommodate individual users' needs. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that our approach improves gesture recognition accuracy by 25% and reduces user frustration by 40% compared to traditional gesture-based systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Data Warehouses using Column Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed data warehouses have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in such systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization technique that leverages column store indexing to reduce query latency and improve resource utilization. Our approach, called 'ColOpt', uses a cost-based optimization framework that takes into account the underlying storage layout and data distribution. We evaluate ColOpt on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to traditional row-store indexing approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Language Models for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep neural language models to learn query expansion strategies. We introduce a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query representation, term weighting, and expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art methods, especially for difficult queries with limited relevance feedback.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous task allocation using deep reinforcement learning. We introduce a decentralized framework, 'MARL-TA', where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities, availability, and environmental conditions. Our approach leverages a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture, combining both local and global rewards to optimize task allocation. Experimental results in a simulated warehouse scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods, achieving a 25% increase in overall system efficiency and a 30% reduction in task completion time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Social media platforms exhibit a plethora of modalities, including text, images, and videos. Effective sentiment analysis in such multi-modal environments is crucial for businesses and policymakers. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages both intra-modal and inter-modal attention mechanisms to capture complex contextual relationships across modalities. Experimental results on a large-scale, multi-modal social media dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in sentiment classification, achieving an F1-score improvement of 8.2% over the best baseline.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on distributed databases poses significant scalability challenges due to the complexities of query optimization. This paper presents 'DynaOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution plans and adapt to dynamic workload changes. DynaOpt integrates a graph neural network-based cost estimator with a reinforcement learning-driven plan enumerator, enabling efficient exploration of the plan space. Experimental results on a 100-node distributed database cluster demonstrate that DynaOpt achieves an average speedup of 3.2x over state-of-the-art optimization techniques for real-time analytics workloads.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, but existing methods often struggle with long-range dependencies and high-dimensional data. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages both local and global contextual information. Our HAN model employs a hierarchical structure to capture multi-scale patterns and an attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant input features. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and computational efficiency, making it suitable for real-world applications such as energy demand forecasting and financial prediction.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Context-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various information retrieval tasks. However, they often rely on exact term matching, neglecting the contextual relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'ConEx', which leverages context-aware embeddings to capture the semantic nuances of query terms. Our method adaptively selects expansion terms based on their contextual similarity to the original query, resulting in improved retrieval accuracy and robustness. Experimental evaluations on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of ConEx in enhancing the performance of neural retrieval models.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with digital information. However, designing VR experiences that engage users remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the role of personalization in enhancing user engagement in VR. We conducted a user study involving 50 participants, where we manipulated the level of personalization in a VR environment and measured user engagement using physiological and behavioral metrics. Our results show that personalized VR experiences lead to increased user engagement, but only when personalized elements are relevant to the user's interests. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more engaging VR experiences and highlight areas for future research.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial task in various applications, including question answering, recommendation systems, and natural language processing. However, existing KGE methods often suffer from scalability issues and neglect the hierarchical structure of relations. This paper proposes a novel KGE approach, HERA, which leverages hierarchical relation attention to model complex relationships between entities. By incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism, HERA can capture both local and global dependencies among relations, leading to improved performance on link prediction and entity classification tasks. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of HERA compared to state-of-the-art KGE methods.

title: Multimodal Embodied Interaction for Virtual Reality Healthcare Training
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in healthcare training, but current systems often rely on simplistic controllers, limiting the realism and effectiveness of simulations. We present 'EmbodiVR', a novel multimodal interaction framework that combines hand tracking, voice recognition, and haptic feedback to create a more immersive and engaging experience. Our user study with medical professionals demonstrates significant improvements in procedural accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR training methods. We discuss the implications of EmbodiVR for realistic skill transfer and its potential applications in fields such as surgical training and patient education.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning via Graph-Based Communication
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, coordinating exploration among agents is crucial to achieve efficient learning and avoid redundant exploration. This paper proposes a novel graph-based communication framework, Graph-CoEx, which enables agents to share their exploration experiences and adapt their exploration strategies accordingly. We introduce a graph neural network-based communication module that learns to represent the exploration landscape and facilitates coordination among agents. Experimental results on several multi-agent environments demonstrate that Graph-CoEx significantly improves the learning efficiency and stability compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing requires efficient query optimization to handle large volumes of data. This paper proposes a machine learning-based approach to optimize query performance. We develop a novel query classification model that predicts the optimal execution plan based on query features and historical query patterns. Our approach reduces query latency by up to 30% compared to traditional optimization techniques. We also propose a dynamic re-optimization strategy that adapts to changing data distributions and query workloads. Experimental results on a real-world data warehousing dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving query performance and reducing resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Indexing for Efficient Range Queries in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used in modern applications, but range query processing remains a performance bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical indexing technique, 'HiRI', which partitions the data space into multiple levels of granularity. By leveraging a combination of Bloom filters and space-filling curves, HiRI enables fast and efficient range query processing with reduced network communication overhead. Experimental evaluations on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HiRI outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of data transfer.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Keyword Relationships for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval systems to improve the recall of relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query expansion, where keywords are represented as nodes in a graph and their relationships are captured through edge weights. We introduce a novel scoring function that leverages the graph structure to identify the most relevant expansion terms. Experiment results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of mean average precision and recall.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents inReducing Cognitive Load for Visually Impaired Individuals
paper_abstract: Individuals with visual impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with digital systems. This study investigates the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in alleviating cognitive load for visually impaired users. We designed an ECA-based interface that employs multimodal feedback and evaluated its effectiveness in a usability study with 20 participants. Results show that the ECA-based system significantly reduces cognitive load and improves task completion times compared to traditional screen-reader-based interfaces. We also found that users' perceived satisfaction and confidence in using the system increased with the ECA's presence.

title: Hyperbolic Neural ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Traditional retrieval methods in search engines rely on Euclidean spaces, which struggle to capture complex semantic relationships between documents. This work introduces 'HyperDocRank', a novel neural ranking model that leverages hyperbolic geometry to learn hierarchical representations of documents. By exploiting the properties of hyperbolic spaces, our approach significantly improves retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, especially for long-tail queries. Experimental results on large-scale datasets demonstrate the superiority of HyperDocRank over state-of-the-art methods in terms of both ranking quality and computational cost.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Heterogeneous Processing Units
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of modern database systems has led to a growing need for efficient query optimization techniques. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization that leverages the capabilities of heterogeneous processing units (HPUs) in distributed database systems. Our framework, 'HPU-Opt', utilizes a combination of CPU, GPU, and FPGA accelerators to execute query operators in a manner that minimizes execution time and energy consumption. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HPU-Opt achieves an average speedup of 3.2x over traditional CPU-based query optimization techniques, while reducing energy consumption by up to 45%.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Framework
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have transformed the way people interact with technology, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a multimodal interaction framework, 'ElderVoice', that aims to improve the accessibility and usability of voice assistants for this demographic. Our framework incorporates advanced speech recognition, natural language processing, and computer vision techniques to support a wide range of interaction modalities, including voice, gesture, and gaze-based input. We evaluate ElderVoice through a user study with 30 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Age-Related Differences in Spoken Language Understanding
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their effectiveness can be hindered by age-related differences in spoken language understanding. This study investigates how older adults' speech patterns, cognitive abilities, and technology experience influence their interactions with voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants aged 65-85, using a custom-built voice assistant and a standardized cognitive assessment battery. Our results show that older adults face significant challenges in using voice assistants, particularly due to cognitive decline and technology anxiety. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing the need for adaptive language processing, clear feedback, and user-centered training protocols.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Real-time Data Warehousing using Column-Oriented Storage
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become crucial for businesses to make timely decisions. However, traditional row-oriented storage systems struggle to handle high query volumes, leading to poor performance. This paper proposes a novel column-oriented storage approach, 'ColStar', designed specifically for real-time data warehousing. ColStar leverages a hybrid storage architecture that combines in-memory column stores with disk-based storage, enabling efficient query processing and reducing storage overhead. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that ColStar outperforms traditional row-oriented systems by up to 3x in query response time while maintaining comparable storage efficiency.

title: Query Expansion using Word Embeddings and Pseudo-Relevance Feedback for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems often struggle to capture the nuances of medical terminology, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages word embeddings and pseudo-relevance feedback to improve the accuracy of MIR systems. Our method, MedQE, uses word2vec to generate semantically similar terms for query expansion, and then incorporates pseudo-relevance feedback to re-rank the expanded query terms based on their relevance to the top-ranked documents. Experimental results on the TREC Medical Retrieval dataset demonstrate that MedQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection in Voice-Controlled Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria often rely on voice-controlled interfaces, but these systems can be error-prone, leading to frustration and decreased adoption. We propose a novel approach that leverages gaze-based input to detect errors in voice-controlled interfaces. Our system, 'GazeCorrect', uses machine learning models to analyze the user's gaze patterns and identify instances of incorrect voice recognition. We evaluate GazeCorrect with a group of participants with dysarthria and demonstrate a significant reduction in error rates compared to traditional voice-only interfaces. Our findings have implications for the design of more accessible and usable voice-controlled systems.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Coordination using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinating large numbers of autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a novel distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) framework that enables agents to reason about their local constraints and negotiate with neighboring agents to find a globally optimal solution. Our approach leverages a hierarchical decomposition of the problem space, allowing agents to focus on local optimization while still ensuring global consistency. Experimental results on a logistics domain demonstrate that our DCOP framework outperforms existing coordination methods in terms of scalability and solution quality.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for dynamic task allocation using reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MARL-TA', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task assignment and scheduling in real-time. Our method leverages a combination of centralized and decentralized critics to improve exploration-exploitation trade-offs and handle partial observability. Experimental results on a simulated manufacturing scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA outperforms traditional optimization methods and achieves near-optimal task allocation with reduced communication overhead.

title: Learning to Optimize Neural Network Architectures for Efficient Inference
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach to automate the design of efficient neural networks. However, existing methods often rely on expensive computations and neglect the inference cost of the discovered architectures. This paper proposes a novel NAS framework, 'EffiNAS', which learns to optimize neural network architectures for efficient inference on resource-constrained devices. We introduce a differentiable search space and a novel reward function that incorporates both accuracy and inference cost. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that EffiNAS discovers architectures with improved accuracy and reduced inference cost compared to state-of-the-art NAS methods.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Dynamic Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used to manage large-scale datasets, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a dynamic replication strategy, called 'DynaRep', which adaptively adjusts the replication factor of frequently accessed data fragments based on query patterns and system workload. Our approach leverages graph-based data partitioning and a cost-benefit analysis to optimize data placement and minimize query latency. Experimental results on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate that DynaRep achieves up to 3.5x improvement in query performance compared to traditional static replication schemes.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed search systems are widely used in modern information retrieval applications, but they often suffer from inefficient query processing due to the complexity of user queries. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQR', for query reformulation in distributed search systems. DeepQR employs a hierarchical neural network to learn a semantic representation of user queries and reformulate them into more efficient and effective search queries. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection show that DeepQR significantly improves the retrieval efficiency and effectiveness compared to traditional query reformulation methods.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning: A Multi-Arm Bandit Approach
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. This paper introduces a novel approach to enhancing the robustness of DRL agents against adversarial perturbations. We formulate the problem as a multi-arm bandit (MAB) problem, where the agent must balance exploration of the environment with exploitation of the learned policy. Our proposed algorithm, 'Robust-MAB', adaptively adjusts the exploration rate based on the observed reward distribution, thereby improving the agent's robustness to adversarial attacks. Experimental results on the Atari benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in robustness compared to state-of-the-art DRL methods.

title: Meta-Learning for Adaptive Dialogue Management in Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Conversational AI systems often struggle to adapt to varying user preferences and dialogue contexts. This paper presents a meta-learning approach to dialogue management, where a neural network learns to update its parameters in response to user feedback. Our proposed method, 'AdaDialog', leverages model-agnostic meta-learning to quickly adapt to new dialogue scenarios, achieving improved response quality and user satisfaction. We evaluate AdaDialog on a range of conversational datasets, demonstrating its ability to generalize across different domains and dialogue styles.

title: Efficient Indexing for Temporal Graph Databases with Incremental Updates
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for modeling dynamic relationships in social networks, traffic patterns, and other applications. However, indexing schemes for efficient query processing are still in their infancy. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, called TempoGI, which leverages the temporal locality of graph updates to reduce index maintenance costs. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that TempoGI outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of update throughput.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning with incomplete information is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper proposes a novel decentralized planning framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn coordination strategies among agents. We introduce a probabilistic graph representation to model agent interactions and incomplete information, and develop a GNN-based planner that can reason about probabilistic dependencies between agents. Experimental results on a range of benchmark scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient and scalable planning with incomplete information.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-powered Disease Diagnosis
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in disease diagnosis, but their lack of interpretability hinders trust and adoption in high-stakes medical applications. This paper proposes a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that integrates medical knowledge graphs and electronic health records to provide explainable AI-powered disease diagnosis. HGAT uses attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph neighborhoods and clinical features, generating interpretable disease association graphs and feature importance scores. Experimental results on a large-scale disease diagnosis dataset demonstrate improved accuracy and explainability compared to existing deep learning models.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Incremental Learning on Evolving Graphs
paper_abstract: Real-world graphs, such as social networks and knowledge graphs, are inherently dynamic, with nodes and edges constantly being added or removed. However, most existing graph neural networks (GNNs) are designed for static graphs, and their performance degrades significantly when faced with graph evolution. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that can efficiently adapt to evolving graphs through incremental learning. HGAT uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most relevant nodes and edges, and a meta-learning framework to quickly adapt to new graph structures. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art GNNs in terms of accuracy and efficiency when dealing with graph evolution.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Explainable AI Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) is crucial for trustworthy decision-making in high-stakes applications. However, existing knowledge graph embedding techniques struggle to balance expressiveness and efficiency. This paper proposes 'KG-Xplain', a novel framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms and hierarchical knowledge graph representations to learn compact, interpretable embeddings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that KG-Xplain outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both link prediction accuracy and inference efficiency, while providing transparent insights into AI-driven decision-making processes.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become a crucial component of modern business intelligence, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes an adaptive query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution plans. We develop a novel neural network architecture that incorporates query workload patterns, data distribution, and system resource utilization to optimize query planning. Experimental results on a real-world data warehousing benchmark demonstrate that our approach achieves an average query response time reduction of 32% compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Autonomous Agent Adaptation in Dynamic Environments using Online Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments require adaptation to changing conditions to maintain optimality. This paper presents an online reinforcement learning framework, 'DynaAgent', that enables agents to adapt their policies in real-time. DynaAgent combines model-based and model-free reinforcement learning to balance exploration and exploitation, leveraging a novel uncertainty quantification mechanism to adjust the agent's confidence in its policy. Experimental results in a simulated robotic navigation domain demonstrate DynaAgent's ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions, outperforming traditional offline learning approaches.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on distributed column-stores is crucial for various applications, including IoT and financial trading. However, optimizing queries for such systems is a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel cost-based optimization framework, 'RTOpt', which leverages machine learning models to predict query execution times and adapts to changing workloads. RTOpt incorporates a novel column-store-aware indexing strategy and a distributed query rewriting mechanism to minimize data transfer and reduce latency. Experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset shows that RTOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3x in query response times.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Protein Structure Prediction
paper_abstract: Protein structure prediction is a fundamental problem in bioinformatics, and recent advances in graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results. However, existing methods often neglect the hierarchical nature of protein structures, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based GNN (HAGNN) architecture, which models protein structures as hierarchical graphs and leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant residue-residue interactions. We evaluate HAGNN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in protein structure prediction accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Large-Scale IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing scale and complexity of IoT networks necessitate efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper presents a decentralized agent-based framework, 'IoT-Agent', which leverages autonomous agents to dynamically allocate resources and optimize network performance. IoT-Agent utilizes a distributed negotiation protocol to facilitate agent-to-agent communication, ensuring adaptability to changing network conditions. We evaluate IoT-Agent using a realistic simulation environment, demonstrating improved resource utilization and reduced latency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to provide transparent and trustworthy suggestions. However, most existing approaches suffer from high computational complexity, limiting their applicability to large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages both user and item embeddings to generate accurate and explainable recommendations. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant features at multiple levels of the hierarchy, reducing computational overhead while maintaining performance. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of our approach in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explainability.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatar Customization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding user engagement and interaction is crucial for its adoption. This paper explores the effect of personalized avatar customization on user experience in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 100 participants, offering varying levels of customization options for their avatars. Our results show that users who created personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, self-presence, and enjoyment compared to those with default avatars. We discuss the implications of these findings on VR system design and provide recommendations for incorporating personalized avatar customization in future VR applications.

title: EyeTracking-based Adaptive Difficulty Adjustment for Virtual Reality Games
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) games often struggle to balance difficulty levels, leading to player frustration or boredom. This paper presents 'GazeFit', a novel VR game adaptation system that leverages eye-tracking data to dynamically adjust game difficulty in real-time. We develop a machine learning model that infers player expertise and affective states from eye movement patterns, such as fixation duration and pupil dilation. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that GazeFit improves player engagement, reduces frustration, and enhances overall gaming experience.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical document retrieval is a challenging task due to the ambiguity of medical terms and the complexity of medical concepts. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method using deep neural networks to improve the retrieval performance of medical documents. Our approach leverages a pre-trained language model to generate a set of expansion terms that capture the semantic meaning of the original query. We evaluate our method on a benchmark dataset of medical articles and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Gaze-Based Intent Recognition for Enhanced Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to intent recognition in human-computer interaction using gaze-based interfaces. We propose a multimodal fusion framework that integrates eye-tracking data with machine learning models to accurately predict user intentions. Our approach leverages a deep neural network to learn gaze patterns and contextual cues, enabling the system to differentiate between intentional and unintentional gaze behaviors. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in intent recognition accuracy and user experience compared to traditional keyboard-and-mouse interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network planning framework for multi-agent systems operating in uncertain environments. We extend the traditional HTN framework to incorporate probabilistic uncertainty models for tasks and agents, allowing for more robust and adaptive planning. Our approach utilizes a layered planning architecture, where a high-level planner generates a abstract plan, which is then refined by a low-level planner using sampling-based motion planning. We evaluate our approach on a range of simulated scenarios, demonstrating improved plan success rates and reduced planning times compared to existing methods.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: The increasing demand for real-time business intelligence has led to the development of data warehousing systems that can support low-latency queries. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework for column-store indexed data warehouses, which leverages statistical correlations and frequency-based indexing to reduce query execution times. Our approach, called 'CorIdx', incorporates a cost-based optimizer that dynamically selects the most efficient indexing strategy based on query workload and data distribution. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that CorIdx outperforms traditional row-store indexing by up to 3x in terms of query response time, making it a promising solution for real-time data analytics.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, facial expressions) is a challenging task in AI-powered human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, enabling more accurate and explainable emotion recognition. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that incorporates domain knowledge from psychology and cognitive science. Experimental results on the benchmark IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recognition accuracy and interpretability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Embeddings for Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial technique in information retrieval (IR) to improve the precision of search results. However, existing QE methods often rely on simplistic term-weighting schemes, ignoring the complex semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel QE approach, 'HierExpan', which leverages hierarchical embeddings to capture nuanced term relationships. By integrating HierExpan into a state-of-the-art retrieval system, we demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness on benchmark datasets, outperforming traditional QE methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Ranking Models for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, aiming to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural ranking models to learn the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. By incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism and a contrastive learning objective, DeepQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision on several benchmark datasets. Our approach is particularly effective for short and ambiguous queries, where traditional methods often struggle.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Domain-Specific Search Engines using Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines often struggle with query formulation, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach that leverages pre-trained word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. We introduce a domain-adaptive weighting scheme that incorporates term frequency, co-occurrence, and semantic similarity to generate an optimal set of expansion terms. Experimental results on a dataset of medical literature demonstrate significant improvements in search precision and recall, outperforming existing query expansion techniques. Our approach is particularly effective for domain-specific searches with limited training data.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Query Expansion and Learning to Rank
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in document retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper presents a deep learning approach to query expansion, which learns to generate context-aware expansion terms from a large corpus of text data. We further propose a learning-to-rank framework that integrates the expanded query with a relevance-based ranking model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: In complex task allocation problems, decentralized decision-making is crucial for scalability and robustness. We present a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn effective task assignment strategies. Our approach, called GraphAttention-MARL, uses a graph neural network to model agent interactions and incorporates attention weights to focus on relevant neighbors. We evaluate our method in a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional decentralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Models
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, query optimization in such systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using graph-based models. We represent the database schema as a graph and leverage graph neural networks to learn the query optimization strategy. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and scalability compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Robustness Enhancement of Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Hierarchical Feature Alignment
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly degrade their performance. This paper proposes a novel defense mechanism, Hierarchical Feature Alignment (HFA), to enhance the robustness of DNNs against such attacks. HFA aligns features at multiple scales to detect and correct misaligned representations, thereby improving the model's resilience to adversarial perturbations. Experimental results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that HFA outperforms state-of-the-art defense methods in terms of both accuracy and robustness, while maintaining inference efficiency.

title: Distributed Multi-Agent Planning under Uncertainty using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to distributed multi-agent planning under uncertainty, leveraging deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize agent policies. We introduce a hierarchical framework, 'MA-DRL', that integrates graph neural networks for agent communication and a decentralized actor-critic architecture for policy learning. Our approach enables real-time adaptation to uncertain environments and improves overall team performance in complex scenarios. Experimental results on a robotic search-and-rescue domain demonstrate the effectiveness of MA-DRL in achieving coordinated behavior among agents.

title: Improving Out-of-Distribution Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Adaptive Confidence Thresholding
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks often struggle to generalize to out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs, which can lead to errors in critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to OOD detection based on adaptive confidence thresholding. Our method dynamically adjusts the confidence threshold for each input based on the model's uncertainty estimates, improving detection performance on unseen datasets. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over existing methods, including the popular Mahalanobis distance-based approach.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media platforms has generated an unprecedented volume of data, necessitating real-time analytics to derive timely insights. Distributed database systems (DDS) are well-suited for handling such workloads, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'RTOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cardinality estimation and adaptive join ordering to minimize query latency. Our experiments on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate that RTOpt achieves up to 3.5x improvement in query response time compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
