paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but designing engaging VR experiences remains a significant challenge. This study explores the impact of personalization on user engagement in VR interfaces. We conducted a series of user experiments using a novel VR platform that adaptively adjusts its visual and interactive elements based on users' preferences, goals, and behavioral patterns. Our results show that personalized VR experiences lead to increased user satisfaction, reduced cognitive load, and improved task performance. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of future VR systems and highlight opportunities for further research.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing demands efficient query processing to support timely business decisions. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, called Column-Store Adaptive Indexing (CSAI), which leverages column-store storage and adaptive indexing to optimize query performance. CSAI dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution, resulting in significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that CSAI outperforms traditional row-store and column-store indexing approaches by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Designing Emotional Feedback Loops for Embodied Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) are increasingly used in human-computer interaction, but their emotional intelligence and feedback mechanisms remain limited. This paper proposes an affective resonance model (ARM) that enables ECAs to recognize, adapt to, and respond to users' emotional states in real-time. ARM integrates multimodal sensing (facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals) with machine learning-based affective computing. We evaluate ARM in a user study, demonstrating improved user engagement, emotional understanding, and overall interaction quality. Our findings have implications for the design of empathetic and socially aware ECAs in various applications, such as virtual coaching, mental health support, and customer service.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing complex relationships between data entities. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the vast search space of possible query plans. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a deep Q-network that learns to select optimal query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query performance. Our experiments on real-world graph datasets show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous traffic management. We propose a novel algorithm, 'DMARL-TM', which enables autonomous vehicles to learn cooperative policies for traffic signal control and route optimization. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model complex traffic interactions and incorporates a decentralized trust mechanism to ensure robustness against malicious agents. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that DMARL-TM outperforms traditional traffic management systems in terms of reduced congestion and travel times.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in decentralized multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and preferences need to be assigned tasks in a dynamic environment. We propose a novel reinforcement learning framework, 'Dec-MARTA', which enables agents to learn optimal task allocation policies through decentralized decision-making. Dec-MARTA incorporates a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a deep Q-network to learn task allocation strategies. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that Dec-MARTA outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time and agent satisfaction.

title: Scalable Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Grids
paper_abstract: Efficient indexing of high-dimensional data is crucial for various applications, including similarity search, clustering, and nearest neighbor retrieval. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'HiGrid', which leverages hierarchical grids to partition the data space. By recursively applying a combination of space-filling curves and k-d trees, HiGrid achieves a logarithmic query time complexity and reduces the index size by up to 50% compared to state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the scalability and efficiency of HiGrid for high-dimensional data indexing and querying.

title: Hierarchical Neural Network-Based Anomaly Detection for Multivariate Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series data is a challenging task due to the complexity of relationships between variables. This paper proposes a hierarchical neural network-based approach, 'HiTS', which leverages both local and global patterns in the data to identify anomalies. HiTS consists of multiple levels of neural networks, each processing a subset of variables and their correlations. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HiTS outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and false alarm rate, making it a promising solution for real-time monitoring and decision-making applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture for multi-agent coordination. HGAN learns to represent agent interactions as a hierarchical graph, allowing it to capture both local and global dependencies between agents. We evaluate our approach on a variety of multi-agent scenarios, including traffic management and resource allocation, and demonstrate significant improvements in coordination efficiency and overall system performance compared to existing approaches.

title: Diversified Deep Retrieval for Comprehensive Answer Generation in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models often struggle to provide comprehensive answers due to the inherent limitations of retrieval-based approaches. This paper presents a novel diversified deep retrieval framework, DDR, which leverages multiple retrieval strategies to gather a diverse set of relevant passages. Our approach integrates a question-dependent passage ranking module with a passage aggregation network to generate coherent and comprehensive answers. Experimental results on the ODQA benchmark demonstrate that DDR outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of answer completeness and ROUGE scores, while maintaining comparable performance in terms of answer accuracy.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems for adaptive resource allocation in complex, dynamic environments. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that leverages a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn optimal resource allocation policies. Our approach enables agents to adapt to changing environmental conditions and learn from experience, while a higher-level coordinator optimizes overall system performance. Experimental results in a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate improved resource allocation efficiency and resilience to disturbances compared to traditional, centralized optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Explainable Reasoning for Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) models often struggle to provide interpretable explanations for their predictions. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based approach, called HARE, which generates explainable reasoning graphs for VQA tasks. HARE leverages a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions of the image and relevant words in the question, while simultaneously modeling the relationships between them. Our experiments on the VQA-X dataset demonstrate that HARE outperforms state-of-the-art VQA models in terms of accuracy and provides more interpretable explanations.

title: Dynamic Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Teams using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to dynamic task allocation for heterogeneous multi-agent teams, where agents have varying capabilities and tasks have different requirements. We formulate the problem as a decentralized Markov decision process and propose a reinforcement learning-based solution that enables agents to learn effective task allocation strategies. Our approach, called HeteroTaskRL, uses a graph neural network to represent agent-task relationships and a deep Q-network to learn the optimal allocation policy. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HeteroTaskRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing team compositions.

title: EyeGazeTracker: A Machine Learning Approach to Predicting User Intentions in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces rely on accurate user intention recognition to provide seamless interactions. This paper presents EyeGazeTracker, a machine learning-based approach that leverages eye-tracking data to predict user intentions in VR environments. We propose a novel gaze-based feature extraction method that captures subtle changes in user attention and combines it with a hierarchical classification framework to recognize user intentions. Our evaluation on a large-scale VR dataset demonstrates that EyeGazeTracker outperforms state-of-the-art methods in predicting user intentions, achieving an average accuracy of 92.5%. The proposed approach has significant implications for enhancing user experience in VR applications.

title: Query-aware Document Expansion for Improving Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on effective passage retrieval to identify relevant texts containing the answer. However, existing methods often struggle with queries that contain ambiguous or rare terms. We propose a novel query-aware document expansion approach, 'QADE', which incorporates query semantics into the passage retrieval process. QADE expands the input query using a neural language model, generating a set of semantically similar queries that are then used to re-rank the retrieved passages. Our experiments on the ODQA benchmark demonstrate that QADE significantly improves passage retrieval accuracy, leading to higher answer accuracy and faster convergence in downstream answer extraction models.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel autonomous task allocation framework that leverages distributed reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in decentralized networks. Our approach, called 'DARLA', enables agents to learn from local interactions and adapt to changing system dynamics. We evaluate DARLA on a simulated logistics scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and system efficiency compared to traditional heuristic-based approaches.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: Modern search engines rely heavily on query expansion techniques to improve document retrieval accuracy. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational costs and suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HQE', which leverages both local and global context to selectively expand query terms. We introduce a new relevance-based clustering algorithm that groups semantically similar documents, enabling efficient and effective query expansion. Experimental results on the TREC-2020 dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both precision and recall, while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition for Individuals with Motor Impairments using Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges in using gesture-based interfaces. This paper proposes a personalized gesture recognition framework that leverages transfer learning to adapt to individual differences in motor abilities. We collect a dataset of gestures from individuals with varying levels of motor impairment and employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) to learn domain-invariant features. Our approach achieves a significant improvement in recognition accuracy compared to traditional machine learning methods, with an average increase of 15.2% in F1-score. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework in a case study with individuals with cerebral palsy, highlighting its potential to enhance accessibility in human-computer interaction.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Robotics Using Causal Graphs
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in robotics, but its lack of transparency hinders trust and adaptability in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel Explainable RL (XRL) framework that leverages causal graphs to model the relationships between actions, states, and rewards. We introduce a graph-based attention mechanism that highlights the most critical factors contributing to the agent's decision-making process. Experimental results on a robotic arm platform demonstrate that our XRL approach improves interpretability, robustness, and adaptability in dynamic environments, while maintaining competitive performance with state-of-the-art RL methods.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation (ED) is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to identify the correct entity corresponding to a mention in unstructured text. While traditional approaches rely on hand-crafted features or supervised learning, we propose a hybrid retrieval model that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to improve ED accuracy. Our approach combines a neural retriever with a knowledge graph-based ranking model, which captures both semantic and structural relationships between entities. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our hybrid model outperforms state-of-the-art ED methods, especially in scenarios with limited training data.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with unique capabilities and limitations must collaborate to achieve complex objectives. This paper introduces HATGNN, a novel hierarchical attention graph neural network that leverages agent-task affinity and inter-agent relationships to optimize task allocation. HATGNN consists of a graph encoder that captures agent-task interactions and a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant agents and tasks. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HATGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Neural Networks for Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial step in various natural language processing and artificial intelligence applications. However, entity disambiguation remains a significant challenge in KGE, as it directly affects the accuracy of subsequent tasks. This paper proposes a novel graph-based neural network approach, called GraphED, to tackle entity disambiguation in KGE. GraphED leverages the graph structure of knowledge graphs to learn entity representations that capture both semantic and relational information. We evaluate GraphED on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods in entity disambiguation and KGE tasks.

title: Exploring Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multi-modal emotion recognition has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to effectively fuse and attend to various modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HAMA', which leverages the strengths of both modal-specific and cross-modal attention mechanisms. We demonstrate the efficacy of HAMA on three benchmark datasets, showcasing improved performance over state-of-the-art methods, particularly in scenarios with noisy or missing modalities. Our analysis reveals that HAMA's hierarchical architecture enables more nuanced and context-aware emotion recognition.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Transformers in Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: Recent advancements in transformers have revolutionized natural language processing (NLP). However, their robustness against adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper investigates the vulnerability of transformer-based models to targeted attacks on the input text. We propose a novel method, 'AdvGrid', which leverages a grid-based search to identify the most critical input features and craft perturbations that maximize the attack's impact. Our experiments on popular NLP benchmarks demonstrate that AdvGrid outperforms existing attack methods, highlighting the need for more robust transformer architectures and defense strategies.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies via Multi-Agent Games
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about their reliability. This paper investigates the adversarial robustness of DRL policies in multi-agent scenarios, where agents interact with each other and the environment. We propose a novel framework, 'RoboGame', which utilizes a min-max formulation to train agents that are resilient to adversarial attacks. Our approach leverages the competitive nature of multi-agent games to encourage agents to develop robust policies. Experimental results on several Atari games demonstrate that RoboGame improves the adversarial robustness of DRL policies, while maintaining their performance in nominal environments.

title: Emotional State Inference using Multimodal Fusion for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate emotional state inference is crucial for empathetic human-computer interaction. This paper proposes a novel multimodal fusion framework, 'EmoFuse', which integrates facial expressions, speech patterns, and physiological signals to infer users' emotional states. We design a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the contributions of each modality and adapt to individual differences. Our evaluation on a large, diverse dataset shows that EmoFuse outperforms state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal approaches, achieving a 15% improvement in emotional state recognition accuracy and a 20% reduction in inference latency.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Dynamic Role Assignment
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, dynamic role assignment can significantly improve coordination and adaptability in the face of changing environmental conditions. This paper presents a novel approach to role assignment, using a hybrid of machine learning and optimization techniques. Our algorithm, 'DyRA', leverages graph neural networks to learn role representations and a genetic algorithm to optimize role assignments. We evaluate DyRA in a series of simulations, demonstrating improved system performance and robustness compared to existing role assignment methods. The proposed approach has applications in various domains, including robotics, smart cities, and disaster response.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Incentive Mechanisms for Autonomous Agents
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, autonomous agents may have conflicting interests and require incentives to participate. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that incorporates incentive mechanisms to encourage agents to contribute to the system's overall welfare. We design a hierarchical auction-based mechanism that allocates tasks to agents based on their capabilities and preferences, while also ensuring fairness and system efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of system utility and individual agent satisfaction.

title: Optimizing Query Response Time with Adaptive Index Structures in Cloud-Based Database Systems
paper_abstract: As cloud-based database systems continue to scale, query response time becomes a critical performance bottleneck. This paper presents an adaptive index structure, called 'AIx', which dynamically adjusts to changing query patterns and data distributions. AIx integrates machine learning-based prediction models with traditional B-tree indexing, enabling efficient query routing and minimizing unnecessary index maintenance. Our experimental evaluation on a cloud-based DBMS demonstrates that AIx reduces average query response time by up to 35% compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques, while maintaining comparable storage overhead.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Multi-Arm Bandits
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems suffer from query performance variability due to node heterogeneity, network latency, and data skew. This paper proposes a novel approach to optimize query performance using multi-arm bandits (MAB). We formulate the problem as a MAB problem, where each arm represents a query execution plan, and the reward is the query execution time. Our algorithm, 'DBExplorer', uses epsilon-greedy exploration to balance exploitation and exploration, adapting to changing system conditions. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that DBExplorer outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Column Stores
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and big data has created a pressing need for real-time analytics. Distributed column stores have emerged as a promising solution, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents 'Raptor', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and optimize query plans. Raptor incorporates a cost-based optimizer, a query execution time predictor, and a feedback loop to continuously refine its optimization strategies. Experimental results on a 100-node cluster demonstrate that Raptor reduces query latency by up to 3x compared to existing state-of-the-art optimizers, making it an attractive solution for real-time analytics workloads.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become increasingly popular for various AI applications, but their lack of interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for explainable knowledge graph embeddings. HGAT incorporates multi-scale attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph structures and entities, thereby generating more informative and interpretable embeddings. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving link prediction and entity classification tasks, while providing insights into the graph attention patterns.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification in graph-structured data is a challenging task, especially when dealing with limited labeled nodes. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HATT-GNN) that leverages both local and global structural information. HATT-GNN adaptively selects relevant nodes and their features at multiple scales, allowing it to learn robust node representations from few labeled examples. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HATT-GNN, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in few-shot node classification tasks.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Graph-Based Relevance Modeling
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval rely on handcrafted features and simplistic query-document interactions. This paper proposes a novel neural graph-based relevance model, 'GraphRM', which captures complex relationships between queries, documents, and entities. We design a heterogeneous graph neural network that incorporates entity embeddings, query-document interactions, and document structure to estimate relevance scores. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphRM outperforms state-of-the-art ranking models, particularly in cases involving ambiguous queries and long documents.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to provide interpretable results. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based neural network architecture, 'HANS', which effectively integrates textual, visual, and acoustic features to predict sentiment scores. By introducing a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant modalities and features, HANS achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the attention weights, demonstrating the model's ability to provide explainable insights into the sentiment prediction process.

title: Designing Emotional Intelligence in Conversational Agents: A Study on Human-Agent Interaction
paper_abstract: Conversational agents are increasingly being used in various applications, but their lack of emotional intelligence hinders their ability to understand and respond to human emotions. This paper presents a novel framework for designing emotionally intelligent conversational agents that can recognize, understand, and respond to human emotions in a more empathetic and human-like manner. We conducted a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of our framework and found significant improvements in user satisfaction and perceived emotional understanding. Our results have implications for the design of more empathetic and effective human-agent interaction systems.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Multi-Objective Reward Functions in Smart Cities
paper_abstract: With the increasing complexity of urban systems, there is a growing need for coordination among heterogeneous agents in smart cities. Existing approaches often rely on simplistic reward functions that fail to capture the nuances of real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating agents with multi-objective reward functions, which incorporates both quantitative and qualitative metrics. We leverage a hybrid approach that combines reinforcement learning with constraint programming to optimize agent behavior while satisfying conflicting objectives. Experimental results on a real-world transportation dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving overall system efficiency and reducing congestion.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention for Autonomous Vehicle Route Optimization
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient route planning to minimize travel time and fuel consumption. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'GRAVO', which leverages graph attention mechanisms to optimize route selection. GRAVO consists of a high-level route planner and a low-level motion controller, both trained using reinforcement learning with graph-structured state and action spaces. We demonstrate that GRAVO outperforms traditional HRL methods and graph-based optimization techniques on a realistic urban traffic simulator, achieving a 23% reduction in travel time and 17% reduction in fuel consumption.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention for Cooperative Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation is a challenging problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must collaborate to achieve a common goal. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that incorporates graph attention mechanisms to model inter-agent dependencies. We introduce a decentralized policy that leverages attention weights to focus on relevant agents and tasks, resulting in improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability. Experimental results on a simulated robotic team demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in various scenarios, including dynamic task arrivals and agent failures.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in large-scale multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities must be assigned to tasks with varying requirements. We propose a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) architecture that learns to represent agents and tasks as graph-structured data. The HGNN efficiently captures complex relationships between agents and tasks, enabling scalable and effective task allocation. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of assignment quality and computational efficiency, even with thousands of agents and tasks.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Urban traffic control systems face the challenge of coordinating heterogeneous agents, including autonomous vehicles, traffic signals, and pedestrians. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. We design a multi-agent framework that integrates graph attention networks and Q-learning to learn effective coordination strategies. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate improved traffic efficiency and reduced travel times compared to traditional control methods. Our approach has potential applications in smart city infrastructure and autonomous transportation systems.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Dynamic Task Allocation for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management requires efficient coordination of heterogeneous agents, including traffic lights, surveillance cameras, and vehicles. This paper presents a novel multi-agent system, 'TrafficCoordinator', which dynamically allocates tasks to agents based on real-time traffic patterns and agent capabilities. We propose a hybrid approach combining auction-based task allocation with a graph-based conflict resolution mechanism to minimize traffic congestion and reduce travel times. Experiments on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate that TrafficCoordinator outperforms existing decentralized approaches, achieving a 23% reduction in average travel time and a 15% decrease in congestion.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Interaction for Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems have revolutionized interactive experiences, but existing interaction modalities often rely on explicit user input. This paper presents a novel gaze-based adaptive interaction framework for VR environments, leveraging machine learning and computer vision techniques. Our approach predicts user intentions from gaze patterns and adapts the interaction modality accordingly, enhancing overall user experience and reducing cognitive load. We evaluate our framework through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction efficiency and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems often struggle with efficient data retrieval due to the complexity of querying and indexing large datasets. This paper proposes a novel approach using hierarchical Bloom filters to accelerate data retrieval in distributed database systems. Our method exploits the hierarchical structure of Bloom filters to reduce the number of false positives and minimize the communication overhead between nodes. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing indexing techniques in terms of query latency and throughput.

title: Optimizing Query Execution Plans for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics workloads. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for distributed databases. We design a Markov Decision Process (MDP) framework that models the query optimization problem and uses Q-learning to learn an optimal policy. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Learning Models Against Real-World Noises
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, but the robustness against real-world noises remains largely unexplored. This paper investigates the performance of various deep learning architectures under different types of real-world noises, such as Gaussian noise, speckle noise, and salt-and-pepper noise. We propose a novel evaluation framework, 'NoiseRobust', which simulates real-world noise distributions and evaluates model robustness using a set of metrics. Our experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets reveal that state-of-the-art models are more susceptible to real-world noises than previously thought, and we provide insights into the design of more robust models.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning via Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive results in various domains, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises concerns about its reliability. This paper presents a novel approach to improve the robustness of DRL agents against adversarial perturbations. We leverage meta-learning to learn a robust policy that adapts to different attack scenarios. Our method, called 'Meta-Adv', uses a meta-controller to adjust the exploration-exploitation trade-off during training, leading to improved robustness against unseen attacks. Experimental results on popular benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of Meta-Adv in enhancing the robustness of DRL agents.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: As graph databases continue to grow in scale and complexity, supporting real-time analytics has become a significant challenge. This paper presents 'GraphAce', a novel query optimization framework designed for distributed graph databases. GraphAce leverages a combination of graph summarization, query rewriting, and adaptive caching to minimize latency and improve throughput. Experimental evaluations on a cluster of 16 nodes demonstrate that GraphAce outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 3.5x for complex graph queries, while maintaining high accuracy and scalability.

title: Deep Graph Attention Networks for Node Embedding in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Heterogeneous Information Networks (HINs) comprise diverse node and edge types, making node embedding challenging. We propose a novel Deep Graph Attention Network (DGAT) that leverages attention mechanisms to capture complex node relationships. Our approach adaptively assigns importance scores to neighbors based on their type and proximity, enabling effective node representation learning. Experiments on multiple HIN benchmarks demonstrate that DGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in node classification, clustering, and link prediction tasks.

title: Scalable Hierarchical Clustering for Continuous Data Streams using Online Learning
paper_abstract: Handling continuous data streams in real-time is a significant challenge in many applications, including IoT and financial analytics. This paper presents a novel online hierarchical clustering algorithm, 'StreamHClust', that adapts to evolving data distributions and concept drifts. By leveraging incremental learning and a probabilistic data structure, StreamHClust achieves efficient clustering updates and accurate results even in the presence of noisy data. Our experiments demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of StreamHClust on various synthetic and real-world datasets.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents need to allocate tasks to maximize overall system efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning approach, called HRL-TA, to solve this problem. HRL-TA consists of a high-level task allocation module and a low-level action selection module, which learn to allocate tasks and select actions in a decentralized manner. We evaluate HRL-TA in a simulated logistics scenario, where agents need to allocate tasks to deliver packages to customers. Experimental results show that HRL-TA outperforms traditional decentralized task allocation methods, achieving higher system efficiency and scalability.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Unsupervised Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Document retrieval systems rely on effective query representation to retrieve relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a novel neural query expansion (NQE) approach that leverages unsupervised learning to improve document retrieval performance. Our NQE model learns to generate context-aware query expansions by optimizing a combination of relevance and coherence objectives. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that our approach outperforms traditional query expansion techniques and achieves state-of-the-art performance in unsupervised document retrieval settings.

title: Efficient Graph Neural Networks for Real-time Traffic Prediction
paper_abstract: Accurate and real-time traffic prediction is crucial for intelligent transportation systems. However, existing graph neural network (GNN) approaches suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel GNN architecture, 'TrafficGNN+', which leverages sparse attention mechanisms and knowledge distillation to reduce inference time while maintaining prediction accuracy. We evaluate TrafficGNN+ on three large-scale traffic datasets and demonstrate its ability to predict traffic patterns 15-30 minutes in advance with state-of-the-art accuracy, while being 3-5x faster than existing GNN models.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. Existing approaches often rely on centralized optimization or iterative negotiation, which can be computationally expensive and prone to communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAT) architecture that learns to allocate tasks in a decentralized, parallelized manner. HAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agent capabilities, task requirements, and environmental context. Experimental evaluations on a range of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that HAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of allocation efficiency, adaptability, and scalability.

title: Designing Accessible Multimodal Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, it is essential to design accessible interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a multimodal interface framework that combines speech, gesture, and tactile input to facilitate intuitive interaction. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults with mild cognitive impairment, evaluating the effectiveness of our framework in comparison to traditional unimodal interfaces. Results show significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and user satisfaction. We also provide guidelines for interface designers to create accessible multimodal systems for this demographic.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval that aims to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using deep semantic word embeddings. We propose a neural network-based model that learns to capture the semantic relationships between words and expands the query with relevant terms. Our approach is shown to outperform traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in handling ambiguous queries and improving the retrieval of relevant documents.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval in Domain-specific Search
paper_abstract: Domain-specific search engines often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the limited query context and vocabulary mismatch. This paper proposes a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE-DSS', which leverages domain knowledge graphs and contextualized language models to generate more informative and diverse query representations. Our experiments on a medical search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, outperforming traditional query expansion methods and state-of-the-art neural ranking models. We also analyze the effectiveness of NQE-DSS in reducing the vocabulary gap between users and domain-specific documents.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly pervasive, human-robot collaboration in VR environments is gaining importance. This paper investigates the role of embodiment in facilitating effective collaboration between humans and robots in VR. We designed a user study where participants interacted with a robot in a virtual assembly task, and manipulated the level of embodiment using different virtual avatar representations. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to improved task performance, higher trust, and reduced communication errors. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future human-robot collaboration systems in VR.

title: Designing Assistive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Upper Limb Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with upper limb impairments face significant challenges when interacting with digital systems. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface designed to provide assistive capabilities for individuals with limited hand dexterity. Our system, 'EasyReach', utilizes a machine learning-based gesture recognition approach that can detect and classify a set of 12 predefined gestures, including grasping, pointing, and manipulation actions. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that EasyReach significantly improved interaction accuracy and reduced fatigue compared to traditional mouse-based interfaces.

title: Efficient Indexing for Non-Volatile Memory-Based Column Stores
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of non-volatile memory (NVM) in modern storage systems has led to a surge in column-store databases. However, existing indexing techniques are inadequate for NVM-based column stores, resulting in poor query performance. This paper presents 'NVMI', a novel indexing framework that leverages the unique characteristics of NVM to optimize query execution. We propose a hybrid indexing approach that combines a cache-friendly layout with a novel compression scheme, achieving an average query speedup of 3.2x over state-of-the-art indexing methods. Experimental results on a real-world analytical workload demonstrate the efficacy of NVMI in reducing query latency and improving overall system performance.

title: Hybrid Agent-Based Framework for Real-Time Traffic Prediction and Route Optimization
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic prediction and route optimization are crucial for intelligent transportation systems. This paper proposes a hybrid agent-based framework that integrates machine learning, graph theory, and multi-agent systems to predict traffic patterns and optimize routes. Our framework consists of two types of agents: traffic predictor agents that utilize graph convolutional networks to forecast traffic flow, and route optimizer agents that employ ant colony optimization to find the shortest paths. Experimental results on a real-world traffic dataset demonstrate that our framework outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and route optimization efficiency.

title: Scalable Explainable Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance on various graph-based tasks, but their black-box nature hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper presents a novel graph attention mechanism, 'ExplainGAT', which incorporates attention weights as a proxy for feature importance. We introduce a scalable sampling-based approach to compute attention weights, enabling ExplainGAT to handle large-scale graphs. Experimental results on multiple node classification benchmarks demonstrate that ExplainGAT not only achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art GNNs but also provides meaningful explanations for its predictions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Fusion in Human-Robot Collaboration
paper_abstract: Human-robot collaboration (HRC) demands effective multimodal fusion to comprehend human intent and adapt to dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for HRC, which integrates visual, auditory, and linguistic cues to enable explainable decision-making. Our HAN model comprises modular attention mechanisms that selectively weight and combine modalities, facilitating interpretable fusion and improved task performance. We demonstrate the efficacy of our approach on a real-world HRC dataset, showcasing enhanced collaboration and trust between humans and robots.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed relational database systems (DRDBS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization in DRDBS remains a challenging task due to the complexity of optimizing queries across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel query optimization algorithm, 'DROPS', which leverages a combination of machine learning and graph-based methods to efficiently optimize queries in DRDBS. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DROPS outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in query execution time.

title: investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized the way we interact with digital information, but personalized experiences are still in their infancy. This paper explores the effect of personalization on user engagement in VR environments. We designed and conducted a user study with 120 participants, exposing them to either a personalized or non-personalized VR experience. Our results show that personalized experiences lead to increased user satisfaction, reduced cognitive load, and higher engagement levels. We also identify key factors influencing personalization effectiveness, including user demographics and task complexity. Our findings have significant implications for the development of personalized VR applications.

title: Scalable Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Object Detection
paper_abstract: Object detection is a fundamental task in computer vision, but the high computational cost of modern detectors hinders their widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) method, 'EffiDet', which automatically discovers efficient object detection models. We introduce a hierarchical search space that leverages knowledge distillation and a novel 'resource-aware' loss function to optimize both accuracy and computational efficiency. Experimental results on the COCO dataset demonstrate that EffiDet achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing inference time by up to 3.5x compared to existing models.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems (MMDBs) have emerged as a promising solution for high-performance data processing. However, their indexing mechanisms often struggle to keep pace with the rapid growth of data volumes and changing query patterns. This paper presents 'AdaptaIndex', a novel indexing framework that dynamically adjusts to the workload and data characteristics of MMDBs. AdaptaIndex leverages machine learning-based cost models to select the most effective indexing strategy, and incorporates a hierarchical indexing structure to minimize memory overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that AdaptaIndex achieves significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art indexing techniques in MMDBs, while ensuring efficient memory utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Swarm Intelligence
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework inspired by swarm intelligence, where agents self-organize to optimize task assignments. Our approach leverages a distributed auction mechanism, where agents bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences. We introduce a novel pheromone-based communication protocol that enables agents to adapt to changing task demands and environmental conditions. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that our framework outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Indexing Techniques for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query processing in these systems remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'GraphIndex', which leverages the structural properties of graphs to accelerate query execution. GraphIndex employs a hierarchical indexing scheme that combines vertex-centric and edge-centric indexing, enabling efficient query processing and minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that GraphIndex outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search has recently gained popularity due to its ability to capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, it often struggles with vocabulary mismatch and lacks robustness to out-of-vocabulary terms. This paper proposes Contrastive Query Expansion (CQE), a novel method that leverages contrastive learning to generate semantically coherent and diverse query expansions. CQE learns to identify relevant terms by contrasting positive and negative samples, and then uses these terms to expand the original query. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CQE improves the retrieval performance of neural search models by up to 15%, while reducing the computational overhead by 30% compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Enhanced Query Reformulation using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval poses significant challenges due to the complexity of user queries and the need for effective query reformulation. This paper presents a novel approach, DeepQR, which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn an optimal query reformulation policy. By modeling the retrieval process as a Markov decision process, we train an agent to reformulate queries based on user feedback and relevance signals. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that DeepQR outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation is a crucial aspect of cooperation and decision-making. However, incomplete information about other agents' preferences and intentions can lead to suboptimal outcomes. This paper presents a novel autonomous negotiation strategy, ' InfoNegotiator', which utilizes partial observability and probabilistic reasoning to adapt to uncertain environments. We introduce a hierarchical Bayesian framework that integrates opponent modeling, preference elicitation, and strategy selection. Experimental results on a simulated supply chain management scenario demonstrate that InfoNegotiator outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of negotiation efficiency and outcome quality.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of multimodal feedback in Virtual Reality-based Gesture Recognition Systems
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but effective gesture recognition remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the role of multimodal feedback in enhancing user performance and experience in VR-based gesture recognition systems. We designed an experiment that compared three types of feedback  visual, haptic, and auditory  and examined their impact on gesture recognition accuracy, user satisfaction, and cognitive workload. Our results show that multimodal feedback significantly improves recognition accuracy and user experience, with haptic feedback being the most effective. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR-based gesture recognition systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Dynamic Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) systems struggle to retrieve relevant documents for complex queries due to the term mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel dynamic query expansion (DQE) approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to adaptively select expansion terms. Our method, RL-DQE, uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy that balances the trade-off between query representation and document relevance. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc benchmark show that RL-DQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art DQE methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Zero-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) for ZSL, which enables explainable predictions by highlighting the most relevant semantic features. Our HAN model consists of two attention modules: a semantic attention module that learns to attend to relevant class semantics, and a visual attention module that focuses on discriminative regions in the input image. We evaluate our approach on three benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art ZSL methods in terms of both accuracy and explainability.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages auction-based mechanisms to facilitate agent-to-agent negotiation. Our approach, dubbed 'AuctionMA', incorporates a novel bidding strategy that considers both task priority and agent capabilities. We prove that AuctionMA converges to an optimal allocation in polynomial time and demonstrate its effectiveness in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario. Experimental results show that AuctionMA outperforms existing decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and resource utilization.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HTA', which enables agents to learn coordinated task allocation strategies. HTA consists of a high-level coordinator that assigns tasks to agents based on their capabilities and a low-level reinforcement learning module that adapts to changing environmental conditions. We evaluate HTA on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system efficiency compared to decentralized and centralized baselines.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in various information retrieval tasks, but often suffer from limited query representation capacity. This paper proposes an adaptive query expansion framework, 'AQE-CL', that leverages contrastive learning to learn informative query augmentation strategies. AQE-CL generates synthetic queries by perturbing the original query using a learned noise distribution, and then fine-tunes the neural search model using a contrastive objective. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AQE-CL significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural search engines, particularly for rare and long-tail queries.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Unknown Attacks in Deep Learning Models
paper_abstract: Deep learning models are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance in critical applications. Existing defense methods focus on known attack types, but unknown attacks can still cause significant damage. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'ATAK', which leverages a generative model to simulate unknown attacks and augment the training dataset. We demonstrate that ATAK improves the robustness of deep neural networks against a wide range of unknown attacks, including those generated by state-of-the-art attack algorithms. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets show that ATAK achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of robustness and accuracy.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional document filtering methods in information retrieval often rely on hand-crafted features and shallow learning models, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a deep neural network-based approach, 'DeepFilter', which learns hierarchical representations of documents and queries to improve filtering accuracy. Our model leverages pre-trained language models and incorporates query-document interaction mechanisms to capture nuanced semantic relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepFilter outperforms state-of-the-art filtering methods, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multimodal retrieval has gained significant attention in recent years, but it remains a challenging task due to the complexity of representing and matching diverse multimedia data types. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages the strengths of deep neural networks to improve the effectiveness of multimodal retrieval. Our method, called 'DeepQE', uses a multi-task learning framework to jointly learn query representations, document representations, and a similarity metric. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset show that DeepQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving an average improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Knowledge Graph Completion
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph completion is a fundamental task in AI, aiming to infer missing relationships between entities. Existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework, which leverages attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant graph structures. By recursively applying graph attention and graph convolutional layers, HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing computational costs by up to 30%. We also provide theoretical guarantees on the approximation error and convergence of HGAT.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Retrieval of Short Text Documents using Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval for improving the retrieval performance of short text documents. However, existing methods often suffer from the problem of semantic drift, where the expanded queries deviate from the original query intent. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages word embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between words. Our approach uses a graph-based algorithm to select the most relevant expansion terms, which are then weighted using a probabilistic framework. Experimental results on several short text datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in terms of retrieval accuracy and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Resource Availability
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task planning in multi-agent systems where resource availability is uncertain. We propose a hierarchical task network planning framework that integrates a probabilistic resource model with a planning-as-satisfiability approach. The framework allows agents to reason about resource uncertainty and adapt to changing availability during plan execution. Experimental results on a logistics domain demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of plan success rate and resource utilization. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the framework's computational complexity and completeness.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence, particularly in scenarios where agents have conflicting goals or limited communication. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems, where a high-level controller learns to issue tasks to agents, and each agent learns to execute tasks using a local reinforcement learning policy. We introduce a novel task allocation mechanism that considers the capabilities and preferences of each agent, and demonstrate its effectiveness in a simulated disaster response scenario. Experimental results show that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems require efficient planning and coordination to achieve complex tasks. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network (HTN) planning framework for cooperative multi-agent systems. Our approach leverages a hierarchical decomposition of tasks into subtrees, enabling agents to reason about both local and global objectives. We introduce a distributed planning algorithm that enables agents to negotiate and adapt their plans in response to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of our approach in a variety of cooperative task scenarios, including robotic search and rescue and autonomous vehicle coordination.

title: Proximity-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from vast, geographically dispersed collections. This paper presents a novel proximity-aware query expansion approach that leverages semantic relationships between query terms to improve document retrieval. We propose a two-stage framework, where the first stage generates a set of expanded query terms using a graph-based method, and the second stage employs a proximity-aware ranking model to prioritize documents based on their relevance and geographical proximity to the user. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and precision compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short Text Retrieval using Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Short text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval due to the limited context and ambiguity of query terms. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between words. Our method, called EmbedEx, uses a graph-based algorithm to select expansion terms that are most similar to the original query terms. We evaluate EmbedEx on several short text datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion techniques. Furthermore, we show that EmbedEx is particularly effective for queries with limited context, such as those encountered in microblog search.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Multimodal Brain-Computer Interfaces
paper_abstract: Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) have revolutionized assistive technology, but their efficiency is often hindered by inadequate visualization of neural signals. This paper introduces 'NeuroVista', a novel multimodal visualization framework that adaptively adjusts to the user's brain activity, cognitive load, and feedback preferences. Our approach combines electroencephalography (EEG) and functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) signals to provide a more comprehensive understanding of user intent. We evaluate NeuroVista through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in BCI accuracy, user satisfaction, and cognitive workload reduction.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Graph-Based Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Graph-based recommendation systems have shown promising performance in capturing complex relationships between users and items. However, the lack of transparency in these models hinders their adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates graph attention and self-attention mechanisms to provide explanations for the recommended items. Our approach, called GraphExplain, leverages the graph structure to identify key users and items that influence the recommendation process. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphExplain not only improves recommendation accuracy but also provides meaningful explanations for the recommended items, enhancing the trustworthiness of the system.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Query Expansion for Passage Retrieval in Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to retrieve relevant passages in response to user queries. However, the effectiveness of these systems is often hindered by the limited context and ambiguity of user queries. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based query expansion approach, 'QLEx', that leverages pre-trained language models to generate context-aware, semantically enriched queries. We evaluate QLEx on several conversational search datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in passage retrieval precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Individuals with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Individuals with dyslexia often face barriers when interacting with conversational interfaces, such as chatbots and voice assistants. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create more inclusive conversational interfaces for individuals with dyslexia. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving surveys, interviews, and usability testing to identify the needs and preferences of individuals with dyslexia. Our findings inform the design of a novel conversational interface that incorporates assistive features, such as text-to-speech, font customization, and error tolerance. Our evaluation shows that the designed interface improves the interaction experience and reduces errors for individuals with dyslexia, highlighting the importance of inclusive design in HCI.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of virtual reality (VR) in education has led to a growing interest in understanding its impact on user engagement. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and learning outcomes in VR-based learning environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, randomly assigning them to either a personalized avatar or a generic avatar condition. Our results show that participants in the personalized avatar condition reported higher levels of presence, enjoyment, and motivation, leading to improved learning outcomes. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR-based educational systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Autonomous Agents with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, coalition formation is crucial for achieving common goals. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often have incomplete information about each other's capabilities and preferences. This paper introduces a decentralized coalition formation algorithm, 'DICA', which leverages Bayesian learning and distributed constraint optimization to facilitate coalition formation among autonomous agents with incomplete information. We prove the convergence of DICA to a stable coalition structure and demonstrate its efficacy in a simulated disaster response scenario. Our results show that DICA outperforms existing centralized approaches in terms of coalition quality and robustness to incomplete information.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Hierarchical Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized the design of deep neural networks, but its computational cost remains a major bottleneck. This paper presents a novel hierarchical Bayesian optimization (HBO) framework for efficient NAS. By modeling the search space as a hierarchical graph, our approach reduces the number of evaluations required to find high-performing architectures. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HBO-NAS on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results while reducing the search time by up to 75% compared to existing methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents to optimize traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to train a multi-agent system for autonomous traffic management. Our approach, 'TrafficCoor', utilizes a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) framework to model the interactions between agents. We employ a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture that combines a high-level coordinator with low-level agent controllers. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate that TrafficCoor significantly reduces travel time and increases traffic flow compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Our method, called 'MATRL', leverages a decentralized DRL framework to enable agents to learn task allocation strategies in a scalable and flexible manner. We evaluate MATRL in a variety of simulated environments and demonstrate its ability to outperform traditional heuristic-based approaches in terms of task completion time and resource utilization. The results suggest that MATRL has significant potential for real-world applications in areas such as robotic swarm control and smart manufacturing.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Conversational Strategies for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their usability for users with disabilities remains a significant concern. This paper investigates the impact of conversational strategies on the accessibility of voice assistants for individuals with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a series of user studies to identify design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants, including the use of multimodal feedback, adaptive dialogue management, and personalized assistance. Our findings highlight the importance of considering disability-specific needs in voice assistant design and provide a framework for creating more inclusive conversational interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal inputs remains a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of modalities. We propose a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, HiCMER, which leverages both intra-modal and inter-modal relationships to learn robust and discriminative representations. Our approach consists of a hierarchical structure that progressively refines the feature representations, and a contrastive loss function that encourages the model to capture both local and global patterns. Experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HiCMER in achieving state-of-the-art performance on multimodal emotion recognition tasks.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph-based Anomaly Detection in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been increasingly vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can manipulate model predictions. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks using graph-based anomaly detection. We represent the neural network's activation patterns as a graph and identify anomalies in the graph structure. Our method, 'GraphGuard', leverages graph convolutional networks to learn a robust representation of the graph and detect deviations from the expected behavior. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphGuard in detecting adversarial attacks, outperforming existing methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness.

title: Designing Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Voice-Controlled Smart Home Systems
paper_abstract: This study investigates the design of conversational interfaces for older adults using voice-controlled smart home systems. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, exploring their needs, preferences, and challenges when interacting with voice assistants. Our findings highlight the importance of designing interfaces that accommodate age-related cognitive and physical declines. We propose a set of design guidelines and recommendations for developing more accessible and usable voice-controlled systems, including the use of clear and concise language, intuitive voice commands, and visual feedback mechanisms. Our work contributes to the development of more inclusive and supportive smart home technologies for older adults.

title: Deep Neural Ranking Models for Session-based Query Suggestion
paper_abstract: Session-based query suggestion aims to recommend relevant queries to users based on their search history. Existing methods rely on traditional collaborative filtering or Markov chain-based models, which struggle to capture complex user behavior. We propose a novel deep neural ranking model, SessionRNN, which leverages recurrent neural networks to model user search sessions and generates personalized query suggestions.
