Our experiments on a large-scale search log dataset demonstrate that SessionRNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of query suggestion accuracy and diversity.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Conventional neural ranking models for document retrieval suffer from high computational complexity and limited scalability. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HiRank', which leverages a coarse-to-fine ranking strategy to reduce the number of documents required for relevance scoring. HiRank employs a two-stage architecture, consisting of a lightweight filter network and a more accurate ranker network, to efficiently identify relevant documents. Our experiments on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that HiRank achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the computational cost by up to 75% compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Hierarchical Graph-Based Encoding
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising paradigm for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing NAS methods often rely on complex, computationally expensive search algorithms. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph-based encoding (HG-Encode) for efficient NAS. By representing neural architectures as hierarchical graphs, we can leverage graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a compact, discrete encoding space. Experimental results on popular NAS benchmarks demonstrate that HG-Encode achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing search time by up to 75% compared to existing methods.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph Attention Networks for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: As autonomous vehicles (AVs) increasingly rely on AI-driven perception systems, they become vulnerable to adversarial attacks. This paper presents a novel approach to detect such attacks using graph attention networks (GATs). We propose a GAT-based architecture that learns to identify suspicious patterns in AV sensor data, leveraging the graph structure of the sensor interactions. Our experiments on a large-scale AV dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a 25% improvement in attack detection accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods. We further analyze the interpretability of our model, providing insights into the most critical sensors and features contributing to attack detection.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with gesture-based interfaces. This paper presents a novel approach to designing accessible gesture recognition systems that adapt to the unique abilities of users with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning-based framework that leverages electromyography (EMG) signals to recognize gestures, and introduces a personalized gesture set selection algorithm to improve recognition accuracy. Our user study with 15 participants with motor impairments demonstrates that our approach significantly outperforms existing gesture recognition systems, enabling more accurate and efficient interaction.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of transparency in learned policies hinders trust and understanding. This paper introduces 'RL-Explain', a novel framework that leverages model-agnostic explanations to provide insights into DRL policies. We propose a hierarchical attribution method that decomposes policy decisions into feature importance and temporal relevance, enabling the identification of critical state features and action sequences. Our experiments on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate that RL-Explain improves policy interpretability without sacrificing performance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown promising results in node classification tasks, but their black-box nature hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to provide interpretable node representations. Our approach learns to recursively aggregate node features while highlighting the most informative neighbors, resulting in improved classification performance and explainability. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in classifying nodes with complex dependencies.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems often rely on complex models that are difficult to interpret, making it challenging to understand their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that incorporates interpretable attention mechanisms to identify influential users and items in the recommendation process. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to provide transparent and personalized recommendations while achieving state-of-the-art performance. Our results show that HGAT outperforms existing graph-based methods, and its interpretability facilitates the identification of biases and errors in the system.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Conversational Search Systems
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to facilitate more natural and interactive search experiences. However, accurately interpreting user queries remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel deep learning approach, 'ConvRef', to reformulate ambiguous or incomplete queries. Our method leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture contextual dependencies between query terms and incorporates a reinforcement learning component to optimize the reformulation process. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational search dataset demonstrate that ConvRef outperforms state-of-the-art query reformulation techniques, leading to improved search result relevance and user satisfaction.

title: Efficient Document Representation Learning for Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) is a key task in natural language processing, requiring accurate document representation to identify sentiment-bearing aspects. This paper proposes a novel document representation learning framework, 'AspectRep', which leverages a multi-task learning strategy to jointly optimize aspect extraction and sentiment classification. We introduce a hierarchical graph attention mechanism that captures complex document structures and aspect relationships. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that AspectRep outperforms state-of-the-art ABSA models, achieving significant improvements in aspect extraction and sentiment accuracy.

title: Designing Personalized Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing personalized gesture recognition systems for individuals with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning framework that leverages a combination of computer vision and sensor data to recognize gestures, and incorporates a user-centered design approach to accommodate individual differences in motor abilities. Our system, called 'GestureFit', uses a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group users based on their gesture patterns, and adapts the recognition model to each user's unique characteristics. We evaluate GestureFit with a user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments, and demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy compared to existing systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalized Accent Recognition for Individuals with Speech Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but individuals with speech impairments often face difficulties interacting with these systems. This paper presents a novel approach to personalized accent recognition for voice assistants, focusing on users with cerebral palsy and Down syndrome. Our proposed framework, 'AccentAdapt', integrates a deep learning-based accent recognition model with a user profiling system, enabling the voice assistant to adapt to individual speech patterns. A user study with 30 participants reveals significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction using AccentAdapt, demonstrating the potential for more inclusive voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities must collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper introduces HAGNET, a novel hierarchical attentional graph neural network architecture for efficient task allocation. HAGNET learns to represent agents, tasks, and their relationships as a hierarchical graph, and uses attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant information when making allocation decisions. Experimental results on a range of synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate that HAGNET outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, latency, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Efficient Indexing of Temporal Graphs for Query Optimization
paper_abstract: Temporal graphs have become increasingly important in various applications, including social network analysis and recommendation systems. However, querying temporal graphs efficiently remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'TGIX', which leverages the temporal and structural properties of these graphs. TGIX employs a hybrid indexing approach that combines a temporal-partitioned graph index with a novel graph-structured Bloom filter. Our experiments on several real-world datasets demonstrate that TGIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Stores Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Modern data analytics relies heavily on distributed column-stores, which pose significant challenges in query optimization. This paper proposes a novel approach to scalable query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design a hierarchical RL framework that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database and observing execution costs. Our approach adapts to changing data distributions and query patterns, achieving significant improvements in query performance compared to traditional rule-based optimizers. Experiments on a distributed column-store demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in reducing query latency and improving system throughput.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Aggregate Queries in Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Column-store databases have become increasingly popular for analytical workloads, but their indexing mechanisms often fail to efficiently support real-time aggregate queries. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'RapidAgg', which leverages a combination of bitmapped indexing, late materialization, and adaptive sampling to accelerate aggregate queries. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RapidAgg outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 5x, while ensuring low storage overhead and minimal maintenance costs.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalized Error Recovery for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interaction designs often neglect the needs of users with disabilities. This paper investigates the impact of personalized error recovery strategies on the user experience of individuals with visual, hearing, motor, or cognitive impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, combining quantitative data from usability testing with qualitative insights from interviews and surveys. Our findings suggest that adaptive error handling can significantly reduce frustration and improve overall satisfaction among users with disabilities. We propose a set of design guidelines for inclusive voice assistants and discuss the implications for future research in HCI.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, efficient resource allocation is crucial for optimal system performance. This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating heterogeneous agents using reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'Agent Harmony', leverages a decentralized, multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to optimize resource allocation in real-time. Experimental results demonstrate that Agent Harmony outperforms traditional, manually designed allocation rules in terms of system throughput and fairness, while adapting to changing environmental conditions.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it can significantly improve the accuracy of search results. However, traditional query expansion techniques are often limited by their inability to capture complex semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Query Expansion (HQE) framework that leverages deep neural networks to learn hierarchical representations of query terms. Our approach outperforms traditional query expansion methods on several benchmark datasets, achieving a mean average precision increase of 12.5%. We also demonstrate the efficiency of HQE in reducing the number of query iterations required for optimal results.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Hash-Based Indexing on Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in data integration, but its scalability is limited by the growth of large-scale databases. We propose 'HashED', a novel indexing approach that leverages hash-based partitioning to efficiently disambiguate entities across distributed databases. By exploiting the properties of hash functions, HashED reduces the number of comparisons required for entity matching, leading to significant performance improvements. Our evaluation on a real-world dataset shows that HashED outperforms existing approaches by up to 3x in terms of query response time, while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval tasks require effective document ranking methods to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Traditional methods rely on handcrafted features and term-matching techniques, which often fail to capture complex query semantics. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'NQG-Rank', which leverages query graphs to model intricate relationships between query terms. Our approach represents queries as graphs, where nodes correspond to terms and edges capture their contextual dependencies. We then employ a graph neural network to learn a continuous representation of the query graph, which is used to rank documents based on their relevance. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQG-Rank outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Efficient Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Object detection is a critical task in autonomous vehicles, requiring accurate and efficient processing of visual data. This paper introduces HANet, a novel hierarchical attention network that selectively focuses on relevant regions of interest in images. We leverage a multi-scale feature fusion strategy to improve detection accuracy, particularly for small objects. Experimental results on the KITTI dataset demonstrate that HANet outperforms state-of-the-art object detectors while reducing computational overhead by 30%. This makes HANet a promising solution for real-time object detection in autonomous vehicles.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Older adults with motor impairments face significant challenges interacting with technology, leading to social isolation and decreased quality of life. This paper presents a novel adaptive gesture recognition system, 'EasyGesture', designed to accommodate varying levels of motor ability. EasyGesture uses a hierarchical machine learning approach, combining computer vision and inertial sensor data to recognize gestures. The system adaptively adjusts its recognition threshold and provides real-time feedback to users, enabling accurate gesture recognition despite motor impairments. A user study with 30 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical_dense Passage Embeddings
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) has witnessed significant progress with the advent of dense passage retrieval (DPR) models. However, these models are computationally expensive and require large-scale indexing infrastructure. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense passage embedding (HDPE) approach that leverages a hierarchical clustering-based indexing strategy to reduce the retrieval complexity. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDPE achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art DPR models while reducing the inference time by 3.5x. We further analyze the effectiveness of HDPE in various ODQA scenarios, including cross-domain and few-shot settings.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Modal Retrieval in Hierarchical Document Collections
paper_abstract: Multi-modal retrieval in hierarchical document collections is a challenging problem due to the complexity of indexing and querying diverse media types. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'Hierarchical Modal Index' (HMI), which leverages the structure of hierarchical collections to efficiently integrate and query multiple modalities. HMI employs a hybrid indexing approach, combining inverted indices for text and feature-based indices for images and audio. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HMI on a large-scale dataset, achieving significant improvements in query performance and reducing the storage overhead compared to existing approaches.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents are increasingly being used in complex systems to optimize resource allocation. However, coordinating these agents to achieve global efficiency remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HARL', which enables autonomous agents to learn coordinated policies for efficient resource allocation. HARL consists of a high-level coordinator agent that guides the exploration-exploitation trade-off of lower-level agents, allowing them to adapt to changing system dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid demonstrate that HARL significantly outperforms traditional decentralized approaches in terms of resource utilization and system stability.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Transformers for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Recent advances in multimodal emotion recognition have leveraged transformer-based architectures to fuse and process visual and acoustic features. However, the robustness of these models to adversarial attacks remains understudied. This paper investigates the vulnerability of transformer-based multimodal emotion recognition models to targeted attacks, demonstrating that imperceptible perturbations can significantly degrade model performance. We propose a novel defense mechanism, 'Multimodal Adversarial Training', which incorporates adversarial examples into the training process to improve robustness. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset show that our approach yields state-of-the-art performance under adversarial conditions, highlighting the importance of robustness in real-world emotion recognition applications.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Hashing for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in data integration and cleaning, but it becomes increasingly challenging in distributed database systems where data is scattered across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel graph-based hashing approach, 'HashED', which efficiently disambiguates entities by exploiting their relational structures. HashED utilizes a distributed graph processing framework to construct a scalable indexing mechanism, enabling fast and accurate entity matching. We evaluate HashED on a real-world dataset and demonstrate its ability to outperform state-of-the-art entity disambiguation methods in terms of both accuracy and scalability.

title: Designing Inclusive Augmented Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to enrich the daily lives of people with visual impairments, but existing interfaces often neglect their needs. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating inclusive AR interfaces that cater to users with visual impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with visually impaired participants, identifying critical accessibility barriers and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed design framework, 'AR4VI', integrates audio-based feedback, tactile cues, and personalized font customization to enhance the AR experience for visually impaired users. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to existing AR interfaces.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Drone Navigation
paper_abstract: Autonomous drone navigation in complex environments requires efficient exploration and adaptation to changing scenarios. We propose Hierarchical Drone Navigation (HDN), a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that leverages a task-agnostic, high-level policy to guide a low-level, reactive controller. HDN achieves significant improvements in navigation efficiency and adaptability compared to state-of-the-art, flat reinforcement learning approaches. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HDN in simulations and real-world experiments, showcasing its potential for rapid deployment in various drone-based applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in text retrieval, but existing methods often rely on heuristics or manual feature engineering. This paper proposes a neural embedding-based approach, 'NEQE', which learns to expand queries by modeling the semantic relationships between words. Our method leverages a pre-trained language model to generate contextualized embeddings, which are then used to compute query-term similarities. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NEQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness. We also show that NEQE is robust to varying query lengths and document collections.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) are increasingly used in complex domains such as robotics, smart cities, and healthcare. However, task allocation in MAS remains a challenging problem, especially when agents have diverse capabilities and tasks require collaboration. This paper proposes a novel reinforcement learning approach, 'RL-TASK', which enables autonomous task allocation in MAS. RL-TASK uses a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn task allocation policies that maximize system-level rewards. We evaluate RL-TASK on a simulated disaster response scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates and reduced response times compared to traditional, rule-based allocation methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: We present a novel approach to decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents learn to allocate tasks autonomously using reinforcement learning. Our method, called 'Dec-TARL', leverages a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn optimal task allocation policies. We evaluate Dec-TARL in a simulated urban search and rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized methods. Our results show that Dec-TARL can effectively scale to large teams of agents, making it a promising solution for real-world multi-agent systems.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and resources need to be assigned to tasks with varying requirements. We propose a decentralized auction-based mechanism, called 'Distributed Task Auction' (DTA), which enables agents to bid on tasks based on their availability and capabilities. DTA ensures efficient task allocation, fairness, and truthfulness, while minimizing communication overhead. We provide theoretical guarantees on the performance of DTA and evaluate its effectiveness through simulations on a range of task allocation scenarios.

title: Refined Gradient Descent with Momentum for Efficient Convergence in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have become ubiquitous in various AI applications, but their training remains computationally expensive. This paper presents a refined gradient descent with momentum (RGDM) algorithm that adaptively adjusts the learning rate and momentum parameters based on the gradient's norm and curvature. We theoretically prove that RGDM converges faster than standard stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and momentum SGD, especially for deep networks with complex architectures. Experimental results on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets demonstrate that RGDM achieves higher accuracy and faster convergence than state-of-the-art optimizers, making it a promising choice for large-scale deep learning tasks.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Column-Store Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed column-store databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large datasets. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complex interplay between data distribution, storage, and query execution plans. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning, where an agent learns to select optimal query plans based on a reward function that balances query latency and resource utilization. We evaluate our approach on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multi-modal emotion recognition (MMER) is a challenging task due to the complexity of integrating and processing disparate modalities such as speech, text, and vision. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Our approach adaptively weighs the contributions of each modality to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art MMER methods while reducing computational overhead.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for timely business intelligence and decision-making. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans in real-time data warehousing environments. Our method, called 'RL-QOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn the best query execution plans based on runtime statistics and system workload. Experimental results on a popular open-source data warehousing platform demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms traditional rule-based optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of average query response time.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Elderly Healthcare: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: This paper presents a participatory design approach to developing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) for elderly healthcare. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with elderly individuals, caregivers, and healthcare professionals to identify key design requirements for ECAs that can effectively support elderly care. Our findings highlight the importance of emotional expression, empathy, and conversational naturalness in ECAs. We propose a novel ECA framework that incorporates these design requirements and demonstrate its feasibility through a prototype implementation. Our study contributes to the development of socially intelligent ECAs that can improve healthcare outcomes and quality of life for the elderly.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when faced with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), which leverages prototypical representations at multiple levels of abstraction. HPN adaptively selects and combines prototypes from a hierarchical memory to form a task-specific model, enabling few-shot learning with improved accuracy and flexibility. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HPN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Assistants: A Study on Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational interfaces often exclude older adults due to usability and accessibility limitations. This study investigates the design of inclusive virtual assistants that cater to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study, combining user interviews, surveys, and usability testing, to identify the challenges faced by older adults when interacting with conversational interfaces. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and concise language, visual feedback, and personalized assistance. We propose a set of design guidelines for developing inclusive virtual assistants and demonstrate their efficacy through a prototype evaluation.

title: Optimizing Join Order Selection in Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial task in distributed database systems, and join order selection is a key component of this process. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, but these methods can be suboptimal or computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to optimize join order selection. We design a deep Q-network (DQN) that learns to select the optimal join order by interacting with the database system and receiving rewards based on query performance. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Batch Processing for Deep Neural Networks using Hierarchical GPU Clustering
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have become ubiquitous in modern AI applications, but their computational requirements pose significant challenges for real-world deployments. This paper presents a novel batch processing framework, 'HierGPU', which leverages hierarchical GPU clustering to accelerate DNN inference. By dynamically allocating batch sizes and distributing computations across a cluster of GPUs, HierGPU minimizes memory overhead and maximizes throughput. Experimental results on popular DNN architectures demonstrate that HierGPU achieves up to 4.5x speedup over state-of-the-art batch processing techniques while maintaining accuracy.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Voice Assistants: A User Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational interfaces often pose barriers for users with disabilities. This paper presents a user study investigating the accessibility of popular voice assistants, highlighting issues with speech recognition, cognitive load, and feedback mechanisms. We propose a set of design guidelines for more inclusive conversational interfaces, including adaptable dialogue structures, multimodal feedback, and personalized error handling. Our findings inform the development of more accessible voice assistants, promoting equal access to information and services for all users.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Interpretable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task in AI. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of each modality to recognize emotions in a more interpretable and accurate manner. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules that learn to focus on relevant features, followed by a hierarchical fusion mechanism that combines the outputs. We evaluate our approach on three benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods. Our ablation studies and visualizations provide insights into the decision-making process of the model, making it more transparent and trustworthy.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing for High-Dimensional Data
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is a crucial component of many applications, including similarity search and data analytics. Traditional indexing methods often suffer from poor query performance due to the curse of dimensionality. We propose an adaptive indexing framework, ADIx, which dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. ADIx leverages a novel combination of hierarchical clustering and dimensionality reduction techniques to identify the most informative features and optimize index construction. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and reduced indexing overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Assistive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with technology. This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system, 'EaseGR', designed to improve the accessibility of gesture-based interfaces for individuals with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning-based approach that leverages transfer learning and domain adaptation to recognize gestures from a variety of input modalities, including electromyography (EMG), computer vision, and inertial measurement units (IMUs). Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates that EaseGR achieves higher recognition accuracy and improved user experience compared to existing systems, highlighting its potential to enhance digital inclusion.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Task Allocation
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, but traditional methods often rely on manual tuning or simplistic heuristics. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to coordinate agents and optimize task assignments. Our framework, 'MASTA', uses a decentralized, multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to adapt to dynamic task requirements and agent capabilities. We evaluate MASTA in a simulated logistics scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced agent idle time compared to baseline methods. The results have implications for real-world applications, such as warehouse management and disaster response.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning in Real-World Robotics
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved impressive results in robotics, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in real-world applications. This paper introduces HAN-RLE, a hierarchical attention network that incorporates multi-level attention mechanisms to provide explainable RL policies for robotic control tasks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN-RLE in a real-world robotic arm manipulation task, showcasing its ability to generate interpretable attention visualizations that align with human intuition. Our extensive experiments illustrate the improved performance and robustness of HAN-RLE compared to state-of-the-art RL methods.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Data Warehouses using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant data warehouses face significant performance challenges due to concurrent query workloads. Traditional query optimization techniques struggle to adapt to dynamic workload patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'RL-Optimizer', which leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for multi-tenant data warehouses. RL-Optimizer learns to predict optimal join orders, indexing strategies, and resource allocation from historical query patterns and workload characteristics. Experimental results on a real-world data warehouse benchmark demonstrate that RL-Optimizer outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often rely on query expansion to improve retrieval effectiveness. However, existing methods may not fully capture the semantic relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach, 'GraphExpan', which leverages semantic embeddings to model query term relationships. GraphExpan constructs a query graph by incorporating word embeddings and semantic role labeling, and then applies a graph-based ranking model to select the most informative expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC Ad-hoc dataset demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Adaptive Thresholding for Real-time Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Real-time information retrieval (IR) systems require efficient document filtering to reduce latency and improve user experience. This paper presents an adaptive thresholding approach, 'AdaFilter', which dynamically adjusts the filtering threshold based on the query characteristics and document relevance distributions. Our method leverages a novel online learning framework to update the threshold in real-time, resulting in significant improvements in filtering accuracy and efficiency. Experimental results on the TREC news dataset demonstrate that AdaFilter outperforms existing filtering methods, achieving a 30% reduction in filtering time while maintaining a 95% recall rate.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems rely on effective query representations to retrieve relevant documents. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, Neural Query Graph Expansion (NQGE), which leverages neural query graph embeddings to capture complex query-document relationships. NQGE uses a graph attention mechanism to learn weighted representations of query terms and their contextual relationships, enabling more accurate expansion of query concepts. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQGE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Speech Recognition and Error Recovery
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This study investigates the challenges faced by older adults when interacting with voice assistants, focusing on speech recognition errors and recovery strategies. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, using a custom-built voice assistant and a think-aloud protocol. Our results show that older adults experience higher error rates due to speech patterns, cognitive load, and lack of feedback. We propose a set of design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants, including personalized speech recognition models, multimodal feedback, and error recovery mechanisms. Our findings have implications for designing accessible and supportive voice assistants for older adults.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Diversified Search Results
paper_abstract: Conventional query expansion techniques often rely on term frequency and co-occurrence, neglecting the nuances of user context and search intent. This paper presents a novel context-aware query expansion framework, CAQE, which incorporates user profiling, query intent classification, and semantic role labeling. CAQE dynamically selects expansion terms based on the user's search history, query semantics, and the desired level of result diversification. Experimental results on a large-scale search logs dataset demonstrate that CAQE improves the diversity and relevance of search results, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Sparse Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Sparse document retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, especially when dealing with short queries and few relevant documents. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HierRank, which leverages both local and global contextual information to improve retrieval accuracy. Our model consists of a query-document interaction module and a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures complex relationships between query terms and document entities. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierRank significantly outperforms state-of-the-art sparse retrieval models, achieving a relative improvement of up to 15% in mean average precision.

title: Elastic Database Scalability with Automated Schema Refactoring
paper_abstract: As modern databases face increasingly large and diverse workloads, scalability becomes a critical concern. This paper presents 'ElasticDB', a novel approach to elastic database scalability that leverages automated schema refactoring. ElasticDB dynamically analyzes query patterns and adapts the database schema to optimize performance, reducing latency by up to 60% in our experiments. Our approach integrates with popular relational databases and is compatible with existing query optimization techniques. We demonstrate ElasticDB's effectiveness on a real-world e-commerce dataset, showcasing its potential to improve responsiveness and reduce costs in cloud-based database deployments.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient and Effective Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines struggle to balance query latency and retrieval effectiveness, particularly when dealing with ambiguous or incomplete user queries. We propose a neural query expansion (NQE) framework that leverages a transformer-based architecture to generate context-aware expansion terms. NQE incorporates a novel attention mechanism that selectively weighs term importance based on query semantics and item attributes. Our experiments on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and recall, while reducing query latency by up to 30% compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Learning to Rank with Deep Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Retrieval
paper_abstract: Multi-modal retrieval systems aim to retrieve relevant documents from heterogeneous sources, such as text, images, and videos. However, existing ranking models often struggle to capture the complex relationships between modalities. We propose a novel deep neural network architecture, 'MMRank', which learns to rank documents by jointly modeling the semantic relationships between text, visual, and acoustic features. Our approach leverages a multi-task learning framework to learn shared representations across modalities, and incorporates a attention-based ranking mechanism to weigh the importance of each modality. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of MMRank in improving retrieval performance and robustness.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Data using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of multi-modal data has created new challenges for efficient information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks (HGNN), which leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and hierarchical clustering to facilitate fast and accurate retrieval of multi-modal data. Our approach represents data as a hierarchical graph, where each node corresponds to a data instance, and edges capture semantic relationships between instances. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and accuracy, while also providing interpretable results.

title: Accelerating Query Processing with Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases have revolutionized query processing by minimizing disk I/O. However, traditional indexing techniques are often suboptimal in this context. This paper proposes a novel learned index structure, 'MemIndex', that leverages machine learning models to predict the memory location of query results. We develop a data-driven approach to index construction, exploiting the compactness of main-memory data to reduce index size and improve query performance. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that MemIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query throughput and 2x in memory efficiency.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Inclusive Elderly Care
paper_abstract: As the global elderly population grows, there is a pressing need for inclusive assistive technologies that can accommodate cognitive and motor impairments. This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system, 'Easy Gesture', which adapts to the abilities and preferences of individual elderly users. Our approach integrates machine learning with participatory design, involving iterative user studies and co-design workshops with elderly participants. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Easy Gesture in a longitudinal study, showing significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Adaptive Auction Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, which leverages adaptive auction mechanisms to efficiently assign tasks to agents. Our approach incorporates a dynamic pricing strategy that adjusts to the changing availability and capabilities of agents, ensuring optimal task allocation and minimizing communication overhead. We evaluate the performance of our framework through extensive simulations, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Real-time IoT Time Series Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has generated vast amounts of time series data, making it challenging to detect anomalies in real-time. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'IoT-ADNet', which leverages a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to identify anomalies in IoT time series data. IoT-ADNet incorporates a transfer learning mechanism to adapt to new devices and scenarios, achieving high detection accuracy and low false positive rates. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of IoT-ADNet in detecting anomalies in real-time, outperforming traditional machine learning and statistical methods.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Personalized Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have revolutionized human-computer interaction, but their adoption among older adults is hindered by limited accessibility and usability. This paper presents a novel approach to personalized dialogue management for voice assistants, tailored to the needs and preferences of older adults. We propose a machine learning-based framework that integrates user modeling, dialogue context, and affective computing to generate empathetic and supportive responses. A user study with 30 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction, engagement, and task completion rates compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Interpretable Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-agent dialogue systems have emerged as a key application of artificial intelligence in human-computer interaction. However, the lack of transparency in these models hinders their widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables interpretable dialogue management in multi-agent systems. Our approach consists of two stages: intra-agent attention and inter-agent attention. The former focuses on identifying relevant context within each agent's dialogue history, while the latter captures relationships between agents' responses. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of dialogue coherence and user satisfaction, while providing visualizable attention weights for improved interpretability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Semantic Search using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Semantic search has gained increasing attention in recent years due to its ability to capture the nuances of user queries. However, existing methods often struggle with query expansion, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to generate context-aware query expansions. Our method, called KG-Expan, uses a graph attention mechanism to selectively incorporate entity relationships and semantic types into the expansion process. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that KG-Expan outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach to scalable query optimization, which leverages graph neural networks to model query dependencies and optimize join ordering. Our approach, called GraphOpt, outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of execution time and scalability. We evaluate GraphOpt on a range of benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to handle complex queries and large-scale datasets.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems have applications in various domains, but efficient task allocation remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-ATA', which enables autonomous task allocation in dynamic environments. HRL-ATA consists of a high-level task allocator that assigns tasks to agents and a low-level controller that learns to execute tasks efficiently. We introduce a novel reward function that balances task completion rates and resource utilization, leading to improved system performance. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse management scenario demonstrate that HRL-ATA outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and resource efficiency.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning: A Hierarchical Attention Framework
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial for real-world adoption of reinforcement learning (RL) systems. Existing approaches focus on providing post-hoc explanations, which can be misleading or incomplete. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HierAttnRL', which incorporates explainability into the RL decision-making process. By learning attention weights over state and action features, our framework provides transparent and interpretable policies. Experimental results on Atari and MuJoCo benchmarks demonstrate that HierAttnRL achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art RL methods while providing insightful explanations for its decisions.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Reinforcement Learning under Adversarial Attacks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised significant concerns. This paper presents a comprehensive robustness analysis of DRL algorithms under different types of adversarial attacks, including observation and action perturbations. We propose a novel attack detection mechanism based on uncertainty estimation and demonstrate its effectiveness in identifying attacks. Our experiments on several benchmarks show that the proposed approach significantly improves the robustness of DRL algorithms, paving the way for their deployment in safety-critical applications.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Autonomous driving requires agents to adapt to diverse scenarios and make decisions in real-time. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-AD', which leverages a deep hierarchical policy to balance exploration-exploitation trade-offs in complex environments. We introduce a curiosity-driven intrinsic reward function that encourages the agent to explore novel situations and a policy abstraction mechanism that enables efficient knowledge transfer across tasks. Experimental results on a realistic autonomous driving simulator demonstrate that HRL-AD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate and overall driving efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data, such as speech, text, and facial expressions, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the varying characteristics of different modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates multiple attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features from each modality. Our HAN architecture consists of three levels of attention: modality-level, feature-level, and decision-level. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods, achieving an average F1-score of 0.842.

title: Efficient Online Learning with Adaptive Regularization for Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are increasingly used for online learning tasks, where the model must adapt to streaming data. However, this setting poses significant challenges, including concept drift, limited labeled data, and computational constraints. We propose an adaptive regularization framework, 'AdaReg', that dynamically adjusts the regularization strength for each layer based on the observed data distribution. Our approach leverages a novel online estimation of the Hessian matrix, enabling efficient computation of the regularization term. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaReg outperforms state-of-the-art online learning methods in terms of accuracy and adaptability to concept drift.

title: Hierarchical Attention Mechanisms for Explainable Multimodal Fusion in Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Multimodal fusion in deep learning has become increasingly prevalent in various applications, including computer vision, natural language processing, and speech recognition. However, the lack of interpretability in these models hinders their adoption in high-stakes domains. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HAtt', which enables explainable multimodal fusion by selectively weighting and aggregating modality-specific representations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAtt on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while providing insightful visualizations of modality attention patterns.

title: Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Robot Navigation
paper_abstract: Autonomous robot navigation in complex, dynamic environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'HierNav', which leverages a hierarchical policy structure to learn both high-level navigation strategies and low-level control primitives. Our approach incorporates a novel state-abstraction mechanism that enables the robot to reason about the environment at multiple levels of granularity. Experimental results on a range of simulated and real-world navigation tasks demonstrate that HierNav outperforms state-of-the-art flat reinforcement learning methods in terms of navigation efficiency and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Dialogue Systems for Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Conversational AI systems have made significant progress in recent years, but their lack of transparency and explainability hinders their widespread adoption. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based framework for dialogue systems, which generates explicit explanations for its responses. Our approach incorporates multiple levels of attention, enabling the model to focus on relevant context, intent, and entities during response generation. We evaluate our approach on a benchmark dialogue dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in response quality, as well as enhanced transparency and trustworthiness. Our model provides a step towards more interpretable and accountable conversational AI systems.

title: Scalable Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data using Graph-Based Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. However, existing methods often struggle with scale and robustness. This paper introduces 'GraphCon', a novel graph-based contrastive learning framework for anomaly detection in time-series data. By modeling the data as a graph and leveraging contrastive learning, GraphCon can efficiently handle large datasets and capture complex patterns. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that GraphCon outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis involves predicting sentiment from multiple sources of data, such as text, images, and audio. Existing approaches often suffer from feature misalignment and modality imbalance. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages graph-based multimodal fusion to address these limitations. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, enabling more accurate sentiment predictions. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSI and POM datasets demonstrate the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods, with significant improvements in sentiment classification accuracy and F1-score.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Coordination for Autonomous Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous urban traffic management requires efficient coordination among multiple agents, including vehicles, traffic lights, and pedestrians. This paper presents a novel decentralized coordination framework, 'MACTraffic', which leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning and graph neural networks to optimize traffic flow. MACTraffic integrates real-time data from various sources, including traffic cameras, sensors, and GPS, to adapt to dynamic traffic conditions. Our experiments on a large-scale simulated urban traffic network demonstrate significant reductions in congestion, travel time, and emissions compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: VibroTactile Feedback in Virtual Reality: Enhancing User Experience through Haptic Cueing
paper_abstract: In virtual reality (VR) systems, users rely heavily on visual and auditory cues to navigate virtual environments. However, neglecting the haptic channel can lead to a sense of disconnection and reduced immersion. This paper presents a novel vibro-tactile feedback framework that leverages haptic cueing to enhance user experience in VR. Our approach utilizes machine learning-based pattern recognition to identify subtle hand and finger movements, generating synchronized vibrotactile feedback to amplify proprioceptive awareness. In a user study with 30 participants, we demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time, accuracy, and overall user satisfaction compared to traditional visual-only interfaces.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks: A Comparative Study of Defense Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have demonstrated exceptional performance in various graph-based applications. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks has raised concerns about their reliability. This paper presents a comprehensive study of defense mechanisms against adversarial attacks on GNNs. We evaluate the effectiveness of six state-of-the-art defense techniques, including adversarial training, graph purification, and attention mechanisms, on three popular GNN architectures. Our results show that while individual defense mechanisms provide some robustness, a combination of techniques can significantly improve the resilience of GNNs to targeted attacks. We also propose a novel ensemble-based defense approach that achieves the best overall performance.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have the potential to improve cognitive functioning in older adults, but their design should consider the unique needs and abilities of this population. This study investigates the impact of embodied cognition on cognitive performance in VR interfaces tailored for older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, aged 65+, who completed cognitive tasks in both embodied and non-embodied VR conditions. Our results show that embodied cognition significantly enhances cognitive performance, particularly in spatial reasoning and memory tasks. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of accessible VR interfaces for older adults.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle to scale to complex scenarios. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model complex interactions between agents. Our approach learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their relationships, enabling more efficient and effective learning in MARL environments. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Multimodal Fusion for Emotional State Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate emotional state recognition is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion framework, 'EmoFuse', which combines computer vision, speech recognition, and physiological signal processing to recognize emotional states in real-time. We introduce a attention-based architecture that adaptively weighs the contributions of each modality based on their contextual relevance. Our experiments on a large, diverse dataset show that EmoFuse outperforms state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal approaches, achieving a recognition accuracy of 92.1% on a 7-class emotion classification task.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks have shown great promise in node classification tasks, but often struggle with noisy or adversarially perturbed graph structures. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph attention mechanism, 'HGAN', which recursively applies attentional aggregation at multiple scales to capture both local and global graph patterns. We demonstrate the robustness of HGAN to various types of graph corruptions and perturbations, achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. Additionally, we provide theoretical guarantees on the stability of HGAN to graph perturbations, making it a reliable choice for real-world applications.

title: Gaze-Based Intent Recognition for Accessible Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but accessibility remains a significant barrier for individuals with motor impairments. This paper presents 'GazeInt', a novel gaze-based intent recognition system for accessible VR interaction. We leverage a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to classify user intentions from gaze patterns, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% on a dataset of 20 participants. Our system enables users to interact with virtual objects using only their gaze, reducing the need for manual input and enhancing overall VR experience.

title: Hierarchical Clustering-based Anomaly Detection for High-Dimensional Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in high-dimensional time series data is a crucial task in various applications, including IoT and finance. Existing methods often struggle with the curse of dimensionality and fail to capture complex patterns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering-based approach, 'HierAD', which leverages a tree-like structure to identify anomalies at multiple scales. By recursively applying density-based clustering and dimensionality reduction, HierAD effectively detects anomalies in high-dimensional space while reducing computational complexity. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of HierAD over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often rely on complex decision-making processes that are difficult to interpret. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAN) framework that enables explainable decision-making in multi-agent settings. HGAN leverages graph attention mechanisms to model agent interactions and hierarchical structures to capture abstract decision-making processes. We evaluate HGAN on a variety of multi-agent benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to existing approaches. Additionally, we provide visualizations and feature importance analysis to illustrate the explanatory capabilities of HGAN.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Adaptive Negative Sampling
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial technique for various AI applications, including question answering and recommender systems. However, existing KGE methods often suffer from inefficient negative sampling strategies, leading to suboptimal model performance. This paper presents an adaptive negative sampling approach, called AdaNS, which dynamically adjusts the sampling distribution based on the entity similarity and graph structure. We demonstrate that AdaNS significantly improves the performance of popular KGE models on several benchmark datasets, including WN18RR and FB15k-237, achieving state-of-the-art results in some cases.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Question Answering
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for multi-modal question answering, which integrates visual and textual features to better understand complex questions. Our HGAT model learns to selectively focus on relevant regions of the image and corresponding text snippets, thereby improving question answering accuracy. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale dataset and demonstrate state-of-the-art performance on several benchmarks, outperforming existing methods by up to 4.5%.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval rely on hand-crafted features and optimization methods, limiting their ability to capture complex document relationships. We propose a novel approach, DeepRank, which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn optimal ranking policies. Our model utilizes a hierarchical neural network to represent documents and a policy gradient method to optimize ranking metrics. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in ranking quality and relevance over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Temporal Graphs
paper_abstract: Temporal graphs have become increasingly prevalent in various domains, including social networks, IoT, and financial transactions. However, querying these graphs in real-time remains a significant challenge due to their large size and dynamic nature. This paper presents 'ChronoOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages graph summarization and incremental indexing techniques to accelerate query execution on temporal graphs. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that ChronoOpt outperforms state-of-the-art approaches by up to 5x in terms of query response time, while maintaining high accuracy and supporting a wide range of analytics queries.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Retrieval Models for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper explores the application of neural retrieval models to query expansion, proposing a novel approach that leverages the semantic capabilities of transformer-based architectures. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroXPand', uses a fine-tuned BERT model to generate context-aware expansion terms, which are then combined with traditional retrieval models to produce a robust ranking. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc track demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and NDCG, especially for difficult queries.

title: Emotional Sentiment Analysis in Human-Robot Interaction using Multimodal Fusion
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, understanding human emotions is crucial for effective communication. This paper proposes a novel multimodal fusion approach for emotional sentiment analysis in human-robot interaction. We leverage facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to recognize emotional states and improve the robot's empathetic response. Our experimental results show that the proposed approach outperforms unimodal methods, achieving an accuracy of 93.5% in recognizing six basic emotions. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a real-world scenario, where a robot uses emotional intelligence to provide comfort to users in a healthcare setting.

title: Eye Movement Analysis for Adaptive Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely on accurate gesture recognition to provide immersive experiences. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages eye movement analysis to enhance gesture recognition in VR. We propose a machine learning model that incorporates eye-tracking data to infer user intentions and adapt gesture recognition accordingly. Our approach addresses the limitations of traditional computer vision-based methods, which can be affected by occlusions, lighting conditions, and individual differences in hand movements. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction when using our eye movement-based approach.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Neural Rewriting for Multi-Attribute Queries
paper_abstract: Multi-attribute queries (MAQs) are a crucial component of modern information retrieval systems. However, their performance is often hindered by the complexity of query rewriting. This paper proposes a novel neural rewriting approach, 'NeuroRewrite', which leverages deep learning to generate optimized query plans for MAQs. Our approach learns to identify keyword patterns, attribute relationships, and query intent to produce rewritten queries that reduce computational overhead and improve result relevance. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that NeuroRewrite outperforms state-of-the-art query rewriting techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Proximity-Aware Neural Ranking for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: The increasing volume of digital documents necessitates efficient and accurate retrieval techniques. This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, ProxNR, which leverages proximity-aware features to capture complex relationships between query terms and document contents. By incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism and a novel proximity-based similarity metric, ProxNR achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing computational costs. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of ProxNR in handling long-tail queries and improving overall retrieval efficiency.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown remarkable success in modeling complex graph-structured data. However, their computational complexity grows exponentially with the graph size, making them inefficient for large-scale graphs. This paper introduces a novel attention mechanism, 'HierAtt', designed specifically for hierarchical GNNs. HierAtt adaptively allocates attention weights based on graph topology and node features, reducing computational overhead by up to 70%. We demonstrate the efficacy of HierAtt on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results on graph classification tasks while significantly improving inference speed.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time-Series Forecasting with Multi-Resolution Inputs
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in many applications, including finance, healthcare, and energy management. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages multi-resolution inputs to improve forecasting accuracy. Our HAN model consists of multiple attention layers that learn to focus on relevant temporal resolutions, capturing both short-term and long-term dependencies. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods, including prophet and LSTM-based models. Furthermore, we provide an interpretability analysis of the attention weights, revealing insightful patterns in the data.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for information retrieval (IR) rely on complex query-document representations, which can be computationally expensive and limit their scalability. This paper proposes a novel approach, Neural Query Graphs (NQG), which represents queries as graph-structured entities and leverages graph neural networks to learn relevance signals. We demonstrate that NQG achieves significant improvements in ranking accuracy and computational efficiency compared to traditional neural ranking models on several benchmark datasets. Additionally, we show that NQG can be easily integrated with existing IR systems, making it a promising solution for large-scale IR applications.

title: Autonomous Decision-Making in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Q-Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, autonomous decision-making is crucial for efficient and effective interactions. This paper proposes a novel approach to autonomous decision-making using deep Q-networks (DQN) in multi-agent systems. We introduce a hierarchical DQN framework that enables agents to learn complex decision-making policies in a distributed manner. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated environment, demonstrating improved decision-making performance and adaptability compared to traditional Q-learning methods. We also analyze the scalability of our approach in large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a widely used technique to improve retrieval performance, but it often relies on simplistic term weighting schemes.
