This paper proposes a deep neural ranking model, dubbed 'NERD', which learns to predict the relevance of expansion terms based on their semantic relationships with the query. We incorporate NERD into a state-of-the-art retrieval pipeline and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness on several benchmark datasets. Our approach outperforms traditional query expansion methods, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Hierarchical Cross-Modal Attention for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis aims to identify sentiment from multiple sources such as text, images, and videos. Existing approaches often rely on early or late fusion strategies, which may not effectively capture cross-modal interactions. This paper proposes a hierarchical cross-modal attention framework, 'HCMANet', that learns to selectively focus on salient regions in each modality and align them to facilitate sentiment prediction. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HCMANet outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 4.2% in sentiment accuracy.

title: Gaze-Based Adaptive Interfaces for Enhancing User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but users often experience fatigue and discomfort due to inadequate interface designs. This paper presents a novel gaze-based adaptive interface framework, 'GAZE+', which leverages eye-tracking and machine learning to dynamically adjust VR interface elements based on user attention and behavior. We evaluated GAZE+ in a user study and found significant improvements in user satisfaction, task completion time, and reduced eye movement. Our approach has implications for enhancing user experience in various VR applications, including gaming, education, and healthcare.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranking for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent from short, ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a neural re-ranking approach to query expansion, which leverages a pre-trained language model to generate a set of contextualized candidate terms. Our method, dubbed 'NeuQE', incorporates a novel term importance estimation module that adaptively weights the contribution of each expansion term based on its semantic relevance to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving state-of-the-art retrieval performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Biomedical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Biomedical information retrieval (BIR) systems rely on effective query expansion techniques to retrieve relevant documents from large repositories. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep neural networks, which learns to capture semantic relationships between terms and generates context-aware expansion terms. Our model, dubbed BioQE, utilizes a combination of word embeddings and convolutional neural networks to identify salient terms and predict their relevance to the query. Experimental results on the TREC 2019 BIR dataset demonstrate that BioQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval precision and recall.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Column-Oriented Database Systems
paper_abstract: Traditional query optimization techniques are often inadequate for real-time analytics in column-oriented database systems, where query patterns and data distributions are dynamic and unpredictable. This paper presents 'Aurora', a novel adaptive query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to predict query performance and adjust optimization strategies in real-time. Our experiments on a popular column-store database show that Aurora reduces average query latency by up to 3.5x and improves query throughput by up to 2.2x compared to state-of-the-art static optimization techniques.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Modern Data Warehouses using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: As data warehouses continue to grow in size and complexity, traditional query optimization techniques struggle to keep up. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans. Our method, called 'QOptRL', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan for a given workload, taking into account various factors such as data distribution, indexing, and system resource utilization. Experiments on a real-world dataset show that QOptRL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of execution time, while also adapting to changing workloads and system configurations.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but individuals with motor impairments often face barriers in interacting with VR systems. This paper presents a novel, inclusive VR interface design framework that accommodates users with motor impairments. We conducted a participatory design study with participants having varying levels of motor impairments and developed a set of accessible interaction techniques, including gesture-based navigation and eye-gaze-based selection. Our user study demonstrates that the proposed interface significantly improves user experience and task performance for participants with motor impairments, paving the way for more inclusive VR applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Acoustic Accessibility for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their acoustic design often neglects the needs of older adults, leading to difficulties in communication. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants, focusing on acoustic accessibility for older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, exploring the impact of speech rate, pitch, and volume on older adults' comprehension and interaction experiences. Our findings inform a set of guidelines for acoustic design, emphasizing the importance of adaptable speech rates, clear enunciation, and personalized volume control. We demonstrate the effectiveness of these guidelines through a prototype voice assistant, showcasing improved comprehension rates and user satisfaction among older adults.

title: Efficient Data Retrieval in Distributed Database Systems using a Hierarchical Hash Index
paper_abstract: With the increasing scale and complexity of modern database systems, efficient data retrieval has become a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical hash index (HHI) that leverages the principles of distributed hash tables to facilitate fast and scalable data retrieval in distributed database systems. Our HHI scheme exploits the hierarchical structure of the index to reduce the number of network hops required for data retrieval, resulting in improved query performance and reduced latency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the superiority of our approach over existing indexing schemes in terms of query response time and system throughput.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when dealing with limited labeled data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to efficiently learn transferable knowledge from base classes. Our approach hierarchically aggregates feature representations from local to global levels, enabling the model to capture complex relationships between classes. Experimental results on standard benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational AI
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational AI is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the multimodal nature of human communication. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that jointly models auditory, visual, and textual features from conversational data. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture contextual relationships between utterances and modalities, and hierarchical graph pooling to aggregate features at multiple scales. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in emotion recognition accuracy and robustness to noisy data.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-Time RDF Graph Processing
paper_abstract: RDF (Resource Description Framework) graphs have become a standard for representing large-scale semantic data. However, querying and indexing these graphs in real-time remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'RDFlex', a novel indexing framework that leverages a combination of graph summarization and dynamic partitioning to achieve efficient query processing. Our approach enables scalable and adaptive indexing of RDF graphs, supporting a wide range of query patterns and graph workloads. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that RDFlex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Optimizing Gesture Recognition using Hierarchical Bayesian Networks for Multimodal HCI Systems
paper_abstract: Multimodal human-computer interaction (HCI) systems rely on accurate gesture recognition to provide seamless user experiences. This paper presents a novel hierarchical Bayesian network (HBN) framework for gesture recognition, which models the complex relationships between various sensor modalities. Our approach leverages the strengths of both model-based and data-driven techniques, achieving improved recognition accuracy and robustness in diverse real-world scenarios. We evaluate our HBN framework using a comprehensive dataset of gestures and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing errors and improving system responsiveness.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource-Constrained Scheduling in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Scheduling tasks in cloud computing environments is a complex problem due to resource constraints and dynamic workload demands. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'CloudSched', which learns to optimize scheduling decisions based on historical workload patterns and resource availability. We design a customized neural network architecture that incorporates graph attention mechanisms to capture dependency relationships between tasks and resources. Experimental results on a real-world cloud computing dataset show that CloudSched outperforms state-of-the-art scheduling algorithms, achieving significant reductions in average response time and resource utilization.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Adaptive Difficulty on Player Engagement in Gamified Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Gamification has been increasingly adopted in educational settings to enhance learner engagement. However, the effectiveness of gamification strategies can be influenced by individual differences in learners' abilities and preferences. This study examines the impact of personalized adaptive difficulty on player engagement in a gamified learning environment. We designed a novel algorithm that dynamically adjusts the difficulty level of game-based learning tasks based on learners' performance, cognitive styles, and emotional responses. Results from a user study with 120 participants show that personalized adaptive difficulty significantly improves learner engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to fixed or adaptive difficulty without personalization.

title: Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (MIR) systems often struggle to effectively capture the nuances of medical terminology, leading to suboptimal search results. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages hierarchical graph convolutional networks (H-GCNs) to model the semantic relationships between medical concepts. Our method, MedExpand, represents medical terms as nodes in a hierarchical graph, allowing the model to capture both local and global contextual information. Experimental results on the TREC Medical Retrieval dataset demonstrate that MedExpand outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision (MAP) and normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG)

title: Gaze-Informed Gesture Recognition for Augmented Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) interfaces rely on accurate gesture recognition to provide seamless user experiences. However, existing approaches often struggle with variability in user behavior and environmental conditions. This paper presents a novel gaze-informed gesture recognition framework that leverages eye-tracking data to disambiguate gesture meanings. We propose a multimodal fusion architecture that combines computer vision, machine learning, and gaze analysis to improve recognition accuracy and robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art gesture recognition methods in AR scenarios, particularly in cases of occlusion or ambiguous hand poses.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in information retrieval that aims to improve the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages deep neural word embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between words. Our approach uses a pre-trained language model to generate context-aware word representations, which are then used to select expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms traditional query expansion techniques and achieves state-of-the-art performance in ad-hoc retrieval tasks.

title: Efficient Document Indexing with Hierarchical Neural Embeddings for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art information retrieval systems rely on dense neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between documents. However, indexing these embeddings for efficient querying remains a significant challenge, particularly for large-scale collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural embedding framework, 'HierIndex', which leverages a tree-based indexing structure to facilitate fast and accurate document retrieval. We demonstrate that HierIndex outperforms existing indexing methods in terms of query latency and memory usage, while maintaining retrieval effectiveness on several benchmark datasets.

title: Exploring Gesture-Based Interaction for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its adoption is hindered by limitations in user interaction. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interaction framework, ' GestureVR', designed to enhance accessibility and inclusivity in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, including individuals with motor impairments, and demonstrated that GestureVR significantly improves user experience and reduces interaction time compared to traditional controller-based methods. Our approach utilizes machine learning algorithms to recognize and classify hand gestures, allowing for more intuitive and natural interaction with virtual objects.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Relational Databases using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but query performance remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing approach that dynamically adjusts to changing query workloads and data distributions. Our method, called 'AIQ', leverages machine learning-based predictions to identify optimal index configurations and incrementally updates the index structure. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that AIQ outperforms existing indexing techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while reducing storage overhead by up to 25%

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Heterogeneous IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has led to increasing complexity in resource allocation. This paper proposes an autonomous agent-based framework, 'IoT-Agent', which leverages decentralized decision-making to optimize resource allocation in heterogeneous IoT networks. Each agent, representing an IoT device, employs a multi-objective optimization strategy to negotiate resource allocation with its peers. We evaluate IoT-Agent on a realistic IoT testbed and demonstrate significant improvements in network performance, energy efficiency, and adaptability to dynamic network conditions compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Complex joins in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query processing for complex joins remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose a novel approach, called 'DJPart', which leverages both data partitioning and join reordering to minimize communication overhead and improve query performance. We introduce a cost-based optimization framework that adaptively selects the best join order and partitioning scheme based on the query workload and data characteristics. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DJPart outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on Foveal Vision and Eye Movement
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current interfaces often rely on cumbersome controllers or gestures. This paper explores gaze-based interaction as a more natural and intuitive approach. We conducted a user study to investigate the relationship between foveal vision and eye movement in AR environments, and developed a novel algorithm that leverages this understanding to enable accurate and efficient gaze-based selection. Our results show significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional methods, and highlight the potential for gaze-based interaction to become a cornerstone of future AR interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Asynchronous Consensus Protocols
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages asynchronous consensus protocols to enable agents to make collective decisions. Our approach, called 'AsyncTA', uses a combination of gossip-based consensus and distributed constraint optimization to allocate tasks to agents in a fair and efficient manner. We evaluate AsyncTA in simulated environments and demonstrate its robustness to agent failures, network partitions, and varying task loads. The results show that AsyncTA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of allocation quality, communication overhead, and convergence time.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration Using Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As robots become increasingly integrated into human-centric workspaces, understanding the factors that influence human-robot collaboration is crucial. This study investigates the role of embodiment in human-robot collaboration using virtual reality (VR). We designed a VR-based experiment where participants interacted with a robot either through a virtual embodiment (VE) or a traditional screen-based interface. Our results show that VE significantly improves collaboration outcomes, including task completion time and user satisfaction, by enhancing the sense of agency and social presence. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of future human-robot collaboration systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained popularity in recent years, but existing methods often rely on simplistic user-item interaction graphs. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention (HGA) framework that models complex relationships between users, items, and attributes. HGA leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph components, enabling the discovery of nuanced patterns and relationships. We evaluate HGA on three real-world datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art ERS methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor disabilities often face challenges interacting with digital systems. This paper presents 'AdaptaGest', a machine learning-based approach for adaptive gesture recognition that accommodates varying abilities and contexts. AdaptaGest employs a novel transfer learning strategy that leverages domain knowledge from able-bodied users to personalize models for individuals with motor disabilities. Our user study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing approaches. We also provide insights into the design implications of AdaptaGest for inclusive HCI systems.

title: Designing Emotional Support Agents for Older Adults: An Embodied Conversational Agent Framework
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for designing embodied conversational agents (ECAs) that provide emotional support to older adults. Our framework, 'EASE', integrates principles from human-computer interaction, affective computing, and gerontology to create personalized, empathetic, and engaging interactions. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, demonstrating that EASE-based agents can effectively recognize and respond to users' emotional cues, leading to increased feelings of comfort, trust, and social connection. The framework's modular architecture enables easy integration with various sensing and actuation technologies, making it a promising tool for promoting healthy aging and social well-being.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Label Classification with Noisy Labels
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a fundamental problem in machine learning, where each instance can be associated with multiple labels. However, real-world datasets often contain noisy labels, which can significantly degrade the performance of classification models. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) to tackle this problem. Our HAN model consists of two stages: a label attention module that adaptively weights the importance of each label, and a instance attention module that selectively focuses on relevant instances. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency, even in the presence of high levels of label noise.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Multimodal Feedback in Virtual Reality-based Gesture Recognition Systems
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but accurate gesture recognition remains a significant challenge. This paper investigates the role of multimodal feedback in improving gesture recognition in VR-based systems. We designed an experiment to evaluate the effectiveness of visual, auditory, and haptic feedback in reducing gesture recognition errors. Our results show that multimodal feedback significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy, particularly for complex gestures. We also found that users' preference for feedback modality varies depending on the type of gesture and individual differences. Our findings have implications for the design of VR-based gesture recognition systems that prioritize user experience and accuracy.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Task Allocation for Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel agent-based task allocation framework for multi-robot systems, enabling efficient and adaptive task assignment in dynamic environments. Our approach leverages autonomous agents to negotiate and allocate tasks based on their capabilities, resource constraints, and real-time feedback from the environment. Experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in system efficiency and robustness compared to traditional centralized allocation methods, making our framework suitable for various real-world applications, including search and rescue operations and environmental monitoring.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Lane Changing
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has shown promise in autonomous vehicle control, but uncertainty estimation remains a crucial challenge. This paper presents a novel DRL framework, 'UncerLane', which integrates uncertainty-awareness into the decision-making process for lane changing. We propose a Bayesian neural network architecture that outputs both the expected action and its uncertainty, allowing the agent to adjust its exploration-exploitation trade-off accordingly. Experimental results on a simulated highway environment demonstrate that UncerLane outperforms state-of-the-art DRL methods in terms of safety, efficiency, and adaptability to changing scenarios.

title: Meta-Learning for Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning in Neural Architecture Search
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, the computational cost of NAS can be prohibitively high due to the need to perform exhaustive hyperparameter tuning. This paper proposes a meta-learning approach that learns to adapt hyperparameters across different neural architectures and datasets. Our method, 'Meta-Tune', leverages a learned prior over hyperparameters to efficiently explore the search space and identify optimal configurations. Experimental results on popular NAS benchmarks demonstrate that Meta-Tune achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing the computation time by up to 5x.

title: EyeGazePredict: A Deep Learning Model for Inferring User Intent from Gaze Patterns in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: In virtual reality (VR) environments, accurately inferring user intent is crucial for seamless interaction. This paper introduces EyeGazePredict, a novel deep learning model that leverages gaze patterns to predict user intent in VR. Our model combines convolutional and recurrent neural networks to extract spatial and temporal features from gaze data, achieving an accuracy of 92.5% on a benchmark dataset. We also conduct a user study to demonstrate the model's effectiveness in reducing interaction latency and improving overall user experience. The results have significant implications for the development of intuitive and efficient VR interfaces.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on Emotional Contagion in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become a popular platform for social interactions, but the emotional contagion effect in these environments remains understudied. This paper investigates the role of personalized avatars on emotional contagion in VR, using a mixed-methods approach combining physiological measures and self-reported surveys. Our results show that users who interact with personalized avatars exhibit increased emotional contagion compared to those with non-personalized avatars, particularly in high-arousal emotional scenarios. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of VR experiences that promote emotional well-being and empathy.

title: Exploring Embodiment in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way humans interact with digital information, but current interaction methods often feel unnatural and limited. This paper investigates the role of embodiment in VR, focusing on gesture-based interaction as a means to enhance user experience. We conducted a user study to compare three gesture recognition systems, evaluating their impact on user engagement, cognitive load, and overall satisfaction. Our results indicate that a machine learning-based approach, incorporating contextual and spatial awareness, outperforms traditional computer vision-based methods. The findings have significant implications for the design of intuitive and immersive VR interfaces, unlocking the full potential of VR for various applications.

title: Efficient Indexing for Distributed Graph Databases using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, efficient indexing mechanisms are crucial to support fast query execution. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, HBF-G, which leverages hierarchical Bloom filters to index graph data across distributed nodes. Our approach reduces the number of nodes to be queried, resulting in significant performance improvements for graph traversal and pattern matching queries. Experimental evaluation on real-world graph datasets demonstrates that HBF-G outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Real-time Human Activity Recognition using Graph-based Temporal Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) has numerous applications in healthcare, surveillance, and robotics. This paper introduces Graph-TAN, a novel deep learning framework that leverages graph-based temporal attention mechanisms to model complex human activities. By explicitly modeling the temporal dependencies between body joints, Graph-TAN achieves state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark datasets, outperforming existing CNN- and RNN-based approaches. We demonstrate the real-time capability of Graph-TAN on a mobile device, enabling accurate and efficient HAR for various applications.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Traffic congestion is a pervasive problem in urban areas, and optimizing traffic signal control is crucial for reducing travel times and improving air quality. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) approach for real-time traffic signal control, which adapts to changing traffic patterns and minimizes congestion. Our method leverages a graph neural network to model the traffic network and a deep Q-network to learn optimal signal control policies. We evaluate our approach using real-world traffic data from the city of Pittsburgh, demonstrating significant reductions in travel times and emissions compared to traditional signal control methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with Column-Oriented Storage
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and real-time analytics applications has created an unprecedented need for efficient data warehousing solutions. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'RT-Colix', designed specifically for column-oriented storage systems. RT-Colix leverages a hybrid approach, combining a compact in-memory index with a disk-based index, to minimize query latency and optimize storage utilization. Our experiments on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that RT-Colix outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 3x faster query execution times and 2x storage savings.

title: Efficient Semantic Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it significantly affects the precision and recall of search results. This paper presents a novel approach to semantic query expansion using deep neural networks, called DeepQE. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly learns to predict query-term importance and semantic relationships between terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision and a 20% reduction in computational time.

title: Query Expansion with BERT-based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval, a fundamental task in information retrieval, aims to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion, a popular technique to improve retrieval performance, involves adding relevant terms to the original query. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'BERT-SE', which leverages BERT-based semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. Our method outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques on several TREC benchmarks, demonstrating the effectiveness of incorporating contextualized semantic representations in ad-hoc retrieval.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic control systems aim to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning for autonomous traffic control. We propose a decentralized framework, 'MA-RLATC', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for traffic signal control. Our approach integrates graph-based attention mechanisms to model spatial relationships between agents and incorporates real-world traffic data to improve policy generalizability. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that MA-RLATC outperforms traditional traffic signal control methods in reducing travel times and increasing network throughput.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization with Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their performance is heavily dependent on the choice of hyperparameters. Bayesian optimization has emerged as a powerful technique for hyperparameter tuning, but it can be computationally expensive and requires significant expertise. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages transfer learning to adapt Bayesian optimization for efficient hyperparameter tuning. Our method, called 'BO-TL', uses pre-trained neural networks as surrogate models to reduce the number of evaluations required for Bayesian optimization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of BO-TL on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in tuning efficiency and model performance compared to existing methods.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data using Graph-based Attention Mechanisms
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. Traditional methods often struggle to handle high-dimensional data and fail to capture complex relationships between variables. This paper proposes a novel graph-based attention mechanism, 'GAT-AD', which models temporal dependencies and correlations in time series data. We leverage graph attention networks to learn node representations and detect anomalies in real-time. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of GAT-AD over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Graph-Based Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuanced semantics of user queries. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep graph-based semantic embeddings to model relationships between entities and concepts. Our method, dubbed 'GraphExpan', represents queries as graph structures and applies graph neural networks to learn dense vector representations. These embeddings are then used to identify relevant expansion terms, yielding significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experiments on the TREC Robust04 and ClueWeb09 datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphExpan in retrieving relevant documents, particularly for ambiguous and complex queries.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: As autonomous systems become increasingly prevalent, the need for explainable AI decision-making processes grows. This paper presents Graph Attention Reinforcement Learning (GARL), a novel framework that integrates graph attention networks with reinforcement learning to provide transparent and interpretable decision-making for autonomous systems. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GARL in a real-world robotics navigation task, showing improved performance and explainability compared to traditional reinforcement learning methods. Additionally, we provide a thorough analysis of the learned graph attention mechanisms, revealing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Designing Accessible Voice-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Individuals with dysarthria often face significant challenges when interacting with voice-based systems. This paper presents a novel framework, 'EasyVoice', which leverages machine learning and natural language processing techniques to improve the accessibility of voice-based interfaces for individuals with dysarthria. Our approach involves adapting speech recognition models to accommodate the unique speech patterns of individuals with dysarthria, as well as developing personalized feedback mechanisms to enhance user experience. We evaluate EasyVoice using a user study with 20 participants and demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc information retrieval, where the goal is to reformulate the initial query to better match the relevant documents. However, existing methods rely heavily on handcrafted features and heuristics, which may not generalize well to diverse query types. We propose a novel reinforcement learning-based approach, 'RL-QE', which learns to select expansion terms by interacting with a simulated retrieval environment. Our experiments on the TREC-8 ad-hoc track demonstrate that RL-QE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Reinforcement Learning Agents under Adversarial Attacks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents have achieved remarkable success in various applications, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper presents a comprehensive robustness analysis of DRL agents under different types of attacks, including model-based and model-free attacks. We develop a novel evaluation framework that assesses the robustness of DRL agents across various attack scenarios and propose a set of defense mechanisms to improve their resilience. Experimental results on several benchmark environments demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing the robustness of DRL agents against adversarial attacks.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on heuristics or manual tuning. We propose a novel query expansion approach, QERL, which leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select expansion terms. Our method incorporates a reward function that balances retrieval precision and recall, and utilizes a deep Q-network to learn the optimal expansion policy. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that QERL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and NDCG@20, with significant improvements in cold-start scenarios.

title: Revisiting Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, yet its performance has plateaued in recent years. We propose a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQE', that leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and document contents. Our model consists of a hierarchical attention network that captures both local and global context, enabling more effective term weighting and selection. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art QE techniques, particularly for queries with low term frequency and high ambiguity.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning via Graph-Based Policy Sharing
paper_abstract: In multi-agent reinforcement learning, the exploration problem is exacerbated by the presence of multiple agents, leading to inefficient and uncoordinated exploration. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphShare', which leverages graph-based policy sharing to facilitate coordinated exploration among agents. By modeling agent interactions as a graph, we enable agents to share their policy updates and adapt to their neighbors' exploration strategies. We demonstrate the efficacy of GraphShare in several multi-agent environments, showcasing improved exploration efficiency and faster convergence to optimal policies.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on accurate and efficient object detection to ensure safety. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'AVOD-NAS', tailored for real-time object detection in autonomous vehicles. AVOD-NAS leverages a differentiable search space and a machine learning-based performance predictor to efficiently identify optimal neural architectures. We demonstrate that AVOD-NAS discovers architectures that outperform state-of-the-art object detectors on the KITTI dataset while achieving significant reductions in computational resources and latency.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Aggregation in IoT Time-Series Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion in time-series data, which poses significant challenges for real-time aggregation and querying. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'TS-Tree', designed specifically for IoT time-series databases. TS-Tree leverages a hierarchical, prefix-compressed structure to minimize storage overhead while enabling fast aggregation and range queries. We evaluate TS-Tree on a large-scale IoT dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art indexing methods.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex domains, but its black-box nature hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel explainability framework, 'ExplainDRL', which integrates attribution methods with model-based RL to provide interpretable insights into agent decision-making. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that highlights relevant state features and abstract representations, enabling users to understand policy decisions in high-dimensional environments. Experimental results on Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of ExplainDRL in improving transparency and trust in DRL systems.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Deep Learned Dense Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper presents a novel approach, called DPR-PR, which leverages deep learned dense representations to encode passages and questions. We explore the use of contrastive learning to train a dense retriever that can effectively capture the semantic relationships between questions and passages. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that DPR-PR outperforms state-of-the-art sparse retrieval methods, achieving a 15% increase in top-20 passage retrieval accuracy while reducing the indexing time by 3x.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Temporal Graph Databases using Time-Series Indexing
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying dynamic network data. However, existing query processing techniques are often inefficient, leading to poor performance and high latency. This paper proposes a novel time-series indexing approach, 'ChronoIndex', which leverages the inherent temporal locality in graph data to accelerate query execution. We introduce a compact index structure that captures both spatial and temporal relationships, enabling efficient processing of complex queries involving time-based predicates. Experimental results on large-scale temporal graph datasets demonstrate that ChronoIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 5x in query response time.

title: Real-time Human Activity Recognition using Graph-based Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Human activity recognition (HAR) is a fundamental task in various applications, including healthcare, surveillance, and robotics. This paper presents a novel graph-based neural network (GNN) framework for real-time HAR, leveraging the structural relationships between body joints. Our model, GraphHAR, incorporates a spatio-temporal graph attention mechanism to capture complex motion patterns and contextual dependencies. Experimental results on public HAR datasets demonstrate that GraphHAR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy, F1-score, and inference speed, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Attribute Imputation
paper_abstract: Node attribute imputation is a fundamental problem in graph data analysis, where missing attributes need to be inferred from available information. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAN) model, which leverages the hierarchical structure of graphs to capture complex dependencies between nodes. HGAN consists of multiple graph attention layers, each of which adaptively assigns importance scores to neighboring nodes based on their attributes. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of imputation accuracy and robustness to noisy data.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our method, called 'NeuroQE', integrates a bidirectional transformer encoder with a weighted term importance estimation module to generate more effective query expansions. Experimental results on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Real-Time Data Warehousing with GPU-Accelerated Join Algorithms
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing imposes stringent performance requirements on query processing. This paper introduces a novel approach to accelerate join operations, a critical component of query processing, using GPU-based parallel processing. We propose a hybrid join algorithm, 'GPU-Join', that leverages the massive parallelism of modern GPUs to accelerate join operations while minimizing memory transfer overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale TPC-H dataset demonstrate that GPU-Join achieves up to 5x speedup over traditional CPU-based join algorithms, making it suitable for real-time data warehousing applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Long-Tail Entity Disambiguation
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in natural language processing, but it remains challenging for long-tail entities, which dominate real-world datasets. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages both local and global context to disambiguate entities efficiently. Our HAN model consists of a novel entity-aware attention mechanism that adaptively weighs the importance of contextual words and a hierarchical aggregation strategy that captures both entity-specific and topic-level information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance with significant improvements in accuracy and speed over existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperation and communication are crucial for achieving common goals. However, most existing approaches rely on complex, black-box models that hinder interpretability and trust. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that enables explainable multi-agent cooperation. HAGNN integrates graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical representations to model agent interactions, intentions, and goals. Our experiments on a variety of cooperative tasks demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both performance and interpretability, providing actionable insights into agent decision-making processes.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Latent Semantic Analysis and Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Information retrieval (IR) systems rely on efficient document filtering to reduce the search space and improve retrieval accuracy. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model that leverages latent semantic analysis (LSA) to learn dense representations of documents and queries. Our approach, dubbed 'NeuralLSA', incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex contextual relationships between documents and queries. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that NeuralLSA outperforms state-of-the-art filtering methods, achieving a 23.5% improvement in mean average precision (MAP) while reducing computational overhead by 40%

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short and ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding approach, 'CAQE', which leverages query-term dependencies and document structures to improve query expansion. Our method incorporates a graph-based attention mechanism to capture semantic relationships between query terms and their surrounding context. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn autonomous task allocation policies. Our method, 'GNN-ATA', represents the agent-task graph as a learnable embedding space, enabling the agents to reason about task dependencies and allocate tasks optimally. Experimental results on a simulated robotics scenario demonstrate that GNN-ATA outperforms traditional heuristic-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of visually impaired users. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing accessible conversational interfaces, focusing on the development of a novel dialogue management system that leverages natural language processing and machine learning techniques. Our system incorporates a range of accessibility features, including real-time speech output, tactile feedback, and personalized user modeling. A usability study with 20 visually impaired participants demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Decentralized Auction-Based Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper presents a novel, decentralized auction-based approach for task allocation, dubbed 'DARTA'. By leveraging a combination of combinatorial auctions and distributed constraint optimization, DARTA enables agents to bid on tasks based on their capabilities and preferences, while ensuring that the overall system objective is optimized. We evaluate DARTA through extensive simulations, demonstrating its scalability, flexibility, and robustness in various application domains, including disaster response and autonomous robotics.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Planning with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel planning framework for multi-agent systems, focusing on scalability and efficiency. We introduce Hierarchical Task Networks (HTNs) to model complex tasks and leverage a hierarchical planning architecture to decompose tasks into smaller sub-tasks. Our approach enables agents to reason about task dependencies and allocate resources effectively, leading to improved plan quality and reduced planning time. Experimental results on a logistics domain demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, outperforming existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of plan quality and execution time.

title: Scalable Indexing for Real-time Time-series Data using a Hybrid B-Tree and Grid Index
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and sensors has led to an explosion of time-series data, posing significant challenges for efficient query processing and indexing. This paper presents a novel hybrid indexing approach, termed 'HybridTS', which combines the benefits of B-Tree and Grid indexing to support fast range queries and aggregations on real-time time-series data. Our approach leverages a dynamic re-balancing mechanism to adapt to changing data distributions and query patterns, ensuring high performance and scalability. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that HybridTS outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks for Efficient Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: As urban populations continue to grow, traffic congestion has become a major challenge for cities worldwide. This paper presents a novel approach to urban traffic management using multi-agent systems coordinated by hierarchical task networks (HTNs). We develop a decentralized agent architecture that integrates traffic signal control, route optimization, and traffic prediction to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. Our experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that the proposed HTN-based approach outperforms traditional traffic management methods, achieving a 23% reduction in average travel time and a 17% decrease in congestion.

title: Beyond BM25: A Neural Ranking Model for Document Retrieval with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval techniques rely on bag-of-words representations and simple ranking functions. This paper presents a neural ranking model, QRex, that leverages query expansion and contextualized embeddings to improve retrieval performance. QRex uses a transformer-based architecture to encode queries and documents, and incorporates a query expansion module to capture relevant keywords and phrases. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that QRex outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, including BM25 and neural IR baselines, in terms of NDCG@10 and MAP.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Multi-modal Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-modal retrieval, which integrates visual and textual features using deep neural networks. Our proposed method, called Adaptive Re-ranking (AR), leverages the strengths of both modalities to improve retrieval accuracy. AR adaptively adjusts the weights of visual and textual features based on the query and document characteristics, achieving better performance compared to fixed-weight fusion methods. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-modal dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of AR in improving retrieval precision and recall.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on Eye Movement Patterns
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems rely heavily on accurate user input, but existing interaction methods often fall short in terms of naturalism and user experience. This paper explores the potential of gaze-based interaction in VR, leveraging machine learning algorithms to decode eye movement patterns. We collected a dataset of eye tracking data from 30 participants and trained a convolutional neural network to classify gaze targets in 3D space. Our results show that our approach achieves an average accuracy of 92.1% in identifying gaze targets, outperforming traditional ray-casting methods. We discuss implications for VR interface design and potential applications in fields such as education and healthcare.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In complex, dynamic environments, task allocation among multiple agents is a critical problem. This paper presents a decentralized coalition formation approach, 'DCF-TA', that enables agents to form coalitions and allocate tasks in a distributed manner. DCF-TA leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and a novel, anytime algorithm to accommodate dynamic task arrivals and departures. We demonstrate the effectiveness of DCF-TA through extensive simulations, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized and traditional distributed approaches.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) methods rely on manual feature engineering and bag-of-words representations, which often fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural embedding framework, 'HiNER', which learns to represent documents as dense vectors in a hierarchical manner. We employ a stacked attention mechanism to capture both local and global context, enabling more accurate document retrieval. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiNER outperforms state-of-the-art IR methods, including those based on BERT and Transformers, in terms of retrieval precision and efficiency.

title: Efficient Outlier Detection in High-Dimensional Data using Isolation Forest and Distance-Based Sampling
paper_abstract: Outlier detection in high-dimensional data is a challenging problem due to the curse of dimensionality. Existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity or poor performance. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'IsoSample', which combines the Isolation Forest algorithm with distance-based sampling to detect outliers efficiently. IsoSample leverages the random feature selection property of Isolation Forest to reduce the dimensionality and then uses distance-based sampling to identify outliers in the reduced space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that IsoSample outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Integrating Neural Query Expansion with Deep Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines neural query expansion with deep learning techniques to improve retrieval performance. Our model, called NQE-DL, leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn semantic query representations and generate expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NQE-DL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 15.2% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Gesture-based Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: The rise of virtual reality (VR) has sparked interest in exploring novel interaction modalities. This paper investigates the role of embodied cognition in gesture-based interaction in VR, focusing on the relationship between motor experiences and cognitive processing. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, using a custom-built VR environment and gesture recognition system. Our results show that embodied cognition significantly influences users' ability to learn and recall gestures, with implications for the design of more intuitive and effective VR interfaces. We also discuss the potential applications of these findings in fields such as education, healthcare, and gaming.

title: EmoReact: Affective State Recognition using Multimodal Fusion of Speech, Facial Expressions, and Physiological Signals
paper_abstract: This paper presents EmoReact, a novel multimodal affective state recognition system that combines speech, facial expressions, and physiological signals to identify emotional states. Our approach leverages deep learning-based feature extractors and a hierarchical fusion framework to capture complex relationships between modalities. We evaluate EmoReact on a large-scale dataset of human-computer interactions, achieving state-of-the-art performance in recognizing emotions, including subtle and nuanced affective states. EmoReact has implications for developing more empathetic human-computer interfaces and enhancing user experience in various applications.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture-based interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments. Our system, 'EasyGest', uses machine learning to adapt to individual users' abilities and preferences, providing real-time feedback and guidance to facilitate accurate gesture recognition. A user study with 20 older adults demonstrates significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces. We also explore the impact of cognitive load on gesture performance and discuss implications for future design. The results have important implications for the development of accessible and inclusive interfaces for older adults.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Caching
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for large-scale data storage and processing. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck due to network latency and data transfer overhead. This paper proposes an adaptive caching framework, 'CacheFlex', which dynamically adjusts cache sizes and content based on query patterns and data access frequencies. We evaluate CacheFlex on a realistic workload derived from the TPC-DS benchmark and demonstrate significant improvements in query response times and throughput. Our results show that CacheFlex achieves up to 3x speedup compared to traditional caching strategies, making it a promising solution for high-performance distributed database systems.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (NIR) models have demonstrated significant improvements over traditional retrieval methods. However, they often rely on manually crafted query expansion (QE) techniques, which can be suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel approach to QE using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We formulate QE as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select expansion terms that maximize the expected retrieval performance. Our experiments on the MSMARCO passage ranking dataset show that the proposed DRL-based QE method outperforms state-of-the-art QE techniques, achieving a 12.5% improvement in mean reciprocal rank.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploration of Cognitive Load and Error Recovery Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of users with cognitive or motor impairments. This paper presents a user-centered study investigating the impact of cognitive load on error recovery in voice-based interactions. We designed and evaluated three error recovery strategies: explicit correction, implicit correction, and adaptive feedback. Our results show that users with higher cognitive load benefit from explicit correction, while users with lower cognitive load prefer implicit correction. Adaptive feedback, which dynamically adjusts to user performance, improves overall user experience and error recovery rates. We provide design recommendations for inclusive voice assistants that accommodate diverse user needs.

title: Relevance-Based Document Expansion for Neural Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural information retrieval (IR) models have demonstrated state-of-the-art performance in various search tasks. However, their effectiveness often relies on the quality of the input documents. This paper proposes a novel relevance-based document expansion approach, 'DocExp', which leverages a neural ranking model to selectively expand the original document with relevant passages from a large external corpus. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism to weigh the importance of expanded passages and integrate them with the original document representation. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DocExp significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural IR models, especially for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Optimizing Query Workloads with Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory databases (MMDBs) have become increasingly popular for high-performance applications. However, optimizing query workloads on MMDBs remains a significant challenge. This paper explores the use of learned index structures to improve query performance. We propose a novel approach, 'QLIS', which leverages machine learning models to predict query access patterns and adaptively reorganize index structures. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world MMDB benchmark demonstrates that QLIS achieves an average query latency reduction of 32% compared to state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Network for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained popularity in recent years due to the need for transparency in AI-driven decision-making. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that incorporates both item-level and user-level graph attention mechanisms to learn complex relationships between users and items. HGAT generates personalized explanations for top-N recommended items, improving user trust and satisfaction. Experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: A Deep Learning Approach to Query Expansion for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the retrieval effectiveness. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, which leverages the semantic relationships between words in the query and document collections. Our approach, called DeepQE, uses a combination of word embeddings and a neural network to learn the optimal query expansion strategy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Elastic Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems with Skew-aware Join Reordering
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) struggle with optimizing queries involving joins, especially in the presence of data skew. Existing solutions either focus on single-node optimization or rely on static join ordering, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper presents ElasticQuery, a novel query optimization framework for DDS that adaptively reorders joins based on runtime data statistics. By incorporating a skew-aware join ordering algorithm and a cost-based optimization strategy, ElasticQuery improves query execution time by up to 3.5x compared to state-of-the-art approaches. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of ElasticQuery in handling complex queries with diverse data distributions.

title: Efficient Indexing for Range Queries on Temporal Graphs
paper_abstract: Temporal graphs have become increasingly important in modeling dynamic relationships between entities. However, querying these graphs efficiently remains a challenging task, particularly for range queries that involve temporal predicates. In this paper, we propose a novel indexing technique, called Temporal Graph Index (TGI), which leverages the temporal locality of graph updates to reduce the search space for range queries. Our approach combines a hierarchical indexing structure with a compact representation of timestamped edges, achieving significant query performance improvements over existing methods. Experimental results on real-world temporal graph datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of TGI in reducing query latency and improving data freshness.

title: Deconfliction Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, deconfliction strategies are crucial to prevent collisions and ensure efficient coordination. This paper presents a novel framework that combines machine learning and graph theory to resolve conflicts in dynamic environments. We propose a decentralized approach where agents learn to predict and adjust their trajectories in real-time, taking into account the changing environment and other agents' intentions. Experimental results in a simulated air traffic control scenario demonstrate that our approach significantly reduces conflicts and improves overall system efficiency compared to traditional rule-based methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Improving Search Engine Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in search engine retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on manual feature engineering and heuristic rules. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep neural networks to learn query expansion strategies from large-scale search logs. Our model, called DeepQE, incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex relationships between query terms and documents. Experimental results on a large web corpus demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in retrieval performance and relevance.

title: Investigating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on Virtual Reality User Experience
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but its adoption is often hindered by motion sickness and user discomfort. This paper explores the role of haptic feedback in enhancing VR user experience. We design and evaluate a novel haptic feedback system that provides synchronized tactile and kinesthetic cues to users. Our user study involving 30 participants shows that haptic feedback significantly reduces motion sickness, improves user satisfaction, and increases task performance. We also identify key design factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback in VR.

title: Efficient Entity Disambiguation using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in information retrieval, but existing approaches often struggle with scalability and accuracy. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for entity disambiguation. HGAT leverages the hierarchical structure of knowledge graphs to selectively focus on relevant context and entities. We propose a new attention mechanism that adaptively weights entity relationships based on their relevance to the query. Experimental results on the Wikidata dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of disambiguation accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Robotics
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has shown promise in robotics, but real-world applications require efficient learning in complex, high-dimensional state-action spaces. We propose a novel hierarchical RL framework, 'HierRL', which leverages a two-level abstraction hierarchy to decompose complex tasks into simpler sub-tasks. By learning a high-level policy over sub-task abstractions, HierRL significantly reduces the exploration-exploitation tradeoff, leading to faster learning and improved performance. We demonstrate HierRL's effectiveness on a real-world robotic arm manipulation task, achieving a 3x speedup over state-of-the-art RL methods.

title: Negotiation Strategies for Autonomous Agents in Multi-Issue Bilateral Negotiations
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents are increasingly employed in various negotiation domains, necessitating effective strategies for bilateral negotiations. This paper presents a novel framework for multi-issue bilateral negotiations, where agents negotiate over multiple interdependent issues. We propose a hybrid approach combining concession-based and learning-based strategies, incorporating insights from behavioral economics. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of negotiation outcome quality, negotiation time, and opponent satisfaction.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality for Enhancing Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction (HCI) by leveraging embodied cognition principles. This paper presents an empirical study examining the effects of VR-induced spatial awareness on user performance in a problem-solving task. Our results show that VR participants outperform their desktop counterparts in terms of task completion time and accuracy, while also exhibiting increased cognitive flexibility. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of immersive interfaces and propose a novel framework for integrating embodied cognition into HCI research.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Semantic Word Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique in ad-hoc retrieval to improve the retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion by leveraging deep semantic word embeddings. We develop a neural network-based model that learns to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion terms. The model is trained on a large-scale query log dataset and generates a set of expanded queries that are semantically similar to the original query. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets show that the proposed approach significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods and achieves state-of-the-art results in ad-hoc retrieval tasks.

title: Deep Transfer Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task in computer vision, particularly when dealing with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel deep transfer learning framework, Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPNs), which leverages the knowledge acquired from pre-trained models to learn efficient representations for few-shot classification. Our approach introduces a hierarchical prototypical embedding space, where class prototypes are learned at multiple semantic levels, enabling the model to capture both global and local features. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HPNs outperform state-of-the-art methods in few-shot image classification, while requiring fewer parameters and computations.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration for Distributed Query Processing using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed query processing is crucial for large-scale data analytics, but optimizing join order enumeration remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively explore the vast space of possible join orders. Our method, called 'JoinRL', utilizes a Markov decision process to model the query optimization problem and learns to make informed decisions about join order enumeration. Experimental results on a range of distributed query workloads demonstrate that JoinRL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers, reducing query execution times by up to 30%.
