title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Adaptive Auctions
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and resources must coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper presents a novel adaptive auction-based framework, 'AuctionMA', which enables efficient task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems. AuctionMA uses a probabilistic bidding strategy that adapts to the agents' task completion probabilities and resource availability, leading to improved system performance and robustness. Experimental results on a simulated search and rescue scenario demonstrate that AuctionMA outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of task completion rate and resource utilization.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper explores the effect of embodiment on social presence in virtual reality (VR) environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, where we manipulated the level of embodiment through different VR interface conditions. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to higher social presence, trust, and cooperation in virtual interactions. Furthermore, we found that the sense of embodiment is influenced by the user's personality traits, such as extroversion and empathy. Our findings have implications for the design of VR systems that aim to facilitate social interactions and collaboration.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles Using Decentralized Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes
paper_abstract: Decentralized coordination of autonomous vehicles is crucial for efficient traffic flow and road safety. This paper proposes a novel approach based on decentralized partially observable Markov decision processes (Dec-POMDPs) to coordinate autonomous vehicles at intersections. We develop a distributed algorithm that enables vehicles to make decisions based on local observations and communication with neighboring vehicles. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated environment, demonstrating improved traffic throughput and reduced collision rates compared to traditional centralized approaches. The proposed framework is scalable and can be applied to various urban traffic scenarios.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) often struggle with query optimization due to the complexity of data distribution and network latency. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'KG-Opt', which leverages knowledge graph embeddings to improve query performance in DDS. We embed database schemas and query graphs into a shared vector space, enabling the capture of semantic relationships between data entities. Experimental results on a real-world DDS benchmark demonstrate that KG-Opt achieves up to 30% reduction in query latency and 25% improvement in query throughput compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in E-Commerce Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique for enhancing the relevance of search results in e-commerce applications. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages user behavior, product categories, and query intent to generate more informative and relevant queries. CAQE incorporates a graph-based method to model the relationships between query terms, products, and user interactions, enabling more accurate and personalized search results. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate that CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision, recall, and user satisfaction.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Effective Retrieval in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search queries often lack sufficient context, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. Our proposed model, 'QE-Net', employs a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query representation, term weighting, and expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques. We also provide insights into the learned query representations and their impact on retrieval performance.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to autonomous task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, called Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Q-Networks (MATADQN), enables agents to learn optimal task assignment policies in complex, dynamic environments. We evaluate MATADQN in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced response times compared to traditional methods. The proposed approach has significant implications for real-world applications, such as search and rescue operations, and warehouse management.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness Against Unseen Attack Vectors in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are increasingly vulnerable to sophisticated attacks that exploit unseen vulnerabilities. This paper proposes an adversarial training framework, 'AdvShield', which leverages a novel ensemble-based approach to improve robustness against diverse attack vectors. Our method combines a generator network with a discriminator network to craft perturbations that simulate real-world attacks, thereby enhancing model resilience. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdvShield outperforms state-of-the-art defense methods in detecting and mitigating unseen attacks, ensuring improved model reliability in real-world applications.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'TrafficMA', designed for real-time traffic management in large-scale urban networks. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that combines centralized traffic signal control with decentralized agent-based decision-making. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model traffic dynamics and incorporates attention mechanisms to facilitate cooperation among agents. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that TrafficMA achieves significant reductions in travel time and congestion compared to traditional traffic management strategies.

title: Robust Image Classification with Hierarchical Attention-based Transformers
paper_abstract: While Transformers have achieved state-of-the-art results in natural language processing, their application to computer vision tasks remains limited. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Transformer (HAT) architecture for image classification, which leverages self-attention mechanisms to capture both local and global contextual information. Our approach integrates a pyramid pooling module to reduce spatial dimensions and increase channel capacity, enabling the model to learn robust features from high-resolution images. Experimental results on the ImageNet dataset demonstrate that HAT outperforms convolutional neural networks and vision Transformers in terms of accuracy and robustness to adversarial attacks.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-robot interaction (HRI) is crucial for developing empathetic and socially intelligent robots. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, acoustic, and linguistic modalities to recognize emotions in HRI scenarios. Our HAN architecture consists of modality-specific attention modules and a hierarchical fusion layer that adaptively weights modalities based on their relevance to the emotional context. We evaluate our approach on the EMOTIC dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in emotion recognition accuracy compared to state-of-the-art multimodal fusion methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Join Operations in Cloud-Based Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: As data warehousing shifts to the cloud, distributed join operations become increasingly critical for query performance. However, optimizing join orders and allocating resources efficiently remain significant challenges. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'DistroJoin', which leverages machine learning and graph-based models to predict optimal join orders and resource allocations. We propose a hybrid approach that combines reinforcement learning with traditional query optimization techniques, resulting in improved query response times and reduced resource utilization. Experimental evaluations on Amazon Redshift and Google BigQuery demonstrate the efficacy of DistroJoin in handling complex distributed join operations.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Conversational Search using Hierarchical Transformers
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to retrieve relevant documents based on user queries. However, the ambiguity and nuances of natural language queries pose significant challenges. This paper proposes a novel deep query expansion approach, 'Converse-QE', which leverages hierarchical transformers to model both local and global contextual relationships in user queries. Our approach incorporates a semantic role labeling module to identify key entities and their relationships, enabling more accurate query expansion. Experimental results on the TREC Conversational Assistant Track dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, especially for complex, multi-turn conversations.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Cooperative Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative agents in multi-agent systems often face the challenge of task allocation, where agents need to assign tasks to themselves and other agents to maximize overall system performance. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'CoopAllocator', enables agents to learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities, preferences, and environmental constraints. We conduct extensive experiments in a simulated robotics environment, demonstrating that CoopAllocator outperforms traditional centralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system efficiency.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Decentralized Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Optimization
paper_abstract: Urban traffic congestion is a pressing concern, and real-time optimization can significantly mitigate its impact. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent system (MAS) framework, 'TrafficOpt', which leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to coordinate autonomous vehicles and traffic signals. We develop a novel, distributed RL algorithm that enables agents to learn from local observations and communicate with neighbors to optimize traffic flow. Experiments on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that TrafficOpt reduces congestion by 23% compared to traditional, centralized approaches, while adapting to dynamic traffic patterns and minimizing communication overhead.

title: Efficient Deep Learning-based Anomaly Detection for Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper presents a novel deep learning-based approach, 'TS_AD', which leverages a combination of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to detect anomalies in multivariate time series data. TS_AD employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and time steps, resulting in improved detection accuracy and reduced computational cost. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of TS_AD in detecting anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Designing Emotional Intelligence in Virtual Assistants: A Multimodal Approach
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) are increasingly integrated into our daily lives, but their lack of emotional intelligence (EI) hinders effective human-computer interaction. This paper presents a multimodal framework for designing VAs with EI, which combines natural language processing, computer vision, and machine learning to recognize and respond to users' emotions. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, demonstrating that our EI-infused VA reduces user frustration and improves overall interaction experience. The proposed framework has implications for developing more empathetic and human-centered VAs in various applications, such as healthcare and education.

title: Gaze-Based Implicit Authentication for Augmented Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly pervasive, ensuring the security of AR interfaces is crucial. This paper presents a novel gaze-based implicit authentication approach, 'GazeAuth', which leverages the user's gaze patterns to authenticate their identity. We develop a machine learning model that analyzes the user's gaze behavior while interacting with an AR interface, achieving an accuracy of 95.2% in distinguishing between genuine and imposter users. Our approach offers a seamless, unobtrusive, and highly secure authentication mechanism for AR applications.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but they often struggle to scale to large graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages a hierarchical graph representation to reduce computational complexity. HGAT uses a pyramid-like architecture to aggregate node features at multiple scales, allowing it to capture both local and global patterns in the graph. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its ability to achieve competitive performance with significantly reduced computational resources.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel auction-based mechanism for task allocation in multi-agent systems. Our approach, called CATAMA, leverages a combinatorial auction framework to efficiently allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, preferences, and resource constraints. We prove that CATAMA achieves optimal task allocation under certain conditions and demonstrate its effectiveness in simulations involving heterogeneous agents and tasks. Experimental results show that CATAMA outperforms existing algorithms in terms of task completion rate, agent utility, and system throughput.

title: Improving Ranking Consistency in Neural Retrieval Models via Self-Supervised Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown promising results in information retrieval tasks, but their ranking consistency often suffers due to the lack of explicit document relationships. This paper proposes a self-supervised learning approach to learn document embeddings, which are then incorporated into a neural ranking model to improve ranking consistency. Our approach, dubbed 'DocEmb', leverages a contrastive learning objective to learn document embeddings that capture semantic similarities. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DocEmb significantly improves ranking consistency and retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art neural retrieval models.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving optimal performance. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-TA', which enables agents to adapt to dynamic environments and allocate tasks effectively. HRL-TA consists of a high-level planning module that assigns tasks to agents based on their capabilities and a low-level execution module that refines task allocations using reinforcement learning. We evaluate HRL-TA in a simulated robotic search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion efficiency and robustness compared to existing methods.

title: Coordinated Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Real-Time Traffic Awareness
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, multi-agent systems require efficient pathfinding algorithms that account for real-time traffic conditions. This paper presents a novel, decentralized approach, 'TrafficAware', which integrates graph-based pathfinding with real-time traffic data from IoT sensors. Our algorithm leverages a hierarchical clustering method to group agents with similar goals, reducing inter-agent collisions and enhancing overall system throughput. Extensive simulations demonstrate that TrafficAware outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of efficiency, safety, and adaptability to changing traffic conditions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-driven Medical Image Segmentation
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in medical image segmentation tasks, but their opacity hinders trust and adoption in clinical practice. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that integrates explainable AI techniques to provide insights into the model's decision-making process. Our approach leverages spatial and channel-wise attention mechanisms to focus on relevant regions and features, respectively, while generating heatmaps that highlight the contribution of each input feature to the segmentation output. Experimental results on the BraTS17 dataset demonstrate that our HAN model achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art methods while providing interpretable explanations for its predictions.
